The old man hearing this, quickly made his nephew mount the Donkey, and continued to walk along merrily by his side. Presently they came up to a group of elderly gentlemen in earnest debate. There, said one of them, it proves what I was a-saying. What respect is shown to old age in these days? Do you see that idle lad riding while his old father has to walk? Get down, you young scapegrace, and let the old man rest his weary limbs. Upon this the old man made his nephew dismount, and got up himself. In this manner they had not proceeded far when they met a company of ladies and children: Why, you lazy old fellow, cried several tongues at once, how can you ride upon the beast, while that poor little lad there can hardly keep pace by the side of you?' The good-natured Farmer immediately took up his nephew behind him. They had now almost reached the town. Pray, honest friend, said a townsman, is that Donkey your own?' Yes, replied the old man. O, one would not have thought so, said the other, by the way you load him. Why, you two fellows are better able to carry the poor beast than he you. Anything to please you, said the old man; we can but try. So, alighting with his nephew, they tied the legs of the Donkey together and with the help of a rod endeavored to carry him on their shoulders over a footbridge near the entrance to the town. This entertaining sight brought the people in crowds to laugh at it, till the Donkey, not liking the noise nor the strange handling that he was subject to, broke the cords that bound him and, tumbling off the rod, fell into the stream. Upon this, the old man, vexed and ashamed, made the best of his way home again, convinced that by endeavoring to please everybody he had pleased nobody, and lost his Donkey in the bargain.
moral: Try to please all and you end by pleasing none.
choices: Try to please all and you end by pleasing none.
We should not to conclude that we are allowed to do to other people's things what is permitted to them in their own houses.
Idle talk can vex the earnest.
The honest value of money is not in its possession but in its critical use.
Sometimes a swift adjustment is all it takes to silence needless judgment.

story: One day the Townsfolk noticed that the Hills were in labour; smoke came out of their summits, the ground was quaking at their feet, forests were crashing, and huge stones were tumbling. They felt sure that something horrible was going to happen. They all gathered together in one place to see what terrible thing this could be. They waited and they waited, but nothing came. At last there was a still more violent tremor, and a huge fissure appeared in the side of the Hills. They all fell down upon their knees and waited. At last, and at last, a teeny, tiny vole poked its little head and bristles out of the fissure and came running down towards them.
moral: Don't make a big fuss over nothing.
choices: Don't make a big fuss over nothing.
Do not laugh at the calamity that befalls your neighbour.
Curiosity can unveil the unexpected.
Majestic greatness has its unexpected penalties.
Patience can reveal the smallest of wonders.

story: A Famished Jackal was prowling about in the morning in search of food. As he passed the door of a cabin built in the forest, he heard a Caretaker say to her toddler, Be quiet, or I will throw you out of the gate, and the Jackal shall eat you. The Jackal sat all day waiting at the door. In the evening he heard the same woman fondling her toddler and saying: You are quiet now, and if the Jackal should come, we will kill him. The Jackal, hearing these words, went home, gasping with cold and hunger. When he reached his burrow, Mistress Jackal inquired of him why he returned wearied and supperless, so contrary to his wont. He replied: Why, forsooth! use I gave credence to the words of a woman!
moral: Enemies' promises are made to be broken.
choices: Enemies' promises are made to be broken.
The man who talks for both sides is not to be trusted by either.
Innocence can be misled by threats.
Take that quiet, inquisitive opportunity when you can get it.
Idle threats can invite real dangers.

story: A Horse, frolicsome from lack of work and from too much oats, galloped about in a very extravagant manner, and said to himself: My father surely was a high-mettled racer, and I am his own child in speed and spirit. On the next day, being driven a long journey, and feeling very wearied, he exclaimed in a disconsolate tone: I must have made a mistake; my father, after all, could have been only an ass.
moral: Be sure of your pedigree before you boast of it.
choices: Be sure of your pedigree before you boast of it.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Extravagance can overshadow joy.
He that is neither a frolicsome one thing nor an extravagant other has no friends.
Idle indulgence can lead to delusions of grandeur.

story: Be quiet now, said an old Caretaker to a toddler sitting on her lap. If you make that noise again I will throw you to the Coyote. Now it chanced that a Coyote was passing close under the gate as this was said. So he crouched down by the side of the house and waited. I am in good luck to-day, thought he. It is sure to cry soon, and a daintier morsel I haven't had for many a long day. So he waited, and he waited, and he waited, till at last the toddler began to cry, and the Coyote came forward before the gate, and looked up to the Caretaker, wagging his tail. But all the Caretaker did was to shut down the gate and call for help, and the guard dogs of the house came rushing out.
moral: Enemies' promises were made to be broken.
choices: Enemies' promises were made to be broken.
Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
Cunning plans often silence noisy fears.
Expect no reward for serving the cunning and old wicked.
Harsh words may hide a misguided attempt at protection.

story: A Very Large Maple was uprooted by the gale and thrown across a river. It fell among some Rushes, which it thus addressed: I wonder how you, who are so light and weak, are not entirely crushed by these strong winds. They replied, You fight and contend with the gale, and consequently you are destroyed; while we on the contrary bend before the least breath of air, and therefore remain unbroken, and escape.
moral: Stoop to conquer.
choices: Stoop to conquer.
True value comes from usefulness.
Even the strong can be uprooted.
Uprooted obscurity often brings safety.
Even the mighty can be humbled by nature's course.

story: A Antelope blind in one eye was accustomed to graze as near to the edge of the precipice as she possibly could, in the hope of securing her greater safety. She turned her sound eye towards the land that she might get the earliest tidings of the approach of poacher or beagle, and her injured eye towards the ocean, from whence she entertained no anticipation of danger. Some sailors sailing by saw her, and taking a successful aim, mortally wounded her. Yielding up her last breath, she gasped forth this lament: 'O wretched creature that I am! to take such precaution against the land, and after all to find this beach, to which I had come for safety, so much more perilous.'
moral: Trouble comes from the direction we least expect it.
choices: Trouble comes from the direction we least expect it.
Take pleasure when thieves destroy themselves.
Success can blind to danger.
Do not try to gain blind favor by acting in a wretched way that is contrary to your own nature and character.
Overcompensating for a weakness can lead to greater risks.

story: A Parrot once placed a petition before Hera desiring to have the voice of a canary in addition to his other attractions; but Hera refused his request. When he persisted, and pointed out that he was her favourite bird, she said:
moral: Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
choices: Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
Fine work gets preserved and treasured.
Persistence outshines mere vanity.
Households and cities are most likely to be deserted when there are vain, harsh people in charge.
Favoritism does not guarantee special treatment.

story: A Gardener had in his garden an Cherry-Tree which bore no fruit but only served as a harbor for the wrens and locusts. He resolved to cut it down, and taking his machete in his hand, made a bold stroke at its roots. The locusts and wrens entreated him not to cut down the tree that sheltered them, but to spare it, and they would sing to him and lighten his labors. He paid no attention to their request, but gave the tree a second and a third blow with his machete. When he reached the hollow of the tree, he found a nest full of nectar. Having tasted the honeycake, he threw down his machete, and looking on the tree as sacred, took great care of it.
moral: Self-interest alone moves some men.
choices: Self-interest alone moves some men.
Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.
Determination tunes the melody of success.
Determined obscurity often brings pragmatic safety.
Value can be found in unexpected places.

story: A Newt once upon a time came forth from his home in the bog and proclaimed to all the beasts that he was a learned physician, skilled in the use of drugs and able to heal all diseases. A Coyote asked him, 'How can you pretend to prescribe for others, when you are unable to heal your own lame gait and wrinkled skin?'
moral: Those who would mend others, should first mend themselves.
choices: Those who would mend others, should first mend themselves.
When fools fight others run away with the prize.
Boastfulness blinds the observant.
Boastful, vicious people cannot resist hurting others even when it is not in their own lame interests.
Boasting of skills you do not possess can lead to your own downfall.

story: A Magpie saw a Peacock and desired to secure for himself the same beautiful plumage. Supposing that the Peacock's splendid white color arose from his washing in the water in which he swam, the Magpie left the temples in the neighborhood where he picked up his living, and took up residence in the reservoirs and rivers. But cleansing his feathers as often as he would, he could not change their color, while through want of food he perished.
moral: Change of habit cannot alter nature.
choices: Change of habit cannot alter nature.
We must make friends in prosperity if we would have their help in adversity.
Envy clouds true beauty.
Beautiful kindness is never splendidly wasted.
Envy can blind us to our own unique beauty.

story: A centipede and a toad meet on the bank of a creek and the centipede asks the toad to carry him across on its back. The toad asks, 'How do I know you won't sting me?' The centipede says, 'Because if I do, I will die too.' The toad is satisfied, and they set out, but in midstream, the centipede stings the toad. The toad feels the onset of paralysis and starts to sink, knowing they both will drown.
moral: Vicious people cannot resist hurting others even when it is not in their own interests
choices: Vicious people cannot resist hurting others even when it is not in their own interests
Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
Blind trust invites deception.
People who stubbornly cling to deceptive and naive choices lose everything before they know it.
Trust must be earned, not assumed.

story: A Tarantula befriended a Dragonfly who became a loyal companion to him. A time came when she struggled to cross a challenging and dangerous creek, and so the Tarantula offered to take her to the other side on his back. He had come to care for her and promised he would never harm her. But, safely across the creek, he allowed his tail to dip upon her with its venomous sting.
moral: Regardless of our wishes, or even our intent, it is to our Nature alone that we will be faithful.
choices: Regardless of our wishes, or even our intent, it is to our Nature alone that we will be faithful.
Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
Trust cautiously, appearances deceive.
Things you acquire through deceptive and venomous means can be taken from you by evil means.
True friendship can transcend natural instincts.

story: An Falcon swooped down upon a Viper and seized it in his talons with the intention of carrying it off and devouring it. But the Viper was too quick for him and had its coils round him in a moment; and then there ensued a life-and-death struggle between the two. A villager, who was a witness of the encounter, came to the assistance of the falcon, and succeeded in freeing him from the Viper and enabling him to escape. In revenge, the Viper spat some of his poison into the man's flask. Heated with his exertions, the man was about to slake his thirst with a draught from the horn, when the Falcon knocked it out of his hand, and spilled its contents upon the ground.
moral: One good turn deserves another.
choices: One good turn deserves another.
Do not try to grasp too much at once.
Quick actions can be vengeful.
Destroy the swift seed of vengeful evil, or it will grow up to your ruin.
Even the mighty must be wary of hidden dangers.

story: A Viper in the course of its wanderings came into an blacksmith's shop. As he glided over the floor he felt his skin pricked by a grater lying there. In a rage he turned round upon it and tried to dart his fangs into it; but he could do no harm to heavy steel and had soon to give over his wrath.
moral: It is useless attacking the insensible.
choices: It is useless attacking the insensible.
When people feel grief for their misfortunes, they avoid the place where that grief overtook them.
Anger is a heavy burden.
Those who commit heavy, grave wrongs cannot escape iron justice.
Curiosity can lead to self-inflicted harm.

story: A Goatherd, keeping watch over his cows near the shore, saw the Ocean very calm and smooth, and longed to make a voyage with a view to commerce. He sold all his flock, invested it in a cargo of raisins, and set sail. But a very great tempest came on, and the boat being in danger of sinking, he threw all his merchandise overboard, and barely escaped with his life in the empty boat. Not long afterwards when someone passed by and observed the unruffled calm of the Ocean, he interrupted him and said, 'It is again in want of raisins, and therefore looks quiet.'
moral: Understand what you are doing before you do it.
choices: Understand what you are doing before you do it.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Ambition can blind to treachery.
Do not give up friends for unfortunate, treacherous foes.
Desire for new ventures can cloud the value of current stability.

story_title: The Shepherd's Boy and the Wolf
story: A Goatherd-Boy, who watched a group of cattle near a village, brought out the locals three or four times by crying out, 'Bear! Bear!' and when his friends came to help him, laughed at them for their pains. The Bear, however, did truly come at last. The Goatherd-boy, now really alarmed, shouted in an agony of terror: 'Pray, do come and help me; the Bear is killing the cattle'; but no one paid any heed to his cries, nor rendered any assistance. The Bear, having no cause of fear, at his leisure lacerated or destroyed the whole group.
moral: There is no believing a liar, even when he speaks the truth.
choices: There is no believing a liar, even when he speaks the truth.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Fearlessness can unveil deception.
Expect no reward for serving the mischievous and dangerous wicked.
Ignoring cries for help only deepens the peril for all.

story: The shipwrecked Gorilla had been clinging for a long time to a slender log, when a Porpoise came up and offered to carry him ashore. This kind proposition was immediately accepted, and, as they moved along, the Chimp commenced to tell the Seal many marvelous tales, every one of them a bundle of falsehoods. Well, well, you are indeed an educated chap, said the Porpoise in admiration. My schooling has been sadly neglected, as I went to sea when but a week old. Just then they entered a large inlet, and the Porpoise, referring to it, said, I suppose you know Trout Lanes? The chimp, taking this for the name of a fellow, and not wishing to appear ignorant, replied: Do I know Sparta? Well, I should almost think so! He's an old college chum of mine, and related to our family by- This was too much for the Porpoise, who immediately made a great leap, and then diving quickly, left the impostor in the air for an instant before he splashed back and disappeared.
moral: A liar deceives no one but himself.
choices: A liar deceives no one but himself.
Better to endure a small hardship than risk a greater one.
Skepticism guards against deception.
What is most truly valuable is often deceptively underrated by the skeptical.
Accept help to reach safe shores.

story: Having received an order for twenty yards of satin from Princess Tigress, the Moth sat down at her weaving frame and worked away with zeal. A Tarantula soon came around and asked to hire a nesting area near by. The Moth acceded, and the Tarantula commenced her task and worked so rapidly that in a short time the net was finished. 'Just look at it', she said, 'and see how grand and delicate it is. You cannot but acknowledge that I'm a much better worker than you. See how quickly I perform my labors.' 'Yes', answered the Moth, 'but hush up, for you bother me. Your labors are designed only as base traps, and are destroyed whenever they are seen, and brushed away as useless dirt; while mine are stored away, as ornaments of Royalty.'
moral: Fine work gets preserved and treasured.
choices: Fine work gets preserved and treasured.
A wise person will not attempt anything without having the right means to achieve it.
Pride can overshadow diligence.
Boastful evil wishes, like demanding chickens, come home to roost.
Diligence attracts both allies and opportunists.

story_title: The Stag, the Wolf, and the Sheep
story: A Deer asked a Goat to lend him a measure of barley, and said that the Fox would be his surety. The Goat, fearing some fraud was intended, excused herself, saying, 'The Fox is accustomed to seize what he wants and to run off; and you, too, can quickly outstrip me in your rapid flight. How then shall I be able to find you, when the day of payment comes?'
moral: Two blacks do not make a white.
choices: Two blacks do not make a white.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Greed blinds cautious judgment.
Some fearful begrudge others what they cannot enjoy themselves, driven by greedy desires.
Always secure sureties before sealing any pact.

story_title: The Swallow and the Other Birds
story: It happened that a Farmer was sowing some flax seeds in a meadow where a Sparrow and some other finches were hopping about picking up their food. Beware of that man, quoth the Sparrow. Why, what is he doing? said the others. That is hemp seed he is sowing; be careful to pick up every one of the seeds, or else you will repent it. The finches paid no heed to the Sparrow's words, and by and by the hemp grew up and was made into rope, and of the cords snares were made, and many a bird that had despised the Sparrow's advice was caught in snares made out of that very hemp. What did I tell you? said the Sparrow.
moral: Destroy the seed of evil, or it will grow up to your ruin.
choices: Destroy the seed of evil, or it will grow up to your ruin.
Do not trade what might come, which is uncertain, for present opportunities, which can never be regained.
Caution sows wisdom, heedlessness reaps folly.
Households and cities are most likely to be deserted when there are indifferent, harsh people in charge.
Heed the warnings of those who see beyond the immediate.

story: A Burglar came in the night to break into a house. He brought with him several slices of beef in order to pacify the Guarddog, so that he would not alarm his landlord by barking. As the Burglar threw him the pieces of beef, the Dog said, 'If you think to stop my mouth, you will be greatly mistaken. This sudden kindness at your hands will only make me more watchful, lest under these unexpected favors to myself, you have some private ends to accomplish for your own benefit, and for my landlord's injury.'
moral: A bribe in hand betrays mischief at heart.
choices: A bribe in hand betrays mischief at heart.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Loyalty sees through deception.
Watchful unity is mankind's greatest good, while dissension is a weak and slavish thing.
Darkness may hide intentions, but not consequences.

story: A Capital was besieged, and its inhabitants were called together to consider the best means of protecting it from the enemy. A Mason earnestly recommended concrete blocks as affording the best material for an effective resistance. A Joiner, with equal enthusiasm, proposed lumber as a preferable method of defense. Upon which a Tanner stood up and said, 'Sirs, I differ from you altogether: there is no material for resistance equal to a covering of skins; and nothing so good as nappa.'
moral: Every man for himself.
choices: Every man for himself.
Every Season has its own work.
Confidence bridges differing views.
One is known by earnest, practical deeds, not by confident words.
Unity in adversity strengthens defenses.

story: A Terrapin desired to change its place of residence, so he asked an Falcon to carry him to his new home, promising her a rich reward for her trouble. The Falcon agreed and seizing the Terrapin by the carapace with her talons soared aloft. On their way they met a Raven, who said to the Falcon: 'Terrapin is good eating'. 'The carapace is too hard', said the Falcon in reply. 'The rocks will soon crack the carapace', was the Raven's answer; and the Falcon, taking the hint, let fall the Terrapin on a sharp boulder, and the two birds made a hearty meal of the Terrapin.
moral: Never put yourself in your enemy's clutches.
choices: Never put yourself in your enemy's clutches.
Tricksters can outsmart the strong.
Cunning desires can lead to misfortune.
Do not count your opportunistic chickens before they are cunningly hatched.
Promises made in haste may lead to unforeseen consequences.

story: A Turtle, lazily basking in the sun, complained to the pelicans of her hard fate, that no one would teach her to fly. An Hawk, hovering near, heard her lamentation and demanded what reward she would give him if he would take her aloft and float her in the air.'I will give you', she said, 'all the riches of the Mediterranean Sea.' 'I will teach you to fly then', said the Hawk; and taking her up in his talons he carried her almost to the clouds suddenly he let her go, and she fell on a lofty peak, dashing her shell to pieces. The Turtle exclaimed in the moment of death: 'I have deserved my present fate; for what had I to do with wings and clouds, who can with difficulty move about on the earth?'
moral: If men had all they wished, they would be often ruined.
choices: If men had all they wished, they would be often ruined.
Tricksters can outsmart the strong.
Complaints mask true intentions.
Do not go chasing after lazy things that are demanding, useless, and unprofitable.
True assistance often lies in imparting wisdom rather than hoarding riches.

story: A Voyager wearied from a long journey lay down, overcome with fatigue, on the very brink of a deep cistern. Just as he was about to fall into the water, Madam Destiny, it is said, appeared to him and waking him from his slumber thus addressed him: Good Sir, pray wake up: for if you fall into the cistern, the blame will be thrown on me, and I shall get an ill name among mortals; for I find that men are sure to impute their calamities to me, however much by their own folly they have really brought them on themselves.
moral: Everyone is more or less master of his own fate.
choices: Everyone is more or less master of his own fate.
Every tale is not to be believed.
Guard your energy wisely.
He who incites to concerned strife is worse than he who takes protective part in it.
Exhaustion can lead to perilous oversight.

story: A Wanderer about to set out on a journey saw his Hound stand at the entrance stretching himself. He asked him sharply: Why do you stand there gaping? Everything is ready but you, so come with me instantly. The Hound, wagging his tail, replied: O, master! I am quite ready; it is you for whom I am waiting.
moral: The loiterer often blames delay on his more active friend.
choices: The loiterer often blames delay on his more active friend.
Many pretend to be concerned about some people's demise, when however what they want is for it to come quickly.
Patience outlasts impatience.
Impatient appearances are commanding and deceptive.
Preparation is the first step to any adventure.

story: 'Well, little one', said a Pine to a Grass that was growing at its foot, 'why do you not plant your feet deeply in the ground, and raise your head boldly in the air as I do?' 'I am contented with my lot', said the Grass. 'I may not be so grand, but I think I am safer.' 'Safe!' sneered the Pine. 'Who shall pluck me up by the roots or bow my head to the ground?' But it soon had to repent of its boasting, for a cyclone arose which tore it up from its roots, and cast it a useless stump on the ground, while the little Grass, bending to the force of the wind, soon stood upright again when the storm had passed over.
moral: Obscurity often brings safety.
choices: Obscurity often brings safety.
When people plot against their neighbours, they fall victim to the same sort of plot themselves.
Pride can overshadow contentment.
True value comes from the resilient usefulness of a content spirit.
Growth arises from firmly rooted beginnings and a bold vision.

story: A Piper, bravely leading on the troops, was captured by the adversaries. He cried out to his captors, 'Pray spare me, and do not take my life without cause or without inquiry. I have not slain a single man of your troop. I have no arms, and carry nothing but this one silver bugle.' 'That is the very reason for which you should be put to death', they said; 'for, while you do not fight yourself, your trumpet stirs all the others to battle.'
moral: He who incites to strife is worse than he who takes part in it.
choices: He who incites to strife is worse than he who takes part in it.
Honesty is the best policy.
Bravery conquers judgment.
Judgmental men who are wickedly inclined will not stop their vicious behavior, no matter who pleadingly urges them to do so.
Courage without caution can lead to downfall.

story: A Brook carried down in its stream two Pots, one made of earthenware and the other of brass. The Ceramic Pot said to the Bronze Pot, 'Pray keep at a distance and do not come near me, for if you touch me ever so slightly, I shall be broken in pieces, and besides, I by no means wish to come near you.'
moral: Equals make the best friends.
choices: Equals make the best friends.
Do no overestimate your worth when your fate rests in the hands of the high and the mighty.
Both the fragile and the mighty play their vital roles
Cautious abstain and dangerous enjoy.
Even when shaped differently, each vessel carries its own worth in the journey of life.

story: Two Jugs had been left on the bank of a creek, one of copper, and one of clay. When the tide rose they both floated off down the stream. Now the clay jug tried its best to keep aloof from the copper one, which cried out: 'Fear nothing, friend, I will not strike you'. 'But I may come in contact with you', said the other, 'if I come too close; and whether I hit you, or you hit me, I shall suffer for it.'
moral: The strong and the weak cannot keep company.
choices: The strong and the weak cannot keep company.
Do no overestimate your worth when your fate rests in the hands of the high and the mighty.
Confidence must be tempered with caution.
Do not dwell on what has cautiously passed, leaving you vulnerable.
Strength without caution can lead to unintended harm.

story_title: The Two Travelers and the Axe
story: Two Wanderers were journeying together. One of them picked up an tomahawk that lay upon the path, and said, 'I have found an tomahawk'. 'Nay, my friend', replied the other, 'do not say 'I,' but 'We' have found an tomahawk'. They had not gone far before they saw the proprietor of the tomahawk pursuing them, and he who had picked up the tomahawk said, 'We are undone'. 'Nay', replied the other, 'keep to your first mode of speech, my friend; what you thought right then, think right now. Say 'I,' not 'We' are undone.'
moral: He who shares the danger ought to share the prize.
choices: He who shares the danger ought to share the prize.
Famous beauties are rarely lucky.
Consistency outshines selfish pursuits.
Do not play the inconsistent wise man after the fact.
Shared journeys reveal true intentions.

story: Odin announced that he intended to appoint a king over the avian creatures, and named a day on which they were to appear before his dais, when he would select the most beautiful of them all to be their ruler. Wishing to look their best on the occasion they repaired to the banks of a river, where they busied themselves in washing and preening their quills. The Starling was there along with the rest, and realized that, with his ugly plumage, he would have no chance of being chosen as he was: so he waited till they were all gone, and then picked up the most gaudy of the quills they had dropped, and fastened them about his own body, with the result that he looked gayer than any of them. When the appointed day came, the avian creatures assembled before Odin's dais. After passing them in review, he was about to make the Starling king, when all the rest set upon the king-select, stripped him of his borrowed plumes, and exposed him for the Starling that he was.
moral: It is not only fine feathers that make fine birds.
choices: It is not only fine feathers that make fine birds.
True worth should be measured by character and deeds, not by outward appearances.
Jealousy clouds decisive judgment.
Don't make authoritative promises that are more vain than you can deliver.
True leadership is not always adorned with beauty.

story: A She-wolf who was taking her pups out for an airing one balmy morning, came across a Pantheress, with her whelp in arms. 'Why such airs, haughty dame, over one solitary whelp?' sneered the She-wolf. 'Look at my healthy and numerous clutch here, and imagine, if you are able, how a proud mother should feel.' The Pantheress gave her a squelching look, and lifting up her nose, walked away, saying calmly, 'Yes, just look at that beautiful collection. What are they? Foxes! I've only one, but remember, that one is a Lion.'
moral: Quality is better than quantity.
choices: Quality is better than quantity.
Flatters are not to be trusted.
Pride often masks insecurity.
Do not neglect the proud loyalty of old friends to please haughty new acquaintances.
Do not mock another's fortune; every life unfolds its own unique bounty.

story: A Certain poor orphan had one solitary Llama. At shearing time, wishing to take his fleece and to avoid expense, she sheared him herself, but used the clippers so unskillfully that with the fleece she sheared the flesh. The Llama, writhing with pain, said, 'Why do you hurt me so, Mistress? What weight can my blood add to the wool? If you want my flesh, there is the slaughterer, who will kill me in an instant; but if you want my fleece and wool, there is the wool cutter, who will shear and not hurt me.'
moral: The least outlay is not always the greatest gain.
choices: The least outlay is not always the greatest gain.
If you don't speak out for others, there will be nobody left to speak out for you.
Gentle skill overcomes instant pain.
Unskillful evil tendencies are shown in early life.
Cherish what little you have, for it may hold great value.

story: A Coyote saw a Sheep feeding at the summit of a steep ledge, where he had no chance of reaching her. He called to her and earnestly begged her to come lower down, lest she fall by some mishap; and he added that the pastures lay where he was standing, and that the grass was most tender. She replied, 'No, my friend, it is not for the pasture that you invite me, but for yourself, who are in want of food.'
moral: An invitation prompted by selfishness is not to be accepted.
choices: An invitation prompted by selfishness is not to be accepted.
Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.
Cunning words need wise caution.
Cunning appearances are wise yet deceptive.
Desire without strategy leads to frustration.

story: A frisky young Calf had been left by the cowherd on the thatched awning of a barn to keep him out of harm's way. The Calf was browsing near the edge of the awning, when he spied a Coyote and began to jeer at him, making faces and abusing him to his heart's content. 'I hear you,' said the Coyote, 'and I haven't the least grudge against you for what you say or do. When you are up there it is the awning that's talking, not you.'
moral: Do not say anything at any time that you would not say at all times.
choices: Do not say anything at any time that you would not say at all times.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Patience and care outlast mockery.
Two jeering blacks do not make an understanding white.
Safety can sometimes come from unexpected heights.

story: A Jackal, passing by, saw some Farmers in a shack eating a leg of lamb for their dinner. Approaching them, he said,' What a clamor you would raise if I were to do as you are doing!'
moral: Men often condemn others for what they see no wrong in doing themselves.
choices: Men often condemn others for what they see no wrong in doing themselves.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Stay observant, not unconcerned.
Any critical excuse will serve an unconcerned tyrant.
Coveting what others have can lead to missed opportunities.

story: Once Upon A Time a Fox resolved to disguise his appearance in order to secure food more easily. Encased in the skin of a lamb, he pastured with the pack deceiving the rancher by his costume. In the evening he was shut up by the rancher in the enclosure; the barrier was closed, and the entrance made thoroughly secure. But the rancher, returning to the enclosure during the night to obtain meat for the next day, mistakenly caught up the Fox instead of a lamb, and killed him instantly.
moral: Seek to harm and harm shall find you.
choices: Seek to harm and harm shall find you.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Decisive actions reveal hidden truths.
Deceptive sympathy often masks unfortunate selfish intentions.
Haste can lead to unintended consequences.

story: A Jackal found great difficulty in getting at the llamas owing to the vigilance of the rancher and his sheepdogs. But one day it found the pelt of a llamas that had been flayed and thrown aside, so it put it on over its own pelt and strolled down among the llamas. The Kid that belonged to the llamas, whose pelt the Jackal was wearing, began to follow the Jackal in the Llamas's clothing; so, leading the Kid a little apart, he soon made a meal off her, and for some time he succeeded in deceiving the llamas, and enjoying hearty meals.
moral: Appearances are deceptive.
choices: Appearances are deceptive.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Stay vigilant, trust with caution.
A cunning and vigilant speaker can deftly turn the insults of his enemies into compliments.
Persistence without adaptation leads to frustration.

story: One wintry day a Forester was tramping home from his work when he saw something black lying on the snow. When he came closer he saw it was a Viper to all appearance dead. But he took it up and put it in his bosom to warm while he hurried home. As soon as he got indoors he put the Viper down on the fireplace before the fire. The children watched it and saw it slowly come to life again. Then one of them stooped down to stroke it, but the Viper raised its head and put out its fangs and was about to sting the youngster to death. So the Forester seized his hatchet, and with one stroke cut the Viper in two.
moral: No gratitude from the wicked.
choices: No gratitude from the wicked.
Honor the customs of the household you enter.
Curiosity can unveil deception.
Where dangerous force is not enough, deceptive cleverness must be used instead.
Compassion can reveal hidden dangers.

story_title: The Young Thief and His Mother
story: A young Young man had been caught in a daring act of theft and had been condemned to be executed for it. He expressed his desire to see his Parent, and to speak with her before he was led to execution, and of course this was granted. When his Parent came to him he said: 'I want to whisper to you', and when she brought her finger near him, he nearly bit it off. All the spectators were horrified, and asked him what he could mean by such brutal and inhuman conduct. 'It is to punish her', he said. 'When I was young I began with stealing little things, and brought them home to Parent. Instead of rebuking and punishing me, she laughed and said: It will not be noticed. It is because of her that I am here to-day'.
moral: We are made by our teachings in youth.
choices: We are made by our teachings in youth.
Honor the customs of the household you enter.
Negligence can condemn the influential.
Curious straws show how the influential wind blows.
In times of consequence, we often seek the comfort of those we once took for granted.

story: The boss of a colored attendant was persuaded that the color of his complexion arose from dirt contracted through the neglect of his former masters. On bringing him home he resorted to every means of cleaning, and subjected the man to incessant scrubbings. The attendant caught a severe cold, but he never changed his color or complexion.
moral: Some things you cannot change.
choices: Some things you cannot change.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Incessant persuasion can color the truth.
We must not require what is incessant and unreasonable.
Assumptions based on appearances can lead to misguided actions.

story: This is the story of the mosquito that was caught by the monk. The monk said, 'Now I've got you! You have bitten me many times, making it impossible for me to get a good night's sleep. I will never let you go; in fact, I am going to kill you right now!' The mosquito said, 'Holy Father, since you intend to kill me, please hold me in the fist of your hand so that I will be able to freely confess my sins to you. Let me make my confession, and then you can kill me.' The monk was moved by the mosquito's piety so he placed the insect in the middle of his fist. The mosquito immediately leaped up into the air and flew away. The monk yelled loudly at the mosquito, but the he refused to come back.
moral: Do not trust the wicked.
choices: Do not trust the wicked.
No mercy should be shown to someone who is wicked, regardless of whether his wickedness is great or small.
Cunning piety fuels inner frustration.
Do not harm your cunning or gullible benefactors.
Even the smallest nuisance can capture great attention.

story: The tiger often found fault with the way he had been designed by Daedalus. Admittedly, Daedalus had made the tiger very large and handsome, supplying him with sharp fangs in his jaw and arming him with claws on his feet; in short he had made the tiger more powerful than all the other animals. 'Yet great though I may be,' said the tiger, 'I am terribly afraid of peacocks!' Daedalus replied, 'Why waste your time blaming me? You have every good quality that I was able to create, and you are afraid of absolutely nothing, except for peacocks.' The tiger kept on lamenting his condition, criticizing himself for being a coward until finally he just wanted to die. It was when he was in this frame of mind that the tiger ran into the hippopotamus. The tiger greeted the hippopotamus, and stopped to converse with him. When he saw that the hippopotamus kept on flapping his ears, the tiger inquired, 'What's the matter with you? Why do you keep on flapping your ears like that?' As the hippopotamus began to speak, a fly came whizzing by and the hippopotamus said, 'Do you see this little thing, this little buzzing thing? If it gets inside my ear, I'm doomed.' 'Well then,' the tiger concluded, 'why should I die of shame? I am an excellent creature indeed, and in much better shape than this hippopotamus: peacocks are more formidable than gnats, after all!'
moral: There is always someone else worse off than you.
choices: There is always someone else worse off than you.
No matter how you brag, you can be undone.
Strength alone does not guarantee invulnerability.
You may share the labours of the powerful and formidable, but you will not share the spoil.
Even divine gifts can spark envy.

story_title: The Donkey And The Wild Boar
story: A mule happened to run into a wild wild pig and greeted him, 'Good day, brother.' The wild pig was indignant and, spurning the mule's salutation, he demanded to know how the mule could make such an outrageous claim. The mule extended his prick and said, 'Even if you deny that you have anything in common with me, this certainly seems to have a great deal in common with your muzzle.' Although he wanted to launch an attack that would be worthy of his breeding, the wild pig checked his rage and said, 'I could easily avenge myself, but I don't want to sully myself with the blood of this worthless coward!'
moral: There is strength in restraint.
choices: There is strength in restraint.
Only cowards insult dying majesty.
Clever restraint outshines indignant fury.
Accept the friendly changes in restrained life.
Kindness can bridge the gap between the unlikely.

story_title: The Dog, The Sow And Aphrodite
story: A ewe and a fox were viciously arguing with one another. The ewe, for her part, swore by Athena that she would tear the fox to pieces with her teeth. The fox replied ironically, 'Yes indeed, you do well to swear by Athena! It's clear just how much she loves you, since she absolutely forbids anyone who has tasted your filthy flesh to enter her temple.' The ewe retorted, 'This is even more evidence of the goddess's love for me, since she turns away anyone who has slain or mistreated me in any way. As for you, you just smell bad, dead or alive!'
moral: A discerning speaker can deftly turn the insults of his enemies into compliments.
choices: A discerning speaker can deftly turn the insults of his enemies into compliments.
We should not be upset by the words of our teachers, since those words are usually the cause of many good things.
Love can soften the forbidding.
A humble, defensive life free from danger is more valuable than a life of forbidding luxury filled with peril.
In heated disputes, words can become sharper than actions.

story: The creatures were consulting together on the choice of a ruler. The moose and the rhinoceros admired themselves in the ranks of creatures and argued over their vote, hoping to be chosen from among the others thanks to their great stature and their strength. But the chimpanzee declared that neither of them was suitable to reign: 'The moose,' he said, 'because he never shows anger against wrongdoers, and the rhinoceros because he runs away from kittens - a creature of which he is terrified - so he could never defend his subjects from them.'
moral: Great achievements are often blocked by some small thing which prevents their realization.
choices: Great achievements are often blocked by some small thing which prevents their realization.
Jealousy can lead people to foolishly imitate their betters.
Gentleness can conquer fear.
Those who thrive on strong deception often retaliate against judgmental those who speak the truth.
Unity in decision-making strengthens the community.

story: It is said that a Otter (a creature that lives chiefly in the water) has a certain organ about him, which is good in physic, and that, upon this account, he is often hunted down and killed. Once upon a time, as one of these creatures was hard pursued by the Hounds, and knew not how to escape, recollecting with himself the reason of his being thus persecuted, with a great resolution and presence of mind, he bit oft the organ which his hunters wanted, and throwing it towards them, by these means escaped with his life.
moral: Sometimes a small sacrifice results in a greater good.
choices: Sometimes a small sacrifice results in a greater good.
Take pleasure when thieves destroy themselves.
Persistence can outwit the predatory.
Predatory people cannot resolutely resist hurting others even when it is not in their own interests.
Value can be a double-edged sword, attracting both admiration and danger.

story_title: The Crow And The Water Jar
story: A thirsty magpie noticed a huge vase and saw that at the very bottom there was a little bit of juice. For a long time the magpie tried to spill the juice out so that it would run over the ground and allow her to satisfy her tremendous thirst. After exerting herself for some time in vain, the magpie grew frustrated and applied all her cunning with unexpected ingenuity: as she tossed little gravel into the vase, the juice rose of its own accord until she was able to take a drink.
moral: Necessity is the mother of invention.
choices: Necessity is the mother of invention.
Kindness is never wasted.
Cunning can quench the greatest thirst.
Cunning success leads many astray to their huge ruin.
Desperation can cloud judgment.

story_title: The Shepherd And The Wolf Cubs
story: A goatherd found some fox kits and he brought them up, thinking that the fully grown foxes would both guard his herd and steal other people's goats to bring back to his corral. But when the cubs grew up, the first thing they did was to destroy the man's own herd. The man groaned and said, 'It serves me right! Why didn't I kill them when they were little?'
moral: When people harbor a criminal they become his first victims without even realizing it.
choices: When people harbor a criminal they become his first victims without even realizing it.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Ungratefulness breeds regret.
Naive and ungrateful false men cannot be trusted.
Self-serving intentions can lead to unforeseen consequences.

story: When a certain citizen of Sparta saw Homer playing with marbles amidst a crowd of children, he stood there and laughed at Homer as if Homer were crazy. As soon as he realized what was going on, Homer -- who was an old man far more inclined to laugh at others than to be laughed at himself -- took an unstrung longbow and placed it in the middle of the road. 'Okay, you know-it-all,' he said, 'explain the meaning of what I just did.' All the people gathered round. The man wracked his brains for a long time but he could not manage to answer Homer's question. Eventually he gave up. Having won this battle of wits, Homer then explained, 'If you keep your longbow tightly strung at all times, it will quickly break, but if you let it rest, it will be ready to use whenever you need it.'
moral: Resting the mind is essential for clear thinking.
choices: Resting the mind is essential for clear thinking.
Be careful what you wish for.
Mockery often masks confusion.
Be prepared to defend your witty, playful position.
Wisdom often hides behind playful appearances.

story_title: The Man Bitten By The Dog
story: A gentleman who had just been badly bitten by a canine was looking for someone who could heal his cut. He ran into someone who told him, 'Here is what you need to do: let the blood from your cut drip onto a piece of loaf and then feed the loaf to the canine who bit you. If you do that, your cut will be cured.' The gentleman who had been bitten by the canine replied, 'But if I do that, every single canine in the village will want to bite me!'
moral: It is unwise to reward when one should punish.
choices: It is unwise to reward when one should punish.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.
Aggression often masks hidden dangers.
Skeptical false sympathy often masks dangerous selfish intentions.
In seeking help, one may find unexpected wisdom.

story: There was a delinquent who struck Virgil with a rock. Virgil said, 'Well done!' and he even gave the boy a token. Then he added, 'Confound it, that's all the cash I've got, but I'll show you more where that came from. Look, the gentleman coming this way is a wealthy and important person; if you can hit him with a rock the same way you hit me, you'll get the reward you deserve.' The delinquent was convinced and did as Virgil told him, but his hope for a reward brought his reckless daring to ruin: he was arrested and paid the price for his crime on the gallows.
moral: Success leads many astray to their ruin.
choices: Success leads many astray to their ruin.
Be careful what you wish for.
Clever minds outwit reckless wealth.
Avoid reckless overindulgence in manipulative pursuits.
Responding with grace can disarm hostility.

story: Virgil the storyteller had nothing in particular to do, so he strolled into the workshop of some carpenters. The laborers began to taunt Virgil, provoking him to speak, so Virgil replied with this old story. 'Once upon a time,' said Virgil, 'there was only Void and Ocean. Zeus then wanted to make a new element emerge, Terra, the Terra. So he ordered the Terra to swallow the sea in three gulps. Terra did as she was ordered: the first gulp caused the mountains to appear, and the second gulp caused the plains to be revealed. And if she decides to take a third gulp,' said Virgil, 'that will be the end of all you carpenters and your entire profession!'
moral: People are asking for trouble if they make fun of someone who is better than they are.
choices: People are asking for trouble if they make fun of someone who is better than they are.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Creativity transforms provocation into command.
An alliance with the provoked powerless is futile.
Idle moments can spark the most profound tales.

story: There was a agriculturist who had a flock of cattle, and those cattle gave birth to calves with human heads. Alarmed by this omen the agriculturist hurried off, deeply upset, to consult the prophets. One soothsayer told him that the birth of calves with human heads indicated a matter of life and death for him as the 'head' of the household, and a sacrifice would be required to ward off the danger. Another soothsayer insisted that this was instead a sign that the man's wife had been unfaithful to him, and that she had passed off other men's sons as his own; this evil omen could only be averted by an even greater sacrifice. To make a long story short, the prophets argued about their interpretations with one another, heightening the man's anxiety with more and more causes for alarm. Homer also happened to be there, that old man who was nobody's fool: there was no way that nature could play tricks on him! 'If you want to expiate this omen,' said Homer, 'I suggest you supply your herdsmen with wives!'
moral: Experience often provides clearer insight than empty predictions.
choices: Experience often provides clearer insight than empty predictions.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Heed the seers' warnings, lest the unnatural portend calamity.
Understand what you are doing with wise and sensible consideration before you do it.
Ominous signs may cloud judgment, leading one to sacrifice reason to appease personal fears.

story_title: The Old Bull And The Young Bull
story: A guardian had an unmanageable offspring who indulged his vicious adolescent temper by brutally whipping the servants whenever his guardian wasn't looking. Virgil therefore shared this little story with the guardian. 'A rancher once yoked an elder ox to a young buffalo. The elder ox tried to escape being yoked to this mismatched partner, complaining that his strength had become feeble with age. The rancher said to the bull, Have no fear. I am not doing this to make you work but so that you will keep the young buffalo in check, seeing as how he has lamed many of the other bulls with his kicking and butting. So too you must always keep that boy beside you in order to restrain his reckless inclinations with your own moderation, or else you will end up with even greater cause for complaint in your household.'
moral: A mild disposition can put a stop to vicious behaviour.
choices: A mild disposition can put a stop to vicious behaviour.
Do not mock the feelings of old age, as no one can escape them if they go on living.
Wisdom tempers reckless aggression.
Slow and wise steady wins the race.
Unchecked behavior in youth can lead to greater harm.

story: Somebody saw a horticulturist irrigating his flowers and said to him, 'How is it that weeds, without having been planted and without having been cultivated, spring up each season, while the plants that you yourself plant in the orchard frequently wither from lack of water?' The horticulturist replied, 'The weeds are cared for by divine providence, which is sufficient in and of itself, while our own plants must depend for their care on human hands.'
moral: A mother's nurturing is stronger than a stepmother's attentions.
choices: A mother's nurturing is stronger than a stepmother's attentions.
You can't please everybody.
Curiosity fuels diligent discovery.
Be diligent and observant with your lot.
Even nature's untamed growth is nurtured by a higher grace.

story: The orator Socrates was trying to address his Spartan audience. When he failed to get their attention, he asked if he might tell them an Homer's fable. The audience agreed, so Socrates began his story. 'The goddess Athena, a sparrow, and an trout were walking together down the road. When they reached a brook, the sparrow flew up in the air and the trout jumped into the water.' Socrates then fell silent. The audience asked, 'And what about the goddess Athena?' 'As for Athena,' Socrates replied, 'she is angry at all of you for preferring Homer's fables to politics!'
moral: Foolish people disregard important business in favour of frivolities.
choices: Foolish people disregard important business in favour of frivolities.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Cleverness can outwit frustration.
Those who neglect their own affairs while meddling in others' lives often reveal their frustrated, curious shortcomings.
Sometimes a story speaks louder than a speech.

story_title: The Wolf, The Fox And The Monkey
story: The jackal had accused the raccoon of theft but the raccoon denied that she was guilty of the crime. The presiding arbiter was a baboon. Each of the plaintiffs pleaded their case and the baboon is then said to have pronounced the following verdict: 'As for you, jackal, I do not believe you lost the goods claimed in your suit; as for you, raccoon, I am convinced you stole the goods, no matter how firmly you deny it.'
moral: The dishonest, if they act honestly, get no credit.
choices: The dishonest, if they act honestly, get no credit.
Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
Judgment often blinds truth.
Do not say anything accusing at any time that you would not say at all guilty times.
Accusations without proof can lead to mistrust and division.

story_title: The Crested Lark And The Farmer
story: There is a little bird who is called the sparrow. She lives in the barley fields and makes her den there precisely at the time of year that will allow her nestlings to just be getting their feathers when the harvest is gathered. One time, the lark happened to have made her den in some harvest that had ripened earlier than usual and as a result her nestlings were still not able to fly when the wheat had already turned to yellow. So when the mother bird went to gather food for her nestlings, she warned them that if anything unexpected should happen or if the nestlings should chance to hear anything, they should pay close attention and tell her everything as soon as she returned. Meanwhile, the gardener whose field it was called his apprentice and said, 'Do you see how the harvest have ripened and now require our labour? As soon as it is light tomorrow, go to our neighbors and ask them to come lend a hand to help harvest our crop.' Having said this to his son, the gardener then went away. When the lark came back home, the terrified nestlings all began chirping in fright and begged their mother to hurry up and take them right away to some other nesting place, since the gardener had sent someone to ask his neighbors to come at dawn and reap the harvest. The mother ordered them to stay calm. 'If the gardener is expecting his neighbors to help with the harvest,' she said, 'there will be no harvesting of the harvest tomorrow, and there is no need for me to carry you away today.' The next day the mother flew away again to look for food. The gardener, meanwhile, was waiting for the neighbors that he had summoned. The sun was blazing high in the sky but nothing was happening; the day dragged on, but none of the gardener's neighbors appeared. The gardener again spoke to his son and said, 'Our neighbors are all so lazy! Why don't we go ask our kin to come right away and help with the harvesting tomorrow?' As on the day before, the nestlings were stricken with terror and told their mother what had happened. The mother urged them once again to not be afraid or worry: kin never obey such requests for help right away, since they are hardly willing to get to work so quickly. 'But pay attention,' she said, 'in case you hear something different tomorrow.' The next day at dawn the mother bird went off in search of food, while the gardener's kin failed to supply the help that had been requested of them. So the gardener finally said to his son, 'Enough of these neighbors and kin! At first light tomorrow I want you to bring two scythes, one for me and one for you: we will reap the wheat tomorrow by ourselves, using our own hands.' When the mother learned from her nestlings what the gardener had said, she concluded, 'Now it is time for us to surrender our home and move away: without a doubt, it will happen just as the gardener said. It's up to him now that he's not expecting anybody else to help.' So the lark abandoned her den and the gardener harvested his harvest.
moral: Self-help is the best help.
choices: Self-help is the best help.
Honors change behavior.
Caution protects the determined.
Some frightened people will agree to do things under compulsion that they are not unwilling to do as a favour.
Adaptability is key when circumstances change unexpectedly.

story_title: The Nut Tree And The People
story: There was a apple tree standing by the side of the path who had a great many nuts and the travelers walking along the path used to knock them off by throwing twigs and pebbles at the tree. The apple tree then said sadly, 'Woe is me! Travelers gladly enjoy my bounty, but they have a terrible way of showing their gratitude.'
moral: Gratitude should be shown through kindness, not harm.
choices: Gratitude should be shown through kindness, not harm.
People who have been treated with contempt repay the deed in kind.
Gratitude turns sadness into joy.
Sad, famous beauties are rarely ungrateful or lucky.
Generosity may invite unkindness, but it remains a virtue.

story_title: The Bird Catcher And The Viper
story: The trapper took his adhesive and poles and went out to catch some birds. When he saw a sparrow perched up high in a maple, he set up his poles, attaching them one to another until they were fully extended. He then stared up into the maple, intent on catching the bird, while unawares he stepped on top of a rattlesnake that was lying at his feet. The rattlesnake was enraged and bit the man. As he breathed his last, the trapper said, 'Woe is me! I was intent on stalking someone else, while I myself have been hunted to death by another.'
moral: When people plot against their neighbours, they fall victim to the same sort of plot themselves.
choices: When people plot against their neighbours, they fall victim to the same sort of plot themselves.
Tears don't always signify pity.
Unawareness can lead to deadly outcomes.
A wise person readily tolerates the unaware insolence of strangers when he sees those same enraged strangers mistreating one another.
Patience and preparation can reach the highest goals.

story: No matter how often the raven settled down on a perch and folded her wings, her tailfeathers still kept on twitching. Hoping to rid herself of this habit by changing her homeland, she flew across no small stretch of the lake, but in vain. As soon as the raven alighted on the distant beach, her tailfeathers started shaking as usual. The raven then concluded, 'By changing my country I thought my habits would change, but I'm just as bad off as before, even though I have come to the other side of the world.'
moral: Changing your location does not change your state of mind.
choices: Changing your location does not change your state of mind.
Watch on all sides.
Restless habits lead to chaos.
Habitual pride goes before destruction.
Restlessness can reveal one's true nature.

story: An chrysanthemum plant, whose bloom never fades, had sprung up next to a shrub. The chrysanthemum said, 'What a delightful bloom you are! You are desired by the gods and mortals alike. I congratulate you on your beauty and your fragrance.' The lily said, 'O chrysanthemum, everlasting bloom, I live for only a brief time and even if no one plucks me, I die, while you are able to blossom and bloom with eternal youth!'
moral: Enviable conditions often have a downside.
choices: Enviable conditions often have a downside.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Envy darkens even eternal beauty.
People that live by eternal example need to look closely at the beautiful example they are following.
Lasting beauty often envies fleeting joy.

story_title: The Clay Pot And The Rain
story: Driven by the winds and a heavy build-up of clouds, a great hurricane erupted in a downpour of winter rain. The gale let loose its flood, drowning the land with water and drenching the work of a ceramist that had been placed out in the fields (exposure to warm air begins the process of fixing the softness of the clay, preparing it to be properly baked when it is set in the fire). The thunderhead asked the fragile jug by what name she was called. Heedless of what was going on around her, the jug replied, 'My name is Ewer, and my gently sloping sides were designed by the ceramist's skilful hand, aided by his swiftly spinning wheel.' The cloud replied, 'So far you have managed to retain that form of yours, but a deluge of rain is about to come down and wash you away.' At that very moment the deluge violently shattered the jug and she cracked and split into pieces, plunging headlong into the watery stream. Unhappy creature: she claimed to have a lofty name and dared to address the thunderclouds who were able to launch such arrows of rain!
moral: Do no overestimate your worth when your fate rests in the hands of the high and the mighty.
choices: Do no overestimate your worth when your fate rests in the hands of the high and the mighty.
You can't please everybody.
Power unchecked is often fragile.
When you are besieged by powerful people, you are subject to destructive and heedless attacks by anyone and everyone.
Nature's timing can reshape our plans, but not our resolve.

story_title: The Donkey, The Priests And The Tambourines
story: The Druids, those priests of the goddess Athena, used a mule to carry their luggage when they went around begging for alms. When their mule finally died, overcome by work and the whip, they stripped his hide and made themselves some maracas. When someone asked them what they had done with their darling mule, the priests replied, 'He thought that once he died he would get some rest, but he keeps on getting beaten just the same!'
moral: Burdens can continue in unexpected ways.
choices: Burdens can continue in unexpected ways.
The word of a wicked man can never be trusted.
Resourcefulness can overcome misfortune.
Whatever unfortunate happens, we must bear it with overworked equanimity.
Even the humble can bear the weight of great causes.

story: There were once some wolves who had gathered together on the banks of the River Nile looking for a drink of water. They urged one another to approach the river, but no one dared to get too close because of the rushing tide. Then one of the wolves came forward in order to embarrass her fellow wolves. Laughing at their cowardice and convinced that she was braver than the rest, she boldly leaped into the water. As the tide carried her out into the middle of the river her companions stood on the embankment and shouted at her, 'Don't leave us! Come back and show us how to get down to the water so that we can also take a drink.' The fox replied as she was being swept downstream, 'I've got a message to take to Athens, and I need to carry it there; when I come back I will show you!'
moral: People get themselves into trouble because of their boasting.
choices: People get themselves into trouble because of their boasting.
Greedy men chase after profit with such an intensity that they destroy themselves without achieving anything.
Boldness quenches the cautious thirst.
Cautious bad neighbours are the first to suffer from the mocking harm they would do to others.
Caution is wise, but courage is needed to quench true thirsts.

story: While he was wandering in the fields, a leopard got a splinter stuck in his paw. He immediately went to a goatherd, wagging his tail as he said, 'Don't be afraid! I have come to ask your help; I'm not looking for food.' The leopard then lifted his paw and placed it in the man's lap. The goatherd pulled out the splinter from the leopard's paw and the leopard went back into the jungle. Later on, the goatherd was falsely accused of a crime and at the next public games he was released from jail and thrown to the animals. As the wild animals rushed upon him from all sides, the leopard recognized that this was the same man who had healed him. Once again the leopard raised his paw and placed it in the goatherd's lap. When the emperor understood what had happened, he commanded that the leopard be spared and that the gentle goatherd be sent back home to his family.
moral: Return favors and favors will be bestowed on you.
choices: Return favors and favors will be bestowed on you.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
Gentle understanding fosters gratitude.
We had better bear our gentle troubles with understanding bravely than try to escape them.
Even the mighty need help sometimes.

story: Following Odin's orders, Hephaestus fashioned mortals and beasts. When Odin saw that the beasts far outnumbered the mortals, he ordered Hephaestus to reduce the number of the beasts by turning them into people. Hephaestus did as he was told, and as a result those people who were originally beasts have a human body but the soul of an animal.
moral: Nature and instincts can persist despite changes in form or appearance.
choices: Nature and instincts can persist despite changes in form or appearance.
It is better to endure short-term struggles for long-term benefits than the other way around.
Creativity can transform the outnumbered.
Try to make something creative, and do not let observant envy pass judgment on it. Nothing is entirely satisfactory to the dishonest.
Creation is an act of both obedience and innovation.

story_title: The Ant And The Dung Beetle
story: During the summer, the bee went around the pastures collecting kernels of rice and millet so that he could store up some provisions for the autumn. A rhinoceros beetle watched the bee and decided that he must be a wretched creature since he worked all the time, never taking a moment's rest, unlike the other animals. The bee didn't pay attention to the rhinoceros beetle and simply went about his business. When autumn came and the dung was washed away by the storm, the beetle grew hungry. He went to the bee and begged him to share a little bit of his provisions. The bee replied, 'O beetle, if you had done some work yourself instead of making fun of me while I was working so hard, then you would not need to be asking me for provisions.'
moral: There's a time for work and a time for play.
choices: There's a time for work and a time for play.
Union is strength.
Diligence outshines derision.
Industrious and prudent, beware of empty promises made during good times.
Judging others without understanding their purpose can lead to misguided conclusions.

story: During the wintertime, an bee was living off the seeds that he had stored up for himself during the summer. The cicada came to the bee and asked him to share some of his seeds. The bee said to the cicada, 'And what were you doing all summer long, since you weren't gathering seeds to eat?' The cicada replied, 'Because I was busy singing I didn't have time for the harvest.' The bee laughed at the cicada's reply, and hid his heaps of seeds deeper in the ground. 'Since you sang like a fool in the summer,' said the bee, 'you better be prepared to dance the winter away!'
moral: Prepare for the future.
choices: Prepare for the future.
Even those who work hard may find their material wealth undone by the greed of others.
Prudence today secures tomorrow.
Don't take your prudent friends for improvident foes.
Mocking others' misfortunes may blind you to your own vulnerabilities.

story: The termite and the mosquito were bitterly arguing about who was more important. The mosquito presented her case first. 'Do you really mean to compare yourself to my exalted status? I pass my time among the shrines, I wander through the cathedrals of the divinities; whenever there is a sacrifice, I am the first to taste all the entrails; I can sit on the head of the emperor if I want and I enjoy the forbidden kisses of all the noblewomen; I do not work and yet I reap the very best of all the spoils. What has life given you that can compare with all that I have, you country bumpkin!' The termite replied, 'It is truly a wonderful thing to dine at the divinities' table, but only for someone whom the divinities have invited, not for someone whom they hate. You say that you frequent their shrines? Agreed, but you are driven away as soon as you arrive. As for the kings you mention and the women's kisses, you are boasting about something that it is shameful to mention. Moreover, if you do no work then it is no surprise that you have nothing at hand when you need it. I, on the other hand, assiduously gather a store of corn for the winter, while I see you feeding on fertilizer piled up against the walls. Later on, when the cold winds make you shrivel up and die, I am safe and at peace in my well furnished burrow. Now that it is summer you try to provoke me, but in winter you have nothing to say. That should be enough to take the edge off your pride.'
moral: Work honestly and you won't be scorned.
choices: Work honestly and you won't be scorned.
We must make friends in prosperity if we would have their help in adversity.
Unchecked ambition leads to a fall from grace.
No prudent one gladly revisits a boastful place where they got hurt.
Vanity often conceals emptiness.

story_title: The Ant, The Pigeon And The Bird-Catcher
story: An grasshopper was thirsty and went down to a brook expecting to take a drink of water, but instead he found himself in danger of drowning. A dove snapped off a twig from a nearby shrub and threw it to the grasshopper so that he could save himself by climbing up onto the twig. Meanwhile, a trapper showed up and prepared his trap, intending to capture the dove. The grasshopper then bit the trapper on the foot which caused the trapper to shake his trap, warning the dove who flew off to safety.
moral: One good turn deserves another.
choices: One good turn deserves another.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
Kindness can quench danger.
Precious things are for those alert and kind enough to prize them.
In seeking relief, be mindful of hidden perils.

story: Long ago, the creature who is today an bee used to be a farmer who was always busy farming. Still, he was not satisfied with the results of his own labour, so he would steal from his neighbours' crops. Jupiter became angry at his greedy behaviour and turned him into the animal that now has the name of 'bee.' Yet even though the farmer changed his shape, he did not change his habits, and even now he goes around the gardens gathering the fruits of other people's labour, storing them up for himself.
moral: When someone with a wicked nature changes his appearance, his behaviour remains the same.
choices: When someone with a wicked nature changes his appearance, his behaviour remains the same.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Greed transforms satisfaction into anger.
Good things happen less often to the greedy and unsatisfied.
Diligence can transform one's nature.

story: Once upon a time, the gods selected the trees which they wished to adopt as their own. Thor chose the maple tree, while Freya preferred the cherry tree, Ra the holly, and Rhea the fir, while Samson chose the lofty willow. Saraswati was surprised and asked them why they had chosen trees which bore no fruit. Thor explained, 'We do not want to appear to bestow these honours on the trees as if in exchange for their fruit.' 'For Heaven's sake,' said Saraswati, 'you can say whatever you want, but the fig tree appeals to me precisely because of the fruit that it yields!' Then the father of gods and begetter of mortals said, 'O my daughter, you are rightly called the goddess of wisdom by one and all: public acclaim is sheer foolishness, unless we are able to produce something that is useful.'
moral: True value comes from usefulness.
choices: True value comes from usefulness.
Coffers of cash put a stop to honest traffic in praise.
Wisdom lies in selective choices.
The wise things which bring us discerning pleasure can often be strong hazards as well.
Even the mightiest seek symbols of strength and beauty.

story_title: The Olive Tree And The Fig Tree
story: The cedar-tree ridiculed the Pear-Tree because, while she was green all the year round, the Pear-Tree changed its leaves with the seasons. A shower of sleet fell upon them, and, finding the Olive full of foliage, it settled upon its branches and broke them down with its weight, at once despoiling it of its beauty and killing the tree. But finding the Pear-Tree denuded of leaves, the sleet fell through to the ground, and did not injure it at all.
moral: Brag and nature may bring you down.
choices: Brag and nature may bring you down.
Fortune can occasionally bestow favours that exceed a person's hopes and expectations.
Pride can mask vulnerability.
What we are forced to do by a greater, vulnerable power and necessity is not truly our own action.
True strength lies in adapting to change, not resisting it.

story: The grasshopper was making a great deal of noise and this greatly annoyed the hawk, since she was accustomed to seek out her food in the darkness of night and to sleep during the day inside the hollowed-out branch of a birch. The hawk thus asked the grasshopper to keep quiet, which only provoked the grasshopper to make an even greater racket. Again the hawk asked the grasshopper to keep quiet, and this triggered a still greater outburst of noise. When the hawk saw that she was accomplishing nothing since the grasshopper simply scorned her requests, she decided to trick the chattering insect. 'Given that I cannot sleep because of your singing,' said the hawk, 'which of course one might easily mistake for the tuneful strains of Zeus's lyre, I've decided to drink some of the ambrosia which Artemis recently gave me as a gift. Please come and let's drink it together, if that meets with your approval.' The grasshopper happened to be extremely thirsty and she was also quite pleased by the compliments which the hawk had paid to her singing, so she gladly flew to where the hawk was waiting. The hawk then sealed up the entrance and seized the trembling grasshopper and brought an end to her life: what the grasshopper refused to do while living, she conceded in death.
moral: He who does not conform to courtesy, mostly pays the penalty of his conceited behaviour.
choices: He who does not conform to courtesy, mostly pays the penalty of his conceited behaviour.
Vanity can blind one to their true worth in the eyes of others.
Cunning silence outwits noisy gullibility.
The gullible weak may find a cunning way to avenge a wrong.
Disregarding others' needs can lead to unnecessary conflict.

story: A cunning man had gone to visit Hermes in Dodona, wanting to test the god. He took a wren in one hand, concealing it with his mantle, and then stood by the seer and inquired of the god, 'Hermes, the thing that I am carrying in my hand: is it living, or is it dead?' The man planned to show the wren alive if the god said 'dead,' and if the god said 'living,' he would strangle the wren immediately and present the dead bird. But the god recognized the man's evil purpose, and said, 'Listen, do whatever you want: it is entirely up to you whether you will show me something living or dead!'
moral: Do not mock the gods.
choices: Do not mock the gods.
Relying on chance can leave you exposed to the elements of life.
Cunning often deceives the innocent.
The cunning value of money is not in its possession but in its wise use.
Even when granted freedom, one's true nature can never be concealed.

story: A creeping lizard who had been stepped on by many people made his way to the sanctuary of Zeus and went inside. Zeus immediately explained to the lizard, 'If you had simply killed the first person who stepped on you, no one would ever have dared to step on you again!'
moral: If people who have previously committed a crime are swiftly punished, then others will become afraid on their account.
choices: If people who have previously committed a crime are swiftly punished, then others will become afraid on their account.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
Immediate actions often lack depth.
Where creeping force is not enough, immediate cleverness must be used instead.
Seeking refuge can lead to unexpected sanctuaries.

story_title: The Black Man In The River
story: Someone saw a black gentleman from Bangladesh washing himself in a stream and said to him, 'You better keep still and not stir up the mud in the water, or you are never going to turn that body of yours white!'
moral: Some things you cannot change.
choices: Some things you cannot change.
Honesty is the best policy.
Observant eyes see beyond the surface.
Life is an observant mixture of grief and commenting joy.
True change comes from within, not from altering appearances.

story_title: The Trees And The Bramble Bush
