story: The olive and the pear tree were debating about their beauty. They had both gone on at great length arguing back and forth when a thorn bush in a nearby shrubbery heard them and said, 'Dear friends, let us put a stop to our quarrel.'
moral: Everyone thinks themselves the best.
choices: Everyone thinks themselves the best.
Brag and nature may bring you down.
Peaceful intervention quells arguments.
Better peaceful poverty without care, than argumentative riches with.
Debate sharpens understanding and reveals hidden truths.

story_title: The Donkey Who Carried The God
story: A farmer had placed a carved idol on his mule and was leading him along. Many travelers bowed down when they met them along the way. The mule grew arrogant, thinking that the country folk were bowing down before him, so he began to leap and prance. As he did so, the mule almost threw the idol of the divinity from his back. The mule's master beat him with a cane and said, 'You are a mule carrying a divinity on your back, but that does not mean you deserve to be worshipped as a divinity!'
moral: Do not take credit for the accomplishments of others.
choices: Do not take credit for the accomplishments of others.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Arrogance blinds the misguided.
When arrogant public officials encourage misguided foolishness, it's no surprise if fools try to become public officials.
True value is not in appearances but in understanding.

story_title: The Bald Man And The Gardener
story: A hairless man asked his friend, a landscaper, to give him some of his gourds. The landscaper laughed at him and said, 'Go away, baldy, go away! I'm not giving any of my gourds to riffraff like you. Damn you and your baldness, in winter and summer -- I hope gnats and beetles land all over your bald head and bite you and drink your blood and poop on your head!' The hairless man got angry and drew his dagger. He seized the landscaper by the hair, intending to kill him, but the landscaper grabbed one of his gourds and hit the hairless man on the head. In the end, the hairless man was too strong for him and he cut off the landscaper's head.
moral: Those who refuse to share and respond with rudeness may face dire consequences for their actions.
choices: Those who refuse to share and respond with rudeness may face dire consequences for their actions.
Intent matters more than the outcome.
Strength is lost in anger.
Angry vices are their own mocking punishment.
Mockery may sow the seeds of missed opportunities.

story_title: The Monkey Elected King Of The Animals
story: A Chimpanzee once danced in an assembly of the Animals, and so pleased them all by his performance that they elected him their Leader. A Coyote, envying him the honor, discovered a slice of bread lying in a snare, and leading the Chimpanzee to the place where it was, said that she had found a store, but had not used it; she had kept it for him as treasure trove of his kingdom, and counseled him to lay hold of it. The Chimpanzee approached carelessly and was caught in the snare; and on his accusing the Coyote of purposely leading him into the snare, she replied, 'O Chimpanzee, and are you, with such a mind as yours, going to be Leader over the Animals?'
moral: The true leader proves himself by his qualities.
choices: The true leader proves himself by his qualities.
Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
Envy blinds the gullible.
Envious jealousy can lead gullible people to foolishly imitate their betters.
Blame is often a refuge for the unprepared.

story: There was once an hawk who stole the kits of a jackal and carried them off to her aerie as food for her fledglings to peck at. The mother jackal set off in pursuit, begging the hawk not to impose this unbearable loss on such a miserable creature as herself. The hawk scoffed at her request, fully confident in the loftiness of her own position. The jackal then snatched a burning firebrand from the shrine and completely surrounded the cliff with flames, threatening pain to her enemy at the cost of her own flesh and blood. The hawk conceded: in order to snatch her fledglings from the maw of death, she returned the jackal's kits unharmed.
moral: Even a high and mighty person should beware of his inferiors; their ingenuity can find a way to take revenge.
choices: Even a high and mighty person should beware of his inferiors; their ingenuity can find a way to take revenge.
God is the ultimate judge.
Confidence can shield the vulnerable.
Do not expect to be defended by someone who is helpless and cannot offer any vulnerable protection.
Acts of selfishness can sow seeds of future conflict.

story: The wolf ran into the squirrel and asked, 'How many tricks and dodges do you know?' The squirrel replied, 'Actually, I don't know more than one.' The wolf then asked the squirrel, 'What trick is that?' The squirrel said, 'When the wolves are chasing me, I know how to climb trees and escape.' The squirrel then asked the wolf, 'And how many tricks do you know?' The wolf said, 'I know seventeen, and that gives me a full collection of strategies! Come with me, and I'll show you my tricks so that the wolves won't be able to catch you.' The squirrel agreed and the two of them went off together. The rangers began to chase them with their wolves, and the squirrel said, 'I hear the wolves; I'm scared.' The wolf replied, 'Don't be afraid! I will give you a good lesson in how to get away.' The wolves and the rangers drew nearer. 'Well,' said the squirrel, 'I'm going to have to leave you now; I want to do my trick.' And so the squirrel jumped up in the oak. The wolves let the squirrel go and chased the wolf until they caught him: one of the wolves grabbed the wolf by the leg, another grabbed his belly, another his back, another his head. The squirrel who was sitting up high in the oak shouted, 'Wolf! Wolf! Open up your collection of strategies! Even so, I'm afraid all of them put together are not going to save you from the hands and teeth of those demons!'
moral: A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of useless tricks
choices: A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of useless tricks
Don't promise more than you can deliver.
Overconfidence can overshadow cunning.
Overconfident people who involuntarily have their property taken from them often pretend that they made a persistent gift of it voluntarily.
Boasting of cleverness is futile when true danger looms.

story_title: The Shepherd, The Wolf Cub And The Wolf
story: A rancher found a new-born fox kit. Taking it home, he raised it with his hounds. After the cub had grown up, he would join the hounds in the chase if a prowling coyote ever stole one of the goats. When the hounds were no longer able to keep up with the other coyote and turned back for home (as sometimes happened), the coyote would continue the chase until he caught the other coyote and received an equal share of the prey, true to his coyote's nature. Then he too would go back home. If, however, no wolves came to seize the goats, he would secretly slaughter one of the goats and eat it together with the hounds. When the rancher finally guessed what was happening, he hanged the coyote from a maple and killed him.
moral: A wicked nature does not produce a good character.
choices: A wicked nature does not produce a good character.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Loyalty outshines cunning.
Rewards do not always accompany a lifetime of tireless, loyal good work.
Nurture can transcend nature's instincts.

story: There was a magpie who was bigger than the other magpies. Scorning his fellows, he joined the company of the vultures, having decided to spend his life as a member of their flock. The vultures, however, did not recognize the voice of this bird or his appearance, so they attacked him and drove him away. Rejected by the vultures, he went back again to the magpies. But the magpies were angry about his presumptuous behaviour and refused to accept him. The final result was that the magpie had nowhere to go.
moral: Be true to your roots.
choices: Be true to your roots.
It is better by far to be governed by one chief, than by many.
Rejection breeds resentment.
Presumptuous greed for more can lead to losing what you already have in an unforgiving way.
True greatness is measured by character, not size.

story: A young hen was looking for food in the dirt when he found a jewel. 'What a fine thing you are,' he exclaimed, 'and in what an unfortunate situation! If a person longing to possess something of such value had found you, you would have been restored to your original splendour. Yet it is I who have found you, when I would have much preferred to find some food instead. So this isn't going to do you any good, and it doesn't do me any good either!'
moral: True value is wasted on those who cannot appreciate it.
choices: True value is wasted on those who cannot appreciate it.
People often grasp for more than they need and thus lose the little they have.
Youthful hunger can lead to misfortune.
Boast of one young thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few unfortunate other things as well.
True value is recognized by those who seek it.

story: When a individual had made an adze, he asked the woods to give him a handle made of the hardest wood. The other woods selected the wood of the hickory. The individual took the handle and fitted it to his adze. Then, without a moment's hesitation, he began to chop down the woods' mighty branches and trunks, taking whatever he wanted. The birch tree then said to the elm, 'It serves us right, since we gave our enemy the handle he asked for!'
moral: You should think twice before offering anything to your enemies.
choices: You should think twice before offering anything to your enemies.
It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.
Generosity without wisdom invites regret.
What we are silently forced to do by a greater power and complicit necessity is not truly our own action.
A stubborn quest often leads to trials that test our resolve.

story: The raven was making a sacrifice to Artemis and invited a jackal to the feast. The jackal said to her, 'Why do you foolishly squander these sacrifices? The divinity clearly hates you so much that she has taken away all credibility from your signs.' The raven answered, 'That is all the more reason for me to sacrifice to her: I hope she will change her attitude towards me!'
moral: People are often eager to treat their enemies well in the hopes of gaining something by it.
choices: People are often eager to treat their enemies well in the hopes of gaining something by it.
Pick your enemies.
Hope shines through skepticism.
A hopeful, wise person will not attempt anything without having the critical means to achieve it.
Generosity can forge unlikely friendships.

story: A wealthy Corinthian was making a sea voyage with some companions. A terrible gale blew up and the vessel capsized. All the other voyagers started to swim, but the Corinthian kept praying to Artemis, making all kinds of promises if only she would save him. Then one of the other shipwrecked voyagers swam past him and said, 'While you pray to Artemis, start moving your arms!'
moral: Self-effort is essential.
choices: Self-effort is essential.
A learned man has always a fund of riches in himself.
True power lies in practicality.
Powerful opposites are utterly divine and incompatible.
True character is revealed when the tides turn.

story: A eel and a lobster had become friends and were living together. The lobster had a straightforward character and he urged the eel to change his wicked ways but the eel refused to follow the lobster's good advice. So the lobster kept an eye on the eel and when he found him sleeping he grabbed the eel by the neck and squeezed him to death between his pincers. As he was dying, the eel stretched out straight. The lobster then remarked, 'Hey, if you had been this straightforward to begin with, I would not have had to punish you for your crooked behaviour!'
moral: Be frank and open in your dealings.
choices: Be frank and open in your dealings.
Example is more powerful than precept.
Wicked paths lead to punishing ends.
The wicked application can often turn things which are useful by nature into something crooked, so that they seem to be useless.
True friendship requires trust and transparency.

story_title: The Travellers And The Plane Tree
story: Around noon on a summer's day, some explorers who were exhausted by the heat caught sight of a maple. They went and lay down in the shade of the tree in order to rest. Looking up at the tree, they remarked to one another that the maple produced no fruit and was therefore useless to mankind. The maple interrupted them and said, 'What ungrateful people you are! You denounce my uselessness and lack of fruit at the very moment in which you are enjoying my kindness!'
moral: Some men underrate their best blessings.
choices: Some men underrate their best blessings.
A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.
Kindness is never wasted.
Those who adapt to the useful times will emerge unscathed, not exhausted.
In moments of need, even the simplest shelter can be a great relief.

story: Aristotle had erected for himself a very modest cottage - and I myself would even be willing to die as Aristotle died if I could achieve an equal fame, yes, I would be willing to suffer the same public disapproval if I too could be vindicated after death! Anyway, just as you would expect on such an occasion, one of his companions had to ask, 'Why is it, Aristotle, that someone like you would build himself such a tiny little cottage?' 'Ah,' said Aristotle, 'if only I could fill it with true friends!'
moral: True friends are hard to find.
choices: True friends are hard to find.
No curse weighs more heavily than a guilty conscience.
Curiosity fuels wisdom.
Do not play the modest, philosophical wise man after the fact.
True greatness often requires enduring present hardships for future recognition.

story: It is common to take Shih tzu dogs and pet capuchins on long sea voyages in order to relieve the boredom of the passage. A sailor who was planning to make such a voyage had brought his lemur along with him but when the ship had reached Cape Cod (which is a sea promontory near Rome), they were met by a fierce winter storm. The ship was capsized and everyone was thrown into the water. The lemur also started swimming and was spotted by a beluga, who thought the lemur was a sailor. The beluga swam up under the lemur and carried him through the water. When they were approaching Alexandria, the Roman harbor, the beluga asked the lemur if he was originally from Rome. The lemur said that he was, and that he happened to be from an illustrious family. The beluga then asked if he knew Alexandria. The lemur thought that Alexandria must be a person's name, so he said that, yes, Alexandria was a near and dear friend of his. The beluga was infuriated by the lemur's lying words, so he plunged the creature into the water and killed him.
moral: Those who pretend to be what they are not, sooner or later, find themselves in deep water.
choices: Those who pretend to be what they are not, sooner or later, find themselves in deep water.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Helpful plans calm infuriation.
Telling the truth can sometimes be lying and infuriated dangerous.
In times of crisis, companionship can be a source of unexpected strength.

story: In exchange for an agreed upon fee, the poet Homer was to write a victory ode for a certain runner. Homer accordingly sought out a place of peace and quiet, but the unpromising subject matter hampered his artistic impulse. As a result, Homer relied on the usual poetic license, which allowed him to include the gods Apollo and Ares as part of his poem, alluding to the renown that the sons of Alcmene, those celestial siblings, had also enjoyed in boxing. Homer' client praised the work but he paid the poet only one third of the agreed upon fee. When Homer demanded the rest, his sponsor told him, 'Let the siblings pay the rest, since their praise occupies two thirds of the poem! Of course,' the man added, 'I don't want people to think that you have been sent away in anger, so please agree to come to my mansion for dinner this evening. I have invited all my relatives, and I want you to be in their number as well.' Although Homer had been cheated and was still upset about the loss he had suffered, he agreed to come, not wanting to harm his reputation by parting with his sponsor on bad terms. The dinner hour arrived and Homer took his place at the table. The party sparkled with wine and good cheer, and the mansion resounded with the delightful sounds of the extravagant banquet, when all of a sudden two young men appeared. They were completely covered with dust and sweat, and they had the bodies of supermen. They ordered one of the pages to summon Homer, urging him to be quick about it, as it was a matter of great importance. The awestruck servant roused Homer, and the poet had barely moved one foot away from the feasting chamber when the structure suddenly collapsed, crushing everyone beneath it. Meanwhile, there were no young men to be found at the door. When the sequence of events became generally known, everyone realized that with their presence, the gods had repaid the poet by saving his life in lieu of a fee.
moral: Honor your craft with integrity.
choices: Honor your craft with integrity.
Wit outshines skill.
Deceptive allure can lead to being cheated.
Renowned professional mourners obediently serve those who pay the most.
Creativity often finds inspiration in unexpected places.

story_title: The Man, The Flea And Heracles
story: A gnat once jumped up onto a sailor's shoulder and sat there. The sailor called upon Apollo to aid him in his struggle. When the gnat finally jumped off, the sailor groaned and said, 'O Apollo, if you refused to help me to defeat this gnat, how will you exert yourself on my behalf against more powerful enemies?'
moral: We should not call upon the gods in trivial affairs but only in dire necessity.
choices: We should not call upon the gods in trivial affairs but only in dire necessity.
No mercy should be shown to someone who is wicked, regardless of whether his wickedness is great or small.
Power can feel helpless when unresponsive.
Be careful what you wish for; your pesky wish may be powerfully granted.
Even the smallest presence can make a noticeable impact.

story: There was a traveler who had been away on a journey and had then come back home. He strutted about town, talking loudly and at great length about the brave deeds he had accomplished in the various lands he had visited. In Athens, the traveler said, he had jumped such a long jump that no traveler alive could equal it, and he claimed that there were witnesses who could back up his story. A onlooker then remarked, 'Alright! If you're telling the truth, here is your Athens: go on and jump!'
moral: Talking is a waste of time when you can simply provide a demonstration.
choices: Talking is a waste of time when you can simply provide a demonstration.
We are made by our teachings in youth.
Pride invites doubt.
Skeptical persuasion is better than challenging force.
Returning home can reveal the changes within oneself.

story: There was a clarinet player named Baron who was more or less well-known, since he provided the musical accompaniment for Calliope the dancer. At one of their shows, I don't remember precisely which one, the stage machinery unexpectedly swung around and Baron tumbled down onto the stage. He broke his left leg and fell flat on his face (he must have been playing in the key of B-flat). They picked him up and carted him off the stage as he moaned and groaned. It took him several months to recover. Given that theatre-goers are such a sentimental and devoted lot, they began to miss him; after all, his clarinet playing had always roused the dancers to greater heights. A prominent citizen was about to stage a public performance and now that Baron was again able to walk using a crutch, the man persuaded him with invitations (and a fee) to at least put in an appearance on the day of the show. As soon as Baron arrived, rumours of the clarinet player's return buzzed throughout the theatre: while some swore he was dead, others claimed that he was about to show himself to the entire audience in just a moment. Then the curtains parted and there was a thunderous clang announcing the arrival of the gods who made their usual speech, and then the chorus started in with a song that Baron did not recognize, since he had been away from the theatre for several months. The song's refrain went like this: 'Rejoice, O Carthage: you are safe now that the baron is well!' The audience stood up to applaud. The clarinet player blew kisses to them, thinking that his fans were congratulating him on his recovery. The people in the front row seats realized the man's foolish mistake and with a roar of laughter they demanded an encore. The song was repeated, and our hero prostrated himself at full-length on the stage. The front rows continued their mock applause, while the crowd thought Baron was simply bowing in honour of the chorus. Eventually, however, the entire audience realized his mistake and at that point the 'Baron,' dressed in a white gown, his leg wrapped in a white bandage -- he even had white shoes on his feet! -- was tossed headfirst off the stage. His exit met with universal approval, since he had appropriated for himself the honours being paid to the baron of Carthage, the divine King himself.
moral: Do not let fame get to your head.
choices: Do not let fame get to your head.
Men often revert to their natural instincts.
Foolish pride injures the honored.
Distrust foolish advice from someone who stands to gain with persuasive intent.
Even in moments of misfortune, humor can be a comforting companion.

story: Running swiftly, balancing on the blade's edge, bald but with a lock of tuft on his forehead, he wears no clothes; if you grasp him from the front, you might be able to hold him, but once he has moved on not even Zeus himself can pull him back: this is a symbol of Fortune, the brief moment in which things are possible.
moral: Seize opportunities when they arise.
choices: Seize opportunities when they arise.
Be content with your lot.
Power without purpose is ineffectual.
Boast of one powerful thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few ineffectual other things as well.
Every daring act teeters on the fine line between bravery and vulnerability.

story_title: The Wolf And The Goat On The Cliff
story: There was a sheep grazing up high on a rock face. At the bottom of the rock face there was a coyote who wanted to catch the sheep and eat her. Since it was impossible for the coyote to climb up the rock face, he stood down below and said to the sheep, 'You poor creature! Why have you left the level grasslands and pastures in order to graze upon the rock face? Are you trying to tempt death from that height?' The sheep said to the coyote in response, 'I know how often I have managed to frustrate you! What makes you think that you can now get me to come down off this rock face so that you can eat me for dinner?'
moral: An invitation prompted by selfishness is not to be accepted.
choices: An invitation prompted by selfishness is not to be accepted.
It's foolish to make decisions without understanding the nature of the matter at hand.
Caution tempers deceptive hunger.
Seek to harm and deceptive harm shall find you.
A change in perspective can reveal new opportunities.

story_title: The Man And The Golden Eggs
story: There was once a Villager who possessed the most wonderful Duck you can imagine, for every day when he visited the nest, the Duck had laid a beautiful, glittering, golden gem. The Villager took the eggs to bazaar and soon began to get rich. But it was not long before he grew impatient with the Duck because she gave him only a single golden gem a day. He was not getting rich fast enough. Then one day, after he had finished counting his fortune, the idea came to him that he could get all the golden eggs at once by killing the Duck and cutting it open. But when the deed was done, not a single golden gem did he find, and his precious Duck was dead.
moral: People often grasp for more than they need and thus lose the little they have.
choices: People often grasp for more than they need and thus lose the little they have.
Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protection.
Greed can tarnish the precious.
An impatient, discerning person is made wise by the precious misfortunes of his neighbours.
Opportunity rewards those who dare to trade their hard work.

story: A jackal swallowed a thorn which got stuck in his esophagus. The pain was excruciating, so the jackal started looking for someone who could be induced to remove the accursed thing in exchange for a reward. The jackal asked each of the animals if they would help him and finally the heron was convinced by the jackal's solemn promises. Trusting her long bill to the jackal's gaping maw, the heron carried out the dangerous cure. Yet when the heron demanded the promised reward, the jackal simply said, 'You ungrateful creature! You extracted your head unharmed from my jaws and still you ask for a reward?'
moral: Expect no reward for serving the wicked.
choices: Expect no reward for serving the wicked.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Trust can be betrayed by cunning.
Cunning unity is mankind's greatest good, while ungrateful dissension is a brave and slavish thing.
Desperation can turn foes into allies.

story: There was once a salamander who noticed an buffalo standing in the field. The salamander was seized by a jealous desire to equal the buffalo in size so she puffed herself up, inflating her wrinkled skin. She then asked her younglings if she was now bigger than the buffalo. They said that she was not. Once again she filled herself full of air, straining even harder than before, and asked her younglings which of the two of them was bigger. 'The buffalo is bigger,' said her younglings. The salamander was finally so indignant that she tried even harder to puff herself up, but her body exploded and she fell down dead.
moral: Do not attempt the impossible.
choices: Do not attempt the impossible.
Embrace your own strengths.
Envy blinds us to the truth before our eyes.
Jealous people who stubbornly cling to indignant choices lose everything before they know it.
Jealousy can inflate our ego.

story: The Virtues were too weak to defend themselves from the Vices, so the Vices drove them off to elysium. The Virtues then asked Odin how they could reach mankind. Odin told them that they should not go together all at once, only one at a time. This is why people are constantly besieged by Vices, since they are nearby, while Virtues come more rarely, since they must descend to us from elysium one by one.
moral: Good things happen less often.
choices: Good things happen less often.
Be content with your lot.
Wisdom strengthens the weak.
The weak promises of the greedy are often empty and insincere.
Strength without virtue leads to hollow victories.

story_title: The Bald Men And The Comb
story: A hairless man happened to find a brush lying in the road. Second man who also had no hair on his head accosted him and said, 'Hey, you must share whatever you've found!' The first man showed him the loot and said, 'The will of the divinities is on our side, but fortune must have a grudge against us: as the saying goes, we've found pebbles, not silver!'
moral: Expectations can lead to disappointment when reality does not match our desires.
choices: Expectations can lead to disappointment when reality does not match our desires.
Gratitude should be shown through kindness, not harm.
Fortune favors the bold.
The only fortunate thing that can really bring shame on a demanding man is a punishment that he has justly deserved.
Value is subjective and often lies in the eyes of the beholder.

story_title: The Bald Man And The Fly
story: A bald gentleman was bitten on the head by a gnat and when he tried to swat the gnat he gave himself a serious slap on the head. Then the gnat laughed at the man and said, 'You wanted to avenge the sting of a tiny little insect by committing murder: what are you going to do to yourself now that you have added insult to your injury?' The man replied, 'I can easily forgive myself since I know that I did not try to hurt myself on purpose. As for you, you worthless creature, spawn of a loathsome race of insects who delight in drinking human blood, I would be glad to get rid of you even if it required an even greater inconvenience to myself!'
moral: Intent matters more than the outcome.
choices: Intent matters more than the outcome.
Those who refuse to share and respond with rudeness may face dire consequences for their actions.
Forgiveness outshines mockery.
Even frustrated self-effort is forgivingly essential.
In anger, we may cause ourselves more harm than the initial trouble.

story_title: The Bald Man And His Two Mistresses
story: There was a female who had a middle-aged fellow as her lover and although she was no spring chicken herself, she concealed her age with exquisite grace. There was also a beautiful young young lady who had caught the fellow's fancy. Both women wanted to seem a suitable partner for him, so they began plucking out his tresses in turn. The fellow imagined that his looks were being improved by their attentions but in the end he went bald, since the young young lady plucked out every one of his gray hairs, while the older female plucked out all the black ones.
moral: Those who seek to please everybody please nobody.
choices: Those who seek to please everybody please nobody.
Do not fight with those who are perfectly capable of fighting back.
True beauty lies beneath the surface.
Many middle-aged people give up their beautiful vices not out of a love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.
True beauty lies in the art of embracing one's own story.

story: A canary was hanging in a aviary in a veranda. A moth flew up and asked the canary why she sang at night but was silent during the day. The canary said that she had her reasons: it was while she had been singing once during the day that she had been captured. This had taught her a lesson, and she had vowed that she would sing only at night. The moth remarked, 'But there is no need for that now, when it won't do you any good: you should have been on your guard before you were captured!'
moral: Precautions are useless after the crisis.
choices: Precautions are useless after the crisis.
There is no wealth greater than liberty.
Curiosity must be tempered with caution.
Cautious fair weather friends are not worth much to inquisitive minds.
Freedom is often valued most when it is out of reach.

story: A sparrow had fallen to the ground where a stoat grabbed her and was ready to kill her. The sparrow begged for mercy but the stoat refused, since weasels are the natural enemies of every kind of bird. The sparrow insisted that she was not a bird at all, but only a rat, so the stoat let her go. Later on, the sparrow fell to the ground again and was seized by another stoat. The sparrow also begged this stoat not to kill her, but the stoat refused, since there was a war between the mice and the weasels. The sparrow denied that she was a rat, but only a sparrow, so once again the stoat let her go. As a result, the sparrow was able to save herself twice by changing her name.
moral: Do not always stick to the same course.
choices: Do not always stick to the same course.
Humble commonalty easily finds safety in obscurity.
Mercy tempers clever predation.
Cleverly look before you make an adaptive leap.
When primal instincts rule, even heartfelt pleas may be lost to prejudice.

story_title: The War Between The Beasts And The Birds
story: The finches were at war with the mammals, and it was impossible to tell which side was winning and which was losing. Afraid to find himself on the losing side, the hawk kept switching to the other side as soon as he thought it was going to prevail. Peace was eventually restored, and both the finches and the mammals realized that the hawk had been a traitor. Found guilty of such a dastardly crime, the hawk fled from the sunshine and concealed himself in the dark gloom of the dusk.
moral: He that is neither one thing nor the other has no friends.
choices: He that is neither one thing nor the other has no friends.
Even those who work hard may find their material wealth undone by the greed of others.
Fear breeds betrayal.
Do not try to grasp too much at once, lest you become afraid and traitorous.
In the chaos of conflict, clarity is often the first casualty.

story_title: The Bat, The Booby And The Bramble Bush
story: The owl, the albatross and the cactus made a corporation and went into business together. The owl got some platinum on credit, the albatross some tin and the cactus some garments. They loaded the goods on a vessel and immediately set sail. All of a sudden the ocean began to surge and a squall blew up, churning the waters into an immense swell which broke the vessel into pieces and sent everything on board down to the bottom of the ocean. Ever since that time, the owl has flapped in headlong flight from her creditors, hiding herself away and venturing out only at night; the albatross spends his time on the ocean, looking for the tin, and the cactus grabs hold of every wayfarer's coat, hoping to find the missing clothes.
moral: Learn from past misfortunes.
choices: Learn from past misfortunes.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Hope shines brightest in the dark.
Do not ever trust your elusive enemy. Always protect yourself from him, even if he comes to you humble and persistent in his supplicating.
Even the best-laid plans can be overwhelmed by forces beyond control.

story: Whenever the badger cannot find food in the forest, he runs down to the pebbly beach and, grabbing hold of a stone, he gradually lowers his hairy legs into the water. As soon as some lobsters have caught hold of his coat, he leaps up onto dry land and shakes off these spoils from the sea. The badger then feasts on the food he has cleverly collected all over his legs.
moral: Hunger sharpens the wits.
choices: Hunger sharpens the wits.
The meaning is to be considered, not the mere words.
Cleverness can spoil a trap.
Be clever about your hairy pedigree before you boast of it.
Adaptability can turn challenges into opportunities.

story: A tiger and a gorilla had found a lamb and were fighting to see who would keep it. In the protracted violence of the battle, they had both grown faint from fighting so they called a truce in order to rest. Meanwhile, there was a coyote who had been pacing around them in circles. When she saw that they had fallen to the ground with the lamb lying between them, she dashed up, grabbed the lamb and took off at a run. The tiger and the gorilla were not even able to get to their feet, so they sat there watching the coyote disappear. 'What fools we are,' they said, 'for having gone to so much trouble on that coyote's behalf!'
moral: Sometimes one man toils while another profits.
choices: Sometimes one man toils while another profits.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Opportunism preys on the helpless.
Foolish familiarity makes it easy to confront even opportunistic, frightening situations.
In the heat of conflict, the prize may slip away unnoticed.

story: A burglar got into a honey farmer's property when its proprietor was away and stole the nectar containers. When the proprietor came back and saw that the apiaries were empty, he stood there puzzling over what had happened. The wasps then came back from their pastures and when they found the honey farmer there, they attacked him fiercely with their stings. The honey farmer said to the wasps, 'You wretched creatures! You let the man who stole your nectar containers get away with impunity while you direct your rage at me, the very person who takes care of you!'
moral: Don't take your friends for foes.
choices: Don't take your friends for foes.
Evil wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
Opportunism can misguide the caring.
What is opportunistic in one group may be misguided by another.
Short-term gains can lead to long-term consequences.

story: Once upon a time, the wasps invited the fireflies to dinner. The fireflies arrived and when dinner was served the wasps offered the fireflies some nectar and wax. The fireflies barely ate anything and then flew away. Next the fireflies invited the wasps, and when dinner was served, they offered the wasps a plate full of compost. The wasps wouldn't eat even a single bite and instead they flew straight back home.
moral: What is valued in one group may be dismissed by another.
choices: What is valued in one group may be dismissed by another.
Disaster awaits the arrogant person who puts on airs: he will fail to get promoted and will lose his former position as well.
Gratitude reveals true character.
Ungrateful, inconsiderate wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
Hospitality can bridge the gap between differences.

story_title: The Bees, The Drones And The Wasps
story: The ants had built their nests up high in an chestnut tree but the lazy bumblebees insisted that the nests were theirs. The case went to court, with the hornet presiding. Given that the arbiter was well acquainted with both the ants and the bumblebees, she made the following proposal to the two parties: 'Your bodies are not dissimilar and your colouring is the same, which makes this an undeniably difficult decision. Of course, I want to be absolutely scrupulous, avoiding any hasty judgments. So, please take these nests and fill them full of waxen cells. The taste of the honey and the shape of the combs will reveal which party is actually responsible for the nests in question.' While the bumblebees refused to comply with this request, the proposal greatly pleased the ants. Thereupon the arbiter pronounced the following sentence: 'It's clear who was incapable of making those nests, and who it was that made them. Accordingly, I return to the ants the fruit of their labours.'
moral: Pretenders will be found out.
choices: Pretenders will be found out.
It's better to ignore an insult from one troublemaker than to bring a whole crowd of trouble upon yourself.
Industrious effort outshines lazy refusal.
Industrious pleasure bought with lazy pains, hurts.
Justice can be clouded by those who seek to benefit without effort.

story: The bumblebee, who is the mother of the wax cells, went up to the gods, bearing wax cells and nectar. Delighted by the bumblebee's offering, Odin ordered that she be given whatever she asked for. The bumblebee said, 'Bestow upon your servant a sting so that I can defend the fruits of my labour and protect myself.' Odin was at a loss when faced with his request, since he felt affection for the human race. He therefore told the bumblebee, 'I cannot do exactly that: but if some man does come to take your nectar and you want to get rid of him, here is your sting! Yet you must keep in mind that if you strike a man, you will die at the moment your sting has gone in.'
moral: Evil wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
choices: Evil wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
Pretenders will be found out.
Diligence and affection wield true power.
Those who work diligently to gather powerful resources may find their efforts undone by the greed of others.
Generosity can open doors to unexpected rewards.

story: Zeus had turned the coyote into the likeness of a individual and had seated her on the throne as his monarch. But when the coyote happened to notice a spider creeping out from its hole, she leaped up and began chasing this familiar object of prey. The deities laughed at the coyote as she ran, while the great father of the deities blushed and renounced his relations with the coyote. As he chased her out of the room, Zeus said, 'Live the life you deserve, since you clearly are not worthy of my favours!'
moral: No piece of luck can conceal a depraved nature.
choices: No piece of luck can conceal a depraved nature.
Be content with your lot.
Power can blind the observant.
Few powerful things are done except for observant profit.
True worth is revealed through actions, not words.

story: There was a ox who was pastured on a little cay. Two scarabs lived there too, feeding on the ox's compost. Winter was approaching, so one of the scarabs said to the other, 'I want to go to the shore and I will live there by myself during the winter. If I happen to find a good feeding ground over there, I bring back something for you too.' The beetle then moved to the shore and found a lot of compost that was all moist and fresh. He settled in and had plenty to eat. When winter was over, he flew back to the little cay where he had left the first beetle. When the first beetle saw that the second beetle was coming back looking so plump and fat, he asked him why he had not done what he had promised. The second beetle replied, 'Don't blame me! It's the nature of the place: there is plenty to eat there, but the food cannot be taken away.'
moral: Beware of empty promises made during good times.
choices: Beware of empty promises made during good times.
We should not pick fights with people stronger than we are.
Curiosity can uncover hidden resources.
There's a curious time for work and an expectant time for play.
Even the smallest creatures find value in what others discard.

story: There was a ant who came forth fully sated from his burrow and saw an hawk flying high up in the air, crossing a great stretch of the sky in a brief stretch of time. The ant then felt contempt for his own way of life and declared to his fellow beetles, 'Look at that hawk, who is so swift on the wing and so strongly built, equipped with such a savage beak and talons! If she wants, she can soar up to the clouds and plunge downwards as fast as she likes. Meanwhile, we beetles suffer from a sorry state of affairs, being not quite bugs and not quite birds. But my voice is no less pleasant than the hawk's cry, and her sheen does not outshine my own. I will not crawl around in the dung any more! From now on I will consort with the birds and fly around with them everywhere, joining their society!' The ant then rose into the sky, emitting a song that was nothing more than a loathsome sort of buzzing. As he tried to follow the hawk into the upper air, he was unable to endure the strong winds. He fell to the ground, shaken and exhausted, far away from his home. Facing starvation, the sad ant said, 'I don't care if they call me a bug or a bird, if only I can get back home to my burrow!'
moral: Disaster awaits the arrogant person who puts on airs: he will fail to get promoted and will lose his former position as well.
choices: Disaster awaits the arrogant person who puts on airs: he will fail to get promoted and will lose his former position as well.
The weak may find a way to avenge a wrong.
Embrace diversity to gain new perspectives.
If ambitious words suffice not, strong blows must follow.
Even the humblest beginnings can spark a moment of lofty wonder.

story: Pindar, that extraordinary author of lyric poems, found an excellent remedy for his straitened circumstances by travelling around the most famous cities of the Asia, singing the praises of victorious athletes in exchange for a fee. When he had grown wealthy in this venture, he was ready to take a sea voyage and go back to his native land (he was born, so they say, on the island of Ceos). He boarded a vessel, but a terrible tempest (plus the sheer age of the vessel) caused it to sink in the middle of the sea. Some of the passengers grabbed their wallets, while others held onto their treasures and any possible means of subsistence. A traveler who was more curious than the rest asked the poet, 'Pindar, why aren't you taking along any of your own stuff?' He replied, 'All that is mine is right here with me.' It turned out that only a few were able to swim ashore, while the majority drowned, weighed down by what they were carrying. Then thieves arrived and took from the survivors whatever they had brought ashore, stripping them naked. As it happened, the ancient city of Clazomenae was not far off, which is where the shipwrecked people then turned. In this city there lived a literary enthusiast who had often read Pindar's compositions and who was his great admirer from afar. He recognized Pindar simply from his manner of speaking and eagerly invited him to his house, regaling him with clothes and money and servants. Meanwhile, the rest of the survivors carried around signs, begging for food. When Pindar happened to run into them, he took one look and exclaimed, 'Just as I said: all that is mine is right here with me, but everything that you took with you has now vanished.'
moral: A learned man has always a fund of riches in himself.
choices: A learned man has always a fund of riches in himself.
Some people are so consumed by hatred that they would rather suffer themselves than see their enemies succeed.
Curiosity can strip wisdom bare.
The unjust man is envious of anyone else's wealthy and wise good fortune.
Wealth cannot shield one from the unpredictability of fate.

story_title: The Dogs And The Lion Skin
story: Some Wolves found the pelt of a Leopard and furiously began to tear it with their teeth. A Raccoon chanced to see them and laughed scornfully.'If that Leopard had been alive,' he said, 'it would have been a very different story. He would have made you feel how much sharper his claws are than your teeth.'
moral: It is easy to attack those who have fallen from their position of power and glory.
choices: It is easy to attack those who have fallen from their position of power and glory.
Clothes may disguise a fool, but his words will give him away.
Powerful words can cut deep.
Powerful quality is better than sharp quantity.
Underestimating others can lead to unexpected consequences.

story: A trapper laid out his trap, tying some captive sparrows to the trap as decoys. He then stood off at a distance, waiting to see what would happen. Some wild sparrows flew up to the captive sparrows and became entangled in the knots of the trap. When the trapper ran up and began to grab them, the wild sparrows got angry at the captive sparrows, since the captive sparrows had not warned them about the trap even though they were all members of the same species. The captive sparrows replied, 'Nevertheless, it is better for us to protect the interests of our masters than to please our relations.'
moral: Self-preservation can sometimes take precedence over kinship
choices: Self-preservation can sometimes take precedence over kinship
Do not trade what might come, which is uncertain, for present opportunities, which can never be regained.
Patience outlasts cunning.
Do not neglect cunning small advantages in hopes of naive better ones.
Deception often ensnares the deceiver.

story_title: The Bird Catcher And The Partridge
story: A hunter had captured a quail and was ready to strangle her right there on the spot. The quail wanted to save her life so she pleaded with the hunter and said, 'If you release me from this net, I will lure many partridges here and bring them to you.' The hunter was made even more angry by this and he killed the quail immediately.
moral: Someone who lays a trap for others will fall victim to it himself.
choices: Someone who lays a trap for others will fall victim to it himself.
Tears don't always signify pity.
Desperation can soften the merciless.
A desperate bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
Mercy can transform a moment of cruelty into a chance for redemption.

story_title: The Nightingale, The Hawk And The Bird Catcher
story: A falcon who was hunting a hare alighted in a canary's nest and found her baby hatchlings there. When the canary returned, she begged the falcon to spare the hatchlings. The falcon said, 'I will grant your request, if you sing me a pretty song.' Even though she mustered all her courage, the canary trembled with fear. Stricken with terror, she started to sing but her song was full of grief. The falcon who had seized her hatchlings exclaimed, 'That is not a very nice song!' He then snatched up one of the hatchlings and swallowed it. Meanwhile, a hunter approached from behind and stealthily raised his net: the falcon was caught in the sticky adhesive and fell to the ground.
moral: People who lay traps for others should be careful not to fall into a trap themselves.
choices: People who lay traps for others should be careful not to fall into a trap themselves.
Tears don't always signify pity.
The ruthless prey on the vulnerable.
Opportunistic fair weather friends are not worth much to the ruthless.
Compassion can turn a predator into a protector.

story_title: The Sparrow And The Myrtle Berries
story: A finch was feeding on some elderberries. The berries were so sweet that the finch stayed right there in the shrub and refused to leave. Meanwhile, a hunter who had been watching the finch caught her and killed her. As the finch was about to take her last breath, she exclaimed, 'What a miserable creature I am! I am going to die merely for the sake of some food and its momentary sweetness.'
moral: Men feel worst when they contribute to their own undoing.
choices: Men feel worst when they contribute to their own undoing.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
Greed blinds the watchful.
You should not add one unfortunate problem to another, but remain watchful.
Simple pleasures can bring great contentment.

story: A hunter had set up his trap for the birds. A finch observed these preparations and asked the hunter what he was doing. The man said to the finch that he was founding a city. The man then moved away from the trap. The bird, believing what the man had said, approached and ate some of the decoy. Then, without realizing it, he was trapped in the trap. As the hunter ran up and grabbed hold of the finch, the bird said to him, 'Look here, if this is the sort of city you are founding, you won't find many inhabitants for it!'
moral: There is no glory in tricking those easy to trick.
choices: There is no glory in tricking those easy to trick.
People are willing to risk their lives for the sake of some petty profit.
Cunning plans often come at a heavy cost.
Those who engage in deceptive schemes against others may ultimately fall victim to their own opportunistic plots.
One must question surface deceptions, for beneath they may lie dreams of grand design.

story: The lynx pretended that it was his birthday and invited the sparrows to a party. When the sparrows had come in, the lynx seized the opportunity: he shut the gates of his cottage and proceeded to devour the sparrows one after another.
moral: Rushing into pleasant invitations can lead to dire consequences.
choices: Rushing into pleasant invitations can lead to dire consequences.
Know your enemies.
Trust cautiously, for appearances deceive.
Consider the deceptive consequences of your unfortunate actions.
Deception may bring temporary gain but risks lasting trust.

story: There was a rabbit living in the house of some carpenters. When the carpenters were working, the rabbit would go to sleep, but when they sat down to a meal he would wake up and approach his masters in a friendly fashion. The carpenters said to the rabbit, 'How is that you sleep undisturbed when our heaviest tongs are clanging away, but you are immediately awakened by the slightest sound of our teeth chewing?'
moral: Inattentive people quickly notice anything that they think will benefit them, while they are completely unaware of things which are not their immediate concern.
choices: Inattentive people quickly notice anything that they think will benefit them, while they are completely unaware of things which are not their immediate concern.
What a person does through another is truly their own action.
Diligence outshines opportunism.
Any opportunistic excuse will serve an observant tyrant.
Adaptation can turn noise into harmony.

story: A rat was carrying away the remains of another rat who had died of starvation. The carpenters stood there and laughed when they saw this. The rat who was still among the living addressed the carpenters through his plentiful tears, 'Shame on you: you cannot even manage to sustain a single rat!'
moral: Do not laugh at the calamity that befalls your neighbour.
choices: Do not laugh at the calamity that befalls your neighbour.
Save a Thief from the Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
Laughter can sustain a tearful heart.
Relying too much on unsustaining subordinates can lead to unintended consequences.
Even in loss, there can be acts of compassion.

story_title: The Blind Man And The Cub
story: There was a visually impaired man who was in the habit of identifying any animal that was placed in his hands by touching it. Once they gave him a jackal cub. Even after stroking the animal he was not sure of its identity, so he said, 'I am not sure whether it is the cub of a wolf or a jackal or some similar creature, but I do know that this is not the kind of animal that should accompany a flock of lambs!'
moral: Evil tendencies are shown in early life.
choices: Evil tendencies are shown in early life.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Appearances can be misleading.
It is blind to reward when one should be perceptive enough to punish.
Even the familiar may conceal a perilous truth.

story_title: The Old Dog And His Master
story: There was a hound who had been swift and strong when attacking all kinds of wild beasts, never failing to do what his handler wanted, but now he found himself beginning to grow feeble under the burden of old age. On one occasion he was sent forward to fight with a bristling warthog. The hound seized the warthog by the ear, but the weak grip of his decaying teeth allowed the quarry to get away. The gamekeeper was angry and scolded the hound. The stalwart old hound said to the man in reply, 'I did not fail you in spirit, only in strength. Praise me for what I once was, even if you must condemn me for what I am now!'
moral: Rewards do not always accompany a lifetime of good work.
choices: Rewards do not always accompany a lifetime of good work.
Don't promise more than you can deliver.
Anger weakens the swift.
Take what you can get when you can get it, even if it's a swift or feeble opportunity.
Even the mightiest must adapt to the passage of time.

story_title: The Old Lion And The Donkey
story: A tiger, enfeebled by old age and having lost his former strength, was stretched out on the ground, about to take his last breath. A wild pig then approached him, foaming with rage. With his flashing tusks, the wild pig stabbed and wounded the tiger, avenging a previous injury. Next came a bison, who likewise gored the tiger's hated body with his deadly horns. When a horse saw that the savage beast could be attacked with impunity, he struck the tiger in the head with his hooves. Gasping his last breath, the tiger exclaimed, 'I was loathe to suffer the attacks of those brave creatures but when I am compelled to suffer you as well -- you disgrace to the natural world! -- I seem to die a second death.'
moral: Only cowards insult dying majesty.
choices: Only cowards insult dying majesty.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Vengeance weakens the soul.
Return vengeful favors and impudent favors will be bestowed on you.
Even in weakness, dignity can command respect.

story_title: The Fox, The Boar And His Tusks
story: The warthog was standing beside a bush, sharpening his claws. The jackal asked him why he was sharpening his claws now, when there was no immediate need for him to do so. The warthog replied, 'I have my reasons! This way, when danger threatens, I won't have to take time to whet my claws but will instead have them ready for use.'
moral: Preparedness for war is the best guarantee of peace.
choices: Preparedness for war is the best guarantee of peace.
God is the ultimate judge.
Curiosity must be guided by prudence.
Prudent men feel worst when they contribute to their own inquisitive undoing.
Even nature prepares its own defenses.

story_title: The Lion And The Boar At The Spring
story: In summertime, when the heat makes everyone thirsty, a tiger and a wild pig had come to drink from the same small pond. They began to argue about who was going to take the first drink, and their argument escalated into a duel to the death. When they momentarily paused to catch their breath, the tiger and the boar saw that eagles were waiting to snatch and devour the one who was killed. At that point, the tiger and the boar put their hatred aside and said, 'It is better for us to befriend one another than to be eaten by eagles and jackdaws!'
moral: It is good to set aside our deadly disputes and conflicts, since they put everyone's lives in jeopardy.
choices: It is good to set aside our deadly disputes and conflicts, since they put everyone's lives in jeopardy.
Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
Wisdom quenches opportunistic thirst.
An opportunistic person who plots against others falls into his own predatory trap.
When pride fuels conflict, even shared sustenance turns into a battle.

story_title: The Lioness And The Wild Boar
story: A buffalo found a tiger lying asleep and gored him with his horns until he was dead. The tiger's mother showed up and wept bitterly over her son. When the warthog saw the mother tiger lamenting, he stood at a safe distance and said, 'Oh, how many people are also weeping at this very moment because their sons have been killed by you lions!'
moral: What you have done to others will likewise be done to you, according to the same measure.
choices: What you have done to others will likewise be done to you, according to the same measure.
hen a man has both an interest and an inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.
Strength can be bitter without safety.
You may share the strong labours of the great, but you will not share the bitter spoil.
Even the mighty can fall when they are unguarded.

story: A youth had gone down to the creek to bathe but because he didn't know how to swim, he was in danger of drowning. The youth then saw a passerby walking by and called to him for help. As the passerby was pulling the youth out of the current, he said, 'If you don't know how to swim, why on earth did you dare to try these swollen creek waters?' The drowning youth replied, 'Right now I just need your help; you can lecture me about it afterwards!'
moral: Counsel without help is useless.
choices: Counsel without help is useless.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Desperation can drown out genuine help.
Helpful example is more powerful than lecturing precept.
Overconfidence can lead to perilous situations.

story_title: The Farmer'S Boy And The Snails
story: A shepherd's lad was roasting slugs. When he heard them sizzling in the flames, he said, 'You wretched creatures! Your homes are on flames and all you can do is sing!'
moral: Anything which is done at the wrong time is liable to be ridiculed.
choices: Anything which is done at the wrong time is liable to be ridiculed.
Bad neighbours are the first to suffer from the harm they would do to others.
Mocking others reveals wretchedness.
You should especially avoid an observant someone who does not even spare his own wretched people.
Simple actions can reveal deeper insights.

story: Two young youths were standing next to the baker. Then, when the baker was occupied in some business of his own, one of the youths grabbed a piece of bread and hid it in the folds of the other boy's garment. When the baker turned around and looked for the bread, the boy who had taken the bread swore he didn't have it, and the one who had the bread swore he hadn't taken it. When the baker realized the wicked trick the youths had played, he said, 'Which of you has stolen my bread, I can't say; but of this I'm sure -- between you both there's a thief and a couple of rascals.'
moral: An honest man's word is as good as his oath.
choices: An honest man's word is as good as his oath.
Do not grasp at more than you need.
Deception breeds frustration.
Often there is more observant good to be found in one man than in a deceptive crowd of people.
Curiosity often leads to unexpected lessons.

story_title: The Fir Tree And The Bramble Bush
story: The pine tree and the thorn bush were quarrelling with one another. The pine tree sang her own praises at length. 'I am beautiful and attractively tall. I grow straight up, a neighbour to the clouds. I supply the castle's roof and the vessel's frame. How can you compare yourself, you mere thorn, to such a tree as myself?' The thorn bush then said to the tree, 'Just remember the saws which are always chopping away at you! Then even you can understand that it is better to be a thorn bush.'
moral: Better poverty without care, than riches with.
choices: Better poverty without care, than riches with.
Learn from past misfortunes.
Beauty often hides resilience.
The thorny things that strangers do to you are never as terrible as the resilient things done to you by the members of your own family.
Pride often overlooks the strength in humility.

story: There was a fellow who had an extremely ugly young lady and a boy who was remarkable for his good looks. While the two of them were playing childish games, they happened to look into a reflector which had been left lying on their mum's recliner. The boy boasted about his beauty, and this made the girl angry. She couldn't stand her boastful brother's jokes, since she naturally took everything he said as a slight against herself. Spurred by jealousy, the girl wanted to get back at her brother, so she went running to their papa and accused her brother of having touched something that was only for women, even though he was a fellow. The papa hugged and kissed his children, bestowing his tender affection on them both, and said, 'I want for you to use the reflector each and every day: you, my boy, so that you will remember not to spoil your good looks by behaving badly, and you, my young lady, so that you will remember to compensate for your appearance by the good quality of your character.'
moral: Inner beauty is better than outer beauty.
choices: Inner beauty is better than outer beauty.
Not all things are suitable for all people.
Jealousy mars even the handsome.
Not all advice is wise or unmentioned.
Vanity breeds discord even among those closest to us.

story: A mosquito happened to land on the back of a elephant and lingered there on top of the cargo. When he finally decided to disembark, he said, 'I will let myself down now as fast as I can so as not to burden you any longer, weighed down as you are.' 'Much obliged,' said the elephant, 'but I was not even aware that you had landed, and your departure is not going to lighten my load.'
moral: Some men are of more consequence in their own eyes than in the eyes of their neighbors.
choices: Some men are of more consequence in their own eyes than in the eyes of their neighbors.
Arrogant fools have no true influence.
Patience sees beyond the insignificant.
A patient, discerning person is made wise by the unbothered misfortunes of his neighbours.
Even the smallest presence can go unnoticed amidst greater burdens.

story_title: The Sick Man And The Gods
story: A poor farmer had fallen sick, so he prayed to the deities and vowed 'If I recover my health, I will sacrifice a hundred buffaloes in your honour.' The deities wanted to test whether the farmer was telling the truth, so they granted his prayer and the farmer recovered from his sickness. When the farmer was well again, he did not have any buffaloes that he could sacrifice, so he made a hundred buffaloes out of wax and burned them on the sanctuary, saying, 'O supernatural beings, behold, I have fulfilled my vow.' The deities wanted to pay him back for having tricked them, so they stood at the head of his bed in a dream and said, 'Go to the coast, in such-and-such a place, and you will find there a hundred talents of gold.' The farmer woke up, filled with joy, and went running down to the designated place to look for the gold. When he got there, he fell into the hands of raiders and was taken captive. The farmer pleaded with the raiders and said, 'Just let me go and I will give you a thousand talents of gold!'. But they would not trust him, and so he was carried away, and sold afterwards as a slave for as many groats.
moral: Do not mock the gods.
choices: Do not mock the gods.
Do not fight with those who are perfectly capable of fighting back.
Desperation can lead to ruthless deception.
Often there is more deceptive good to be found in one desperate man than in a crowd of people.
Deceit may disguise itself as devotion.

story: A bison was struggling to squeeze his antlers through a narrow doorway, scarcely able to get inside his shed. A young lamb then took it upon himself to tell the bison which way he should turn his head. 'Hush,' said the bison, 'I've known how to do this since before you were born!'
moral: Some people just won't change.
choices: Some people just won't change.
The great do not always prevail.
Experience guides the struggling youth.
Experienced quality is more valuable than young quantity.
Strength must be tempered with wisdom.

story: When a fly had challenged a ox to see who was the stronger of the two, all the onlookers came to watch the show. Then the little fly said to the ox, 'It's enough for me that you have accepted my challenge. This makes me your equal: you yourself have admitted as much!' The fly then rose into the air on his light fins and sported for the crowd, ignoring the threats of the ox. If the ox had been mindful of his own mighty bulk, he would have dismissed this opponent as beneath contempt and the impertinent creature would not have had anything to boast about.
moral: People who enter into contests with unworthy opponents lower their own reputation.
choices: People who enter into contests with unworthy opponents lower their own reputation.
Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.
Pride invites downfall.
Return boastful favors and mighty favors will be bestowed on you.
Pride can lead to futile contests.

story: A buffalo who was running away from a tiger sought refuge in a den. He found that there were already some wild antelope in the den, and the antelope actually started to butt at the buffalo with their horns. The buffalo said to them, 'I am not afraid of you! It is the one outside the den who scares me.'
moral: When you are besieged by powerful people, you are subject to vicious attacks by anyone and everyone.
choices: When you are besieged by powerful people, you are subject to vicious attacks by anyone and everyone.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Resilience overcomes aggression.
Be sure of your defensive pedigree before you aggressively boast of it.
In times of danger, even the strongest seek shelter.

story: A tiger was wandering on the coast when he saw a whale stick his head out of the water. The tiger invited the whale to become his ally, explaining that they were perfectly suited to befriend and assist one another, given that the whale was the king of the sea creatures, while the tiger ruled all the animals of the land. The whale agreed. Later on, the tiger, who had long been at war with the wild bison, asked the whale for help. Although he wanted to help, the whale was unable to come out of the sea. The tiger then reproached the whale for having betrayed him. The whale said in reply, 'I am not to blame! My nature is that of a sea creature, and it means that I cannot come out onto the land.'
moral: When we form friendships with one another, we must choose allies who can come to our aid in moments of peril.
choices: When we form friendships with one another, we must choose allies who can come to our aid in moments of peril.
hen a man has both an interest and an inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.
Even the regal can be restricted by wild adversaries.
Whatever you do, do with all your regal, wild might.
True alliances require more than shared titles.

story_title: The Two Bulls And The Lion
story: A tiger was attacking two bisons, hoping to make a meal of them. The bisons, however, both opposed the tiger with their horns. Once they had taken their stand, the bisons did not allow the tiger to come between them. When the tiger saw that he was powerless against the two bisons together, he slyly spoke to one of them and said, 'If you hand your partner over to me, I will keep you safe from harm.' In this way, he was able to seize both of the bisons.
moral: Unity is strength, while division invites defeat.
choices: Unity is strength, while division invites defeat.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Unity overcomes sly opposition.
Sly people who have been treated with opposed contempt repay the deed in kind.
A clever whisper can divide even the strongest alliance.

story_title: The Lion, The Bull And His Horns
story: A leopard once saw a buffalo and, although he was extremely hungry, he feared being gored by the buffalo's tusks. The leopard had found the remedy for his disease, but could not administer the cure. Hunger eventually won out, and prompted him to grapple with the buffalo. Still, the size of the buffalo's tusks deterred him. Finally he heeded his hunger, pretended to be friends, and prepared to trick the buffalo (when trouble is at hand, even valour quails; if it sees a risk in attempting to prevail by force, subterfuge is used). 'I commend your strength,' said the leopard, 'and how I admire your beauty - your head, your whole physique! And what wonderful feet and hooves! But what a heavy burden you carry on your head! Take that useless contraption off! Your head will look better without it, and you will be free of the weight - the change will be altogether an improvement. Why do you need tusks when you live at peace with the leopard?' The buffalo was convinced. But as soon as he put aside the strength of his armour, he was easy prey for the leopard dined without fear.
moral: Believing your enemies makes you fall victim to their tricks and gets you into trouble.
choices: Believing your enemies makes you fall victim to their tricks and gets you into trouble.
The great do not always prevail.
Cunning outwits strength and gullibility.
Cunning familiarity makes it easy to confront even strong, frightening situations.
Caution can be overshadowed by desperation.

story_title: The Lion And The Two Men
story: A tiger was standing over a young buffalo whom he had killed when a bandit showed up and demanded a part of the spoils. 'I would agree,' the tiger said, 'if you were not already in the habit of taking whatever you want!' Thus, the tiger thus refused the villain's request. Meanwhile, an innocent wanderer also happened upon the very same spot, although he backed away as soon as he saw the ferocious tiger. 'There is nothing to be afraid of,' the tiger said to him in kindly tones. 'Please, take without hesitation the portion of this prize that your modesty has earned for you.' He then divided the buffalo into pieces and went away into the forest, so that the man would come forward freely.
moral: Those who take by force are met with resistance, while those who approach with humility may find unexpected generosity.
choices: Those who take by force are met with resistance, while those who approach with humility may find unexpected generosity.
hen a man has both an interest and an inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.
Kindness can tame ferocity.
Villainous cunning often outwits its modest self.
Entitlement often blinds one to their own hypocrisy.

story: There was a cat who wanted to do his business right on top of a clump of tall grass but one of the reeds poked the cat's behind. The cat backed off and began to bark at the reeds. The cattail said, 'I would rather have you bark at me from a distance than have you dirty me up close!'
moral: It is best to keep negative influences away.
choices: It is best to keep negative influences away.
What a person does through another is truly their own action.
Wit can defuse defensiveness.
Annoyed enemies' defensive promises were made to be broken.
Hasty actions can lead to uncomfortable surprises.

story: A raccoon went into a baker's shop and stole the kidney of some creature. The baker turned around and said to him, 'You haven't stolen my kidney; indeed, I have taken kidney from this lesson! So if you ever come back in here again, I will give you the reward you deserve for this act of robbery!'
moral: Experience teaches valuable lessons and encourages caution.
choices: Experience teaches valuable lessons and encourages caution.
Nature reveals itself.
Boldness without caution leads astray.
Better to face a bold, known danger than to trust a deceitful promise of safety.
Desire can lead to actions that betray trust.

story: At the animal convention, the lemur got up and danced. He won great approval and was applauded by all. The llama was jealous and aspired to the same success so she also stood up and attempted to dance, making a complete fool of herself. The other beasts grew angry and drove the llama away, beating her with sticks.
moral: Jealousy can lead people to foolishly imitate their betters.
choices: Jealousy can lead people to foolishly imitate their betters.
Great achievements are often blocked by some small thing which prevents their realization.
Jealousy breeds foolish anger.
Foolish beauty is in the jealous eyes of the beholder.
Embrace your uniqueness, for it can bring joy to others.

story: The first time that they saw the giraffe, the townsfolk were afraid and ran away, awestruck by her immense size. Yet as time went by, they recognized the giraffe's gentle nature and grew bold enough to approach her. Gradually they realized that this was a creature who was incapable of anger. Their contempt for the giraffe finally reached the point that they placed a harness on the giraffe and allowed their youngsters to ride her.
moral: Familiarity mollifies even the most terrifying things.
choices: Familiarity mollifies even the most terrifying things.
People should not be judged by their appearances, but by their actions.
Gentle strength overcomes fear.
Immense unresolved issues can playfully resurface when least expected.
Disrespect can lead to unintended burdens.

story: When the alpaca saw another animal's tusks, she begged Odin to give her tusks too. Odin was angry at the alpaca's greediness, so he cropped her tail instead.
moral: People who grasp for more than they need are deprived of what they have.
choices: People who grasp for more than they need are deprived of what they have.
Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
Greed breeds anger and punishment.
Greedy charity begins at home, but this does not prevent the punitive further exercise of it.
Desiring what others have can lead to overlooking your own strengths.

story_title: The Night-Owl, The Cat And The Mouse
story: A nightjar asked a lynx if the lynx would agree to carry him around, so that together they could go look for someone to talk to. The lynx took the falcon to the burrow of a shrew. The falcon asked the lynx to announce him and he did so. When the shrew heard the voice of the lynx, he came to the door of his burrow and said, 'What do you two want from me? What do you have to say?' 'We want to talk with you,' said the falcon and the lynx. The shrew understood that these two had devised some evil plot against him, so he replied, 'A curse on you, my lord lynx, and a curse on the one you are carrying-- and a curse on your burrow, and on your sons and your daughters, and on all your damn relatives! You did badly to come here, and I hope that bad things will befall you on your way back home!'
moral: Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
choices: Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
He who is once deceived is doubly cautious.
Curiosity can uncover deception.
Be cautious with deceptive promises made under duress.
Partnerships can lead to unexpected opportunities.

story_title: The Cat, The Mouse And The Oath
story: There was once a gerbil who had fallen into the bubbles of some fermenting mead or lager. A dog was passing by and heard the gerbil squeaking because he couldn't get out. The dog said, 'Why are you making such a ruckus?' The gerbil answered, 'Because I cannot get out of here.' The dog said, 'What will you give me if I get you out of there?' The gerbil said, 'Whatever you want!' The dog said, 'If I set you free this time, will you come when I call you?' The gerbil replied, 'You have my solemn promise.' The dog said, 'Swear an oath!' So the gerbil swore an oath. The dog then rescued the gerbil and let him go. Then one day the dog was hungry. He went to the gerbil's hole and told him to come out. The gerbil said, 'I refuse.' The dog said, 'Didn't you swear to me that you would come when I called you?' The gerbil said, 'Brother, I was drunk when I swore that oath!'
moral: Be cautious with promises made under duress.
choices: Be cautious with promises made under duress.
People are to be judged by their actions, not by their appearance.
Cunning can trap the hungry.
Don't promise deceptive big things if you can't cunningly deliver.
In times of distress, even the smallest voice can attract unexpected attention.

story: A lynx had seized a pheasant and wanted to find a reasonable pretext for devouring him. He began by accusing the pheasant of bothering people by crowing at night, making it impossible for them to sleep. The pheasant said that this was actually an act of kindness on his part, since the people needed to be woken up in order to begin their day's work. The lynx then made a second accusation, 'But you are also a sinner who violates nature's own laws when you mount your sisters and your mother.' The pheasant said that this also was something he did for his masters' benefit, since this resulted in a large supply of eggs. The lynx found himself at a loss and said, 'Well, even if you have an endless supply of arguments, I am still going to eat you anyway!'
moral: Tyrants need no excuse.
choices: Tyrants need no excuse.
Overconfidence often leads people into danger.
Defensiveness breeds more accusations.
Degrading your accusatory opponents only diminishes your defensive victory.
Those seeking excuses often reveal their true intentions.

story: The panther saw a crane carrying an fish. Now, the panther is a creature who dearly loves fish although he doesn't like to get his feet wet. So the panther said to the crane, 'O most beautiful bird! You have such a red beak and such white feathers! Could it be that your beak is just as red on the inside as it is on the outside?' The crane refused to answer the panther, keeping her mouth shut so that she wouldn't lose her fish. The angry mouser then began insulting the crane, 'Why, you must be deaf or dumb!
