Why don't you answer me, you wretched creature? You do eat snakes sometimes, don't you? Snakes are poisonous and filthy! A nice animal likes to eat nice things, but you like to eat filthy things that are not nice at all! That means you are the most filthy bird in the world!' The crane didn't say anything, and just kept on walking, carrying her fish.
moral: Stay focused on your goals.
choices: Stay focused on your goals.
Do not fear death, as it is the final goodbye to all the troubles, pains, and dangers of life.
Beauty can mask cunning intentions.
Don't be seduced by cunning, deceptive words, they will cause nothing but beautiful trouble.
Flattery often masks hidden intentions.

story_title: The Eagle, The Sow And The Cat
story: An hawk had made her nest up high in an maple tree; meanwhile, in a hollow halfway up the tree, a raccoon had given birth to cubs; finally, at the foot of the tree there was a forest-dwelling doe and her litter of lambs. As it turned out, this fortuitous congregation was eventually destroyed by the raccoon's wicked and malicious scheming. First, she went to the hawk's nest and said, 'You are about to be destroyed, and so am I! Woe is me! You can see for yourself how the treacherous doe keeps digging in the dirt day after day: she plans to uproot the tree so that she will be able to attack our offspring down there on the ground.' After having scared the hawk out of her wits with these words, the raccoon then crept down to the den of the bristly doe. 'Your litter is in grave danger,' said the raccoon, 'because the hawk is ready to seize your little lambs as soon as you go out to look for food.' Having filled the houses of both the hawk and the doe with terror, the sneaky creature hid herself safely inside her hollow in the tree. She crept out at night on tiptoe, finding plenty of food for herself and her cubs, but during the day she only poked her nose out of her den, pretending to be afraid. Meanwhile, the hawk didn't stir from the branches since she expected some disaster and the wild doe would not venture out of doors, since she wanted to protect her home from the hawk's attack. To make a long story short: the doe and the hawk both died of hunger, together with their children, thus supplying the raccoon and her cubs with a bountiful feast.
moral: Gossips are to be seen and not heard.
choices: Gossips are to be seen and not heard.
Quality is more valuable than quantity.
Protect the innocent from the wicked.
Live your innocent lives in the protective clothes that suit you.
Deceit born in the shadows can shatter even the safest havens.

story: There was a certain fellow who had some bread in his cupboard. Then a rat came and began to gnaw at the bread. The fellow did not know what to do. Finally he put a dog in the cupboard but the dog ate both the rat and the bread.
moral: Relying too much on subordinates can lead to unintended consequences.
choices: Relying too much on subordinates can lead to unintended consequences.
People are to be judged by their actions, not by their appearance.
Greed blinds the helpless.
Beware of when the powerful and the sneaky, predatory deceitful collaborate.
Guard your treasures, for even the smallest can attract the greatest attention.

story_title: The Fox And The Goat In The Well
story: A jackal had unwittingly fallen down a cistern and found herself trapped inside its high walls. Meanwhile, a thirsty sheep had made his way to that same place and asked the jackal whether the stream was fresh and plentiful. The jackal set about laying her trap. 'Come down, my friend,' said the jackal. 'The stream is so good that I cannot get enough of it myself!' The bearded billy-sheep lowered himself into the cistern, whereupon that little vixen leaped up on his lofty antlers and emerged from the hole, leaving the sheep stuck inside the watery prison.
moral: Look before you leap.
choices: Look before you leap.
True friends are hard to come by.
Cunning often preys on the naive.
No one is so cunning or naive that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
In desperation, even the clever can become the deceived.

story: The coyote is said to have started it by inviting the crane to dinner and serving a liquid stew on a granite slab which the hungry crane could not so much as taste. The crane, in turn, invited the coyote to dinner and served a narrow-mouthed pitcher filled with crumbled food. The crane was able to thrust her beak inside and eat as much as she wanted, while her guest was tormented with hunger. As the coyote was licking the neck of the pitcher in vain, the crane is supposed to have said, 'When others follow your example, you have to grin and bear it.'
moral: One bad turn deserves another.
choices: One bad turn deserves another.
Expect no reward for serving the wicked.
Cunning plans often backfire.
A cunning and mild disposition can put a stop to vindictive behaviour.
Thoughtless hospitality can breed resentment.

story_title: The Lion And The Man Disputing
story: A fellow and a tiger were arguing about who was best, with each one seeking evidence in support of his claim. They came to a statue on which a fellow was shown in the act of strangling a tiger, and the fellow offered this picture as evidence. The tiger then replied, 'It was a fellow who painted this; if a tiger had painted it, you would instead see a tiger strangling a fellow. But let's look at some real evidence instead.' The tiger then brought the fellow to the coliseum and showed him so he could see with his own eyes just how a tiger strangles a fellow. The tiger then concluded, 'A pretty picture is not proof: facts are the only real evidence!'
moral: When the evidence is fairly weighed, a colourfully painted lie is quickly refuted by the facts.
choices: When the evidence is fairly weighed, a colourfully painted lie is quickly refuted by the facts.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
Reason alone cannot overcome determined rhetoric.
Take observant warning from the logical misfortunes of others.
In debating superiority, both may miss the true value of humility.

story: A rattlesnake entered a farrier's workshop and bit the grater, testing it to see if this was something she could eat. The grater protested fiercely, 'You fool! Why are you trying to wound me with your teeth, when I am able to gnaw through every sort of iron?'
moral: It is useless attacking the insensible.
choices: It is useless attacking the insensible.
When you need someone to lend a hand, mere words are no help at all.
Curiosity without wisdom invites folly.
Foolish injuries may be forgiven, but not indignant forgotten.
Boasting of strength invites unnecessary challenges.

story_title: The Charcoal Burner And The Fuller
story: A chimney sweep who lived in a certain hut decided it would be a good idea to live together with a launderer who had moved in next door. But the launderer told him, 'How on earth would I be able to carry on with my work? I am afraid that whatever I washed white, you would cover with soot!'
moral: Opposites are utterly incompatible.
choices: Opposites are utterly incompatible.
Appearances can be deceiving.
Caution cleans inconsiderate actions.
Clean honesty is the best cautious policy.
Shared spaces require shared understanding.

story_title: The Two Men, The Eagle And The Fox
story: An falcon was once caught by a individual who immediately clipped his wings and turned him loose in the house with the geese. The falcon was utterly dejected and grief-stricken. Another individual bought the falcon and restored the falcon's feathers. The falcon then soared on his outspread wings and seized a squirrel, which he promptly brought back as a gift for the individual who had rescued him. A coyote saw what the falcon was doing and shouted, 'He's not the one who needs your attention! You should give the squirrel to the first individual, so that if he ever catches you again, he won't deprive you of your wing feathers like the first time.'
moral: Favor those who do you kindness.
choices: Favor those who do you kindness.
Count the cost before you commit yourselves.
Kindness can restore the dejected.
Unfortunate pride goes before careless destruction.
Stripping one's freedom can diminish their spirit.

story: A cricket was singing on top of a tall maple. The jackal wanted to eat the cricket, so she came up with a trick. She stood in front of the maple and marvelled at the cricket's beautiful song. The jackal then asked the cricket to come down and show himself, since the jackal wanted to see how such a tiny creature could be endowed with such a sonorous voice. But the cricket saw through the jackal's trick. He tore a twig from the maple and let it fall to the ground. Thinking it was the cricket, the jackal pounced and the cricket then said, 'Hey, you must be crazy to think I would come down from here! I've been on my guard against foxes ever since I saw the wings of a cricket in the spoor of a jackal.'
moral: A discerning person is made wise by the misfortunes of his neighbours.
choices: A discerning person is made wise by the misfortunes of his neighbours.
God is the ultimate judge.
Clever trickery breeds deception.
Cautious fear of the future can lead to clever actions that bring about the very fate we seek to avoid.
Cunning plans often reveal true intentions.

story: A cricket saw that a trapper was trying to capture him, so he said, 'Why don't you go and hunt those finches instead? They would actually be useful to you! You don't stand to gain anything by catching me.'
moral: Do not go chasing after things that are useless and unprofitable.
choices: Do not go chasing after things that are useless and unprofitable.
A wise person readily tolerates the insolence of strangers when he sees those same strangers mistreating one another.
Determination without wisdom leads astray.
Persuasive big talkers are not suited for unwise trust, business, or conversation.
Distraction can be a clever defense.

story: An hawk was caught by a gardener but the gardener let him go when he realized what he had caught. The hawk did not forget this good deed, and when he saw the gardener sitting under a barrier that was on the verge of collapsing, he snatched the hat from the man's head, wanting to rouse the man from his seat and make him stand up. After the man set off in pursuit, the kindly hawk dropped what he had snatched and thus fully repaid the man's good deed: the man would have been crushed by the barrier's collapse if he had stayed there any longer. After a while the man came back to where he had been sitting and found that the upright section of the barrier had fallen to the ground.
moral: Those who do you a favour you must repay kind.
choices: Those who do you a favour you must repay kind.
True worth should be measured by character and deeds, not by outward appearances.
Gratitude reveals hidden fortune.
Do not neglect grateful small advantages in hopes of perceptive better ones.
Recognizing the value of freedom can lead to acts of kindness.

story_title: The Monkey And The Lion's Breath
story: When the panther made himself king of the beasts, he wanted to be known for his fairness, so he gave up his old habits and contented himself with a limited diet just as the other animals did, committed to dispensing justice with complete honesty. As time went by, however, the panther's resolution began to waver. Since he was not able to alter his natural inclinations, he began to take certain animals aside in private and ask them whether or not his breath smelled bad. It was a clever strategy: the animals who said that it smelled bad and the animals who said it did not were all killed just the same and the panther was thus able to satisfy his appetite. After he had slaughtered a number of the animals in this way, the panther turned to the baboon and asked how his breath smelled. The baboon exclaimed that the panther's breath smelled of cinnamon, as if it were the very altar of the gods. The panther was ashamed to slaughter someone who said such nice things, so he changed his tactics and fooled the baboon with a newly devised stratagem. The panther pretended that he was sick. The healers came right away, of course, and when they checked the panther's veins and found that his pulse was normal, they ordered him to eat some food that would be light on his stomach, thus alleviating his nausea. 'Kings may eat what they like,' admitted the panther. 'And I've never tried baboon meat... I would like to have a taste of that.' No sooner said than done: the obsequious baboon was quickly killed so that the panther could eat him immediately.
moral: The penalty for speaking and for keeping silent is one and the same.
choices: The penalty for speaking and for keeping silent is one and the same.
Do not neglect the loyalty of old friends to please new acquaintances.
Flattery can mask ruthless intentions.
Cunning fine clothes may disguise, but flattering silly words will disclose a fool.
True leadership is forged in integrity, as even the mighty must adapt to serve justice fairly.

story_title: The City Mouse And The Country Mouse
story: A metropolitan mouse once happened to pay a visit to the house of a rural mouse where he was served a humble meal of nuts. The metropolitan mouse finished his business in the country and by means of insistent invitations he persuaded the rural mouse to come pay him a visit. The metropolitan mouse then brought the rural mouse into a room that was overflowing with food. As they were feasting on various delicacies, a steward opened the door. The metropolitan mouse quickly concealed himself in a familiar burrow, but the poor rural mouse was not acquainted with the house and frantically scurried around the floor tiles, frightened out of his wits. When the steward had taken what he needed, he closed the door behind him. The metropolitan mouse then urged the rural mouse to sit back down to dinner. The rural mouse refused and said, 'How could I possibly do that? Oh, how scared I am! Do you think that the man is going to come back?' This was all that the terrified mouse was able to say. The metropolitan mouse insisted, 'My dear fellow, you could never find such delicious food as this anywhere else in the world.' 'Nuts are enough for me,' the rural mouse maintained, 'so long as I am secure in my freedom!'
moral: It is better to live in self-sufficient poverty than to be tormented by the worries of wealth.
choices: It is better to live in self-sufficient poverty than to be tormented by the worries of wealth.
Consider the consequences of your actions.
Familiarity can ease the unfamiliar.
Save a familiar Thief from the humble Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
A persuasive invitation to abundance can open doors to experiences beyond one's familiar world.

story_title: The Clown, The Farmer And The Pig
story: There was a certain affluent gentleman, a prominent inhabitant, who was about to sponsor a public entertainment. He invited anyone who had some novelty to perform, promising to pay them a fee. Professional performers came to compete for public acclaim, and among them was a comedian who was well known for his sophisticated sense of humour. He said that he had a type of spectacle that had never been performed in any auditorium before. The rumour spread throughout the city, sparking the public's interest. Auditorium seats that had recently been left empty were now not enough for the gathering crowd. After the comedian came out by himself on the stage, with no equipment and no assistants, a hush of anticipation silenced the spectators. Then the comedian suddenly lowered his head towards his chest and imitated the sound of a little hog. The sound was so true to life that the audience maintained that there must be a real little hog concealed under his mantle and they demanded that it be shaken out. But when the mantle was shaken out, it proved to be empty, so they lavished the comedian with praise and he left the stage to resounding applause. A rustic fellow saw what had happened and said, 'By gosh, I can do better than that!' He immediately promised that he would do the same thing, only better, the following day. The crowd grew still larger and favouritism had already swayed their perception; you could tell that they had not come to watch the performance so much as to make fun of it. The two men came out onto the stage. The comedian squealed as he had done the day before, provoking the audience's applause and shouts of approval. Now it was the turn of the rustic fellow, who pretended to conceal a little hog beneath his clothes -- and this time there really was a hidden hog, although of course the audience had not found anything under the comedian's mantle at the previous performance. The man then pulled the ear of the real hog that was hidden in his clothes, producing an authentic squeal of pain. The audience shouted that the comedian had given a far more realistic performance and they were prepared to drive the rustic fellow off the stage. But he then pulled the actual hog from inside his mantle and showed it to the audience, denouncing their gross error with incontrovertible evidence. 'Here you go!' he said. 'This little hog proves what kind of judges you are!'
moral: Men will stand behind a judgment made in error until the actual fact of the matter later compels them to regret their choice.
choices: Men will stand behind a judgment made in error until the actual fact of the matter later compels them to regret their choice.
True friends are hard to come by.
True wealth lies in authenticity.
Do not try to gain favor by acting in a sophisticated way that is contrary to your own authentic nature and character.
True innovation often lies in the unexpected.

story: Jupiter ordered Thoth to instill a dose of deceit in every smith. With a muller and bowl, Thoth ground the elixir into a fine powder and after dividing it into equal portions he began to apply it to each of the craftsmen. In the end, only the shoemaker was left and a great deal of the elixir was still left over, so Thoth poured the entire contents of the bowl onto the shoemaker. As a result, all craftsmen are liars, but cobblers are the worst of all.
moral: It is natural to be a knave; men must rise above.
choices: It is natural to be a knave; men must rise above.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
Power can be deceitful.
The deceitful promises of the greedy are often empty and dishonest.
Even the most skilled hands can be swayed by deception.

story: An untalented shoemaker had gone completely broke, so he set up shop as a healer in a city where no one knew him. By marketing an 'remedy' with a fictitious name and making all sorts of extravagant claims, the shoemaker gained a wide reputation. When the ruler of the city had grave need of a healer, he decided to put this man to the test: he called for a cup, filled it with liquid and pretended to mix the healer's remedy together with a fatal toxin. The ruler then ordered the healer to drink the mixture, offering him a reward if he would do so. The prospect of death scared the shoemaker into confessing that he had no knowledge of medicine whatsoever and that he had in fact acquired his fame only thanks to universal gullibility. The ruler then assembled the inhabitants and said to them, 'Are you completely out of your minds? You willingly trusted this man in matters of life and death when he could not even be trusted in matters of sandals and shoes!'
moral: Beware of swindlers that exploit the foolishness of others.
choices: Beware of swindlers that exploit the foolishness of others.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Misguided pride often leads to downfall.
Hunger sharpens the wise and skeptical wits.
Adversity can inspire reinvention, even when skills fall short.

story: When a hog kept destroying a rancher's plants and trampling his fertile pastures, the rancher cut off the hog's tail. He then let the hog go, expecting that the hog would remember what had happened to him, since he carried with him a reminder of the need to treat the rancher's plants with due respect in the future. Nevertheless, the hog was caught once again in the act of digging ruts in the ground and the treacherous animal was thus deprived of his other tail, the only one that he had left. But as soon as he was let loose again, the hog plunged his deformed head into the aforementioned plants. His multiple offenses had made him a marked hog, so the rancher caught him and consigned him to his lord's sumptuous feast. The rancher sliced and served the various parts of the hog at dinner but when there was no more left, the lord asked what had happened to the hog's liver. The fact was that the greedy baker had stolen them, so the rancher calmed his lord's understandable outrage by saying that the foolish hog didn't have any liver to begin with. 'Why else would that hog have kept risking life and limb,' said the rancher, 'and let himself be caught over and over again by the same opponent?'
moral: Only fools indulge into michief and excessive risks.
choices: Only fools indulge into michief and excessive risks.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Greed and deception breed only more discord.
Sumptuous everything pleases at first, but greedy nothing pleases for long.
Punishment without understanding breeds resentment, not respect.

story_title: The Lion, The Cow, The She-Goat And The Sheep
story: A bison and a ewe and a long-suffering ram decided to become the panther's companions. They went into the jungle together and there they caught an extremely large moose which they divided into four portions. Then the panther said, 'I claim the first portion by right of my title, since I am called the king; the second portion you will give me as your partner; then, because I am strongest, the third portion is mine ... and woe betide anyone who dares to touch the fourth!' In this way the wicked panther carried off all the spoils for himself.
moral: An alliance made with the high and mighty can never be trusted.
choices: An alliance made with the high and mighty can never be trusted.
Nature reveals itself.
A submissive friend may enable wicked dominance.
Seek the companion friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering submissive help even in a dominant time of adversity.
Choosing allies wisely can determine your fate.

story_title: The Coward And The Lion Of Gold
story: There was a certain greedy timid soul who found a panther of silver and said, 'I do not know how to act in such circumstances. This is driving me crazy! I can't decide what to do: my love of money and my innate cowardice are tearing me in two. What kind of accident or supernatural power could have produced a panther of silver? My mind is at war with itself when it confronts this problem: it longs for the silver but it fears the object which the silver has been made into. My desire urges me to seize it, but my character urges me to keep away. O fortune, you have given me this thing but you do not allow it to be taken! O treasure that offers no satisfaction! O welcome gift of a god that is so unwelcome! What to do? How can I get some advantage from this? How can I contrive a means to approach it? I will go get my assistants and bring them here and order them to launch a mass attack and grab the panther, while I watch them from a distance.'
moral: Wealth is of little value if one is too afraid to use or enjoy it.
choices: Wealth is of little value if one is too afraid to use or enjoy it.
Nature reveals itself.
Greed blinds the cowardly.
It is better to serve in cowardly safety than to rule in distant peril.
Indecision is the thief of opportunity.

story: A timid soldier was leaving on his way to war. Some crows cawed at him, so he put his arms down and stood still. Then he took up his arms once more and proceeded on his way, but the crows cawed at him again. The timid soldier stopped and finally said, 'Squawk at me as long as you want: you are still not going to get a bite out of my flesh!'
moral: True courage involves overcoming fears, even when faced with intimidation.
choices: True courage involves overcoming fears, even when faced with intimidation.
Beware the sort of person who uses tricks.
Persistence overcomes indecision.
No fearful gratitude from the indecisive wicked.
Cowering in fear can render the mightiest warriors powerless.

story: A shrimp came up from out of the ocean and was looking for food on the beach. A hungry coyote saw the shrimp, ran up, and grabbed him. As he was about to be eaten, the shrimp exclaimed, 'It serves me right! I am a creature of the ocean but I wanted to live on dry beach.'
moral: Contentment with our lot is an element of happiness.
choices: Contentment with our lot is an element of happiness.
Value is what others think of you, not what you think of yourself.
Desperation can drive even the most cunning astray.
Our misplaced anticipations of life outrun its opportunistic realities.
Venturing beyond familiar shores can lead to new opportunities.

story: A heron and a magpie had made a mutual pledge of assistance, agreeing that the heron was to defend the magpie from other birds, while the magpie would use her powers of prophecy to warn the heron about future events. These two birds often went to the field of a certain man and ate the crops that he had sowed there, tearing them up by the roots. When the gardener saw what was happening to his field, he was upset, and said to his lad, 'Give me a rock.' The magpie alerted the heron, and they prudently made their escape. On another occasion, the magpie again heard the gardener asking for a rock and warned the heron so that the heron would not get hurt. After some thought, the man understood that the magpie was able to predict what was happening. He said to the lad, 'When I say, give me some loaf, I want you to give me a rock.' The gardener then went to the field and told the lad to give him some loaf, so the lad gave him a rock. The gardener threw the rock at the heron and broke both his legs. The injured heron said to the magpie, 'What has become of your god-given prophecies? Why didn't you warn me that this was going to happen?' The magpie then said to the heron, 'In this case it is not my understanding that is at fault. The counsels of wicked people are always deceptive, since they say one thing and do another!'
moral: Don't be seduced by deceptive words, they will cause nothing but trouble.
choices: Don't be seduced by deceptive words, they will cause nothing but trouble.
Do unto others what you would have them do unto you.
Prudence guards against deception.
Do no overestimate your defensive worth when your unwitting fate rests in the hands of the high and the mighty.
Mutual agreements can falter when they ignore the consequences of their actions.

story: The pheasant kept waving his golden wings back and forth while he argued with the grey-winged heron. The heron finally exclaimed, 'You may make fun of the colour of my wings, but I can rise on them up to the stars and high into the sky. You, on the other hand, can only flap those gilded wings of yours down there on the ground, just like a quail. You are never seen soaring up high in the sky!'
moral: The useful is of much more importance and value, than the ornamental.
choices: The useful is of much more importance and value, than the ornamental.
Do not boast to have something you do not.
Pride can cloud common sense.
Even a vain and proud person should beware of his capable inferiors; their ingenuity can find a way to take revenge.
Pride in appearance can overshadow the value of perspective.

story: A young child had gone far off into the prairie where he was catching locusts to put them in traps. When he noticed a tarantula in their midst, he mistook it for another cricket. The child reached down to pick the tarantula up off the ground, whereupon the tarantula pointed his sting at the child, ready to stab him, and said, 'If you had gone so far as to touch me, I would have set both you and your locusts free!'
moral: You should not treat bad people the same way that you treat good people.
choices: You should not treat bad people the same way that you treat good people.
There is no wealth greater than liberty.
Curiosity can lead to danger.
Curious respect is often better shown by refraining from defensive disrespect.
In seeking to capture freedom, one may find themselves lost.

story: A mule heard the sound of a katydid chirping and he enjoyed the sound so much that he asked, 'What kind of food gives you that sweet-sounding voice?' The katydid replied, 'My food is the wind and the mist.' The mule thought that this diet would also make him sound like a katydid, so he clamped his mouth shut, letting in only the wind and having nothing but mist for his food. In the end, he died of hunger.
moral: You must not act unnaturally, trying to achieve some impossible thing.
choices: You must not act unnaturally, trying to achieve some impossible thing.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Imitation lacks true contentment.
Do not take naive credit for the imitative accomplishments of others.
Admiration can lead to misguided assumptions.

story: Legend has it that when dogs drink from the Mississippi they do so on the run to avoid being caught by the crocodiles. So when a certain jackal started to lap some river as he ran, a caiman said, 'Drink as much as you want, take your time, don't be afraid!' The jackal then said to the caiman, 'By god, I would do just that, if I didn't already know that you have a craving for my flesh!'
moral: If you try to deceive someone who has his wits about him, you will waste your time and be made fun of as well.
choices: If you try to deceive someone who has his wits about him, you will waste your time and be made fun of as well.
He who covets what belongs to another, deservedly loses his own.
Beware those who hide their true nature.
Deceptive sympathy often masks predatory intentions.
Caution is wise, but haste can lead to oversight.

story: A person had committed a murder and was being pursued by the injured party's kin. He reached the creek Nile and when he found a tiger there, he was afraid and climbed up a sycamore; in the sycamore, he saw a viper and was practically scared to death, so he threw himself into the creek, where a alligator devoured him.
moral: Those who commit grave wrongs cannot escape justice.
choices: Those who commit grave wrongs cannot escape justice.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
Desperation can be more dangerous than fear.
Desire dangerous things you don't understand and you accept the frightening consequences.
In haste to escape fear, one may fall into greater danger.

story_title: The Birds, The Peacock And His Feathers
story: The pheasant was a remarkable bird both because of the beauty of his quills with their various colours and also because he was gentle and courteous. On his way to the assembly of the birds, the pheasant ran into the rook. The rook asked the pheasant if he would give him two of his quills. The pheasant said, 'What will you do for me in return?' The rook replied, 'I will squawk your praises throughout the courts in the presence of all the other birds!' So the pheasant gave the rook two of his quills. The magpie then made the same request of the pheasant and obtained two of the pheasant's quills, as did the nightingale and all kinds of other birds, until finally the pheasant was plucked completely bare. The pheasant was supposed to nourish and protect his hatchlings but he was unable to do so since he didn't have any quills. Winter came, and he died. His hatchlings went away and lived as best as they could on their own.
moral: Vanity can lead to self-destruction.
choices: Vanity can lead to self-destruction.
Do not boast to have something you do not.
Opportunism can overshadow courtesy.
Sorrow not over what is abandoned and lost forever, but be resilient.
True beauty shines through kindness and grace.

story: A magpie, puffed up with foolish pride, found some flamingo quills that had fallen on the ground. He picked up the quills and, putting them on, he tried to join the lovely flamingo flock, scorning his fellow jackdaws. The peacocks, however, tore the quills off that presumptuous bird and pecked at him until he went away. After having been badly mauled by the peacocks, the magpie then sadly returned to his own folk, but he was cast out once again and suffered the pain of public humiliation. One of the jackdaws whom he had originally scorned said to him, 'If you had been content to dwell among us, satisfied with what Nature had bestowed on you, then you would not have been humiliated by the peacocks, nor would your disgrace have met with our rebuff.'
moral: Live your lives in the clothes that suit you.
choices: Live your lives in the clothes that suit you.
Do not boast to have something you do not.
Pride often precedes rejection.
Prideful big talkers are not suited for aggressive trust, business, or conversation.
False pride can lead to a fall from grace.

story: Apollo wanted to test Calchas's prophetic power, so the god stole some of Calchas' sheep from the pasture. He then assumed human form and went to the village in order to pay Calchas a visit. When Calchas was told about the loss of his sheep, he took Apollo with him and they went out together to seek an sign regarding the theft. Calchas asked Apollo to tell him about any sign from the birds that he happened to see. The first sign Apollo saw was an falcon flying from the left to the right, and he reported this to Calchas. Calchas said that this didn't have anything to do with the sheep. Next, Apollo saw a raven sitting on a pine who first looked up and then looked down towards the ground. Apollo reported this observation to the soothsayer and at this point Calchas declared, 'Yes, that raven is swearing by both Heaven and Earth that I could get my sheep back... if you were willing to cooperate!'
moral: Vanity betrays every fraud.
choices: Vanity betrays every fraud.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
Foresight is wasted without discernment.
Majestic physical stature does not guarantee perceptive wisdom or intelligence.
Not all signs immediately align with our problems.

story: The pheasant came to see Athena, because he could not accept with equanimity the fact that the goddess had not given him the song of the lark. The pheasant complained that the lark's song was wondrously beautiful to every ear, while he was laughed at by everyone as soon as he made the slightest sound. Athena then consoled the pheasant and said, 'You are superior in beauty and superior in size; there is an emerald splendour that shines about your neck, and your tail is a fan filled with jewels and painted feathers.' The pheasant protested, 'What is the point of this silent beauty, if I am defeated by the sound of my own voice?' 'Your lot in life has been assigned by the decision of the Norns,' said Athena. 'You have been allotted beauty; the falcon, strength; the lark, harmony; the vulture has been assigned prophetic signs, while unfavourable omens are assigned to the jackdaw; and so each is content with his own particular gift.'
moral: Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
choices: Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
True strength lies in harmony.
Beware of unfavorable enterprizes where the mysterious risks are not equal.
Embrace your unique gifts rather than coveting those of others.

story_title: The Crow, The Eagle And The Feathers
story: There was a raven who saw that she was ugly and black, so she complained to the hawk. The hawk told her to borrow some quills from her fellow birds. The raven did as the hawk suggested, taking quills from the tail of the turkey, from the wings of the pigeon, and so on and so forth, appropriating the other birds' quills. When the raven decided that she was sufficiently well-dressed, she began to laugh at the other birds and yell at them. The other birds then went and complained to the hawk about the boastful raven. The hawk replied, 'Let every bird take back her quills, and thus humiliate the raven.' This is what they did, and so the raven was left ugly and naked.
moral: Do not boast to have something you do not.
choices: Do not boast to have something you do not.
Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
Wisdom outshines boastful authority.
Wise worth should be measured by graceful character and deeds, not by outward appearances.
True beauty is found in embracing one's own uniqueness.

story: A pigeon who lived in a certain aviary was boasting about the number of children she had given birth to. The raven heard her and said, 'Stop your bragging! The more children you have, the greater the slavery you bring into the world!'
moral: Many children are a great blessing; but a few good ones are a greater.
choices: Many children are a great blessing; but a few good ones are a greater.
Kindness is never wasted.
Humility is the path to true wisdom.
A wise and proud person will not attempt anything without having the right means to achieve it.
A crowded nest does not replace the freedom to spread one's wings.

story: The jackdaw was jealous of the hawk's power to reveal signs to mankind by means of omens, since the hawk was always being consulted to find out what was going to happen. When the jackdaw saw some explorers passing by, she flew up into a birch and perched there, squawking loudly. The men turned towards the sound in alarm, but then one of them said, 'Hey, let's go! It's just a jackdaw, whose squawking doesn't mean a thing.'
moral: Those who assume a character which does not belong to them, only make themselves ridiculous.
choices: Those who assume a character which does not belong to them, only make themselves ridiculous.
Someone who cannot manage his own affairs is not qualified to give advice to his neighbours.
Jealousy magnifies the insignificant.
Those who pretend to be what they are not, sooner or later, find themselves in jealous, dismissive deep water.
Envy blinds us to our own unique gifts.

story: An hawk carried a armadillo high up into the air but the armadillo's flesh was hidden inside a home of horn, tucked away safely inside so no harm could come to it. A raven then arrived on the scene and as she winged her way past the hawk she said, 'Well now, you have grasped an excellent prize in your talons, but unless I show you what to do with it, its weight will exhaust you to no avail.' When the hawk promised to share with the raven, the raven advised her to drop the hard carapace from the starry heights down onto the cliffs. After the carapace had been shattered, the armadillo's meat would be easily consumed. The hawk was persuaded by the raven's clever counsel and carried out the plan, generously sharing the feast with her teacher. Thus even something protected by a gift of nature was no match for these two, and the armadillo died a pitiful death.
moral: Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
choices: Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
Tricksters can outsmart the strong.
Generosity shields the clever.
It is a foolish thing to give clever, advisory advice to others while not looking out for oneself.
True value often lies beneath the surface, beyond immediate grasp.

story: The falcon was strolling beside the ocean one day, intending to go fishing. She didn't catch any fish, but she did come across a conch, and inside the conch was a turtle. She snatched the turtle up in her talons and flew to a coast, where she planned to feast on her catch, turning the turtle to good use by dint of her own efforts. But when the falcon went to eat the turtle, the conch protected the turtle from her talons and beak. Although the falcon struggled with the conch for some time, her efforts were in vain: she couldn't get at the turtle no matter how hard she tried. A raven then happened along and saw the falcon hopelessly trying to open the conch. The falcon was on the verge of giving up when the raven approached her and said, 'That is food fit for a king. By no means should it be tossed away!' 'Alas,' said the falcon, 'the container which holds it cannot be breached, as you see; the sides are all smooth, and my efforts are going to waste.' The raven then said to the falcon, 'If you will agree to divide the spoils with me, I will show you the way to open it up.' 'Tell me how!' said the falcon, 'then you and I will enjoy this feast together.' The tricky raven said, 'What you must do is fly up high in the sky. Then, when you find yourself far above some rocky shore, release the container from the grip of your talons so that it falls through the air and strikes against the cliffs. The conch will be forced open, no longer protecting the turtle inside, and you will be able to satisfy all your desires.' The falcon agreed and, following the raven's instructions, she flew up in the air and let the turtle drop from her talons. Below, the raven was there waiting for the turtle to fall. As soon as the turtle reached the ground, the raven snatched it for herself and thus deceived the hungry falcon.
moral: Tricksters can outsmart the strong.
choices: Tricksters can outsmart the strong.
Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
Deceptive tricks can leave the determined helpless.
Do not go chasing after tricky things that are deceptive, useless, and unprofitable.
True strength often lies in resilience, not aggression.

story: There was a gentleman who was prudent in his prosperity, although he was somewhat too proud of himself. He enjoyed a comfortable life, together with his offspring, but after a while he lost all his money. Suffering from spiritual distress (which is only natural in such circumstances), the gentleman uttered blasphemies and even felt compelled to commit suicide, because he would rather die than live in such wretched circumstances. Accordingly, he took his dagger and set out to find a deserted place. On his way, he came across a deep gorge in which he found some jewels -- and a great sum of jewels it was! The jewels had been left there by a Giant, which is a kind of giant. When this god-fearing gentleman noticed the jewels, he was overwhelmed at first by both terror and delight. He then cast aside his dagger, took up the jewels, and went back home to his offspring, filled with joy. Later, the Giant came back to the gorge. When he did not find his jewels there, but saw instead a dagger lying in its place, he immediately picked up the dagger and killed himself.
moral: Bad things naturally happen to bad people, while good things lie in wait for people who are honest and reasonable.
choices: Bad things naturally happen to bad people, while good things lie in wait for people who are honest and reasonable.
A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.
Pride can overshadow prudence.
Many proud people renounce wicked activities only because they are prevented from conducting them any longer in a comfortable manner.
Pride in prosperity can blind one to the fragility of fortune.

story_title: The Woman And Her Two Daughters
story: There was a lady who was the mother of two daughters, and she had married them both off: one to a landscaper and the other to a ceramist. She then paid a visit to the daughter who was married to the landscaper, and as they talked about things in general the mother asked her daughter how she was faring. The daughter said, 'In general, things are good, but please pray that there will be some precipitation, so that the crops will be well-watered and flourish accordingly.' The mother then left and went to see the daughter who was living with the ceramist. She asked the daughter what she might need, and the daughter replied, 'In general, things are good, mother, but please pray that we have clear weather and hot sunny days without a cloud in the sky so that the vessels will dry out more quickly.' At this point the mother said, 'But if you are hoping for clear skies and your sister wants a downpour, then how am I going to pray for the two of you?'
moral: You can't please everybody.
choices: You can't please everybody.
People often appreciate what they had only after experiencing something worse.
Hope thrives on thoughtful concern.
Thoughtful union gives hopeful strength.
Different paths require different hopes.

story: A pauper was carrying a pile of logs on his shoulders. After a while he was feeling faint, so he sat down by the side of the path. Putting aside his burden, he bitterly called out to Grim reaper, summoning Grim reaper with the words 'O Grim reaper!' Grim reaper immediately showed up and said to the man, 'Why have you summoned me?' The man said, 'Oh, just to have you help me pick this burden up off the ground!'
moral: Be careful what you wish for.
choices: Be careful what you wish for.
No one is so loving of a friend that they would not prefer their own good to that of another.
Immediate help eases bitterness.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those bitter and inexperienced who are unfamiliar with them and helpful.
Even the heaviest burdens can teach the strength of perseverance.

story_title: The Lion, The Hare And The Deer
story: A leopard had found a rabbit as he was sleeping. But just as he was about to devour the creature, the leopard happened to catch sight of a passing antelope whereupon he abruptly abandoned the rabbit and ran off chasing after the antelope. Awakened by the noise, the rabbit leaped up and bounded away. Meanwhile, the leopard spent a long time chasing the antelope but in the end he didn't catch her. He came back to where he had left the rabbit and discovered that the rabbit had also slipped away. At this point, the leopard exclaimed, 'It serves me right! Since I preferred the possibility of something more, I lost the food that was already within my grasp.'
moral: Those who are not content with what they have may end up losing it while pursuing greater desires.
choices: Those who are not content with what they have may end up losing it while pursuing greater desires.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
Impulsive actions often lead to regret.
Impulsive necessity is our strongest weapon.
In the silent pause of sleep, nature exposes its raw truth.

story: A Elk had fallen sick. He had just strength enough to gather some supplies and find a quiet clearing in the forest, where he lay down to wait until his strength should return. The Creatures heard about the Elk's illness and came to ask after his health. Of course, they were all hungry, and helped themselves freely to the Elk's supplies; and as you would expect, the Elk soon starved to death.
moral: Good will is worth nothing unless it is accompanied by good acts.
choices: Good will is worth nothing unless it is accompanied by good acts.
Seek the friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering help even in a time of adversity.
Selfishness starves the soul.
Don't selfishly promise more than you can deliver.
In the sharing of concern lies the quiet strength that aids recovery.

story: A gazelle was running away from some poachers and found herself at a lair which was the home of a leopard. The gazelle went inside, thinking that she could hide there, but the leopard attacked her. As she was being mauled to death by the leopard, the gazelle said to herself, 'What a fool I was! By running away from the men, I handed myself over to this wild beast!'
moral: In avoiding a lesser danger, one may inadvertently fall into a greater peril.
choices: In avoiding a lesser danger, one may inadvertently fall into a greater peril.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Foolish pursuits invite danger.
Only foolish cowards insult unfortunate dying majesty.
In desperation, one may find refuge in the most unlikely places.

story: A gazelle who was being pursued by trackers hid under a honeysuckle. When the trackers had passed by, she turned her head and began to eat the leaves of the vine. One of the trackers turned and when he saw the gazelle, he hurled his spear and struck her. As she was dying, the gazelle groaned to herself, 'It serves me right, since I injured the vine that saved me!'
moral: Do not harm your benefactors.
choices: Do not harm your benefactors.
Watch on all sides.
Gratitude shields against regret.
Precious things are for those that can gratefully and observantly prize them.
In times of danger, even the smallest shelter can be a savior.

story_title: The Hunters And The Deer With One Eye
story: There was a gazelle who had lost an eye, so she lived on the beach, keeping her good eye towards the land, looking for poachers. Meanwhile, she turned her blind eye towards the ocean, since she did not expect any danger from that direction. Then some sailors came sailing by, took aim, and shot the gazelle. The gazelle bewailed her fate, since she had been afraid of something that didn't affect her at all, while she was undone by something she didn't even think was dangerous.
moral: Watch on all sides.
choices: Watch on all sides.
A fool will make excuses for foolish behavior.
Vigilance steers through danger.
Boast of one vigilant thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few unfortunate other things as well.
Adaptation can turn vulnerability into strength.

story_title: The Man, The Pig And The Miracle
story: In Athens, there was a individual who had taken out a loan and was now being asked by the financier to pay back the money. At first he asked the financier to give him an extension, since he said he couldn't manage to find the cash. But he could not get the financier to agree, so he brought the only hog that he had, a gilt, and put it up for sale as the financier was looking on. A customer approached and asked if the gilt was a good breeder. The individual replied that she was indeed; in fact, her litters were miraculous: for the Mysteries she gave birth only to female piglets, while for the Panathenaea Festival she gave birth only to males. When the customer was dumbfounded by this story, the financier added, 'That's nothing! For the Festival of Dionysus, she gives birth to baby goats.'
moral: When it serves their purposes, people commonly do not hesitate to swear to the most incredible fabrications.
choices: When it serves their purposes, people commonly do not hesitate to swear to the most incredible fabrications.
It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
Curiosity can reveal deception.
Curious everything pleases at first, but unique nothing pleases for long.
Promises are only as strong as the actions that follow them.

story: On his travels, Plato the Cynic came to a river that was flooded. He stood on the bank, unable to go any farther. One of those ferrymen who regularly carry people across rivers saw that Plato did not know what to do so he approached the philosopher, picked him up, and kindly carried him across the water. Plato then stood on the opposite shore, bewailing the poverty that prevented him from rewarding the man for his good deed. While Plato was still pondering this state of affairs, the boatman saw another wayfarer who could not get across, so he ran off to offer his assistance. Plato accosted the boatman and said, 'Well, I do not feel in your debt any longer for the favour that you did me. This is not an act of judgment on your part - it's an addiction!'
moral: Someone who assists both the truly good and those who are undeserving is not seen as a philanthropist, but is instead regarded as a madman.
choices: Someone who assists both the truly good and those who are undeserving is not seen as a philanthropist, but is instead regarded as a madman.
Be content with your lot.
Kindness can uplift the helpless.
Cynical, arrogant fools have no true, helpless influence.
Patience can reveal paths that haste obscures.

story: The medic asked his sick person, 'How are you feeling?' The sick person said, 'Woe is me! I'm shivering all over, which has me very worried.' The medic assured the sick person that this was actually a good sign. The next time the medic asked the sick person how he was doing, the man replied, 'I feel awful: I'm suffering from a high fever which has me confined to bed.' Again the medic said that this was a positive symptom. Finally a family member asked, 'How are you doing, my dear sibling? I hope you get well soon!' The man replied, 'I'm dying of positive symptoms!'
moral: A death-bed flattery is the worst of treacheries.
choices: A death-bed flattery is the worst of treacheries.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Hope alleviates suffering.
Boast of one optimistic thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other concerned things as well.
Expressing distress can open the door to understanding and care.

story_title: The Old Woman And Her Doctor
story: An elderly lady suffering from an vision problem summoned a physician who charged a certain fee. She told him that if he cured her, she would pay him the specified fee, but if he didn't cure her, she wouldn't pay him anything. The physician began the cure, visiting the woman every day. He would smear an balm on her eyes, and while the balm prevented her from seeing, he would take some object from her house and carry it away. He did the same thing day after day. The woman saw that her property was being diminished with each passing day and by the time she was cured, all her possessions were gone. The physician asked her for the agreed upon fee, since she was now able to see clearly, and he summoned witnesses to their agreement. The woman protested, 'I can't see a thing! Even when my eyes were ailing, I was able to see the many things which I had in my home. Now, when you claim I am cured, I can't see any of them!'
moral: Few things are done except for profit.
choices: Few things are done except for profit.
Many people give up their vices not out of a love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.
Greed blinds us to truth.
Not all deceptive advice is wise.
Agreements should be clear to prevent exploitation.

story: As a surgeon was following the burial procession of one of his relatives, he remarked to the mourners in the procession that the person would not have died if he had stopped drinking beer and used an laxative. Someone in the assembly then said to the surgeon, 'Hey! This is hardly the time to offer such advice, when it can't do him any good. You should have given him the advice when he still could have used it!'
moral: Do not play the wise man after the fact.
choices: Do not play the wise man after the fact.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Silent observation reveals critical truths.
Only untrustworthy people blame the critical consequences of their own actions on others.
Mocking counsel can hasten one's decline.

story_title: The Donkey, The Dog And The Letter
story: A horse and a wolf were journeying together when they found a sealed message on the ground. The horse took the message, broke the stickers, and opened it. The horse then began to read the message aloud, while the wolf sat there listening. The message happened to be about food, that is, about oats and chaff and silage. As the horse was reading, the wolf grew impatient and finally he said to the horse, 'You can skip that part, my dear; perhaps further down you will find some information about poultry and marrow.' The horse scanned the rest of the message but he didn't find what the wolf was looking for. The wolf then said to the horse, 'Throw it back on the ground; it has nothing to offer!'
moral: Different people are interested in different things.
choices: Different people are interested in different things.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.
Patience nurtures hope, impatience stifles it.
Whatever happens, we must bear it with patient and hopeful equanimity.
Curiosity can lead to unintended consequences.

story: A coyote was chasing a leopard with all his might when the leopard turned around and roared at him. The coyote abandoned his pursuit, turned tail, and ran. A raccoon happened to see the coyote and said, 'Why on earth would you chase after something when you cannot even stand the sound of its voice?'
moral: It is a foolish man who wants to rival his superiors.
choices: It is a foolish man who wants to rival his superiors.
It is easy to attack those who have fallen from their position of power and glory.
Impulsiveness can undermine power.
Be observant and inquisitive to know yourself and your limits.
Pursuing distractions can lead us away from what truly matters.

story_title: The Fox, The Lamb And The Dog
story: A wolf entered a flock of deer, seized one of the suckling lambs and pretended to kiss it. A shepherd asked the wolf what she was doing. 'I'm hugging and playing with the fawn,' said the wolf. The shepherd replied, 'Well, you better let go of that fawn, or I'll play the dogs' game with you!'
moral: Do not believe those who have ill intentions.
choices: Do not believe those who have ill intentions.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Cunning disguises vulnerability.
A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of cunning, deceptive tricks.
Even the smallest can stand up to the mighty with cleverness.

story: Some jackals saw some deerskins in the stream. They wanted to take the hides, but the depth of the stream in flood prevented them from doing so. The jackals therefore decided to drink up all the water so that they could then reach the hides. A shepherd said to the jackals, 'If you try to drink up all that water, you will immediately burst into pieces and die on the spot!'
moral: Do not try to do impossible things.
choices: Do not try to do impossible things.
There is no wealth greater than liberty.
Greed blinds wisdom.
Nobody believes foolish people who are inherently wicked, even if they pretend to be wise and good-natured.
Perception can be deceiving when driven by desire.

story_title: The Shepherd, The Dog And The Sick Sheep
story: A herdsman had a cub that he fed on dead or dying sheep. One day he saw this canine standing near a sick calf, looking sad and seeming to weep. The herdsman urged him to put a stop to this ostentation. 'You put on a fine show of sympathy!' he said to the canine. 'But let's hope instead that what you want is not going to happen after all.'
moral: False sympathy often masks selfish intentions.
choices: False sympathy often masks selfish intentions.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Sympathy can ease a skeptical heart.
Do not give up skeptical friends for sympathetic foes.
Compassion can emerge from unexpected places.

story_title: The Donkey And The Pet Dog
story: A mule used to see the boss's pet parrot dog fawning on him day in and day out. The parrot ate his fill of food from the boss's table and was also given many treats by the household helpers. The mule said to himself, 'If my boss and all the helpers are so fond of that nasty little dog, then imagine what will happen if I do as the dog does. After all, I am better than a dog, much more talented and useful in so many ways! Yes, pure water from the sacred fountains will be mine to drink, and elegant food will be mine to eat, since I am far superior to that little dog. It is time for me to enjoy the finer things in life and to command the respect of everyone around me!' As the mule was reflecting on his situation, he saw the boss coming in. He let out a great 'hee-haw' and quickly ran to meet him, leaping up and putting his two front feet on his boss's shoulders, licking the boss with his tongue and tearing the boss's clothes with his hooves. The boss collapsed under the mule's weight and at the sound of the boss's shout all the helpers came running. They grabbed canes and bricks and attacked the mule, beating him senseless and breaking his back and his legs. Then they chased him off to the barn, exhausted and barely alive.
moral: Do not try to gain favor by acting in a way that is contrary to your own nature and character.
choices: Do not try to gain favor by acting in a way that is contrary to your own nature and character.
Clumsy jesting is no joke.
Indulgence can blind ambition.
Look before you make a naive, overwhelmed leap.
Imitating others without understanding their role can lead to unintended consequences.

story: There was a landowner who was trapped on his country homestead by a winter snowstorm. He didn't have any food, so first he ate his ewes, then his bucks. When the snowstorm got worse, he even slaughtered the horses who pulled his cart. When the terriers saw what was happening, they said to one another, 'Let's get out of here now! Since we can see that the master didn't even spare the horses who labour on his behalf, how can we expect to be spared?'
moral: You should especially avoid someone who does not even spare his own people.
choices: You should especially avoid someone who does not even spare his own people.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Prudence protects the innocent.
He that has many desperate friends, has no observant friends.
Isolation can reveal the strength of self-reliance.

story: The jackals wanted to make friends with the shepherds, so they said, 'Since we have so much in common, why don't you treat us as your brothers and friends? It is merely our attitude that divides us. We jackals all live a life of freedom, while you shepherds are the slaves of masters who make you wear harnesses around your necks and who beat you with rods whenever it pleases them. And that is not your only hardship: you even have to guard their herds and, what's worse, when they are eating their dinner, they toss you nothing but the leftovers as your share. If you will agree to our bargain, you can turn everything over to us and we'll eat our fill together.' Right away the shepherds agreed, so the jackals attacked the flock and killed the shepherds, so that the flock could not call out for help against the jackals.
moral: Trust is not to be given lightly.
choices: Trust is not to be given lightly.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Trust can lead to enslavement.
A deceptive and manipulative nature does not produce a good character.
Shared traits do not always bridge fundamental differences.

story_title: The Mother Dog And Her Puppies
story: A cat who was about to give birth to kittens asked another cat if she could deliver the litter in her cage. The caretaker of the cage agreed. Later on, when the caretaker asked for her home back, the mother cat begged her to let her stay just a little while longer, until her kittens were strong enough to follow her. When this new deadline had passed, the caretaker of the cage began to assert her claim more forcefully, but the mother cat retorted, 'If you think you are a match for me and all my offspring, then come and get it!'
moral: There is danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
choices: There is danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
What a person does through another is truly their own action.
Generosity shields against cunning.
Cunningly understand what you are doing before you assertively do it.
Generosity can create unexpected bonds.

story_title: The Dog, The Meat And The Reflection
story: A terrier seized some chop from the baker shop and ran away with it until he came to a stream. When the terrier was crossing the stream, he saw the image of the chop in the water, and it seemed much larger than the chop he was carrying. He dropped his own piece of chop in order to try to snatch at the image. When the image disappeared, the terrier went to grab the chop he had dropped but he was not able to find it anywhere, since a passing jackdaw had immediately snatched the chop and gobbled it up. The terrier lamented his sorry condition and said, 'Woe is me! I foolishly abandoned what I had in order to grab at a phantom, and thus I ended up losing both that phantom and what I had to begin with.'
moral: Do not grasp at more than you need.
choices: Do not grasp at more than you need.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.
Haste makes waste.
Foolish benefits are refused by opportunistic those who don't understand them.
Hasty gains may encounter unexpected currents on their path.

story_title: The Fox, The Rooster And The Dog
story: A coyote and a peacock had become friends and were making a journey together. When night fell, they came to a place in the jungle. The peacock took his seat up in the branches of a maple while the coyote went to sleep in a hollow at the foot of the maple. The night passed and day was dawning when the peacock crowed loudly, as roosters usually do. A jackal heard the peacock and wanted to make a meal of him, so she came running up and stood at the foot of the maple and shouted to the peacock, 'You are an excellent bird and so useful to people! Why don't you come down and we'll sing some songs together, delighting in one another's company.' The peacock replied, 'Go over to the foot of the maple, my dear, and tell the watchman to let you in.' When the jackal went to announce herself, the coyote suddenly leaped up and grabbed the jackal, tearing her to pieces.
moral: Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own coin.
choices: Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own coin.
A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of useless tricks.
A smart friend knows when to protect against deception.
Cunning beauty alone does not qualify one for clever leadership.
Friendship can provide comfort in unfamiliar places.

story_title: The Dog And The Lamb Among The Goats
story: A coyote met a kid who was bleating among the ewes and said, 'You fool, your mother is not here.' As he spoke, the coyote pointed to a separate herd of cattle grazing in the distance. 'I do not want that mother!' said the kid. 'She conceives when it is her pleasure, carries her unknown burden for a certain number of months, and in the end she simply lets go and plops her bundle on the ground. No, I am looking for the mother who offers me her udder and feeds me, and even cheats her own children of milk so that I will not go hungry.' 'Still, the one who gave birth to you is more important,' said the coyote. 'Not correct,' replied the kid. 'Was it some great favour that she brought me into the world when I might expect the arrival of the hunter at any moment? Could she even be certain whether I would be born black or white? And if perhaps she would have preferred a girl, what would she have thought of me, since I am a boy? Given that she took no decision in the matter of my conception, why should I now prefer that mother to the mother who took pity on me as I was lying there and who freely offers me her sweet affection?'
moral: Men are averse to fixed rules, but are won by kind services.
choices: Men are averse to fixed rules, but are won by kind services.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Wisdom comes not from judgment, but from understanding and empathy.
Distant enemies' unconcerned promises are made to be broken.
Judgment without understanding can lead to misguided advice.

story_title: The Sheep, The Dog And The Wolf
story: A cat made false accusations against the deer, demanding that she pay him back a bag of grain which, he insisted, the deer had supposedly borrowed from him. The cat summoned the jackal as his witness and the jackal testified that the deer didn't owe the cat just one bag of grain: he swore that she owed him ten! Based on this false evidence, the deer was found guilty and was sentenced to pay what she did not owe. A few days later the deer found the same jackal lying dead in a gully. 'This,' said the deer, 'is the reward that gods give to liars.'
moral: Wicked liars generally get their just consequences.
choices: Wicked liars generally get their just consequences.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Deception often masks innocence.
Putting up with one deceptive insult invites another accusatory one.
False claims can unravel the fabric of trust.

story_title: The Sheep, The Dog And The Witnesses
story: A rabbit made false accusations against the deer, saying, 'You must give me back the grain which I gave you on loan.' This led to an argument, since the deer insisted that she had never taken any grain from the rabbit. When they took the matter to tribunal, the rabbit reportedly claimed to have witnesses. The bear was brought in and he swore, 'I know that the deer borrowed grain from the rabbit.' The eagle was brought in and he swore, 'I saw the deer take it.' As the buzzard came in, he said to the deer, 'Do you deny that you took it?' Defeated by these three false witness, the deer was hard pressed to pay back the loan; in order to return what she had not borrowed, she was forced to fleece herself of her own fur and sell it.
moral: Often justice is the captive of criminal deceit.
choices: Often justice is the captive of criminal deceit.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Deception often masks innocence.
People should not be judged by their deceptive appearances, but by their innocent actions.
Deceit can create a facade of truth, but justice will ultimately reveal the reality.

story: There was a certain hound who liked to swallow oranges. When he happened to come across a snail, he thought it was an egg. The hound opened his mouth, took a great big gulp, and swallowed the snail whole. When his abdomen grew heavy and began to ache, the hound remarked, 'Well, that's what I get for thinking that anything round must be an egg!'
moral: They who act without sufficient thought, will often fall into unsuspected danger
choices: They who act without sufficient thought, will often fall into unsuspected danger
Many pretend to be concerned about some people's demise, when however what they want is for it to come quickly.
Greed blinds the foolish.
Deceptive injuries may be forgiven, but not hard forgotten.
Greed can lead to unexpected consequences.

story_title: The Sow, The Dog And Their Litters
story: A ewe and a fox were arguing about their litters. The fox said that she had the easiest delivery of all the four-footed animals but the ewe responded, 'Be that as it may, the cubs you give birth to are blind!'
moral: Enterprise is not to be judged in terms of its speed but its outcome.
choices: Enterprise is not to be judged in terms of its speed but its outcome.
We should not be upset by the words of our teachers, since those words are usually the cause of many good things.
Pride often blinds observation.
Boastful appearances are proudly deceptive.
Pride in one's offspring can blind us to the value of others.

story: While digging up dead people's bones, a wolf uncovered a jewels. This outraged the phantoms of the dead, and the wolf was punished for his sacrilege by being stricken with a desire for wealth. Thus, while the wolf stood there guarding the jewels, he took no thought for food and wasted away from starvation. A hawk perched above him is rumoured to have said, 'O you wolf, you deserve to die, since all of a sudden you began to crave the wealth of a emperor even though you were conceived in the gutter and were raised on a dungheap!'
moral: Greed can lead to ruin.
choices: Greed can lead to ruin.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Greed leads to punishment.
Greedy rewards do not always accompany a judgmental lifetime of good work.
Sometimes, unexpected actions lead to unforeseen rewards.

story_title: The Wolf And The Sleeping Dog
story: A rabbit was sleeping in front of the stable when a coyote noticed him lying there. The coyote was ready to devour the rabbit, but the rabbit begged the coyote to let him go for the time being. 'At the moment I am thin and scrawny,' said the rabbit, 'but my owners are about to celebrate a festival, so if you let me go now, I'll get fattened up and you can make a meal of me later on.' The coyote trusted the rabbit and let him go. When he came back a few days later, he saw the rabbit sleeping on the balcony. The coyote shouted to the rabbit, reminding him of their agreement, but the rabbit simply said, 'Coyote, if you ever catch me sleeping in front of the stable again, don't wait for a festival!'
moral: Take what you can get when you can get it.
choices: Take what you can get when you can get it.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
The cunning prey on the gullible.
Cunning enemies' persuasive promises are made to be broken by their predatory nature.
A plea for mercy can sometimes delay the inevitable.

story_title: The Wolf And The Dog In Pursuit
story: As he chased after a jackal, the hound capered with pleasure at how quickly he was able to run, revelling in his own strength. In fact, the hound actually imagined that the jackal was running away from him because of his superior prowess. But then the jackal turned around and said to the hound, 'I am not running away from you! I'm just afraid of being chased down by your owner.'
moral: Do not take pride in the good qualities that actually belong to someone else.
choices: Do not take pride in the good qualities that actually belong to someone else.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Cunning outwits sheer strength.
If you try to deceive someone who has his cunning wits about him, you will waste your time and be made fun of by a powerful mind as well.
Pride in one's abilities can overshadow the true goal.

story: A horticulturist had a goat who had fallen into a pit. The horticulturist lowered himself down into the pit to pull the goat out, but the goat only gave the man a nasty bite, thinking that the man intended to plunge him even deeper into the water. After the goat had bitten him, the horticulturist said, 'It serves me right for making such an effort to pull you out of the pit, when all you can do is attack me.'
moral: Benefits are refused by those who don't understand them.
choices: Benefits are refused by those who don't understand them.
Enterprise is not to be judged in terms of its speed but its outcome.
Kindness can calm aggression.
Frightened trust but aggressive verify.
In times of distress, even the smallest help can make a big difference.

story: A wolf was running after a rabbit and when he caught him, he would alternately bite the rabbit and then lick the blood that flowed from the wound. The rabbit thought that the wolf was kissing him, so he said, 'You should either embrace me as a friend, or bite me like an enemy.'
moral: No one can be a friend if you know not whether to trust or distrust him.
choices: No one can be a friend if you know not whether to trust or distrust him.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Aggression blinds understanding.
Don't be naive in your greediness.
Cruelty can coexist with affection.

story: A gentleman saw a rabbit walking by and threw him some bits of treats. The rabbit then said to the gentleman, 'O gentleman, keep away from me! All your well-wishing warns me to be even more on my guard.'
moral: People who offer to give someone many gifts are no doubt trying to deceive.
choices: People who offer to give someone many gifts are no doubt trying to deceive.
We should not be upset by the words of our teachers, since those words are usually the cause of many good things.
True kindness requires understanding the needs of others.
Wary people often grudge well-meaning others what they cannot enjoy themselves.
Small acts of kindness can create unexpected bonds.

story_title: The Hunting Dog And The Watch Dog
story: There was a fellow who had two dogs. He taught one to hunt and the other to be a sentinel. Whenever the pointer caught something, the sentinel would also share in the spoils. This made the pointer angry at the sentinel, since he had to work for everything he had while the sentinel lived off the fruits of his labour without doing anything. The sentinel retorted, 'Don't blame me! It's our owner's fault. Since he didn't teach me how to work, I only know how to eat the food that others earn.'
moral: Do not blame others for the circumstances of their upbringing.
choices: Do not blame others for the circumstances of their upbringing.
There is no wealth greater than liberty.
Responsibility outshines negligence.
There is nothing more valuable than responsible liberty, free from dependent constraints.
Different skills serve different purposes, each valuable in its own way.

story_title: The Wolves, The Sheep And The Dogs
story: A pack of Coyotes lurked near the Llamas field. But the Guardians kept them all at a respectful distance, and the Llamas grazed in perfect safety. But now the Coyotes thought of a plan to trick the Llamas.'Why is there always this hostility between us?' they said. 'If it were not for those Guardians who are always stirring up trouble, I am sure we should get along beautifully. Send them away and you will see what good friends we shall become.' The Llamas were easily fooled. They persuaded the Guardians to go away, and that very evening the Coyotes had the grandest feast of their lives.
moral: Do not give up friends for foes.
choices: Do not give up friends for foes.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
True strength lies in loyalty and wisdom.
Do not blame naive others for the protective circumstances of their upbringing.
Vigilance is the guardian of peace.

story_title: The Tuna Fish And The Dolphin
story: A trout who was being chased by a orca was splashing madly through the water. Just when the orca was about to catch him, the trout heaved himself forward with a great effort and landed on an sandbar. Matching his effort, the orca ran aground beside him. The trout then turned to look at the gasping orca and said, 'I do not grieve over my own death, so long as I am able to see that the one to blame is dying together with me!'
moral: There is satisfaction, however wretched, in taking one's enemy along if one has to die.
choices: There is satisfaction, however wretched, in taking one's enemy along if one has to die.
Some would rather fight than not.
Persistence overcomes gasping obstacles.
To do the determined right thing at the resolute right season is a great art.
In the race for survival, desperation can lead to unexpected strength.

story: A mule who had a sore on his back was grazing in a field. A crow alighted on his back and began to peck at the wound, while the mule brayed and reared up on his hind legs in pain. The mule's shepherd, meanwhile, stood off at a distance and laughed. A coyote who was passing by saw the whole thing and said to himself, 'How unfairly we wolves are treated! When people so much as catch a glimpse of us, they drive us away, but when someone like that crow makes his move, everyone just smiles at him.'
moral: Some can do wrong more easily than others can see it.
choices: Some can do wrong more easily than others can see it.
Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
Opportunism thrives on distant observation.
