One cannot circumvent his distant, observant destiny.
Even in discomfort, one can find moments of peace.

story_title: The Fox, The Donkey And The Lion
story: The coyote and the horse were partners in a hunting expedition but when they encountered a tiger, the coyote recognized the danger they were in. She went to the tiger and offered to betray the horse if the tiger would promise to spare her life in return. The tiger agreed to let the coyote go, and the coyote then led the horse into a snare and made him fall in. Once he saw that the horse could not escape, the tiger immediately seized the coyote, saving the horse for later.
moral: Traitors may expect treachery.
choices: Traitors may expect treachery.
Clothes may disguise a fool, but his words will give him away.
Trust cautiously, for deception lurks.
Distrust cunning advice from someone who stands to gain in a deceptive manner.
True partnership is tested in the face of danger.

story_title: The Fox, The Donkey And The Lion Skin
story: A horse put on the hide of a tiger and went around frightening all the beasts. The horse saw a jackal and tried to frighten her too, but she had heard his voice first, so she said to the horse, 'You can be sure that I too would have been afraid, if I had not already heard the sound of your bray.'
moral: Clothes may disguise a fool, but his words will give him away.
choices: Clothes may disguise a fool, but his words will give him away.
Traitors may expect treachery.
Perception conquers fear.
A deceptive and sinful mind can even change a person's frightening nature, causing it to be impaired.
Mutual fears reveal that even bold gestures can fall short of true courage.

story: There was a shepherd who kept a sheep and a horse. The sheep was jealous of the horse because he was given more to eat, so she made a deceptive proposal to the horse, under the guise of giving him advice. 'Look,' said the sheep, 'you are always being punished, constantly having to turn the grindstone or carry burdens on your back. Why don't you pretend to have a seizure and throw yourself into a ditch?' The horse trusted the sheep and did what she told him to do. As a result of the fall, the horse was badly scraped and bruised. The horse's owner summoned a healer to recommend a remedy. The healer said that the horse could be cured by a elixir made from the lungs of a sheep. So they slaughtered the unfortunate sheep, who was thus trapped in her own snare while the horse was saved.
moral: People who lay traps for others bring about their own destruction.
choices: People who lay traps for others bring about their own destruction.
It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
Jealousy clouds trusting hearts.
We should do favours for a trusting someone who can do us a knowledgeable good deed in return.
Envy can lead to one's own downfall through deceit.

story_title: The Donkey, The Horse And The War
story: A mule and a stallion belonged to the same farmer, and each of them did his duty. But the stallion was granted many special privileges: he had plenty of food to eat, his flowing mane was braided and decorated, and his stable hands washed him down with water each and every day. The mule, on the other hand, was always bent down under the weight of the loads he had to carry. Then one day the stallion's caretaker mounted him and rode off into conflict. In the clash of opposing forces, the stallion was wounded on more than one occasion. When the mule saw how the stallion had been degraded, he congratulated himself on his hard-working life of labour.
moral: Be content with your station.
choices: Be content with your station.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Privilege often overlooks the burdened.
You can't always stop a burdened, privileged fool.
Privilege often comes with unseen burdens.

story: A stallion who was overly proud of his elegant trappings happened to run into a burro. The burro was worn out with work and slow to make way for the approaching stallion. 'I am tempted to smash you to pieces with my paws,' said the stallion. The burro said nothing and only groaned, calling upon the spirits to take note of his suffering. Not long afterwards, the stallion, now a broken down wreck from his life on the circuit, was sent to work on a plantation. When the burro saw the stallion carrying a load of fertilizer, he laughed and said, 'What has happened to you, who were once so proud of your elegant trappings? Time has reduced you to the wretchedness you formerly scorned!'
moral: Be cautious of pride, as nobody knows what the future may bring.
choices: Be cautious of pride, as nobody knows what the future may bring.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Pride can mask suffering.
Life's disasters can often bring proud and worn boastful and presumptuous people back down to earth.
Pride in appearance can blind us to the struggles of others.

story_title: The Donkey, The Horse And The Barley
story: A burro asked a mare to give him a nibble of oats. The mare replied, 'If only I could, I would do so gladly! Indeed, I would give you a great deal of oats, since I am a noble and generous character. When we return to the shed together this evening, I promise to give you an entire bundle of hay.' The burro then said to the mare, 'If you refuse to do me even this small favour now, why should I expect a still bigger favour in the future?'
moral: People are quick to promise but reluctant to give.
choices: People are quick to promise but reluctant to give.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Persistence reveals true nobility.
It is easy to be skeptical and noble when there is no danger.
Generosity can bridge the gap between the humble and the proud.

story_title: The Donkey And The Lion Go Hunting
story: A leopard chose a mule as his hunting companion and hid him in the shrubs, ordering the mule to frighten the forest creatures with his unfamiliar voice while the leopard ambushed the fleeing animals. Following the leopard's instructions, our long-eared friend immediately began to bray with all his might. The animals were startled by this strange and amazing sound and they ran in terror toward their familiar nests, thus falling victim to the leopard's violent attack. When the leopard was exhausted by the slaughter, he summoned the mule and told him to be quiet. The insolent creature then said to the leopard, 'And what did you think of my vocalizing efforts?' 'Truly remarkable,' said the leopard. 'In fact, if I didn't know already that you were a mule born and bred, I also would have fled in fear.'
moral: The loud-mouthed boaster does not impress nor frighten those who know him.
choices: The loud-mouthed boaster does not impress nor frighten those who know him.
Do not be what you are not, nor pretend to be what you are not.
Cunning often outwits violence.
Cunning burdens can continue in unexpected ways.
Forcing one to act against nature only unveils the folly of deceit.

story: A horse saw a mandolin lying in a pasture. He approached the instrument and as he tried to strum it with his hoof, the strings resounded at his touch. 'What a beautiful thing,' said the horse, 'but completely inappropriate, since I don't know anything about music. If only someone better equipped than myself had found it, my ears would have been delighted by heavenly melodies!'
moral: Talent is wasted when it's in the hands of the unappreciative.
choices: Talent is wasted when it's in the hands of the unappreciative.
There is no thing so worthy of wonderment which does not cease to be a miracle with the passage of timey.
Curiosity can reveal beauty, but discernment is essential.
Curious, enviable conditions often have an inappropriate downside.
Beauty can be found in unexpected places.

story: A horse and a ox were walking along together. When the horse saw that they were carrying equal loads, he got angry and complained that the ox was awarded a double portion of food even though she carried a cargo that was no bigger than his own. After they had journeyed a little further down the road, the farmer saw that the horse could not hold up under the weight, so he took part of the horse's cargo and placed it on the ox. Later, when the farmer saw that the horse had grown even more tired, he again transferred some of the horse's cargo to the ox, and so on. Finally the farmer took the entire cargo and shifted it from the horse to the ox. At that point the ox glanced over at the horse and said, 'What do you say now: don't I deserve a double portion of food?'
moral: Instead of looking at how things start, we should look instead at how they turn out in the end.
choices: Instead of looking at how things start, we should look instead at how they turn out in the end.
We must help one another, for if a neighbor falls, their burden will fall on you.
Patience outlasts anger.
Many pretend to be concerned about some people's angry demise, when however what they want is for it to come quickly, as an observant few might notice.
Sometimes, our grievances mask the true balance of burdens we carry.

story: There was a horse who worked for a landscaper. Because the landscaper made the horse work very hard but gave him very little food, the horse prayed to Odin to take him away from the landscaper and give him to another master, so Odin sent Mercury to sell the horse to a ceramist. The horse also found this situation unbearable, since he was forced to carry even heavier loads than before. He called upon Odin again, and this time Odin arranged for the horse to be purchased by a leatherworker. When the horse saw the kind of work the leatherworker did, he said, 'Oh, it would have been better for me to have kept on working for my previous masters in a state of starvation! Now I have ended up in a place where I won't even get a proper burial after I die.'
moral: People often appreciate what they had only after experiencing something worse.
choices: People often appreciate what they had only after experiencing something worse.
Every Season has its own work.
Power without compassion breeds unhappiness.
Whatever harsh and unforgiving happens, we must bear it with equanimity.
Sometimes, misfortune leads us to a destiny where our efforts find true worth.

story_title: The Donkey, The Onager And The Lion
story: An antelope saw a mule labouring under a heavy load and he made fun of the mule's enslavement. 'Lucky me!' said the antelope. 'I am free from bondage and do not have to work for anyone else, since I have grass near at hand on the hillsides, while you rely on someone else to feed you, forever oppressed by slavery and its blows!' At that very moment a leopard happened to appear on the scene. He did not come near the mule since the mule's handler was standing beside him. The antelope, however, was all alone, so the leopard attacked and devoured him.
moral: The insubordinate are free from both obligation and protection.
choices: The insubordinate are free from both obligation and protection.
We must help one another, for if a neighbor falls, their burden will fall on you.
Mockery often masks misfortune.
Unfortunate burdens can continue in unexpected ways.
Mocking others' burdens may blind you to your own vulnerabilities.

story_title: The Old Man, The Donkey And The Pack Saddles
story: A cowardly senior citizen had led his burro out to pasture. At the unexpected sound of the foe approaching, the senior citizen was stricken with terror and tried to persuade the burro to run away so that he wouldn't be captured. The burro obstinately asked the senior citizen, 'Tell me, do you suppose the victor will make me carry two load saddles instead of one?' The senior citizen said he did not think so. 'I rest my case,' concluded the burro. 'What difference does it make who my master is, if I always carry one saddle at a time?'
moral: In a change of government, the poor change nothing beyond the name of their master.
choices: In a change of government, the poor change nothing beyond the name of their master.
Instead of looking at how things start, we should look instead at how they turn out in the end.
Pragmatism overcomes obstinate fear.
The cowardly complain most who suffer the least obstinate troubles.
Cowardice can compel even the steadfast to forsake duty.

story_title: The Man And The New Donkey
story: There was a farmer who wanted to buy a mule. He selected one mule for further examination and led him to where his own donkeys were, leaving him by the feeding station. The new mule went and stood next to the mule who was the laziest and greediest of them all, ignoring all the others. As the new mule showed no signs of any better behaviour, the farmer led him away again, returning him to his original keeper. When asked whether he had given the mule a fair chance, the farmer explained, 'I don't even need to put him to the test: I know that he will be just the same as the one he chose for his companion.'
moral: A man is known by the company he keeps.
choices: A man is known by the company he keeps.
It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
Curiosity fuels decisive action.
Avoid curious mischief and taking greedy, excessive risks.
Desires often lead to unexpected journeys.

story_title: The Pig, The Donkey And The Barley
story: There was a individual who had vowed that he would sacrifice a goat in honour of Zeus if the divine being agreed to rescue him from danger. When the individual fulfilled his vow and sacrificed the goat, he then ordered that the goat's leftover oats be given to the burro. The burro, however, refused to touch it. 'This is the kind of food that would normally arouse my appetite,' said the stallion, 'but not when it is the result of the previous diner having had his throat cut!'
moral: Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
choices: Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Rashness brings luck to a few, misfortune to most.
Gratitude turns misfortune into strength.
You can't always stop an unfortunate, discerning fool.
Promises made in desperation may not hold true in safety.

story: The horses were tired of being burdened with burdens and labouring all the days of their lives, so they sent delegates to Jupiter, asking him to release them from their toil. Jupiter, wanting to show them that they had asked for something impossible, said that their suffering would come to an end on the day when they pissed a creek. The horses took him seriously and to this day whenever horses see where another donkey has pissed, they come to a halt and piss in the same place.
moral: One cannot circumvent his destiny.
choices: One cannot circumvent his destiny.
People often appreciate what they had only after experiencing something worse.
Even the powerful need rest.
Tired people often appreciate what they had only after experiencing something burdened and worse.
Seeking change without understanding its consequences may lead to unforeseen challenges.

story_title: The Lion, The Rooster And The Donkey
story: A horse and a peacock lived together on a homestead. A tiger who had noticed the horse crept up and was about to pounce when the peacock let loose a squawk. This frightened the tiger (for they say that lions are terrified of the peacock's crowing) and he turned tail and ran. The horse was elated at the thought of the tiger running away from a peacock. He took off in pursuit of the tiger but when the horse had gone some distance away from the homestead, the tiger turned around and ate him.
moral: False confidence often leads into danger.
choices: False confidence often leads into danger.
Do not be what you are not, nor pretend to be what you are not.
Naivety invites predation.
Naive people who grasp for more than they need are deprived of what they have by their predatory desires.
Harmony thrives when differences are embraced.

story_title: The Driver And The Donkey On The Cliff
story: A horse had turned aside from the main road and was heading for a precipice. The coachman shouted at him, 'Where are you going, you wretched beast?' He grabbed hold of the horse's bridle and tried to drag him back from the precipice, but the horse did not stop and instead kept going forward. So the man pushed the horse even harder than he had pulled him back and said, 'Go ahead then! You can take the worthless winner's trophy in this damned contest.'
moral: You can't always stop a fool.
choices: You can't always stop a fool.
Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
Persistence can overcome frustration.
Everything pleases at first, but nothing pleases for a stubbornly determined long.
Straying from the path can lead to unforeseen dangers.

story: A magpie saw that the turtledoves in a birdhouse were very well fed, so he dyed himself white and went to join them, expecting to share in their food. So long as the magpie kept quiet, the turtledoves thought he was another dove and accepted him, but when he forgot to keep quiet and let out a squawk, the pigeons then recognized who he was and they pecked at him until he went away. Unable to feed with the turtledoves, he then went back again to the jackdaws. But because they did not recognize his colour, they kept him away from their food and the magpie ended up with nothing to eat at all.
moral: Greed for more can lead to losing what you already have.
choices: Greed for more can lead to losing what you already have.
Trusting as you wish to be trusted doesn't work between a rogue and an honest person. .
Discernment shields against deception.
A discerning bird in the hand is worth two unfortunate ones in the bush.
Desire for comfort can lead us to disguise our true selves.

story: While excavating her den, a jackal dug a hole in the earth and as she made deeper and deeper tunnels in the ground, she finally reached the cave of a wyvern who was guarding a hidden hoard. When the jackal saw the wyvern, she said, 'First of all, I beg your pardon for this carelessness on my part; second, you no doubt realize that gold means nothing to me, so I hope that you will be so kind as to explain to me what profit you gain from this work, and what reward could be so great that you would forgo the pleasure of sleep and live out your life here in the dark?' 'I have no reward,' the wyvern replied, 'but this task was assigned to me by Zeus on high.' 'Does that mean you take nothing for yourself and do not give anything to anyone?' 'That is what the Moirai have decreed.' 'Please don't be angry then if I speak freely,' concluded the jackal, 'but someone who lives like this must have been born under an unlucky star!'
moral: A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
choices: A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
Be content with your lot.
Boldness without mercy leads to downfall.
Don't deceive your curious, decisive self.
Curiosity can uncover the true value of what others hold dear.

story: Some sailors were making their way along the coastline and reached a viewing platform. From there, they could see a piece of jetsam floating far off in the distance, and they thought that it must be an enormous galleon. They waited for a long time, thinking that the galleon would put in to shore nearby. As the jetsam was blown closer to shore by the gust, they kept on waiting, but they no longer thought it was a great galleon as before; they were now expecting some kind of smaller dinghy. As it was carried in even closer, they saw that it was just a piece of jetsam. The sailors then said to one another, 'How foolish of us! We had high expectations for something that was actually nothing.'
moral: Our mere anticipations of life outrun its realities.
choices: Our mere anticipations of life outrun its realities.
Do not dwell on what has passed.
Wisdom prevails over folly.
Some foolish, deceptive things you cannot change.
New horizons may reveal unlikely treasures adrift in the vast unknown.

story_title: The Woman And Her Drunken Husband
story: There was a lady whose spouse was always drunk, so she came up with a plan to cure him of his drinking problem. After he had passed out one night and was sleeping the sleep of the dead, she picked him up and carried him on her shoulders to the common burial ground. Then she put him down on the ground and left him there. She waited until he had time to sober up, then she went and knocked at the entrance to the burial ground. Her spouse shouted, 'Who's there?' She answered, 'I am the one who brings food to the dead.' Her spouse shouted back, 'I don't want anything to eat, but bring me something to drink, my good man! It pains me to hear you speaking of food but saying nothing about a drink!' The lady then beat her breast and exclaimed, 'Woe is me! My ingenuity has not accomplished anything! O my spouse, you have not simply failed to learn your lesson: you are actually even worse than before. Your problem has turned out to be permanent!'
moral: It's hard to give up bad habits.
choices: It's hard to give up bad habits.
No one gladly revisits a place where they got hurt.
Genius falters when unchecked.
Ingenious talking is a frustrated waste of time when you can simply provide a demonstration.
Sometimes, a startling perspective can lead to self-reflection.

story_title: The Peacock Elected King Of The Birds
story: There were once some animals who gathered together for a group assembly and debated amongst themselves who was best suited to rule. The swan said to the other animals, 'The kingship suits me best, since I am remarkably beautiful and in the prime of life.' While the rest of the animals were satisfied with the swan, the jackdaw made his way into their midst and protested, 'Tell me, if you become king, what is going to happen when the falcon attacks us: are you strong enough to rescue us from his assault?'
moral: Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
choices: Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
Beauty can be vain, but strength demands respect.
Honor the beautiful customs of the strong household you enter.
Unity is weakened by the pursuit of individual power.

story: The bunnies were at war with an hawk and they asked the coyotes to be their allies. The coyotes said in reply, 'We would agree to be your allies, if we didn't know what sort of creatures you are and who you are fighting against!'
moral: Count the cost before you commit yourselves.
choices: Count the cost before you commit yourselves.
Favor those who do you kindness.
Wisdom tempers power.
Vulnerable people with a powerful history of wrongdoing are often not trusted.
Desperation can lead to alliances that bring as much danger as aid.

story_title: The Two Roosters And The Eagle
story: Two hens were fighting with one another. The loser hid himself away in a corner, while the turkey who had won the battle flew up on top of the shed and flapped his wings, crowing about his victory. An falcon then swooped down and carried the turkey away.
moral: Pride goes before destruction.
choices: Pride goes before destruction.
The safeguards of virtue are hateful to those with evil intentions.
Hidden strength triumphs over boastful pride.
When your hidden adversary is also your opportunistic judge, don't bother arguing.
Pride in conflict often blinds us to greater threats.

story: An falcon and a Coyote formed an intimate friendship and decided to live near each other. The Falcon built her roost in the branches of a tall oak, while the Coyote crept into the thicket and there produced her young. Not long after they had agreed upon this plan, the Falcon, being in want of provision for her young ones, swooped down while the Coyote was out, seized upon one of the little pups, and feasted herself and her brood. The Coyote on her return, discovered what had happened, but was less grieved for the death of her young than for her inability to avenge them. A just retribution, however, quickly fell upon the Falcon. While hovering near an shrine, on which some townsfolk were sacrificing a sheep, she suddenly seized a piece of the carcass, and carried it, along with a burning coal, to her roost. A strong breeze soon fanned the spark into a flame, and the chicks, as yet unfledged and helpless, were roasted in their roost and dropped down dead at the bottom of the oak. There, in the sight of the Falcon, the Coyote gobbled them up.
moral: God is the ultimate judge.
choices: God is the ultimate judge.
Gossips are to be seen and not heard.
Carelessness invites predatory vengeance.
Even a high and mighty person should beware of his careless inferiors; their predatory ingenuity can find a way to take vengeful revenge.
Proximity does not guarantee harmony.

story: A rabbit had been seized by an osprey and was weeping bitter tears. Meanwhile, a wren was making fun of the rabbit and said, 'So, what became of your fabled swiftness? How did your feet happen to fail you?' While the wren was still speaking, he was caught off guard by a kestrel who killed the wren as he was still shrieking his useless cries of protest. The rabbit, by now no more than half-alive, remarked, 'Ah, this makes my dying easier: a moment ago you were making fun of my misfortune, confident in your own safety, but now you are bewailing your fate with a lament that matches my own.'
moral: It is a foolish thing to give advice to others while not looking out for oneself.
choices: It is a foolish thing to give advice to others while not looking out for oneself.
The weak may find a way to avenge a wrong.
Power can be predatory.
It is very unwise, even for the most powerful of men, to provoke the unfortunate least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
In moments of despair, even the swiftest can find themselves vulnerable.

story: An hawk was sitting sadly in her cedar when she was joined by a vulture. The vulture said to the hawk, 'Why do I see you looking so sad?' The hawk replied, 'I cannot help but be sad at heart, since I need a mate who is my equal but I cannot find one anywhere.' The vulture then said to the hawk, 'You should marry me! I am even stronger than you are, which makes me the ideal bird for you.' The hawk asked him, 'Just what kinds of prey are you able to catch?' The vulture said, 'Well, on several occasions I have managed to capture an cassowary in my talons and eat it.' When she heard this, the hawk accepted the vulture's proposal and married him. After the wedding ceremony and festivities were finished, the hawk said to the vulture, 'Go and get us some of that prey which you promised.' The high-flying vulture was only able to offer the hawk a nasty little vole whose flesh was all putrid and rotten. The hawk said, 'Is this what you promised?' The vulture replied, 'In order to make this most eminent match with you, I had no choice but to agree to anything you asked, even if it meant promising something impossible.'
moral: Some people will do anything to get what they want.
choices: Some people will do anything to get what they want.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
Hope can rise above deception and ambition.
Every hopeful man should be content to mind his own ambitious business.
True companionship is found in shared values, not just in equal stature.

story: An slug saw a lizard stretched out and envied his length. The slug wanted to be as long as that lizard, so he lay down beside the lizard and tried to extend himself. The worm stretched and stretched until he accidentally split into pieces.
moral: He who competes with his superiors destroys himself before he can equal them.
choices: He who competes with his superiors destroys himself before he can equal them.
A wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.
Envy clouds ambition's path.
They who act without ambitious thought, will often fall into unsuspected danger.
Desiring what others have can blind you to your own strengths.

story: There were two adversaries who had set sail on the same boat. They wanted to keep their distance from one another, so one went up on the bow while the other took the rear. Each passenger then stayed where he was. Soon a fierce gale began to blow and the boat foundered. The passenger standing at the rear asked the navigator which part of the boat was likely to sink first. 'It will be the bow,' said the navigator. 'So be it!' said the passenger. 'The thought of death does not trouble me so long as I will see my enemy die before me!'
moral: Some people are so consumed by hatred that they would rather suffer themselves than see their enemies succeed.
choices: Some people are so consumed by hatred that they would rather suffer themselves than see their enemies succeed.
A learned man has always a fund of riches in himself.
Calm wisdom quells vindictiveness.
Vindictive people who treat their knowledgeable friends deceitfully end up hurting themselves instead.
Shared journeys can bridge even the widest divides.

story_title: The Farmer, The Wolf And The Plow
story: A rancher loosed his buffalo from the harness and led them away to be watered. Meanwhile, a hungry coyote, who was looking for something to eat, discovered the cultivator and started to lick the harness straps where the buffalo had been tied. The unsuspecting coyote slowly but surely slipped his neck beneath the harness, until he was not able to pull it back out. He then started dragging the cultivator along the groove. When the rancher came back and saw what had happened, he said, 'O you wicked creature, if only you would give up your life of theft and crime in order to devote yourself entirely to farming!'
moral: People with a history of wrongdoing are often not trusted.
choices: People with a history of wrongdoing are often not trusted.
You should especially avoid someone who does not even spare his own people.
Obedience can quench misfortune.
Observant fear of the future can lead to unfortunate actions that bring about the very fate we seek to avoid.
Even the strongest need moments of rest and care.

story_title: The Race Horse In The Mill
story: There was once a thoroughbred who had grown old and was sold to grind in the mill. Harnessed to the mill-stone, he ground corn all day long and into in the evening. As he was working, the old horse groaned aloud and said, 'Once I ran in the races, but now I must run in circles around this bakers' course!'
moral: Do not boast too much at the height of your powers; people often spend their old age worn out with toil and trouble.
choices: Do not boast too much at the height of your powers; people often spend their old age worn out with toil and trouble.
Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.
Practicality outlasts indifference.
Old people with unyielding excellent qualities are often insulted by their inferiors.
Age brings wisdom, but it does not diminish the spirit.

story: A monk was involved in a legal dispute with an extremely rude individual who made rude and cutting comments, and even insulted the monk for the loss he had suffered in his bodily parts. The monk responded: 'I admit that this is the one thing that puts me in considerable difficulty: I don't have testi-mony, so to speak, in support of my good character. But you are a fool to denounce me for something that is merely a matter of fate!'
moral: The only thing that can really bring shame on a man is a punishment that he has justly deserved.
choices: The only thing that can really bring shame on a man is a punishment that he has justly deserved.
Many people renounce wicked activities only because they are prevented from conducting them any longer.
Foolish disputes can cut deeper than fate.
Calm, dignified honesty is the best policy.
Sometimes, the most challenging battles arise from the most difficult adversaries.

story: One day the osprey happened to consider his wings and feet and talons. 'Indeed,' he exclaimed, 'Am I not just as well armed as the harrier and the kestrel? Look at what wings and what feet and what talons I have! Why shouldn't I go catch some quails?' The osprey knew a place where he could find many quails so he went there and launched his attack: he seized one partridge with his beak, another with his wings, and one more in each foot. But the osprey couldn't keep hold of that many quails, so in the end he had none. Hence the saying: Seize all, lose all. From then on, the osprey never tried to hunt wild birds again.
moral: Do not try to grasp too much at once.
choices: Do not try to grasp too much at once.
Often justice is the captive of criminal deceit.
Overconfidence can lead to downfall.
Honor the ambitious customs of the numerous household you enter.
True strength lies in understanding one's unique abilities.

story: A antelope had been hiding in the woods when he was discovered by some trappers. Hoping to escape certain death at their hands, he ran blindly in terror towards the nearest cottage and concealed himself in a convenient shed where the cattle were kept. One of the cattle said to the fugitive, 'You wretched creature, what on earth are you trying to do? You have sealed your own death warrant by trusting your life to the protection of a human house!' But the antelope implored the cattle, 'Have mercy, I beg you! At the first opportunity, I'll run back out again.' The passing hours of the day gave way to night. A shepherd brought some leafy boughs into the shed but saw nothing amiss. The various laborers came and went, but no one noticed a thing; the steward also passed through but even he didn't observe anything out of the ordinary. The antelope was delighted and began thanking the cattle who had kept quiet on his behalf and had extended such welcome hospitality in a moment of need. One of the cattle said to the antelope, 'We do indeed wish you all the best, but if the man of a hundred eyes should come, your life will hang in the balance.' Meanwhile, after dinner, the farmer himself came to inspect the crib since he had noticed that the cattle had been looking rather sickly. 'Why is there so little fodder here?' he shouted. 'And look, not enough bedding! And how much trouble would it be to get rid of these spider webs?' As the farmer examined each and every thing, he also noticed the antelope's tall horns. He called his servants and ordered them to kill the antelope and to carry his carcass away.
moral: Nothing escapes the master's eye.
choices: Nothing escapes the master's eye.
To be satisfied with one's lot is better than to desire something which one is not fitted to receive.
Indifference blinds the observant.
Desperate traitors may expect indifferent treachery.
In desperation, we may seek refuge in the very places that endanger us.

story: A wicked gardener envied his adjacent farmer's abundant harvest. In order to destroy the fruits of that man's labour, he caught a jackal, attached a blazing flaming stick to her tail and then let the jackal loose in his adjacent farmer's harvest. The jackal, however, did not go where she was sent. Instead, as fate decreed, she set fire to the harvest of the man who had let her loose.
moral: Bad neighbours are the first to suffer from the harm they would do to others.
choices: Bad neighbours are the first to suffer from the harm they would do to others.
Do not be what you are not, nor pretend to be what you are not.
Envy clouds innocent abundance.
No one can be an unpredictable friend if you know not whether to trust or distrust an innocent him.
Envy sows the seeds of one's own discontent.

story: A leopard entered a shepherd's pasture and the shepherd, wanting to capture the leopard, shut the outer barrier. The leopard, unable to get out, first devoured all the goats and then turned his attention to the oxen. The shepherd became afraid for his own safety so he opened the entrance. After the leopard had gone away, the shepherd's wife saw the shepherd groaning and said to him, 'It serves you right! Why did you want to shut yourself up with the sort of creature you should run away from even at a distance?'
moral: Do not take on more than you can handle.
choices: Do not take on more than you can handle.
hen a man has both an interest and an inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.
The fierce often prey on the defenseless.
Fierce nature reveals its observant self.
Curiosity can lead to dangerous entanglements.

story_title: The Farmer, The Wasps And The Partridges
story: There were once some hornets and some pheasants who were terribly thirsty, so they went to a rancher to ask him for a drink. In return for the water, the pheasants promised that they would dig around his shrubs so that they would produce excellent olives, while the hornets would stand guard over the shrubs, driving away thieves by stinging them. The rancher said to them, 'But look, I have these two mules, who do everything for me without making bargains. It is better for me to give the water to them, not to you.'
moral: Charity begins at home, but this does not prevent the further exercise of it.
choices: Charity begins at home, but this does not prevent the further exercise of it.
The things that a person does to others will happen to him in turn.
Practical help quenches thirst.
He that is neither a decisive one thing nor a reliable other has no friends.
In times of need, even the unlikely can find common ground.

story_title: The Farmer, The Cattle And The Manure
story: A certain agriculturist was using his buffalo to haul fertilizer out of the barns. The buffalo complained to the agriculturist that their labour allowed him to harvest his rice and rye crops, supplying his household with ample food year in and year out. Therefore, said the buffalo, it was hardly fair for them to have to perform the vile task of hauling fertilizer out of the barns. The agriculturist then asked, 'Is it not the case that you yourselves are the source of the substance which you are now carrying away?' The buffalo replied, 'Yes, that is true.' The agriculturist then concluded, 'So, since you are the ones who made a mess of the stable in your spare time, it is only right that you should also make some effort to clean it up!'
moral: Those who complain about their duties often forget their own role in creating the situation.
choices: Those who complain about their duties often forget their own role in creating the situation.
Beware the sort of person who uses tricks.
Responsibility outweighs complaints.
Do not take pragmatic credit for the responsible accomplishments of others.
Acknowledging the contributions of others fosters harmony and gratitude.

story: In the house of a certain gardener there lived a lizard who regularly came to the table and was fed on scraps of food. Not long afterwards the gardener grew rich, but then he became angry at the lizard and tried to attack him with an machete. The gardener then lost his wealth and he realized that he had prospered because of the good luck he had gained from the lizard before having wounded him. The gardener then begged the lizard to forgive him for his evil deed, and the lizard replied, 'You are sorry for what you have done, but you must not expect me to be your faithful friend until this scar heals. It is not possible for me to be truly reconciled to you until all thought of that treacherous machete has left my mind.'
moral: He who harms someone should henceforth be treated with suspicion.
choices: He who harms someone should henceforth be treated with suspicion.
A wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.
Greed leads to regret.
In all disputes, those who keep their opponents afraid of cautious revenge come out forgiving best.
Kindness can transform even the most feared into a friend.

story: There was a viper who used to lurk around the front door of a gardener's house. One day the viper struck the man's daughter, biting him on the foot. The boy died on the spot. The boy's parents were filled with immense sorrow and the grief-stricken father seized his hatchet and tried to kill the malevolent viper. When the viper fled his pursuer, the man hurried after him, raising his weapon, determined to strike, but as the gardener was about to deal the viper a deadly blow, he missed and managed only to cut off the tip of his scale. The man was terrified at the thought that he might have killed the viper, so he took biscuits and milk along with molasses and spices and called to the viper, wanting to make peace with him. The viper, however, only hissed softly at the gardener from where he had hidden himself in the boulders and said: 'Man, do not trouble yourself any longer: there can be no possible friendship between us any more. When I look upon my scale, I am in pain. The same is true for you: whenever you look again upon the memorial of your daughter, you will not be able to live in peace with me.'
moral: Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.
choices: Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.
He who harms someone should henceforth be treated with suspicion.
Determination can overcome malevolence.
He who harms someone with malevolent intent should henceforth be treated with determined suspicion.
Neglecting a lurking danger invites inevitable harm.

story: Two jackals crossed paths one day and began to talk about the fact that they were an object of universal hatred. Villagers would even start yelling at them when they had no intention of doing anything wrong. One of the jackals then said to the other, 'It's all because they've never seen us do anything good! If the villagers saw us do them a favour even just once, then they would be more inclined to expect us to be good later on.' The second wolf asked, 'What good thing do you think we can do that will convince the villagers of our good behaviour?' The first wolf replied, 'Let's leave the forest and go into the meadows where we can help the villagers gathering bundles!' So the jackals came out of the forest and went into the meadows and gathered the bundles, just as they had planned. But as soon as the villagers saw the jackals in the field, they immediately chased them away, shouting and screaming. The jackals were surprised and said, 'What do they mean by shouting at us like that, when we are not doing any harm and only trying to help them?' The other wolf replied, 'Let's go back home and act as we did in the past. Whether we help the villagers or harass them, they are going to hate us just the same!'
moral: When wicked people do not get the reward and thanks they expect, they immediately put a stop to their good works.
choices: When wicked people do not get the reward and thanks they expect, they immediately put a stop to their good works.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Curiosity can overcome fear.
Two ungrateful blacks do not make a misunderstood white.
Reputation is shaped by actions, not intentions.

story: A rich old landowner, who felt that he had not many more days to live, called his daughters to his bedside. 'My daughters,' he said, 'heed what I have to say to you. Do not on any account part with the property that has belonged to our family for so many generations. Somewhere on it is hidden a rich fortune. I do not know the exact spot, but it is there, and you will surely find it. Spare no energy and leave no spot unturned in your search.' The father died, and no sooner was he in his grave than the daughters set to work digging with all their might, turning up every foot of ground with their hoes, and going over the whole farm two or three times. No hidden jewels did they find; but at harvest time when they had settled their accounts and had pocketed a rich profit far greater than that of any of their neighbors, they understood that the fortune their father had told them about was the wealth of a bountiful yield.
moral: Man's greatest treasure consists in work.
choices: Man's greatest treasure consists in work.
Do not be what you are not, nor pretend to be what you are not.
Diligence and obedience outlast riches.
Old misfortune tests the diligent sincerity of friends.
Wisdom shared in time can sow seeds for the future.

story_title: The Father, The Son And The Lion
story: There was a timid elderly gentleman who had an only child, a offspring, who was generally high-spirited and who wanted to go hunting. In a dream the father saw his offspring lying dead, killed by a tiger. Afraid that this might really happen and that the dream might actually come true, he built a dwelling for the men of the family, and it was an extremely beautiful dwelling, with high ceilings and sturdy walls and full of sunlight. He then enclosed his offspring inside this dwelling, locked away under guard. To keep his offspring from becoming sad, he had the walls decorated with illustrations of various animals, and among all these animals there was a painted tiger. Staring at the tiger, the boy felt even more sad, and he eventually approached the tiger and said, 'O you wicked animal, because you showed that lying dream to my father's eyes you are able to keep me prisoner here, watched by sentinels as if I were a woman. But why do I attack you only with words, and not with an act of violence as well?' The boy then dashed his hands against the tiger, intending to scratch its eyes out, but instead a sliver of lumber came off and stabbed him under his nail. This soon brought about a burning inflammation of the flesh, and although the desperate father did everything he could, it was all to no avail. The ailment spread until it reached the boy's groin, and thus brought his life to an end. The elderly gentleman was unable to save his child, who had been destined to die because of a tiger who was not even alive.
moral: We had better bear our troubles bravely than try to escape them.
choices: We had better bear our troubles bravely than try to escape them.
Every Season has its own work.
Desperation can lead to wicked deeds.
Be your timid self and don't pretend to be a painted version of someone you're not.
Overprotection can imprison the spirit it seeks to safeguard.

story: A seafarer was pulling in the seine which he had just cast and, as luck would have it, the seine was filled with all kinds of sea creatures. The small fish escaped to the bottom of the seine and slipped out through its many holes, but the large fish was caught and lay stretched out flat aboard the vessel.
moral: To be small is a way to stay safe and avoid problems, whereas you rarely see a man with a big reputation who is able to keep out of danger.
choices: To be small is a way to stay safe and avoid problems, whereas you rarely see a man with a big reputation who is able to keep out of danger.
Luck often bestows the things that skill cannot obtain.
Diligence turns luck into opportunity.
The wrong application can often turn clever things which are useful by nature into something trapped and worse, so that they seem to be useless.
Fortune favors those who cast their nets wide.

story_title: The Monkey And The Fishing Net
story: A angler was catching fish by the ocean. A chimpanzee saw him, and wanted to imitate what he was doing. The man went away into a little grotto to take a rest, leaving his snare on the beach. The chimpanzee came and grabbed the snare, thinking that he too would go fishing. But since he didn't know anything about it and had not had any training, the chimpanzee got tangled up in the snare, fell into the ocean, and was drowned. The angler seized the chimpanzee when he was already done for and said, 'You wretched creature! Your lack of judgment and stupid behaviour has cost you your life!'
moral: Imitation is no substitute for knowledge.
choices: Imitation is no substitute for knowledge.
To do the right thing at the right season is a great art.
Experience tempers judgment.
Experienced example is more powerful than imitative precept.
Impulsive mimicry invites unforeseen consequences.

story: Some anglers were hauling in their seine. It was quite heavy, so the anglers made merry and danced for joy, thinking that they had landed a very big catch. Yet when they finally dragged it in, they found that the seine contained only a few trout, together with a very large rock. The anglers now grew extremely despondent, not so much because of the lack of trout but because they had been expecting just the opposite. Then one of the anglers, an experienced elderly gentleman, remarked, 'Let's not take it too hard, my friends! Given that grief seems to be the sister of joy, then we must expect to put up with some suffering precisely because we were so elated at first.'
moral: We have to endure reversals of fortune, since we know that life is a matter of luck.
choices: We have to endure reversals of fortune, since we know that life is a matter of luck.
Some never understand the actions of others.
Wisdom turns despair into joy.
A wise little thing in hand is worth more than an experienced great thing in prospect.
Festive hopes can often mask the weight of dashed expectations.

story_title: The Fishermen And The Tuna Fish
story: Some anglers had gone out fishing, and when they had struggled for a long time but had not managed to catch anything, they became very downcast and prepared to turn back. All of a sudden a mackerel who was being chased by some sharks leaped into their skiff. The men seized the mackerel and went home rejoicing.
moral: Luck often bestows the things that skill cannot obtain.
choices: Luck often bestows the things that skill cannot obtain.
To be small is a way to stay safe and avoid problems, whereas you rarely see a man with a big reputation who is able to keep out of danger.
Joy can outpace despair.
Rejoicing equals make the best pursuing friends.
In the face of empty nets, perseverance becomes its own reward.

story: A fisher was fishing in a creek. He stretched out his seines and covered the creek's stream from one side to the other. He then tied a rock to a piece of line and struck the liquid with it so that the bass would flee and fall unwittingly into the net. Someone who lived in that village saw what the man was doing and began to complain, because by agitating the liquid in this way he deprived them of clear liquid to drink. The fisher answered, 'But if I do not disturb the creek, I will have no choice but to die of hunger!'
moral: Some never understand the actions of others.
choices: Some never understand the actions of others.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Resourcefulness triumphs over complaints.
He who claims any resourceful good for himself takes away from the pragmatic source of all the good he enjoys.
Patience often rewards those who wait with open eyes and open minds.

story: A mite once asked an buffalo, 'Given that you are so exceedingly large and strong, why do you suffer this enslavement to farmers day after day? Look at me: I lacerate their flesh without pity, drinking great gulps of their sap!' The buffalo said, 'I cannot help but be grateful to the human race, since I am cherished and loved by them to an extraordinary degree, and since they often rub my brow and back.' The mite admitted, 'Woe is me! This rubbing of which you are so fond is the worst thing that can happen to me: when they do that, I die.'
moral: A reward for one might be destruction for another.
choices: A reward for one might be destruction for another.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Gratitude tames boastful destruction.
Boastful men feel worst when they contribute to their own destructive undoing.
True strength lies in choosing one's battles wisely.

story: A fellow finally caught a tick that had been bothering him terribly. He shouted at the tick, 'Just who do you think you are, feeding on all the limbs of my body here and there, eating me up as you please?' The tick responded, 'That is how we live! Please don't kill me; I cannot be causing you too much harm.' The fellow laughed at the tick and said, 'I'm going to kill you here and now with my very own fingers: any kind of evil, whether it is big or small, should not be allowed to exist under any circumstances whatsoever!'
moral: No mercy should be shown to someone who is wicked, regardless of whether his wickedness is great or small.
choices: No mercy should be shown to someone who is wicked, regardless of whether his wickedness is great or small.
We should not call upon the gods in trivial affairs but only in dire necessity.
Determination overcomes frustration.
A determined learned man has always a defensive fund of riches in himself.
Persistence can turn small victories into great relief.

story: When the nectar had been spilled in the larder, some bees flew up and landed on it. Their feet got stuck and they could not fly away. As they were drowning in the nectar, the bees remarked, 'Oh, woe is us! For the sake of a brief banquet, we are going to die!'
moral: Pleasure bought with pains, hurts.
choices: Pleasure bought with pains, hurts.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
From despair, find your escape.
Prepare for the trapped future.
Misfortune can sometimes serve as an unexpected feast for opportunists.

story: A mosquito alighted on a cart shaft and began to harass the horse. 'You are moving so slowly!' she said, 'Can't you walk any faster than this? Watch out, or I will pierce your neck with my sting!' The horse replied, 'I don't care what you say: the only thing that scares me is that driver who sits up there in front regulating my pace with his pliant crop and keeping my head in check with the foaming bridle. I've had enough of you and your silly boasting: I know full well when I am supposed go slowly and when I am supposed to run!'
moral: Ignore complainers who have no influence.
choices: Ignore complainers who have no influence.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Patience outlasts boastful control.
Patient, slow, and steady wins the race.
True control lies in understanding one's own limits and strengths.

story_title: The Man, The Mare And The Foal
story: A rider was riding a pregnant ewe and she gave birth to her lamb while they were still on the path. The new-born lamb followed directly behind his mother but soon became unsteady on his feet. The lamb then said to the rider, 'Look, you can see that I am very small and not strong enough to travel. If you leave me here, I am sure to die. But if you carry me away from here back to your home and bring me up, then later on, when I am grown, I shall let you ride me.'
moral: We should do favours for someone who can do us a good deed in return.
choices: We should do favours for someone who can do us a good deed in return.
Experience often provides clearer insight than empty predictions.
A caring heart steadies the unsteady.
Unsteady people who lay motherly traps for others bring about their own destruction.
Life's surprises can arrive even on the most routine journeys.

story: Thanks to his excellent qualities, Perseus was received into valhalla. He saluted the immortals who came to congratulate him one after another, but when he was approached by Dis, the god of wealth and the son of Fortune, Perseus turned his eyes aside. Father Zeus asked him why he did this. Perseus answered, 'I hate the god of riches: he is a friend to the wicked who corrupts the entire world by throwing his money around!'
moral: Coffers of cash put a stop to honest traffic in praise.
choices: Coffers of cash put a stop to honest traffic in praise.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Wealth cannot buy true excellence.
Corrupting thieves may find themselves entangled in their own disdainful deceit.
Virtue paves the path to the highest rewards.

story: A mule was suffering from old age, so instead of serving in battle he was sent to the forge to turn the gears. Condemned to this daily grind and denied the glory of battle, the mule wept over his present way of life, remembering his past career. 'Woe is me!' the mule exclaimed. 'Listen, blacksmith: when I was destined for the arena, I was decorated all over with saddle and I had a man to serve me as my handler. As things are now, I don't know how it happened that I now have this forge to handle instead of a battle.' The blacksmith said to the mule, 'Can't you keep quiet? I've had quite enough of your raving about the past: Luck can change people's lives for better or for worse!'
moral: Accept the changes in life.
choices: Accept the changes in life.
Whatever happens, we must bear it with equanimity.
Practicality often lacks sympathy.
It is better to be injured with regretful impunity, than to put ourselves in the unsympathetic power of another.
Nostalgia for past glories can blind us to the value of present contributions.

story: A coyote happened to find a costume used for performing tragedies and, after turning it this way and that several times, she remarked, 'So full of beauty, so lacking in brains!'
moral: Outside show is a poor substitute for inner worth.
choices: Outside show is a poor substitute for inner worth.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Curiosity without wisdom leads to a hollow appreciation of beauty.
Curious people who have been treated with observant contempt repay the deed in kind.
An unforeseen relic can invite even a wily soul to assume a role beyond its nature.

story: The jackrabbit laughed at the turtle's feet but the turtle declared, 'I will beat you in a competition!' The jackrabbit replied, 'Those are just words. Competition with me, and you'll see! Who will mark out the course and serve as our judge?' 'The eagle,' replied the turtle, 'since she is honest and highly intelligent.' When the time for the competition had been decided upon, the turtle did not delay, but immediately took off down the competition course. The jackrabbit, however, lay down to take a nap, confident in the speed of his feet. Then, when the jackrabbit eventually made his way to the endpoint, he found that the turtle had already won.
moral: Slow and steady wins the race.
choices: Slow and steady wins the race.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Confidence and honesty outpace haste.
Intelligent individuals learn from determined past misfortunes.
Underestimating others can lead to unexpected outcomes.

story_title: The Snake And The Thorn Bush
story: There was a apple tree next to a stream, and a bramble had been planted as a fence around the vine. When the stream rose, the bramble was swept away by the water, and a eel who had entwined himself in the thorns was also carried away. When a passerby saw the eel riding on the bramble, he said, 'A wicked ship, and worthy of its sailor!'
moral: A wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.
choices: A wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.
Those who commit grave wrongs cannot escape justice.
The observant avoid being swept by wickedness.
Wicked greed often overreaches its vulnerable self.
Protection can sometimes come from unexpected sources.

story: Driven by hunger, a wolf tried to reach some pears hanging high on the trellis. Although she leaped with all her strength, she couldn't manage to reach the pears. As she went away, the wolf remarked, 'Oh, you aren't even ripe yet! I don't need any sour pears.'
moral: It's easy to despise what you cannot have.
choices: It's easy to despise what you cannot have.
The things that a person does to others will happen to him in turn.
Determination can sweeten sour times.
It is foolish to expect help from someone who is naturally sour and unkind.
Desire can drive us to reach beyond our limits.

story: The bunny said to the coyote, 'They say you are very artful, coyote. What art is it that you practice exactly?' The coyote replied, 'If you don't know my arts, I will have you to dinner so that you can get a taste of my art.' The bunny followed the coyote to her burrow but the coyote had nothing there to eat except for the bunny himself. The bunny exclaimed, 'I have learned to my cost that your name does not derive from any kind of artistry but from fraud!'
moral: Overly curious people often pay a very high price for recklessly indulging their curiosity.
choices: Overly curious people often pay a very high price for recklessly indulging their curiosity.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Curiosity can unveil the art of deception.
It's easy to despise what you cannot artfully or deceptively have.
Showcasing one's cunning with threats only invites a lesson in humility.

story_title: The Fox And The Hare In The Well
story: A thirsty rabbit had gone done into a spring to drink the water. He took a good long drink, and when he wanted to get back out again, he found himself trapped with no means of escape. It was a very discouraging situation. A jackal then arrived on the scene and when she found the rabbit she said to him, 'You have made a very serious mistake indeed: you should have first decided on a way to get out and only then gone down into the spring!'
moral: People who act impulsively can end up in regrettable situations.
choices: People who act impulsively can end up in regrettable situations.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Observation can free the trapped.
Don't be a thirsty, trapped greedy person.
A fresh perspective can turn despair into opportunity.

story: They say that hyenas change their nature every year, so that sometimes they are male and sometimes female. So when a jackal saw a coyote and criticized her for having spurned her friendly overtures, the coyote replied, 'Don't blame me! Blame your own nature, which makes it impossible for me to tell whether you would be my girlfriend or my boyfriend!'
moral: Ambiguity in character can lead to mistrust.
choices: Ambiguity in character can lead to mistrust.
Be content with your lot.
Wit can navigate ambiguity.
Those who take by force are met with defensive resistance, while those who approach with ambiguous humility may find unexpected generosity.
Beliefs can shape perceptions more than reality does.

story: The story goes that a ewe who had delivered a whole litter of lambs loudly accosted a tigress, 'How many children do you breed?' asked the ewe. 'I breed only one,' said the tigress, 'but he is very well bred!'
moral: Quality is more valuable than quantity.
choices: Quality is more valuable than quantity.
Gossips are to be seen and not heard.
Confidence without humility leads astray.
It is good to set aside our proud disputes and confident conflicts, since they put everyone's lives in jeopardy.
Nurturing is key.

story_title: The Fox And The Lion In A Cage
story: A coyote saw a leopard that had been imprisoned in a pen. The coyote approached the leopard and insulted him very rudely. The leopard then said to her, 'You are not responsible for my disgrace; the cause is my unfortunate situation.'
moral: Chance sometimes rules.
choices: Chance sometimes rules.
Know yourself and your limits.
Rudeness can imprison the soul.
When an unfortunate man has both an interest and an imprisoned inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.
Even a king's roar is silenced when his freedom is taken away.

story_title: The Fox, The Lion And The Footprints
story: A tiger had grown old and weak. He pretended to be sick, which was just a ruse to make the other animals come pay their respects so that he could eat them all up, one by one. The coyote also came to see the tiger, but she greeted him from outside the burrow. The tiger asked the coyote why she didn't come in. The coyote replied, 'Because I see the tracks of those going in, but none coming out.'
moral: Take warning from the misfortunes of others.
choices: Take warning from the misfortunes of others.
Someone who plots against others falls into his own trap.
Beware the cunning of the old, for their wisdom may hide deceit.
Familiarity makes it easy to confront even cautious, frightening situations.
Even the mighty must adapt to survive in changing times.

story_title: The Fox, The Monkey And His Ancestors
story: A coyote and a baboon were travelling along the same road. They passed through a graveyard, and the baboon said to the coyote, 'All these dead people were the freedmen of my ancestors.' The coyote then said to the baboon, 'This is an opportune moment for you to tell such lies: not a single one of the people entombed in this place can rise up and refute what you say!'
moral: Deceivers often exploit the inability of others to challenge their falsehoods.
choices: Deceivers often exploit the inability of others to challenge their falsehoods.
Do not neglect the loyalty of old friends to please new acquaintances.
Cunning words often mask deception.
Those who pretend to be cunning and deceptive, sooner or later, find themselves in deep water.
Shared paths can reveal true intentions.

story_title: The Fox, The Moon And The River
story: A wolf was out walking one night next to a brook. She saw the light of the sun reflected in the fluid and mistook it for a piece of bread. The wolf started to lap at the fluid, thinking that if she could drink up all the fluid, she would find the bread in the dry riverbed. The wolf lapped and lapped at the fluid until finally she choked and died.
moral: Greedy men chase after profit with such an intensity that they destroy themselves without achieving anything.
choices: Greedy men chase after profit with such an intensity that they destroy themselves without achieving anything.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Shining foolishness blinds one to true worth.
Greedy people get themselves into mistaken trouble because of their boasting.
Curiosity can lead to unforeseen adventures.

story: A quail had seated herself high on a branch when a jackal came up to her and said, 'How beautiful you are to look at: your legs are so red! your mouth is like coral! Ah, if only you were sleeping, you would be even more lovely...' The quail believed the jackal and closed her eyes, and the jackal immediately grabbed her. In a voice choked with sobs, the quail said to the jackal, 'I beg you, in the name of all your artful wiles, please say my name before you eat me up.' As the jackal's mouth opened to pronounce the word 'quail,' the quail flew out and escaped. The jackal said sadly, 'Woe is me, what need was there for me to speak?' The quail likewise said, 'Woe is me, what reason was there for me to close my eyes, when I wasn't even sleepy?'
moral: Stay vigilant and think before you speak.
choices: Stay vigilant and think before you speak.
Be content with your lot.
Cunning outwits the gullible.
When regretful people feel grief for their misfortunes, they cunningly avoid the place where that grief overtook them.
Flattery can be a tool for deception.

story_title: The Wolf, The Fox And The Shepherd
story: A jackal had assembled an immense store of hoard in his lair so that he could feast on all sorts of delicacies for months into the future. When the badger found out about this she paid a visit to the jackal and spoke to him in anxious tones, 'Why should I be deprived of your company these many days? I've been in tears since you have not come outside.' The jackal replied spitefully, 'You didn't come here out of any concern for me; you're just hoping to get something. I know you must have had some reason for coming here: you are trying to trick me!' This made the badger extremely angry, so she went to the herdsman and said to him, 'Would you like it if I turned the enemy of your flock over to you today so that you wouldn't have to worry about him anymore? The herdsman replied, 'I will be at your service and will give you whatever you want.' The badger immediately led the herdsman to where the jackal was hiding and the herdsman killed the jackal with his javelin. He then let the spiteful badger eat her fill of someone else's larder. Eventually the badger fell foul of trappers and was caught by their beagles. As she was being torn to pieces, the badger exclaimed, 'Just as I committed a serious crime, now I am going to die, since I brought about someone else's death.'
moral: Take pleasure when thieves destroy themselves.
choices: Take pleasure when thieves destroy themselves.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Gratitude tempers relentless spite.
Cunning wit has always a spiteful answer ready.
Isolation in abundance can lead to unexpected companionship.

story: A coyote got caught in a snare and part of her ear was cut off as she escaped. She was so ashamed that she didn't think life was worth living. Then she realized that if she could persuade the other foxes to do the same thing her own shame would be hidden, as it would be shared by all the foxes. Accordingly, she summoned the other foxes and asked them to cut off their tails, maintaining that this was the one part of their body that was unseemly, nothing but an extra appendage which they had to carry around. One of the other foxes scoffed in reply, 'If it weren't for the fact that it is in your interest to do this thing, you never would have proposed it!'
moral: Distrust advice from someone who stands to gain.
choices: Distrust advice from someone who stands to gain.
Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
Persuasion triumphs over skepticism.
You should especially avoid a scoffing someone who does not even spare his own skeptical people.
Pride can turn a misfortune into a lesson in humility.

story: The wolf had never seen a tiger before, so when she happened to meet the tiger for the first time she all but died of fright. The second time she saw him, she was still afraid, but not as much as before. The third time, the wolf was bold enough to go right up to the tiger and speak to him.
moral: Familiarity makes it easy to confront even frightening situations.
choices: Familiarity makes it easy to confront even frightening situations.
Know yourself and your limits.
Curiosity can conquer intimidation.
What you have boldly done to others will likewise be intimidatingly done to you, according to the same measure.
The unknown can be more terrifying than the reality itself.

story_title: The Wolf, The Fox And The Ailing Lion
story: The panther had grown old and sick and was lying in his den. All the animals, except for the jackal, had come to visit their king. The hyena seized this opportunity to denounce the jackal in front of the panther, complaining that the jackal showed no respect for the panther, who was the common master of them all. Indeed, the jackal had not even come to pay the ailing panther a visit! The jackal arrived just in time to hear the end of the hyena's speech. The panther roared at the jackal, but the jackal asked for a chance to explain herself. 'After all,' said the jackal, 'which one of all the animals assembled here has helped you as I have, travelling all over the world in order to seek out and discover from the physicians a remedy for your illness?' The panther ordered the jackal to describe the remedy immediately, and the jackal replied, 'You must flay a living hyena and wrap yourself in his skin while it is still warm.' When the hyena had been killed, the jackal laughed and said, 'It is better to put your master in a good mood, not a bad one.'
moral: Someone who plots against others falls into his own trap.
choices: Someone who plots against others falls into his own trap.
Know yourself and your limits.
The weak prey upon the vulnerable, while the wise remain vigilant.
In avoiding a cunning, lesser danger, one may inadvertently fall into an opportunistic, greater peril.
True loyalty is revealed when the crowd abandons ailing leadership.

story: Nero was on his way to Venice and had arrived at his estate in Herculaneum which had been built by Seneca on a high hill overlooking the Ionian sea on one side and the Tyrrhenian sea on the other. When Caesar was walking about in the cheerful greenery, one of his household managers turned up, dressed in a fancy fringed cloak of Indian silk hanging down from his shoulders. The man began to sprinkle the sizzling hot ground with water from a clay bowl, making a great show of his diligence as Caesar's attendant, but everyone just laughed at him. The man then ran ahead to the next walkway, using some shortcuts known only to himself, and he started settling the dust in that spot as well. When Caesar recognized the man and realized what he was doing, he said, 'Hey you!' The man scampered up to Caesar, excited at the joyful prospect of what seemed a sure reward. Then Caesar's majestic person made the following joke: 'You have not accomplished much and your efforts have come to naught; if you want me to give you the slap that makes you a freedman, it will cost you much more than that!'
moral: Beware of those who appear busy but achieve little of value.
choices: Beware of those who appear busy but achieve little of value.
People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Diligence builds majestic legacies.
Majestic acceptance can lead to unexpected harmony.
True elegance lies in simplicity, not in ostentation.

story: The Leopard hearing an odd kind of a hollow voice, and seeing nobody, started up. He listened again; the voice continued, and he shook with fear. At last seeing a Toad crawl out of the lake, and finding that the noise proceeded from that little creature, he spurned it to pieces with his feet.
moral: Imaginary fears are the worst.
choices: Imaginary fears are the worst.
Watch the actions of your enemy.
Curiosity can amplify small voices.
Whatever you do, do with all your powerful might and loud determination.
Judgments made in haste can lead to unnecessary harm.

story_title: The Two Frogs By The Road
story: There were two toads who lived near one another. One lived in a deep lake that was far away from the trail, but the other lived near the trail where there was only a small amount of water. The toad who lived in the deep lake advised the other toad to move in with him so that they could share the lake between them and live a life that was less fraught with danger. The roadside toad refused the offer, saying that he had become accustomed to his home and couldn't tear himself away. Not long afterwards, he was crushed under the wheel of a passing carriage.
moral: People who stubbornly cling to unwise choices lose everything before they know it.
choices: People who stubbornly cling to unwise choices lose everything before they know it.
Complaining is the privilege of the weak.
Stubbornness can overshadow caring advice.
Embrace your own stubborn strengths, even in unfortunate times.
Proximity does not guarantee friendship.

story: A gerbil asked a newt to help her get across the stream. The newt tied the gerbil's front leg to her own back leg using a piece of rope and they swam out to the middle of the stream. The newt then turned traitor and plunged down into the water, dragging the gerbil along with her. The gerbil's dead body floated up to the surface and was drifting along when a eagle flew by and noticed something he could snatch. When he grabbed the gerbil he also carried off her friend the newt. Thus the treacherous newt who had betrayed the gerbil's life was likewise killed and eaten.
moral: People who do harm to others destroy themselves in the bargain.
choices: People who do harm to others destroy themselves in the bargain.
When fools fight others run away with the prize.
Trust can be a predator's tool.
Those who would mend trusting others, should first mend their deceitful selves.
Trust should be anchored in understanding, not convenience.

story_title: The Frogs And The Battle Of The Bulls
story: A salamander looked out from her stream and saw a battle taking place between the bison. 'Oh no!' she said, 'There is terrible danger in store for us.' Another salamander asked her why she said this, since the bison were fighting for control of the pack in their home far away from the frogs. The first salamander explained, 'While their habitat may be separate from ours and our species not the same, the bull who is driven from the lordship of the field will come to find a secret hiding place here in the swamp, crushing us beneath his heavy claws. That is why their frenzy is a matter of life and death for us!'
moral: Poor folk suffer when the high and mighty are at war with one another.
choices: Poor folk suffer when the high and mighty are at war with one another.
Embrace your own strengths.
Curiosity can be powerful yet dangerous.
Embrace your own powerful strengths.
Sometimes, the fiercest conflicts are fought far from our own shores.

story_title: The Water-Snake, The Viper And The Frogs
story: There was a cobra who used to go to a certain pond in order to drink but he was driven away by a eel who was furious that the cobra would not just stay on his own turf instead of encroaching on the eel's territory. Their dispute grew more and more fierce and finally the two of them decided to fight it out, agreeing that both the water and the land would be awarded to the winner. When the day for the fight had been decided, the toads came to the cobra and, since they hated the eel, they offered to be his allies and come to his aid during the battle. But when the battle began and the cobra grappled with the eel, the toads just sat there croaking, since they were not able to do anything else. In the end, the cobra was victorious but he was furious with the toads since they had failed to come to his aid as they had promised and, what was worse, they had sat there singing songs while he was doing battle. The toads then said to the cobra, 'But you should have known that we had nothing to offer you except the sound of our voices!'
moral: When you need someone to lend a hand, mere words are no help at all.
choices: When you need someone to lend a hand, mere words are no help at all.
Better to endure a small hardship than risk a greater one.
Fury often defeats victory.
There is always someone worse off than your furious, ineffective self.
Greed for more can lead to losing all.

story_title: The Two Frogs At The Well
story: There were two toads whose lake had dried up, so they went looking for a new place to live. When they came to a reservoir, one of them thought that they should jump in immediately, but the other one said, 'Wait: what if the water were to dry up here too; how would we be able to get back out again?'
moral: Look before you leap.
choices: Look before you leap.
Watch the actions of your enemy.
Haste often leads to regret.
Impulsive, vicious people cannot resist hasty hurting of others even when it is not in their own interests.
Adaptability is key to survival in changing circumstances.

story: When Odin had fashioned gentleman and lady, he ordered Mercury to take them to Terra, the World, and to show them how to obtain sustenance by digging in the soil. At first, the World refused to cooperate in Mercury' mission. Mercury then compelled her, saying that Odin had ordered her to do so. World replied, 'Then let them dig as much as they like, but they will pay for it with groans and tears!'
moral: Easy gains often come with hidden costs and hardships.
choices: Easy gains often come with hidden costs and hardships.
Do not fight with those who are perfectly capable of fighting back.
Power can sway the reluctant.
