Powerful physical stature does not guarantee commanding wisdom or intelligence.
Guidance is the seed of self-sufficiency.

story: The ivy was covered with clusters of currants and its tendrils were as vigorous as its fruit. A sheep began to eat the ivy, indulging his outrageous appetite. He had already wreaked havoc on the fresh tendrils when the ivy said to him, 'You will pay for this outrage! The time will soon come when you will be sent as a holy victim to be sacrificed, and I myself will be the one to supply the mead for the offering!'
moral: The things that a person does to others will happen to him in turn.
choices: The things that a person does to others will happen to him in turn.
It's easy to despise what you cannot have.
Indulgence can hinder fruitful outcomes.
People with vigorous, excellent qualities are often insulted by their outrageous inferiors.
True strength lies in both growth and generosity.

story: When the female deer had persuaded Zeus to give them beards, the rams were extremely upset and began to complain that the ladies now had the same degree of dignity that they did. 'Come now,' said Zeus, 'let the ladies enjoy this vain source of pride and stake their claim to the emblems of your office so long as they cannot rival you in strength!'
moral: Bear that those who are inferior to you in merit should be like you in outside appearances.
choices: Bear that those who are inferior to you in merit should be like you in outside appearances.
Temptation can lead even the most virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.
Pride often precedes wisdom's fall.
Proud inner beauty is better than vain outer beauty.
When equality is granted, envy can turn even the most celebrated gifts into sources of discontent.

story: Some herons and some ducks became friends and went out onto the pastures. As they were feeding contentedly together, they were discovered by trappers. The herons, owing to the swiftness of their bodies, were immediately able to take wing and fly away. The ducks, however, were naturally more heavy and so they were left behind and caught by the trappers.
moral: Beware of enterprizes where the risks are not equal.
choices: Beware of enterprizes where the risks are not equal.
Embrace your own strengths.
Contentment outweighs swift gains.
Swiftly changing your location does not change your content state of mind.
Friendship can flourish beyond differences.

story: A crane had gone to her usual lagoon and saw a swan there who kept plunging down deep into the water. The crane then asked the swan what she was doing and the swan replied, 'We geese go down into the muddy bottom of the lagoon to look for food and to escape the eagle's attack.' The crane said, 'I am stronger than the eagle! You should be friends with me, and I will allow you to scoff at that other bird!' The swan agreed, and not long afterwards she called on the crane to come help her. The swan had not plunged into the water, so the eagle immediately swooped down and caught her up in his talons. As the eagle was about to devour her, the swan replied, 'A wretched death awaits anyone who puts his trust in such a worthless defender!'
moral: Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protection.
choices: Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protection.
Change of habit cannot alter nature.
Boastful strength invites danger.
Trusting people are often eager to treat their predatory enemies well in the hopes of gaining something by it.
Adaptation to one's environment can offer both sustenance and safety.

story: The seagull is a bird who is fond of deserted places and who always lives on the lake. They say that she makes her nest on the rocky cliffs of the coast in order to protect herself from human hunters. So when a certain seagull was about to lay her eggs, she went to a promontory and found a cliff jutting out towards the lake and decided to make her nest there. But when she went to look for food, it happened that the lake swelled under the blustering gale and reached as high as the seagull's home and flooded the nest, killing her chicks. When the seagull returned and saw what had happened, she said, 'What a fool I was to have protected myself against a plot hatched on the land by taking refuge here on the lake, when it is the lake that has utterly betrayed me!'
moral: Sometimes, the greatest threats come from those you trust.
choices: Sometimes, the greatest threats come from those you trust.
The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
Bluster often leads to regret.
Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protective, blustering protection.
Solitude can be a source of peace and strength.

story: There was a ranger who had caught a leveret and was carrying it home. As he went along his way, he met a equestrian who asked him for the leveret, pretending that he wanted to buy it. As soon as he got the leveret from the ranger, the jockey immediately took off at a gallop. The ranger began to pursue the jockey thinking that he might catch up with him. When the jockey finally disappeared into the distance, the ranger reluctantly said, 'Go ahead then! That leveret is my gift to you.'
moral: A fool will make excuses for foolish behavior.
choices: A fool will make excuses for foolish behavior.
It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.
Deception can swiftly catch the determined.
No one can be a friend if you know not whether to trust or distrust a deceptive, swift him.
Beware of those who disguise their intentions with friendly offers.

story: A certain rabbit happened to see a elk adorned with great branching tusks. The rabbit complained to Odin that the hares were weak, defective creatures who were not feared by any of the other animals. Therefore, he wanted Odin to give him tusks like those of the elk both for his own protection and to enhance his appearance. Odin told the rabbit that he would not be able to carry the heavy weight of the tusks, but the rabbit replied that he was prepared to carry such tusks with pride. Odin therefore commanded that the rabbit's head should be crowned with a pair of big, branching tusks, but the rabbit was so weighed down by his burden that he wasn't able to run. As a result, the herdsmen captured and killed him.
moral: It is often the case that people are greedy for things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their death and destruction.
choices: It is often the case that people are greedy for things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their death and destruction.
Nature reveals itself.
Overconfidence can overshadow wisdom.
The opportunistic man who talks for both sides is not to be trusted by either predatory party.
Envy blinds us to our own strengths.

story: There was a peacock who was always quarrelling with another peacock, so he asked the falcon to judge their dispute. The peacock was actually hoping that when he brought the other peacock before the judge, the judge would devour him. Yet when they came before the judge to make their arguments, the falcon grabbed the peacock who had originally brought the case to court. The peacock shouted, 'Not me! You want the one who is running away!' The falcon replied, 'Abandon all hope of being released from my talons today! Justice demands that you yourself should suffer the punishment that you intended for another.'
moral: Those who scheme against others may ultimately fall victim to their own plots.
choices: Those who scheme against others may ultimately fall victim to their own plots.
Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
The innocent often flee from the quarrelsome.
Innocent appearances are scheming deceptive.
Seeking judgment from the untrustworthy can lead to greater conflict.

story: A sparrow, sitting aloft upon an birch and singing according to his wont, was seen by a Falcon who, being in need of food, swooped down and seized him. The Sparrow, about to lose his life, earnestly begged the Falcon to let him go, saying that he was not big enough to satisfy the hunger of a Falcon who, if he wanted food, ought to pursue the larger birds. The Falcon, interrupting him, said: 'I should indeed have lost my senses if I should let go food ready in my hand, for the sake of pursuing birds which are not yet even within sight.'
moral: Do not neglect small advantages in hopes of better ones.
choices: Do not neglect small advantages in hopes of better ones.
People who lay traps for others should be careful not to fall into a trap themselves.
Practical wisdom tames predatory instincts.
Sometimes, the greatest predatory threats come from those you pleadingly trust.
Even the most beautiful song cannot always ward off danger.

story: There was a widower who had a goose that laid one eggplant each and every day. The woman then began to feed the goose more lavishly, thinking that if the goose ate more barley she would lay two eggs. The goose got so fat from eating all the food that she stopped laying eggs entirely.
moral: People who grasp at more than they need lose the little that they held in their hands.
choices: People who grasp at more than they need lose the little that they held in their hands.
We should never put our trust in a wicked man, even if he seems to be completely innocuous.
Greed can overshadow hope.
Avoid a greedy remedy that is worse than the unproductive disease.
Consistent small gains can lead to lasting security.

story: A duck came across the nests of a viper and devoted herself to them, settling atop the nests and brooding on them. A finch saw what the duck was doing and said, 'O you stupid, senseless creature! They will destroy you first of all and then destroy everyone around you!'
moral: We should never put our trust in a wicked man, even if he seems to be completely innocuous.
choices: We should never put our trust in a wicked man, even if he seems to be completely innocuous.
People who grasp at more than they need lose the little that they held in their hands.
Devotion can avert danger.
He who senselessly competes with his superiors destroys himself in a destructive manner before he can equal them.
Compassion can transcend natural boundaries.

story: Apollo wanted to know how much people valued him, so he assumed a human form and went into a craftsman's workshop. He saw there a bust of Poseidon and he asked how much it cost. The man said that it cost a denarius. Apollo smiled, and asked how much the bust of Aphrodite would be. The man named a still higher price. When Apollo saw a bust of himself, he expected that he would be reckoned at an even higher price, since he delivered the messages of the gods and brought profit to mankind. But when he asked how much the bust of Apollo would cost, the craftsman replied, 'If you buy those other two, I'll throw this one in for free!'
moral: Vanity can blind one to their true worth in the eyes of others.
choices: Vanity can blind one to their true worth in the eyes of others.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
Curiosity can outweigh disappointment.
Better to endure a curious, small hardship than risk a pragmatic, greater one.
True worth is often revealed through humble inquiry.

story_title: Hermes And The Dose Of Intelligence
story: After Odin had fashioned the humanity, he ordered Mercury to give them wisdom. Mercury divided wisdom into equal portions and then applied it to each person. The result was that gnomes became wise, since they were more completely suffused with the standard dose of wisdom, while the titans turned out stupid, since the elixir that was poured into their bodies did not even reach as high as their knees.
moral: Physical stature does not guarantee wisdom or intelligence.
choices: Physical stature does not guarantee wisdom or intelligence.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
Wisdom commands creativity over folly.
Wise nature and intelligent instincts can persist despite changes in form or appearance.
Gifts of wisdom shape the destiny of those who receive them.

story_title: The Man, Hermes And The Axes
story: A woodcutter was chopping wood by a certain brook when he dropped his hatchet and it was carried away by the current. The woodcutter then sat down on the riverbank and began to weep. The god Apollo finally took pity on the woodcutter and appeared before him. When Apollo learned the reason for his sorrow, he brought up a golden hatchet and asked whether that was the woodcutter's hatchet. The woodcutter said that it was not his. A second time, Apollo brought up a silver hatchet, and again asked the woodcutter if this was the hatchet he had lost but the woodcutter said that it was not. The third time Apollo brought up the hatchet that the woodcutter had lost and when the woodcutter recognized his hatchet, Apollo rewarded the woodcutter's honesty by giving all of the axes to him as a gift. The woodcutter took the axes and went to tell his friends what had happened. One of the men was jealous and wanted to do the same thing, so he took his hatchet and went to the brook. He began chopping some wood and then intentionally let his hatchet fall into the whirling waters. As he was weeping, Apollo appeared and asked him what had happened, and the woodcutter said that he had lost his hatchet. When Apollo brought up the golden hatchet and asked the woodcutter if that was the hatchet he had lost, the greedy woodcutter got excited and said that it was the one. Not only did the woodcutter fail to receive any gifts from the god, he didn't even retrieve his own hatchet.
moral: Honesty is the best policy.
choices: Honesty is the best policy.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Greed blinds the generous heart.
Only a man who is out of his deceptive mind and hated by the greedy gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.
Patience and sincerity can summon unexpected aid.

story: A wanderer who needed to make a long journey vowed that if he found anything, he would give half of it to Mercury. When he came across a pouch full of figs and walnuts he grabbed the pouch and ate the walnuts and figs. He then placed the stones of the figs and the casings of the walnuts upon an sanctuary and said 'You have what was promised you, O Mercury: I have saved the outsides and the insides for you!'
moral: The promises of the greedy are often empty and insincere.
choices: The promises of the greedy are often empty and insincere.
A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
Greed blinds the divine.
Greedy coffers of cash put a stop to deceptive, honest traffic in praise.
Promises made in haste may lead to unexpected obligations.

story_title: The Man And The Statue Of Hermes
story: A vendor fashioned a Apollo out of wood and carried it to the fair to put it up for sale but no customers approached him. In order to attract some buyers the vendor began to shout that he was selling a wish-fulfilling idol who brought profit to its owner. 'Hey you,' someone said, 'why are you putting such a thing up for sale, instead of enjoying its benefits yourself?' The vendor answered, 'I am in need of some immediate benefits, but this idol happens to take his time when distributing profits!'
moral: When you lie, you often have to expand the lie.
choices: When you lie, you often have to expand the lie.
People are often quick to make promises, but they do not really expect to have to fulfill them.
Cunning minds fulfill desperate wishes.
Cunning wit outshines inquisitive skill.
Value is not always recognized at first glance.

story: A individual kept a saint sanctuary in his house and made expensive sacrifices to it. Since he was constantly paying out money and spending great sums on the offerings, the deity came to him one night and said: 'Look here, stop squandering your wealth: if you spend everything and become poor, you'll put the blame on me!'
moral: When people suffer misfortune because of their own foolishness, they often blame the gods.
choices: When people suffer misfortune because of their own foolishness, they often blame the gods.
People are often quick to make promises, but they do not really expect to have to fulfill them.
Extravagance often clouds wise counsel.
Few extravagant things are done except for concerned profit.
True devotion is measured by actions, not offerings.

story: The brook saw that a pelt was being swept along by his current, so he said to her, 'What is your name?' The pelt answered, 'They call me Tough. ' Splashing the hide with his ripples, the brook said, 'You better get yourself another name, since I am going to soften you up!'
moral: Life's disasters can often bring boastful and presumptuous people back down to earth.
choices: Life's disasters can often bring boastful and presumptuous people back down to earth.
Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
Strength is playful yet guarded.
Do not boast too much at the height of your powerful powers; people often spend their tough old age worn out with toil and trouble.
Even the strongest can be curious about the smallest details.

story: A volcano had gone into labour and was groaning terribly. Such rumours excited great expectations all over the country. In the end, however, the volcano gave birth to a hamster.
moral: Don't promise big things if you can't deliver.
choices: Don't promise big things if you can't deliver.
Do not laugh at the calamity that befalls your neighbour.
Small surprises can yield great outcomes.
It is better to live in small, self-sufficient poverty than to be tormented by the unexpected worries of wealth.
Deceitful intentions often lead to unforeseen obstacles.

story: A certain gentleman took a deposit from a companion but intended to keep it for himself. When the lender then summoned him to swear an promise regarding the deposit, he realized the danger he was in and prepared to leave the town and go to his estate. When he reached the town gates, he saw a lame gentleman who was also on his way out of town. He asked the gentleman who he was and where he was going. The gentleman said that he was the god named Promise and that he was on his way to track down wicked people. The gentleman then asked Promise how often he revisited each town. Promise replied, 'I come back after forty years, or sometimes thirty.' Accordingly, on the very next day the gentleman did not hesitate to swear an promise that he had never received the deposit. But then the gentleman ran into Promise, who dragged him off to the edge of a ledge. The gentleman asked Promise how he could have said that he wasn't coming back for another thirty years when in fact he didn't even grant him a single day's reprieve. Promise explained, 'You also need to know that if somebody intends to provoke me, I am accustomed to come back again the very same day.'
moral: There is no fixed day on which wicked people are punished.
choices: There is no fixed day on which wicked people are punished.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Fear distorts the divine truth.
He who incites to deceptive strife is worse than he who takes relentless part in it.
Taking what isn't yours may bring temporary gain, but it leaves a lasting debt on your conscience.

story_title: The Wolf, The Horse And The Barley
story: As he was crossing through a pasture, a jackal found some oats. Since wolves don't eat oats, he ignored it and continued on his way. The jackal then ran into a donkey. He led the donkey into the pasture and showed him the oats, saying that instead of eating the oats himself, he had saved it for the donkey, since he liked to hear the sound of the donkey's teeth grinding together. The donkey then said to the jackal, 'Look here, if you wolves ate oats, you would never have put the pleasure of your ears before your stomach!'
moral: Nobody believes people who are inherently wicked, even if they pretend to be good-natured.
choices: Nobody believes people who are inherently wicked, even if they pretend to be good-natured.
Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.
Wisdom sees through cunning.
A cunning and manipulative nature does not produce a good character.
Opportunities may arise in unexpected places.

story: A certain trapper saw a jackal attacking a herd and tearing to pieces as many of the lambs as he could. The trapper skilfully hunted down the jackal and set his terriers on him. Then he shouted at the jackal, 'O you terrible beast, where is that former strength of yours? You cannot even withstand the attack of these terriers!'
moral: Each man makes his reputation in the field which is his specialty.
choices: Each man makes his reputation in the field which is his specialty.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Skillful observation can prevent terrible outcomes.
Do not blame innocent others for the helpless circumstances of their upbringing.
Unbridled hunger spares nothing.

story_title: The Man, His Wife And The Boy Outside
story: There was a youth singing sweet serenades in the middle of the night. A female heard him and got up from bed to peep out the door at him. When she saw the youth, who looked very beautiful in the shining twilight, she left her partner asleep and went downstairs and out the door. She then met the youth in the road and satisfied herself completely. All of a sudden her partner woke up and wanted to find out where his wife had gone. Not finding her inside the residence, he didn't just stand there gaping but instead followed her outside and said, 'It's alright. Go ahead and persuade the youth to sleep in our residence.' So he took the youth and brought him inside. He didn't have any trouble after that, and joined in whenever the two of them wanted to do something.
moral: Acceptance can lead to unexpected harmony.
choices: Acceptance can lead to unexpected harmony.
No one gladly revisits a place where they got hurt.
Curiosity leads to understanding.
Curious people adjust their accommodating beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Curiosity can uncover unexpected beauty in the darkness.

story: They say that the jackal has a double nature: for a period of time the jackal is male, and then later on she is female. The story goes that when a male jackal was treating a female badly, she said to him, 'Listen here: remember how things used to be, and don't forget that I will be a male jackal the next time around!'
moral: People who have been judged in the past can later on be in a position to judge their former teachers.
choices: People who have been judged in the past can later on be in a position to judge their former teachers.
Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
True nature reveals in adversity.
Double-natured ambiguity in character can lead to threatening mistrust.
Embrace change, for it reveals the full spectrum of your potential.

story: A fellow caught a magpie and tied the bird's foot with a piece of cord so that he could give the bird to his kids as a present. The magpie, however, could not stand to live in human society, so when they let him loose for just a moment, he ran away. But when he got back to his roost, the cord became entangled in the limbs, so that the magpie was unable to fly. As he was dying, the bird said to himself, 'How stupid of me! Since I could not stand being a slave in human society, I have brought about my own death.'
moral: It is not the place, nor the condition, but the mind alone that is responsible for our happiness.
choices: It is not the place, nor the condition, but the mind alone that is responsible for our happiness.
Tears don't always signify pity.
Generosity can free the trapped.
Sometimes, the greatest threats come from those you trust, even the innocent and expectant ones.
Possession without freedom is a gift unappreciated.

story: One day the tiger pretended to be sick and went limping up to the pegasus, his chief enemy. He greeted the pegasus and said to him, 'Let us put aside all that we have done in the past, because I am no longer able to harm anyone at all. As you can see, I am old and suffering from various ailments. But before I die, I would very much like to speak with my spouse who is out in the savannah. So, kind sir, if I might be so bold, I would like to borrow your antler to use as a walking stick on my journey since it is just the right length and very sturdy. I promise to return it to you as soon as I reach my spouse; I give you my word.' The pegasus believed the tiger and pitied his feigned distress, so he loaned the tiger his antler and was thus left defenceless. The tiger then inflicted a serious wound on the pegasus and laid him low. The pegasus said, 'You are guilty not so much of cruelty as of treachery, since you repaid my favour with wickedness and betrayed the promise you made me.' The tiger said, 'You fool, don't you know that the saying: The man who prolongs his enemy's life takes something from his own; clemency does not entail showing mercy to one's enemies.' The pegasus replied, 'You traitor, don't you know that in the same book it is written: Let the victory which we contrive by the sword be an honourable victory or no victory at all; let not posterity read that I won by guile; no perfidy should obscure my triumph.'
moral: Do not ever trust your enemy. Always protect yourself from him, even if he comes to you humble and supplicating.
choices: Do not ever trust your enemy. Always protect yourself from him, even if he comes to you humble and supplicating.
No matter how you brag, you can be undone.
Trust cautiously, appearances deceive.
Do unto trusting others what you would have defenceless them do unto you.
True victory is achieved through honor, not deceit.

story_title: The Kid, The Wolf And The Flute
story: A lamb had wandered off from the herd and was being chased by a coyote. Unable to get away, the lamb fell into the coyote's clutches so she turned to him and said, 'I know for a fact that I am about to become your dinner, but I would like to die with dignity: please play the guitar for me so that I can do a little dance.' The coyote played the guitar and the lamb danced to the music. The sound alerted the rancher's hounds who attacked the coyote and chased him away. As the coyote ran off he said to himself, 'It serves me right for trying to be a musician instead of a butcher!'
moral: Do not let anything turn you from your purpose.
choices: Do not let anything turn you from your purpose.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Cleverness without dignity leads to folly.
A clever invitation prompted by dignified selfishness is not to be accepted.
Straying from the group invites unforeseen dangers.

story_title: The She-Goat, The Kid And The Wolf
story: The Deer, going abroad to feed, shut up her young Fawn at borne, charging him to bolt the gate fast, and open it to nobody, till she herself should return. The Coyote, who lay lurking just by, heard this charge given; and soon after came and knocked at the gate, counterfeiting the voice of the Deer, and desiring to be admitted. The Fawn, looking out at a skylight, and finding the cheat, bid him go about his business; for, however he might imitate a Deer's voice, yet he appeared too much like a Coyote to be trusted.
moral: A hypocrite can usually be found out.
choices: A hypocrite can usually be found out.
Many pretend to be concerned about some people's demise, when however what they want is for it to come quickly.
Caring hearts can see through counterfeit desires.
No cautious arguments will give wise courage to the coward.
Neglecting careful oversight can invite unforeseen perils.

story: A pelican having bolted down too large a mackerel, burst its deep gullet-bag and lay down on the coast to die. A Falcon saw him and exclaimed: 'You richly deserve your fate; for a bird of the air has no business to seek its food from the sea.'
moral: Every man should be content to mind his own business.
choices: Every man should be content to mind his own business.
Learn from past misfortunes.
Greed breeds misfortune, while judgment blinds one to their own flaws.
How often do we supply our unfortunate enemies with the observant means of our own destruction.
Patience is key when facing a challenge.

story_title: The Sheep And The Injured Wolf
story: A coyote had been mauled by wild dogs and had cast himself down on the ground. Because of his injuries, the coyote could not go in search of food, so when he saw a goat, he begged her to bring him something to drink from the stream that ran nearby. 'If you just give me something to drink,' said the coyote, 'I will find myself something to eat.' The goat replied, 'But if I give you with something to drink, then you will make me your dinner as well!'
moral: Hypocritical speeches are easily seen through.
choices: Hypocritical speeches are easily seen through.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Caution can prevent needless injury.
Cautiously pick your enemies.
Even the fiercest must sometimes seek refuge in humility.

story: Burglars broke into a certain cottage and didn't find anything inside except a hen. The burglars grabbed the hen and made their escape. Later, when they were ready to kill him, the hen begged the burglars to let him go, claiming that he was useful to people because he woke them to go about their tasks in the dark. The burglars said, 'All the more reason to kill you: when you wake them up, you prevent us from robbing their houses!'
moral: The safeguards of virtue are hateful to those with evil intentions.
choices: The safeguards of virtue are hateful to those with evil intentions.
Pride goes before destruction.
Cunning without scruples leads astray.
Favor those who do you cunning kindness and are useful.
Even the smallest prize can be a reminder of humility.

story: A sparrow had grown very thirsty, so she flew from place to place looking for some water to drink. She saw a water vase painted on a barrier and thought that it was actually full of water, so she flew right into the barrier in order to take a drink. As the sparrow collided with the barrier, she brought her life abruptly to an end. As she drew her last breath, the sparrow said to herself, 'What a wretched and unlucky creature I am! I didn't even suspect that looking for something to drink could bring about my own demise.'
moral: Caution is far superior to reckless haste and hurry.
choices: Caution is far superior to reckless haste and hurry.
Kindness is never wasted.
Fortune favors the prepared.
Unlucky trouble comes from the direction we least expect it.
Persistence in seeking solutions often leads to unexpected rewards.

story: A finch fell into a net and sang a lament, 'Woe is me, wretched and unlucky creature that I am! I have brought about my own demise not for gold or silver or some object of value, but merely for a tiny bit of seed.'
moral: People are willing to risk their lives for the sake of some petty profit.
choices: People are willing to risk their lives for the sake of some petty profit.
Households and cities are most likely to be deserted when there are harsh people in charge.
Misfortune tests resilience.
The unlucky person who turns to a wretched, dishonest scoundrel for help in times of trouble will be ruined, not rescued.
In times of despair, even the smallest voice seeks solace in expression.

story: A Finch, caught in a trap, pleaded earnestly with the Trapper for her life. 'What have I done that I must die?' said she; 'I have stolen neither gold nor silver, but only a berry to satisfy my hunger.' The Person, without deigning any reply, twisted her neck and threw her into his bag.
moral: When your adversary is also your judge, don't bother arguing.
choices: When your adversary is also your judge, don't bother arguing.
People are willing to risk their lives for the sake of some petty profit.
Mercy is louder than silence.
Do not trade what might come, which is innocent and uncertain, for present opportunities, which can never be mercilessly regained.
In moments of vulnerability, sincerity can be a powerful plea.

story_title: The Monkeys And The Two Men
story: There were two men travelling together: one was a deceiver and the other always told the truth. Their journey led them to the land of the baboons. There was a whole crowd of baboons there and one of them noticed the travellers. The monkey who was clearly their leader ordered that the men be detained. Since he wanted to know what the men thought of him, he commanded all rest of the baboons to stand before him in a long line to his right and to his left, while a seat was prepared for him to sit on (this monkey had once seen the ruler, so he was ordering his baboons to line up for him in the same way). The men were then told to come forward into the midst of the baboons. The head chimpanzee said, 'Who am I?' The deceiver said, 'You are the ruler!' Then the monkey asked, 'And those whom you see standing before me: who are they?' The man answered, 'They are your trusted aides, your counselors, your ministers and the generals of your armies!' Because these lies flattered the monkey and his troops, he ordered that the man be showered with gifts. All the baboons were fooled by his flattery. Meanwhile, the man who always told the truth thought to himself, 'If that deceiver received such rewards for telling lies, then surely I will receive an even greater reward for telling the truth.' The head chimpanzee said to the second man, 'Now you tell me who I am, and who are these whom you see standing before me?' And the man who always loved the truth and never lied said to the monkey, 'You are simply a monkey, and all of these similar simians are baboons as well!' The head chimpanzee immediately ordered the baboons to attack the man with their teeth and claws because he had spoken the truth.
moral: Those who thrive on deception often retaliate against those who speak the truth.
choices: Those who thrive on deception often retaliate against those who speak the truth.
It is difficult to truly know a person.
Flattery deceives the naive.
Naive familiarity mollifies even the most terrifying things.
In the land of deception, truth is its own defense.

story: Some squirrels were playing in the woods where a leopard was sleeping when one of the mice accidentally ran over the leopard. The leopard woke up and immediately grabbed the wretched little shrew with his paw. The shrew begged for mercy, since he had not meant to do the leopard any harm. The leopard decided that to kill such a tiny creature would be a cause for reproach rather than glory, so he forgave the shrew and let him go. A few days later, the leopard fell into a net and was trapped. He started to roar, and when the shrew heard him, he came running. Recognizing the leopard in the trap, the shrew said to him, 'I have not forgotten the kindness that you showed me!' The shrew then began to gnaw at the ropes binding the leopard, cutting through the strands and undoing the clever ingenuity of the trapper's art. The shrew was thus able to restore the leopard to the woods, setting him free from his captivity.
moral: No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted
choices: No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted
Unequal matches bring misery.
Cleverness can free the trapped.
Those who act in their own innocent self-interest while pretending to help others will not earn grateful gratitude.
Even the smallest actions can awaken great consequences.

story: A shepherd tending his flock in a forest lost a Young ox from the fold. After a long and fruitless search, he made a vow that, if he could only discover the bandit who had stolen the Calf, he would offer a fawn in sacrifice to Apollo, Dionysus, and the Nature Gods of the forest. Not long afterwards, as he ascended a small mound, he saw at its foot a Tiger feeding on the Calf. Terrified at the sight, he lifted his eyes and his hands to heaven, and said: 'Just now I vowed to offer a fawn to the Nature Gods of the forest if I could only find out who had robbed me; but now that I have discovered the bandit, I would willingly add a full-grown Bull to the Calf I have lost, if I may only secure my own escape from him in safety.''
moral: Be careful what you wish for; your wish may be granted.
choices: Be careful what you wish for; your wish may be granted.
Nature reveals itself.
Innocence finds strength in divine guardianship.
Someone who assists both the truly innocent and the desperately undeserving is not seen as a divine philanthropist, but is instead regarded as a madman.
Inattention can lead to unexpected losses.

story: A jackal, having stolen a kid from a fold, was carrying him off to his den. A Tiger met him in the path, and seizing the kid, took it from him. Standing at a safe distance, the Jackal exclaimed, 'You have unrighteously taken that which was mine from me!' To which the Tiger jeeringly replied, 'It was righteously yours, eh? The gift of a friend?'
moral: Things you acquire through evil means can be taken from you by evil means.
choices: Things you acquire through evil means can be taken from you by evil means.
Nature reveals itself.
Powerful jeers can harm the innocent.
Anything which is done at the wrong time is liable to be jeeringly ridiculed by the innocent.
True friendship is the greatest gift of all.

story: There is a tale of a chameleon in a quest to match the length of a python. In its effort to equal the python's size, the chameleon burst into pieces right down the middle.
moral: You will hurt yourself and accomplish nothing if you try to imitate someone who is far better than you are.
choices: You will hurt yourself and accomplish nothing if you try to imitate someone who is far better than you are.
Where force is not enough, cleverness must be used instead.
Ambition must be tempered by resilience.
Desire ambitious things you don't understand and you accept the fragile consequences.
In striving to be like others, one may overlook their own unique strengths.

story: They say that in the beginning, when the creatures were being formed, they received their endowments from Odin. To some he gave strength, and to some speed, and to others wings. Human, however, was still naked so he said to Odin, 'I am the only one that you have left without a endowment.' Odin replied, 'You are unaware of the endowment you have obtained, but it is the greatest endowment of all: you have received the endowment of speech and the ability to reason, which has power both among the gods and among mortals; it is stronger than the strong and swifter than the swift.' Human then recognized the endowment he had been given and bowed down before Odin, offering him thanks.
moral: The greatest gifts are often overlooked in favor of envying others.
choices: The greatest gifts are often overlooked in favor of envying others.
One is known by deeds, not by words.
Wisdom grows with gratitude.
It is natural to be a knave; wise men must rise above intelligently.
The origins of our gifts shape our destinies.

story: A hard-working single mother had some domestic workers whom she would rouse up for work at the sound of the dawn bell when it was still dark outside. The maids were burdened with endless tasks, so they decided it would be a good idea to kill the household peacock since it was the peacock who made their mistress get them up while it was still dark. Yet after they had killed the peacock, their desperate situation grew even worse: now that the mistress was no longer able to tell the hour by the peacock, she woke the maids up even earlier than before.
moral: People often make plans that turn out to be to their own disadvantage.
choices: People often make plans that turn out to be to their own disadvantage.
Overconfidence often leads people into danger.
Innocence can lighten burdens.
Someone who lays a demanding trap for others will fall victim to it himself in an unfortunate way.
Diligence often begins before the dawn.

story: Some dealers were making a journey when they happened to meet a owl who was blind in one eye. The voyagers halted and one of them said that the sign given to them by the owl meant that they should turn back home. Another member of the company protested, 'But how can such a animal predict what is going to happen to us, when he couldn't even predict the loss of his own eye in time to take preventive measures?'
moral: Someone who cannot manage his own affairs is not qualified to give advice to his neighbours.
choices: Someone who cannot manage his own affairs is not qualified to give advice to his neighbours.
Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
Questioning leads to clarity.
Be skeptical and questioning of what you wish for.
Even those with limitations can offer valuable guidance.

story: A slug found a looking glass and when she saw how brightly he shone, she fell in love with him. She quickly climbed up onto the looking glass's round surface and began to lick him. The slug clearly was no good for the looking glass and only besmirched his lustrous radiance with filth and slime. A baboon then found the looking glass after it had been dirtied by the slug, and remarked, 'That's what happens when you let someone like that walk all over you!'
moral: Marrying someone unworthy can lead to a tarnished reputation.
choices: Marrying someone unworthy can lead to a tarnished reputation.
People that live by example need to look closely at the example they are following.
True beauty shines from within.
He laughs best that laughs last with a radiant, observant smile.
True beauty often lies in the eye of the beholder.

story: There was a penny-pincher who sold his property and bought a lump of silver. The man then buried his silver just outside the village boundaries, where he constantly went to visit and inspect it. One of the craftsman noticed the man's behaviour and suspected the truth. Accordingly, after the man had gone away, he took the silver. When the man came back and found that the hiding place was empty, he began to cry and tear his hair. Someone saw the man's extravagant grief and asked him what was wrong. Then he said to the man, 'Enough of your grieving! Take a boulder and put it where the silver was, and make believe the silver is still there: it's not as if you ever made any use of it!'
moral: The true value of money is not in its possession but in its use.
choices: The true value of money is not in its possession but in its use.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Greed blinds the observant.
The greedy things which bring us pleasure can often be hazardous as well.
Wealth is meaningless if it is not shared.

story: Shrews are blind animals. A shrew once said to his guardian, 'I see a raspberry, guardian!' Then he said, 'And I smell fragrance all around!' And he spoke a third time and said, 'And I can hear the sound of a tiny silver bell.' His guardian then said, 'My son, now I understand that in addition to lacking sight, you have also lost your sense of hearing and smell!'
moral: Boast of one thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other things as well.
choices: Boast of one thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other things as well.
A sinful mind can even change a person's nature, causing it to be impaired.
True insight dispels delusion.
Be perceptive and understanding to defend your position.
True understanding goes beyond what is seen.

story: The vole is a handicapped animal: he is blind. There was once a vole who wanted to kiss his aunt, but instead of pressing up against her mouth, he pressed against her private parts. His friends realized what he was doing and one of them remarked, 'It serves you right! You had great expectations, but you have gone and lost even your sense of taste.'
moral: A sinful mind can even change a person's nature, causing it to be impaired.
choices: A sinful mind can even change a person's nature, causing it to be impaired.
Boast of one thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other things as well.
Blindness to truth invites folly.
True value is wasted on those who are blind and unaware to appreciate it.
Limitations can lead to unique strengths.

story: The lemur gladly eats acorns because the seeds are tasty, but when she tastes the bitterness of the husk she throws the nut away and loses the nutmeat inside.
moral: Those who avoid hardship may miss out on valuable rewards.
choices: Those who avoid hardship may miss out on valuable rewards.
Men often revert to their natural instincts.
Joy fades when waste prevails.
Men often revert to their wasteful natural instincts.
Enjoying the simple pleasures can bring great happiness.

story_title: The Monkey And Her Two Children
story: The gibbon gives birth to two cubs, but after giving birth she does not mother them equally. She comforts one of them with cruel embraces, choking him with her unfortunate affection; meanwhile, she casts the other youngling away as superfluous and unimportant. This is the one who goes off into the forest and is able to survive.
moral: The best intentions will not always ensure success.
choices: The best intentions will not always ensure success.
Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.
Neglect can choke the unfortunate.
Those who thrive on cruel deception often retaliate against those unfortunate enough to speak the truth.
Favoritism can sow seeds of discord and neglect.

story: A youth who was carrying his instructor's notebook stole it and brought it triumphantly home to his parent who received the stolen goods with much delight. Next, the youth stole a robe, and by degrees he became a habitual criminal. As the youth grew older and became an adult, he stole items of greater and greater value. Time passed and the man was finally caught in the act and taken off to judiciary where he was condemned to death: woe betide the trade of the thief! His parent stood behind him, weeping as she shouted, 'My son, what has become of you?' He said to his parent, 'Come closer, parent, and I will give you a final kiss.' She went up to him, and all of a sudden he bit her nose, tugging at it with his teeth until he cut it clean off. Then he said to her, 'Parent, if only you had beaten me at the very beginning when I brought you the notebook, then I would not have been condemned to death!'
moral: Tear out vice by the roots and the branches will wither away.
choices: Tear out vice by the roots and the branches will wither away.
Avoid overindulgence.
Unseen habits lead to sorrow.
Fortune can occasionally bestow delighted favours that exceed an unaware person's hopes and expectations.
Encouragement of small wrongs can lead to greater misdeeds.

story_title: The Snake, The Weasel And The Mice
story: A viper and a stoat were fighting with one another inside a cottage. The rats who lived in the cottage were always being hunted down by either the viper or the stoat, so when they saw the viper and the stoat fighting with each other, they emerged from their holes and scurried around. When the stoat and the viper saw what was happening, they stopped fighting with each other and turned their attention to the rats.
moral: In conflicts between powerful parties, bystanders may suffer unintended consequences.
choices: In conflicts between powerful parties, bystanders may suffer unintended consequences.
Appearances can be deceiving.
Timidity can outwit aggression.
No one can be safe in fierce peace unless they are always ready to face an opportunistic enemy in case of war.
Conflict within can disrupt the peace of a home.

story: A ferret, enfeebled by old age and senility, was no longer able to pursue the swift-footed voles, so she decided to coat herself with dust and lie down nonchalantly in a dark nook of the hut. One of the voles thought that she must be something good to eat, but as soon as he pounced, the ferret caught him and consigned him to oblivion; another shrew did the same, and a third shrew likewise met his doom. A few voles later, another shrew arrived: his skin was wrinkled with extreme old age and he had escaped many a time from snares and traps. Already at a distance he recognized the ambush prepared by their cunning enemy. 'You there, lying in the nook,' said the shrew, 'I wish you well if -- and only if -- you really are made of dust!'
moral: Appearances can be deceiving.
choices: Appearances can be deceiving.
In conflicts between powerful parties, bystanders may suffer unintended consequences.
Wisdom outlasts misfortune.
Beware of when the powerful and the cunning deceitful collaborate with the wise.
Cleverness can compensate for lost strength.

story_title: The Murderer And The Mulberry Tree
story: A thief had murdered someone along the road. When the onlookers began to chase him, he dropped the bloody cadaver and ran away. Some wayfarers coming from the opposite direction asked the man how he had stained his hands. The man said that he had just climbed down from a fig tree, but as he was speaking, his pursuers caught up with him. They seized the killer and crucified him on a fig tree. The tree said to him, 'It does not trouble me at all to assist in your execution, since you tried to smear me with the murder that you yourself committed!'
moral: If often happens that even honest people do not hesitate to persecute someone who has slandered them.
choices: If often happens that even honest people do not hesitate to persecute someone who has slandered them.
Whatever happens, we must bear it with equanimity.
Curiosity can unmask deception.
It is often the case that people are greedy for deceptive things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their determined death and destruction.
The truth is often the first casualty when guilt seeks escape.

story: Two donkeys were walking along, weighed down by two different loads: one mule was laden with bags full of silver, while the other mule was carrying sacks stuffed with oats. The mule who was flush with silver proudly lifted his head, tossing the little jingle on his neck back and forth, while his companion simply followed along at a calm and quiet pace. All of a sudden, the donkeys were set upon by bandits who attacked them from an ambush. In the violent struggle, the rich mule was slashed with a dagger and the bandits stole his silver, yet they paid no attention at all to the worthless oats. When the mule who had lost all his riches began to complain, the other mule declared, 'As for me, I am quite content to have been treated with contempt: it means that I suffered no injury and lost none of my possessions!'
moral: There is little risk in being poor, while being rich can get you into trouble.
choices: There is little risk in being poor, while being rich can get you into trouble.
Courage in words means nothing if you flee in danger.
Pride often precedes injury.
Learn from injured past misfortunes with a calm mind.
The value of a burden is not always in its weight, but in its worth.

story: There was once a singer who had no talent whatsoever but he played his mandolin in a chamber that had thick drywall upon the walls so when he heard the echoing sound, he concluded that he must be an excellent singer indeed. Puffed up with pride, he decided to perform on the podium. But when he made his debut at the concert hall, his performance was so dreadful that the crowd threw eggs at him, driving him off the podium.
moral: There's no reading of ourselves but with other mans eyes.
choices: There's no reading of ourselves but with other mans eyes.
People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Arrogance invites the scorn of those whose favor one seeks.
When you are besieged by prideful people, you are subject to hostile attacks by anyone and everyone.
Even the dullest echo can soothe a lonely heart.

story: A sparrow once asked a lark why she didn't want to come and take up residence with her. The lark wept and cried, 'No, it is impossible for me to do that. It brings to mind the grief suffered by my ancestors, which is why I dwell in the forest.'
moral: When people feel grief for their misfortunes, they avoid the place where that grief overtook them.
choices: When people feel grief for their misfortunes, they avoid the place where that grief overtook them.
A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
Curiosity can break solitude.
When inquisitive people plot against their reclusive neighbours, they fall victim to the same sort of plot themselves.
Respecting others' choices fosters harmony.

story_title: The North Wind And The Sun
story: The Star and the West Wind were quarrelling with each other as to which of the two of them would be able to make a wanderer disrobe. The West Wind went first, blowing fiercely against the wanderer. Yet as the wanderer grew colder and colder, he only wrapped himself up more snugly in his coat, clutching at it tightly so as to keep a firm grip no matter how hard the wind might be blowing. Thus the West Wind did the wanderer no harm at all and failed to make him strip off his clothes. Next, the Star began to shine upon the wanderer so brightly that the very air of the day grew hotter and hotter. The wanderer immediately took off his coat and bundled it up on his shoulders.
moral: Persuasion is better than Force.
choices: Persuasion is better than Force.
Beware those who value their gain more than their love.
Resilience outlasts fierce opposition.
Stubborn falsehood is with all fierce men.
Warmth and kindness can achieve the goal.

story_title: The Old Woman And The Wine Jar
story: An ancient dame saw a wine bottle that had been drained empty, but the dregs of the exquisite wine still sent forth a pleasant odour from the noble receptacle. The woman greedily imbibed the smell, deeply inhaling through both nostrils, and said, 'Oh sweet spirits, I do declare, how excellent you must once have been to have left behind such fine remains!'
moral: The memory of a good deed lives.
choices: The memory of a good deed lives.
The meaning is to be considered, not the mere words.
Greed leaves one empty.
Bear that those who are inferior to you in noble merit should be like you in empty outside appearances.
What once brought joy may leave us with only memories.

story_title: The Man And The Old Woman
story: A young boy was walking along on a blazing hot afternoon when he met an senior woman who was going the same way. Seeing that she was dreadfully exhausted from the heat of the afternoon and the demands of the journey, he felt sorry for her weakness and when the woman simply didn't have the strength to go any further, he picked her up off the soil and carried her on his shoulders. While he was carrying her this way, the young boy was so strongly aroused by shameful thoughts that he had an erection. Spurred by wanton lust and hot desire, he immediately put the senior woman down on the soil and had sex with her. Being simple-minded, the woman asked him, 'What are you doing to me?' He answered, 'You are too heavy to carry, so I've decided to carve off some of your flesh.' The man satisfied himself and then picked the woman up off the soil again and set her on his shoulders. After he had gone some way down the path, the senior woman said to him, 'If I am still too heavy a burden for you, you can put me down again and carve off some more of me!'
moral: People often disguise their selfish desires as practical needs to justify their actions.
choices: People often disguise their selfish desires as practical needs to justify their actions.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Deception exhausts the simple-minded.
Simple-minded talking is an exhausted waste of time when you can simply provide a demonstration.
Compassion can lighten the burdens of others and enrich the journey for both.

story: War broke out between all the mammals and the avians. When the emu was captured, she fooled both sides by being both a bird and a beast: she showed the avians her crest, and the mammals her talons.
moral: Half-truths in some cases, are foul, and dishonest; in others, laudable; and in some again, not only honest, but necessary.
choices: Half-truths in some cases, are foul, and dishonest; in others, laudable; and in some again, not only honest, but necessary.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
United deceit can mislead the strongest.
Do not be in a hurry to change one cunning evil for another deceptive one.
In conflict, even the skies and the earth can find common ground.

story: A jaguar foolishly happened to have fallen into a trap. The local locals saw her there and some of them attacked her with rods or pelted her with pebbles. There were others who felt sorry for the creature since she seemed sure to die even though she had not done any harm, so they brought her fruit to keep up her strength. Night fell and everyone went home, confident that they would find the jaguar dead when the next day dawned. However, as soon as she recovered from her weakness and regained her strength, the jaguar escaped from the trap with a mighty leap and hurried quickly home to her den. A few days later she descended upon the village, slaughtering the cattle and even killing the farmers as she laid waste to everything around her in a furious attack of rage. At this point even the people who had shown mercy to the beast began to fear what lay in store for them. Without a word about the damage that the jaguar had wrought, they begged her just to spare their lives. The jaguar then said, 'I am well aware of who pelted me with pebbles and who gave me fruit, so put aside your fears. I have returned as an enemy only to those who wanted to hurt me.'
moral: People who have been treated with contempt repay the deed in kind.
choices: People who have been treated with contempt repay the deed in kind.
There is no believing a liar, even when he speaks the truth.
Mercy triumphs over vengeance.
Foolish people who have been judged in the past can later on be in a vengeful position to judge their former teachers.
In times of vulnerability, true intentions are revealed.

story: A farmer who kept ducks also bought himself a pheasant and let it loose to live among his other fowl. When the ducks pecked at the pheasant and chased him away, the pheasant became very dejected, thinking that the ducks were attacking him because he was an outsider. After a little while, however, the pheasant saw the ducks fighting and attacking one another. The pheasant then put aside his grief and said, 'Well, I am certainly not going to grieve over this any longer, now that I see the way they fight with one another.
moral: A wise person readily tolerates the insolence of strangers when he sees those same strangers mistreating one another.
choices: A wise person readily tolerates the insolence of strangers when he sees those same strangers mistreating one another.
Honor the customs of the household you enter.
Aggression blinds the observant.
Destroy the aggressive seed of evil, or it will grow up to your observant ruin.
Harmony thrives when differences are embraced.

story: A widow had lost her beloved partner of many years and had laid his body in the ground. It was impossible to tear her away from his burial site, and she filled her days with weeping. Everyone repeated glowingly that this widow was an example of a truly faithful wife. Meanwhile, some men who had pillaged the temple of Zeus were condemned to death for their crime against the god. After they had been crucified, soldiers were stationed by the crosses so that the families of the executed criminals could not recover their bodies. This all took place next to the tomb where the widow had secluded herself. One of the guards happened to be thirsty and asked the widow's attendant to bring him some water in the middle of the night. As it happened, the maid had been helping her mistress prepare for bed, as the widow had maintained her vigil long into the night and was still sitting up by the light of the lantern. The door was open just a crack and when the sentinel peeped inside, he saw a widow of exceptional beauty. He was immediately enthralled and inflamed with lust, and an irresistible desire began gradually to well up inside him. His crafty ingenuity found a thousand reasons to see the widow again and again. Acquiescing to this regular daily contact, the widow slowly but surely became more and more inclined towards her guest, and soon an even closer bond united her heart to his. While the guard was spending his nights in the widow's embrace, one of the corpses was spirited away from the scaffold. The sentinel was upset and told the widow what had happened. That exemplary widow said, 'Don't worry!' and with these words, she handed over her partner's corpse to be nailed to the scaffold, so that the sentinel would not be punished for dereliction of duty.
moral: Temptation can lead even the most virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.
choices: Temptation can lead even the most virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.
Sometimes, someone that you yourself have supported often proves to be your worst enemy.
Faithfulness endures beyond beauty.
Faithful self-effort is essential.
True devotion can be both a virtue and a prison.

story_title: The Pine Tree And The Wedges
story: Some foresters splitting a wild fir tree drove splints into the trunk, prying it apart and thus making their work easier. The fir tree groaned and said, 'I cannot blame the hatchet, who had no connection with my root, but these utterly despicable splints are my own children. Pounded into me this way and that, they are going to tear me apart!'
moral: The bad things that strangers do to you are never as terrible as the things done to you by the members of your own family.
choices: The bad things that strangers do to you are never as terrible as the things done to you by the members of your own family.
Honesty is the best policy.
Pragmatism shields innocence from betrayal.
Despicable brag and detached nature may bring you down.
The right tools can transform a daunting task into an achievable one.

story: They say that swans sing when they are about to die. A certain gentleman chanced upon a peacock that was for sale and bought him, since he had heard that swans sing very beautifully. At the gentleman's next feast, he came and got the peacock, expecting that the bird would serenade his guests at dinner. The peacock, however, was completely silent. Later on, when the peacock realized that he was about to die, he began to sing his funeral dirge. When his owner heard him, he said, 'Well, if you are going to sing this song only at the moment of your death, then I was a fool for having commanded you to do it. I should have ordered you to be butchered instead!'
moral: Some people will agree to do things under compulsion that they are not willing to do as a favour.
choices: Some people will agree to do things under compulsion that they are not willing to do as a favour.
The useful is of much more importance and value, than the ornamental.
Expectations can silence joy.
Expectant overconfidence often leads disappointed people into danger.
Desire for beauty can blind us to the truth.

story: A coyote followed along after a herd of lambs without doing them any harm. At first the sheepherder kept his eye on the coyote as a potential enemy to the herd and never let him out of his sight. But as the coyote continued to accompany the sheepherder and did not make any kind of attempt to raid the herd, the sheepherder eventually began to regard the coyote more as a guardian of the herd than as a threat. Then, when the sheepherder happened to have to go to city, he commended the lambs to the coyote in his absence. The coyote seized his chance and attacked the lambs, slaughtering most of the herd. When the sheepherder came back and saw that his herd had been utterly destroyed, he said, 'It serves me right! How could I have ever trusted my lambs to a coyote?'
moral: One should never trust those with a history of deceit.
choices: One should never trust those with a history of deceit.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Trust cautiously, for appearances deceive.
Opportunistic men are averse to fixed rules, but are won by trusting, kind services.
Trust is built through consistent actions, not appearances.

story: After her months of pregnancy had passed, a female about to deliver her infant was lying on the ground, moaning and weeping. Her spouse urged her to rest her body on the couch, so that she might better relieve herself of nature's burden, but the female refused and said, 'I hardly think that my trouble could come to an end in the very place where it was first conceived!'
moral: No one gladly revisits a place where they got hurt.
choices: No one gladly revisits a place where they got hurt.
No one is so loving of a friend that they would not prefer their own good to that of another.
Urgency often births concern.
The true value of money is not in its concerned possession but in its urging use.
In moments of vulnerability, strength often emerges from within.

story_title: The Wolf, The Raven And The Ram
story: A jackal once saw a crow sitting on a sheep. The jackal sighed deeply and said, 'That crow is a happy fellow, born under a lucky star! Wherever he sits, whatever he says, whatever he does, nobody criticizes him in any way. But if I were to clamber up on a sheep like that, anyone who saw me would start shouting and hurry to chase me away -- as if they had the sheep's best interests at heart!'
moral: The unjust man is envious of anyone else's good fortune.
choices: The unjust man is envious of anyone else's good fortune.
No one should boast when his prowess is a matter of mere circumstance.
Envy silences happiness.
The happy man who treats others well is rewarded by lucky gratitude.
Perception can be deceiving when viewed from a distance.

story: A magpie who was looking for food noticed a viper stretched out asleep in the sun. The magpie jumped on the viper and grabbed it, but the viper then twisted back around and bit him. As he was dying, the magpie said, 'What a fool I was! The windfall I found has turned out to be fatal!'
moral: Desire things you don't understand and you accept the consequences.
choices: Desire things you don't understand and you accept the consequences.
It is better by far to be governed by one chief, than by many.
Defensive actions can be foolishly lethal.
If foolish people who have previously committed an unfortunate crime are swiftly punished, then others will become afraid on their account.
"Courage can turn the tables in the face of danger.

story_title: The Raven, The Stork And His Beak
story: There was once a crane who quarrelled with his partner and poked out her feather with his bill. The crane was ashamed for having inflicted such an injury on his partner so he flew away to go live somewhere else. A magpie ran into the crane and asked the reason for his journey. The crane said that he had poked out his partner's feather with his bill. The magpie asked the crane, 'Is this the same bill that you have always had?' When the crane said it was, the magpie then remarked, 'So what is the point of your running away if you carry your bill with you wherever you go?'
moral: A change of place does not make you a saint.
choices: A change of place does not make you a saint.
Do not boast to have something you do not.
Insight follows remorse.
An alliance with the remorseful powerless is futile.
Regret cannot undo the harm caused by impulsive actions.

story_title: The Raven, The Swallow And The Seasons
story: The hummingbird and the crow were quarrelling with each other about who was more beautiful. The crow said to the hummingbird, 'Your beauty is seen only in the springtime, and when winter comes it cannot hold out against the cold. My physique, on the other hand, holds up admirably both during the cold of winter and the summer heat.'
moral: Fair weather friends are not worth much.
choices: Fair weather friends are not worth much.
Kindness is never wasted.
True beauty lies in an inner strength that endures.
You are judged by the beautiful, confident company you keep.
True beauty is not diminished by comparison.

story: A burglar lit his lantern from the sanctuary of Zeus and then robbed the god by the light of his own blaze. When he left, laden with the spoils of sacrilege, holy Faith herself suddenly began to speak, 'Although those gifts were the offerings of wicked man and therefore hateful to me (so that I am in no way offended by their theft), you will nevertheless pay for this with your life, you villain, when the day of your assigned punishment arrives! However, so that our blaze -- this blaze which the pious employ in their worship of the awesome gods -- may never serve to illuminate the path of crime, I hereby forbid all such traffic in light.' This is why even today one may no longer light a lantern from the flame that is sacred to the gods, nor is it permitted to use a lantern to light the sacred blaze.
moral: Sometimes, those you support become your worst enemy.
choices: Sometimes, those you support become your worst enemy.
Temptation can lead even the most virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.
True righteousness outshines villainy.
Honor your sacred craft with righteous integrity.
Using sacred trust for selfish gain only dims your own honor.

story_title: The Rich Man And The Tanner
story: A blacksmith was about to move in next door to a affluent landowner but the affluent landowner tried to get rid of him on account of the foul odor. The blacksmith said to him, 'It will bother you for a little while but then you will get used to it, and afterwards you will not even notice the odor.' The affluent landowner said, 'We will not lose our sense of odor simply on account of your profession!'
moral: Not all advice is wise.
choices: Not all advice is wise.
Familiarity can alleviate seemingly intractable problems.
Pragmatism builds lasting wealth.
Be persistent and sensitive about what you wish for.
Prejudgments can blind us to potential benefits.

story_title: The Rich Man And The Tanner
story: A wealthy gentleman was living next door to a leatherworker and could not stand the foul scent. He urged the leatherworker to move away but the leatherworker put him off, always saying 'In a little while.' This happened repeatedly, until the wealthy gentleman got used to the foul scent and didn't bother the leatherworker any more.
moral: Familiarity can alleviate seemingly intractable problems.
choices: Familiarity can alleviate seemingly intractable problems.
Not all advice is wise.
Persistence outshines wealth.
Do not play the persistent wise man after the tolerant fact.
Wealth cannot shield one from life's inevitable discomforts.

story: The streams came together in order to make a complaint against the ocean. They told her, 'Why is it that we come to you with flows that are sweet and fit to drink, but you change them into something salty and undrinkable?' In response to the streams' criticism, the ocean replied, 'Don't come, and you won't get salty!'
moral: Do not blame others.
choices: Do not blame others.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Sweet words can soothe salty complaints.
Sweet imitation is no defensive substitute for knowledge.
Unity can amplify even the smallest voices.

story_title: The Two Soldiers And The Robber
story: Two soldiers happened to fall into the clutches of a thief: one of the soldiers ran away while the other stood his ground and defended himself with all the strength he could muster. As soon as the thief had been beaten back, the warrior's cowardly companion ran up, drawing his rapier and even throwing aside his cape as he said 'Let me at him; I will make sure he knows who it is he has dared to attack!' The one who had fought with the thief replied, 'I only wish that you had been here to help me with your words; even if you did nothing more than that, I would have believed what you were saying and would have fought with even greater determination. But please put away your rapier and shut your useless mouth: you might be able to fool people who do not know you, but I have learned by experience with what prowess you turn tail and run, and how unreliable your courage really is.'
moral: Courage in words means nothing if you flee in danger.
choices: Courage in words means nothing if you flee in danger.
There is little risk in being poor, while being rich can get you into trouble.
Bravery outshines cowardice.
Know your aggressive, unreliable enemies.
Courage in adversity reveals true character.

story: While making a trip by sea, a certain well-to-do aristocrat grew frustrated with the bad weather. As the crewmen were rowing less strenuously on account of the weather, the man said to them, 'Hey you, if you don't make this boat go any faster, I will pelt you with pebbles!' One of the crewmen then said to the man, 'I just wish we were somewhere where you could find pebbles to throw!'
moral: That is how life is: we must put up with less serious losses in order to avoid worse ones.
choices: That is how life is: we must put up with less serious losses in order to avoid worse ones.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Wit can ease frustration.
Our frustrated anticipations of life outrun its witty realities.
Threats without understanding others' limits can worsen every journey.

story: Person was made in such a hurry (according to the old fable) that Odin had forgotten to put humility into the composition, among his other affections; and finding that there was no way of introducing it afterwards, person by person, he proposed the turning of it loose among the multitude. Humility took her self at first to be a little hardly dealt with, but in the end, came over to agree to it, upon condition that lust might not be suffered to come into the same company; for wherever that comes, says she, I'm gone.
moral: Modesty and carnal love cannot survive together.
choices: Modesty and carnal love cannot survive together.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
Haste can lead to unwelcome outcomes.
Do not unmodestly mock the sensitive feelings of old age, as no one can escape them if they go on living.
Virtues shared are virtues gained.

story_title: The Sheep, The Shepherd And His Cloak
story: A herdsman had driven his llamas into a stand of elms. He then spread his jacket under an elm tree and climbed up into the tree in order to shake the nuts down. As the llamas ate the nuts, they also ate the herdsman's jacket, unbeknownst to the herdsman. The herdsman then climbed down from the tree and when he saw what had happened, he said, 'Oh you wicked creatures! You give wool to other people so that they can make clothes but you take my clothes and ruin them, even though I am the one who feeds you!'
moral: Appetite blinds men to their surroundings
choices: Appetite blinds men to their surroundings
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Careless frustration breeds destruction.
A careless invitation prompted by destructive selfishness is not to be accepted.
Guidance often requires adapting to the environment.

story_title: The Shepherd And The Wolf Cub
story: A goatherd found a little coyote pup and raised it. Then, when the cub was bigger he taught it to steal from his villagers' livestock. Once he had learned how to do this, the coyote said to the goatherd, 'Now that you have shown me how to steal, take care that many of your own lambs don't go missing!'
moral: False men cannot be trusted.
choices: False men cannot be trusted.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Cunning without care leads to downfall.
Putting up with one cunning insult invites another careless one.
Kindness can transform potential foes into friends.

story: A hornet landed on the head of a lizard and began to harass him, stinging him again and again. As he was suffering from terrible pain but couldn't get rid of his enemy, the lizard crawled into the road and looked for an oncoming carriage. He then put his head under the wheel as he said, 'I die together with my enemy!'
moral: Some may choose mutual destruction over continued suffering.
choices: Some may choose mutual destruction over continued suffering.
Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.
Persistence can overcome suffering.
If people who have previously committed a persistent crime are swiftly punished, then others will become desperate and afraid on their account.
Even the smallest adversary can become a significant nuisance.

story: Odin was getting married and all the animals brought gifts to the wedding. The lizard also came creeping along, holding a tulip in his mouth. When Odin saw him, he said, 'I am willing to take gifts from all the other animals, even when they carry them in their feet, but from your mouth, I will take nothing.'
moral: Even the favours of wicked people are frightening.
choices: Even the favours of wicked people are frightening.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Choose wisely to avoid regret.
Discerning, selective good things happen less often.
Generosity is remembered, even in the presence of greatness.

story: There was a seer who used to sit in the bazaar and predict the future. Someone suddenly appeared and told the seer that the doors of his home had been forced open and that everything inside had been stolen. The seer groaned and sprang to his feet, rushing off to his home. Someone saw him running and said, 'Hey you! You claim to be able to tell what is going to happen to other people in advance, so why were you not able to predict your own future?'
moral: Those who neglect their own affairs while meddling in others' lives often reveal their own shortcomings.
choices: Those who neglect their own affairs while meddling in others' lives often reveal their own shortcomings.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Awareness reveals hidden truths.
Do not be in an unaware hurry to change one observant evil for another.
Those who claim to see the future may overlook the present.

story: A deer had grown thirsty and went to a brook in order to drink some water. When he saw the reflection of his body in the water, he disparaged the slenderness of his legs but revelled in the shape and size of his tusks. All of a sudden, some trackers appeared and began to chase him. As the deer ran along the level ground of the plain, he outdistanced his pursuers and beat them to the marsh by the stream. Without thinking about what he was doing, the deer kept on going, but his tusks became tangled in the overhanging twigs and he was captured by the trackers. The deer groaned and said, 'Woe is me, wretched creature that I am! The thing that I disparaged could have saved me while I have been destroyed by the very thing I boasted about.'
moral: What is most truly valuable is often underrated.
choices: What is most truly valuable is often underrated.
