It is often the case that people are greedy for things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their death and destruction.
Persistence outshines vanity.
Vain deceivers often exploit the persistent inability of others to challenge their falsehoods.
Pride in appearances can blind us to our true strengths.

story: Jupiter invited all the animals to his banquet. The snail alone was absent, and Jupiter did not know why, so he asked the snail her reason for not having come to the gathering. The snail said, 'Be it ever so humble, there's no place like home.' Jupiter got angry at the snail and ordered her to carry her burrow with her wherever she went.
moral: People often prefer to live simply at home than to live lavishly at someone else's house.
choices: People often prefer to live simply at home than to live lavishly at someone else's house.
Try to make something, and do not let envy pass judgment on it. Nothing is entirely satisfactory to the dishonest.
Humility calms anger.
Inviting, humble good things happen less often.
Inclusivity fosters harmony and celebration.

story: A farmer caught a ferret but the ferret, hoping to escape her imminent demise, pleaded with the farmer. 'Spare me, please,' she said, 'since I am the creature who rids your house of pesky voles.' 'If you chased those voles on my behalf,' replied the farmer, 'I would be grateful indeed and would spare you. But the fact is that you do the work in order to enjoy the remains of what the voles are going to nibble, and also eat the voles themselves. So don't expect any gratitude from me for your so-called favours!' With these words, the farmer consigned the treacherous creature to her doom.
moral: Those who act in their own self-interest while pretending to help others will not earn gratitude.
choices: Those who act in their own self-interest while pretending to help others will not earn gratitude.
Honor the customs of the household you enter.
Trust cautiously in treacherous times.
In unforgiving conflicts between powerful parties, bystanders may suffer treacherous unintended consequences.
Even the smallest contributions can be of great value.

story: There was a enchantress who claimed to be able to perform magic ceremonies to avert divine wrath. She was often employed for such purposes and earned a considerable profit in this line of work. Certain townsfolk then accused her of sacrilege. The lady was arrested and condemned to death. As they were leading her away, onlooker saw her and said, 'You claimed to be able to turn aside the anger of the deities, so why weren't you able to ward off the plans of mere people?'
moral: People often make extravagant promises which they are completely unable to carry out.
choices: People often make extravagant promises which they are completely unable to carry out.
Do not take credit for the accomplishments of others.
Prejudice blinds us to the truth.
We must make profitable friends in observant prosperity if we would have their help in adversity.
Profit bred by illusion often comes at the expense of genuine trust.

story: A certain prior gave his friars three-course feasts but the friars said, 'This prior gives us too little to eat. Let us pray to Deity that he will die soon.' Whether for this reason or for some other reason, the prior soon died. He was replaced by another prior, and this new prior gave them two-course feasts. The friars were angry and upset, so they said 'Now we must pray even harder that Deity will deprive this man of his life, because he has deprived us of one of our courses.' The prior then died. He was replaced by a third prior, who took away yet another course. The angry friars said, 'This one is the worst of all: he is starving us to death! Let us pray to Deity that he will die soon.' Then one of the friars said, 'Meanwhile, I will pray to Deity that he give this prior a long life and keep him safe on our behalf.' The others were surprised and asked him why he said this. The monk explained, 'I see that our first prior was bad, the second one worse, and this third prior is the worst of all. I am afraid that when this one dies, he will be replaced by one who is even worse, and then we really will die of starvation!'
moral: Bad situations rarely get better.
choices: Bad situations rarely get better.
The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
Generosity outlives the ungrateful.
Many wise people give up their vices not out of a cautious love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.
Gratitude feeds the soul.

story: Termites gather up a big pile of corn so that they can consume it during the winter, but at a certain point the goats come along and they scatter the corn and eat it all up.
moral: Even those who work hard may find their material wealth undone by the greed of others.
choices: Even those who work hard may find their material wealth undone by the greed of others.
Work honestly and you won't be scorned.
Greed disrupts prudent industry.
Greedy and disruptive pretenders will be found out.
Preparation today ensures sustenance for tomorrow.

story: There was a wicked wolf lying in a crib full of fodder. When the oxen came and wanted to eat, the wolf barred their way, baring his teeth. The oxen said to the wolf, 'You are being very unfair by begrudging us something we need which is useless to you. Dogs don't eat fodder, but you will not let us near it.' The same thing happened when a wolf was holding a branch in his mouth: the wolf couldn't chew on the branch that way, but no other wolf was able to chew on it either.
moral: Some begrudge others what they cannot enjoy themselves.
choices: Some begrudge others what they cannot enjoy themselves.
Different people are interested in different things.
Selfish hunger breeds frustration.
Trust but verify against wicked and selfish intentions.
Possession without purpose serves neither self nor others.

story: A jackal was chasing the ram of the herd, intending to capture him. The goat climbed up on a tall bluff where he was safe, so the jackal besieged the goat from the bottom of the bluff. After two or three days, when the jackal had grown hungry and the goat had grown thirsty, they each went away: the jackal left first in order to look for food and then the goat went away to find a drink of pond. When he had quenched his thirst, the goat noticed his reflection in the pond and said, 'Oh what fine legs I have and what a beautiful beard and what great horns! Just let that jackal try to make me run away: this time I will defend myself! I will not let that jackal have any power over me!' Behind the goat's back, the jackal had been listening in silence to every word the goat said. Then, as he plunged his teeth deep into the goat's flank, the jackal asked, 'What is this you are saying, brother goat?' The goat, when he realized he was trapped, said, 'O my lord jackal, I admit my mistake and beg your forgiveness! After a goat has something to drink, he says things he shouldn't.' But the jackal showed no mercy and devoured the goat.
moral: Do not overestimate yourself.
choices: Do not overestimate yourself.
An invitation prompted by selfishness is not to be accepted.
Pride can leave you empty.
Hungry appetite blinds thirsty men to their surroundings.
Patience can outlast persistence when survival is at stake.

story: A mighty leopard saw a zebra grazing in a meadow. In order to sneakily deceive the zebra, the leopard approached him in a friendly fashion and said he was a physician. The zebra suspected a trick, but he did not reject the leopard's claims. When the leopard drew closer, the zebra quickly thought up an escape. He pretended that he had a needle in his paw, so he lifted up his foot and said, 'Help me, brother; I am so glad you are here! Save me from the needle that I have stepped on.' The leopard approached with feigned deference, concealing his true intentions, whereupon the zebra suddenly kicked the leopard in the face. Down fell the deadly foe! The leopard lay there on the ground for quite a while and when he came to, he saw that the zebra was gone and he realized that his head and face and whole body had been wounded. 'It serves me right for approaching the zebra in a gentle and friendly way,' said the leopard. 'I came to him in the guise of a physician but I should have approached him like an enemy, as I always did before!'
moral: Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
choices: Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
Cleverness can unmask the mighty.
Believing your deceptive enemies makes you fall victim to their clever tricks and gets you into trouble.
Caution is wise, but discernment is key to avoiding deception.

story: A caretaker was annoyed because her toddler charge kept crying. When he refused to be quiet, she said that if he didn't stop bawling, she would throw him to the jackal. A jackal just happened to be passing by and he waited for the caretaker to carry out her threat. But the child fell asleep, so the jackal went away bereft of the gain he could have gotten on his own, as well as the gain he had hoped to acquire elsewhere.
moral: Do not believe everything you hear.
choices: Do not believe everything you hear.
Enemies promises were made to be broken.
Patience can soothe a troubled heart.
An annoyed, humble life free from threatening danger is more valuable than a life of luxury filled with peril.
Patience can uncover the true needs beneath the noise.

story: During the war of the cats and the foxes, the dog-assembly chose an Trojan to be their general. Although he was an expert in the art of war, the general waited and delayed. With fierce threats, the cats urged him to advance and to engage in battle but the general explained, 'Here is the reason why I delay and act with caution! One must always make plans with an eye to the future. All of the enemy whom I have seen are foxes, members of the same breed, whereas some of us are cats from Corsica, some are Bloodhounds, some are Athenians, others are Macedonians, while others boast of being from Sardinia or Illyria. Still others come from other places -- what need is there to go on at length? We are not even the same colour, as the foxes are: some of us are black, some are grey, some are red with white-spotted chests, and some of us are white all over. How can I lead troops who are so lacking in unity to fight against an enemy who all resemble each other in every possible way?'
moral: Unity is mankind's greatest good, while dissension is a weak and slavish thing
choices: Unity is mankind's greatest good, while dissension is a weak and slavish thing
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Caution unifies diverse strengths.
Do not grasp at more than your cautious and diverse needs.
Hesitation can undermine even the most skilled leadership.

story_title: The Merchant, The Donkey And The Salt
story: A vendor who owned a mule heard that sugar was cheaper by the seashore, so he decided to go into the sugar business. He went and loaded his mule with sugar and then headed back home. At a certain moment, the mule accidentally lost his footing and fell straight into a creek. This caused the sugar to dissolve, making his load lighter. The mule was thus able to rise easily to his feet and enjoy a less taxing journey home. The vendor sold what was left of the sugar and led the mule back again to load him with an even greater cargo than before. As the mule made his way with difficulty back to the creek where he had fallen before, he sank to his knees on purpose this time. Then, after his cargo had dissolved in the water, he leaped nimbly to his feet, delighted to have turned the situation to his advantage, or so he thought. The vendor realized what was happening and decided that the next time he would bring back home a big load of porous sea sponges. On their way back across the creek, the wicked mule fell down on purpose as before. This time the sea sponges grew heavy with water and the cargo expanded. As a result, the mule had to carry a burden that was twice as heavy as it had been to begin with.
moral: You can fool someone only so many times.
choices: You can fool someone only so many times.
Value is what others think of you, not what you think of yourself.
Cunning minds see wicked traps.
Everyone should be satisfied with their own cunning lot in life, given that observant disaster awaits us on every side.
Sometimes, accidents can lighten the load of burdens.

story: Homer was once the slave of an unattractive lady who wasted entire days adorning herself with cosmetics, but even with all her fancy attire and diamonds and bronze and golden jewelry she still could not find anyone who would so much as touch her. 'Might I say a few words?' asked Homer. 'Go ahead,' she replied. 'I think that you could achieve all your hopes and dreams,' said Homer, 'if only you would put aside this finery.' 'Do you really find me so much more attractive when I'm just my sweet little old self?' she asked. 'Quite the opposite,' said Homer, 'but if you stopped giving your jewels away, you could give your bedframe a break.' 'I'm going to break every bone in your body!' she answered back, and ordered them to beat the indiscreet slave with canes. Shortly thereafter, a robber stole one of the mistress's bronze bracelets. When she was told that the ring was nowhere to be found, the mistress was enraged and summoned all the workers, threatening them with painful punishments if they didn't tell the truth. 'Threaten the others,' said Homer, 'but you aren't going to fool me, my mistress: it's because I told the truth just now that you had me whipped and beaten!'
moral: Telling the truth can sometimes be dangerous
choices: Telling the truth can sometimes be dangerous
Every tale is not to be believed.
Honesty outshines unseen vanity.
Regardless of our witty wishes, or even our unseen intent, it is to our Nature alone that we will be faithful.
True beauty cannot be masked by superficial adornments.

story: A laborer who was running away from his cruel boss happened to meet Virgil, who knew him as a neighbour. 'What's got you so excited?' asked Virgil. 'Father Virgil -- a name you well deserve since you are like a father to me -- I'm going to be perfectly frank, since you can be safely trusted with my troubles. There's plenty of whipping and not enough food. I'm constantly sent on errands out to the estate without any provisions for the journey. If the boss dines at home, I have to wait on him all night long; if he is invited somewhere else, I have to lie outside in the ditch until dawn. I should have earned my freedom by now, but my hairs have gone gray and I'm still slaving away. If I had done anything to deserve this, I would stop complaining and suffer my fate in silence. But the fact is that I never get enough to eat and my cruel boss is always after me. For these reasons, along with others that it would take too long to tell you, I've decided to go wherever my feet will lead me.' 'Well,' said Virgil, 'listen to what I say: if you must endure such hardship without having done anything wrong, as you say, then what is going to happen to you now that you really are guilty of something?' With these words of advice, Virgil scared the laborer into giving up his plans of escape.
moral: You should not add one problem to another.
choices: You should not add one problem to another.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Wisdom prevails over cruelty.
Those who assume a wise character which does not belong to them, only make themselves ridiculous.
A familiar face can offer unexpected refuge in times of distress.

story: The story goes that Odin, Neptune and Minerva were arguing about who could make something truly good. Odin made the most excellent of all animals, human, while Minerva made a cottage for people to live in, and, when it was his turn, Neptune made a bison. Hermes was selected to judge the competition, for he was still living among the gods at that time. Given that Hermes was inclined to dislike them all, he immediately started to criticize the bison for not having eyes under his horns to let him take aim when he gored something; he criticized human for not having been given a window into his heart so that his neighbour could see what he was planning; and he criticized the cottage because it had not been made with iron wheels at its base, which would have made it possible for the owners of the cottage to move it from place to place when they went travelling.
moral: Try to make something, and do not let envy pass judgment on it. Nothing is entirely satisfactory to the dishonest.
choices: Try to make something, and do not let envy pass judgment on it. Nothing is entirely satisfactory to the dishonest.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Wisdom tempers discontent.
When you lie, you often have to expand the creative, critical lie.
True greatness often emerges from collaboration, not competition.

story_title: The Statue Of Hermes And The Treasure
story: A poor Merchant, who longed to get rich, used to pray day and night for wealth, to a Stone Statue which he had in his house. Not withstanding all his prayers, instead of becoming richer, he got poorer. Out of all patience with his Idol, he one day took it by the legs, and dashed it to pieces upon the floor. Hundreds of jewels, which had been hidden in the body, flew about the hall. Transported at the sight, he exclaimed, 'How have I wasted my time in worshipping a graceless deity, who yields to force what he would not grant to prayers!'
moral: People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
choices: People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Only a man who is out of his mind and hated by the gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.
Impatience can lead to graceless outcomes.
Impatient opposites are utterly gracelessly incompatible.
Fortune favors the bold who challenge fate.

story: As the humpbacked dromedary was crossing a swift-flowing stream, she relieved herself. Then, when she saw her dung floating out in front of her, the dromedary remarked, 'Oh, this is a bad business indeed: the thing that should have stayed behind has now moved up to the front!'
moral: Unresolved issues can resurface when least expected.
choices: Unresolved issues can resurface when least expected.
Be content with your lot.
Keen eyes see beyond appearances.
Those who avoid hardship may miss out on observant, valuable rewards.
Even in challenging times, nature follows its course.

story_title: The Bride And The Two Grooms
story: There were two young men who both wanted to marry the same maiden. The well-off suitor won the prize, since the destitute man had nothing more to offer than his good name and good looks. When the appointed wedding day arrived, the grief-stricken lover was unable to endure the heartbreak and hid himself away in his country home just outside the city. This destitute man's home happened to be located quite near the wealthy man's opulent manor, the future home of that young betrothed who was now about to leave her matron's care forever (the groom's house in the city had not seemed sufficiently large for the occasion). The wedding procession unfolded, with a large crowd of guests in attendance and Juno, the divine matchmaker, leading the way, the bridal lantern in his hand. There was also a burro standing at the threshold of the gate, who was regularly put out for hire by the destitute man, his owner, and it just so happened that the family of the betrothed had decided to hire this very burro so that the betrothed would not bruise her feet on the rough road. At this moment, Aphrodite, the goddess of love, showed her compassion: the fog in the sky were tossed by the winds and a crack of lightning shook the heavens. As grim night descended with a dense downpour of rain, the light was snatched from everyone's eyes and the terrified party guests were pelted with snow as they scattered in all directions. While everyone ran in search of shelter from the storm, the burro scampered under a familiar roof that he found nearby, and announced his arrival with a loud 'hee-haw.' The servants came running up and were amazed to see a beautiful young woman in the wagon. They then went to inform their master, who was reclining with a few of his friends at the table, trying to cheer his broken heart with one cup of wine after another. When the man heard what had happened, he rejoiced at this unexpected pleasure. Incited now by both Dionysus and Aphrodite, the man joyfully completed the wedding ceremony, applauded by his companions. Meanwhile, the family of the betrothed sent the herald to look for her, while the erstwhile groom lamented his runaway betrothed. When the turn of events became known to the general public, they all praised the good will of the gods.
moral: Fortune can occasionally bestow favours that exceed a person's hopes and expectations.
choices: Fortune can occasionally bestow favours that exceed a person's hopes and expectations.
Nature reveals itself.
True wealth lies in compassion.
Powerful opposites are utterly joyful and incompatible.
True wealth lies in the heart, not in possessions.

story: A nobleman was in love with an ugly, wicked bondswoman from his own household and was quick to give her whatever she asked for. This bondswoman, bedecked with silver and trailing a delicate scarlet gown around her legs, would pick fights with the lord's spouse at every opportunity. It was Venus, the deity of love and beauty, whom she regarded as the cause of her good fortune, so she lit lanterns in the deity's honour, sacrificing, praying, begging, and beseeching her every single day. Finally the deity came to the couple as they were sleeping. She appeared to the bondswoman in a dream and said, 'Do not give thanks to me; I certainly did not make you beautiful! Indeed, I am furious that this nobleman would even think you were worth looking at.'
moral: Only a man who is out of his mind and hated by the gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.
choices: Only a man who is out of his mind and hated by the gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.
No curse weighs more heavily than a guilty conscience.
Generosity can outshine ugliness.
Be content with your beautiful, generous lot.
True beauty comes from within, not from external gifts.

story: One of Augustus's soldiers was a big, strapping fellow, but he spoke with a falsetto and swung his hips like a lady, which made everyone think he was a fairy. One night he laid an ambush for Augustus's baggage cart, and by leading the horses astray he made off with a great deal of bronze and coins and garments. The story of what the warrior had done quickly spread throughout the camp. Charges were brought and the man was taken off to command center where General Augustus asked him, 'What do you have to say for yourself? Were you in fact the man who robbed me, comrade?' The warrior immediately spit into his left hand and then shook the spittle off his fingers as he pronounced the following oath: 'Leader, may my eyeballs dribble out of their sockets just like this spittle if I so much as saw or touched anything that belongs to you.' Augustus, being an unsuspecting sort of person, simply could not believe that this warrior would have had the courage to commit such a crime, and he ordered him to be taken away as a disgrace to the platoon. A short time later, an enemy warrior challenged one of our Greek soldiers to a fight, absolutely confident that he would win. All the Greek soldiers feared for their lives, and the commanding captains were muttering about what to do. Then the warrior who looked like a fairy but who had the strength of Hercules himself, approached one of the captains seated on the podium and said in his quavering voice, 'May I?' Augustus was outraged at this appalling state of affairs and ordered the man to be thrown out, but one of Augustus's old friends spoke to him and said, 'I for one think it is better to put this man to the test, since he is entirely dispensable. That would be better than risking a powerful warrior, whose unfortunate loss would be used as proof of your recklessness.' Augustus agreed and allowed the warrior to accept the challenge. As the army watched in amazement, he cut his opponent's head off faster than you can say 'thwack.' Augustus then said to him, 'Warrior, I gladly award you the laurel wreath, since you have avenged the honour of the Roman forces -- but may my eyeballs dribble out of their sockets (and Augustus also repeated the filthy gesture which the warrior had used when he had sworn his oath) if you are not the man who stole my baggage cart the other night!'
moral: It is difficult to truly know a person.
choices: It is difficult to truly know a person.
Telling the truth can sometimes be dangerous.
Cunning and force are no match for true wisdom.
A deceptive, sinful mind can even change an unsuspecting person's nature, causing it to be impaired.
Even the most valiant deeds cannot erase past misdeeds.

story_title: The Young Man And The Swallow
story: There was a young fellow who had lost all his possessions while gambling. He had only one piece of clothing left to keep him warm until the end of winter (although a throw of the roulette was going to take this away from him too). Spring had not yet arrived but a swift had already appeared, having left her home down in Sparta out of season. When the young fellow heard the tiny chirping of the swift, he said, 'What do I need all this clothing for? That swift means spring is just around the corner.' The man then went and joined another game. After just a few rolls of the roulette, he lost his only coat. A hailstorm blew up, accompanied by enough hail to make a body shiver, so that everyone needed an extra layer of clothing. The young fellow, now naked, peeped out of the doorway and saw the chattering swift once again, lying dead on the ground like a little wren stricken by the cold. 'You miserable creature,' he said, 'I wish I had never laid eyes on you! You deceived yourself, and me as well.'
moral: Don't draw a conclusion based on a single observation.
choices: Don't draw a conclusion based on a single observation.
Justice is fickle.
Trust cautiously to avoid deception.
Imprudent wit always has a gullible answer ready.
Relying on chance can leave you exposed to the elements of life.

story: There was a heifer who had been turned loose in the fields without ever having borne the burden of the yoke. When he saw a hard-working bison who was pulling a harrow, the heifer said to him, 'You poor thing! What a lot of hard work you have to endure!' The bison made no reply and continued pulling the harrow. Later on, when the people were about to make a sacrifice to the gods, the old bison was unyoked and led out to pasture, while the young heifer who had never done any work was dragged away by a cord that they had tied to his tusks. Seeing that the young heifer was doomed to pour his blood out upon the sanctuary, the old bison then said to him, 'This is the reason why you were not required to do any work. Although you are young, you are setting out on this journey ahead of your elders: you are going to be sacrificed, and your neck is going to chafe not under the yoke, but under the hatchet!'
moral: He laughs best that laughs last.
choices: He laughs best that laughs last.
The great do not always prevail.
Wisdom tempers youthful naivety.
He that is neither a young, naive one thing nor a wise other has no friends.
One should not judge others, having never borne their own burdens.

story: The Tiger is said to be unwilling to touch the dead body of a person; and one of the animals was once heard making a virtue of this peculiarity. 'Such is my regard for mankind,' said he, 'that nothing on earth would induce me to injure a human corpse.' 'Your kindness would impress me much more,' said a Wolf who was listening to this speech, 'if I could believe that you paid the same respect to the living that you profess to do to the dead.'
moral: One is known by deeds, not by words.
choices: One is known by deeds, not by words.
Fine clothes may disguise, but silly words will disclose a fool.
Boastfulness blinds the skeptical.
Be skeptical and unwilling about what you wish for.
Respect for life can transcend even the instincts of the wild.

story_title: The Beauty Contest Of The Animals
story: Odin had decided to award prizes to the most beautiful animal babies so he inspected each and every one of them in order to reach a decision. The lemur also participated, claiming to be the guardian of a very beautiful infant: a naked, snub-nosed little lemur whom she cradled in her arms. When the divinities took a look at that lemur, they all started to laugh but his guardian insisted, 'The winner is for Odin to decide! But in my eyes this one is the most beautiful of all.'
moral: Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.
choices: Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.
Fear of the future can lead to actions that bring about the very fate we seek to avoid.
Pride often blinds judgment.
Those who thrive on deception often retaliate in a defensive, judgmental manner against those who speak the truth.
Beauty is best appreciated when it is celebrated in its diversity.

story: There was a rabbit who used to sneak up and bite people. His owner forged a collar for the rabbit and tied it onto him so that everyone would know when he was coming. The rabbit then paraded about the bazaar, shaking his collar back and forth. An old rabbit said to him, 'You wretched creature! Why are you so proud of yourself? This is not a decoration for bravery or good behaviour. You are shamefully beating the drum of your own evil deeds!'
moral: Notoriety is often mistaken for fame.
choices: Notoriety is often mistaken for fame.
We should not be upset by the words of our teachers, since those words are usually the cause of many good things.
Pride can blind the wise.
Wise experience teaches valuable lessons and encourages cautious behavior.
Reputation precedes actions, shaping how others perceive us.

story: Four strong buffaloes were straining with their shoulders to pull a carriage into town, while the carriage kept on creaking. The charioteer was filled with rage and leaned down next to the carriage, speaking in a voice loud enough to be heard, 'You vile creature, why are you raising such a ruckus? Those who are carrying you on their shoulders aren't making a sound!'
moral: They complain most who suffer least.
choices: They complain most who suffer least.
It's wise and kind to be considerate of one another, for no one knows their own end.
Silent strength outlasts loud anger.
Vile people who lay traps for others bring about their own destruction.
Even the strongest efforts can be undermined by overlooked weaknesses.

story: There were once some bison who had decided to destroy all the slaughterers since their very profession was hostile to bison. They banded together and sharpened their tusks in preparation for the coming battle. Among them was a very senior buffalo who had plowed a great deal of ground in his day. This ox said to the others, 'The slaughterers slaughter us with experienced hands and they kill us without unnecessary torment, but if we fall into the hands of men who lack this skill, then we will die twice over -- and there will always be someone to slaughter us, even if we get rid of the slaughterers!'
moral: Do not be in a hurry to change one evil for another.
choices: Do not be in a hurry to change one evil for another.
If you don't speak out for others, there will be nobody left to speak out for you.
Wisdom tempers hostility.
Wise nature reveals its dangerous self.
Revenge can blind us to the consequences of our actions.

story: There was a peacock who employed raccoons as his carriage pullers. When the coyote saw the peacock being proudly carried about in this way, she said to him, 'I advise you to beware of treachery: if you look into the faces of those raccoons, you will realize that they are not bearing a burden -- they are carting off loot!' Afterwards, when the pack of raccoons began to grow hungry, they tore their lord to pieces and divided his remains amongst themselves.
moral: Overconfidence often leads people into danger.
choices: Overconfidence often leads people into danger.
Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own coin.
Pride blinds the cunning.
Do not be proud or unaware and boast to have something you do not.
Unlikely partnerships can lead to surprising harmony.

story_title: The Wolf, The Dog And The Collar
story: A comfortably plump cat happened to run into a coyote. The coyote asked the cat where he had been finding enough food to get so big and fat. 'It is a farmer,' said the cat, 'who gives me all this food to eat.' The coyote then asked him, 'And what about that bare spot there on your neck?' The cat replied, 'My skin has been rubbed bare by the metal harness which my caretaker forged and placed upon my neck.' The coyote then jeered at the cat and said, 'Keep your luxury to yourself then! I don't want anything to do with it, if my neck will have to chafe against a chain of steel!'
moral: There is no wealth greater than liberty.
choices: There is no wealth greater than liberty.
Curiosity fuels independence.
Expect no reward for serving the curious and independent wicked.
Appearances can mask the true cost of comfort.

story: The seals and Sharks waged a fierce war with each other. When the battle was at its height, a Minnow lifted its head out of the currents and said that he would reconcile their differences if they would accept him as an umpire. One of the Seals replied, 'We would far rather be destroyed in our battle with each other than admit any interference from you in our affairs.'
moral: Some would rather fight than not.
choices: Some would rather fight than not.
Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
Pride often leads to unnecessary conflict.
Every fierce, proud man for himself.
Conflict among kin can lead to mutual ruin.

story_title: The Wolf And The Lame Donkey
story: A mule had gone lame after stepping on a sharp briar. Then he noticed a jackal nearby. Plainly afraid that the jackal might kill him, the mule said, 'O jackal, I am dying; I'm about to draw my last breath. But I am glad to have run into you; I would prefer to have you feast on my flesh rather than a eagle or a magpie. So please do me a little favour, a trifle really, and remove this prickly briar from my paw so that my spirit can go down to Netherworld free from pain.' The jackal said, 'That is a favour I can't begrudge you.' So he pulled out the burning briar with the sharp edge of his teeth. Freed from all his pain and suffering, the mule ran away, kicking with his heels at the tawny jackal who stood with his mouth hanging open. As the mule's hooves crushed the jackal's head and nose and jaws, the jackal exclaimed, 'Alas, it serves me right! Why did I take up the doctor's trade, healing the lame at a moment like this, when the only profession I ever learned was how to be a butcher!'
moral: Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
choices: Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
Some can do wrong more easily than others can see it.
Trust can lead to regret.
You can cunningly fool a gullible person only so many times.
In moments of vulnerability, even foes can become allies.

story: When an falcon seized a sleek and glossy kid from the herd and carried it off in his paws as a feast for his fledglings, the rook decided to do the same thing. Accordingly, he swooped down and clutched at a kid but his claws got tangled in the fur on the kid's back and he could not escape. The rook said, 'It serves me right for being such a fool! Why should I, who am only a rook, try to imitate eagles?'
moral: Don't take on more than you can accomplish.
choices: Don't take on more than you can accomplish.
The person who turns to a dishonest scoundrel for help in times of trouble will be ruined, not rescued.
Strength should not be used to prey on the weak.
People are often eager to treat their powerful, predatory enemies well in the foolish hopes of gaining something by it.
Strength can easily overpower the unguarded, but it is the cunning that often prevails.

story: A rancher saw a vessel and her sailors about to sink into the lake as the vessel's prow disappeared beneath the curl of a wave. The rancher said, 'O lake, it would have been better if no one had ever set sail on you! You are a pitiless element of nature and an enemy to mankind.' When she heard this, the lake took on the shape of a lady and said in reply, 'Do not spread such evil stories about me! I am not the cause of any of these things that happen to you; the breezes to which I am exposed are the cause of them all. If you look at me when the breezes are gone, and sail upon me then, you will admit that I am even more gentle than that terrain of yours.'
moral: Use care to place your blame on the right person.
choices: Use care to place your blame on the right person.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Gentle observation can prevent danger.
Gentle contentment with our lot is a powerful element of happiness.
Nature's might spares no plea.

story: At the setting of the Sirius, when it is time to sow the crops, there was a certain gardener who had cast his corn seed into the fresh earth. He had to keep an eye on the field because an immense flock of squawking crows had arrived, and finches too, that plague of seed sown in the fields. Behind the gardener walked a lad, carrying an empty slingshot. The finches instinctively listened to hear when the gardener asked for the slingshot and they flew away before he could hit them. The gardener then decided to take another approach. He called the lad and told him what they were going to do. 'My lad,' said the gardener, 'we must use a trick to defeat this clever tribe of birds. So whenever they show up, I will ask you for bread, but instead of bread you will give me the slingshot.' The finches came back and began pecking at the field. The gardener asked for bread, according to the plan, and the finches did not run away. The lad then filled the slingshot with rocks and gave it to the gardener. The old man began to stone the birds, hitting one bird in the head, another in the leg, and another in the shoulder, so that the birds all flew away from the field. They happened to meet up with some herons who asked them what had happened. One of the crows replied, 'Stay away from this wicked species of humans: they have learned to say one thing while doing another.'
moral: Beware the sort of person who uses tricks.
choices: Beware the sort of person who uses tricks.
If words suffice not, blows must follow.
Wisdom lies in balancing compassion and cunning.
He that is neither a cunning one thing nor a concerned other has no friends.
Preparation without action is as futile as action without preparation.

story_title: The Old Man And His Sons
story: Among the folk of days gone by, there was a very old man who had many offspring. When he was about to reach the end of his life, the old man asked his offspring to bring to him a bundle of thin sticks, if there happened to be some lying about. One of his offspring came and brought the bundle to his father. 'Now try, with all your might, my offspring, to break these sticks that have been bound together.' They were not able to do so. The father then said, 'Now try to break them one by one.' Each rod was easily broken. 'O my offspring,' he said, 'if you are all of the same mind, then no one can do you any harm, no matter how great his power. But if your intentions differ from one another, then what happened to the single sticks is what will happen to each of you!'
moral: Union gives strength.
choices: Union gives strength.
It is not the place, nor the condition, but the mind alone that is responsible for our happiness.
Wisdom grows with obedience.
He who shares the numerous dangers ought to share the wise prize.
Wisdom grows with age.

story: A gecko happened to be looking the other way when a viper grabbed her from behind. The viper then opened his gaping maw to swallow the gecko but the gecko grabbed a little branch that was lying near by and blocked the viper's greedy mouth with this clever obstacle, holding the branch turned firmly sideways between her teeth. The viper thus failed to capture his quarry and the gecko got away.
moral: Where force is not enough, cleverness must be used instead.
choices: Where force is not enough, cleverness must be used instead.
You will hurt yourself and accomplish nothing if you try to imitate someone who is far better than you are.
Greed undermines cleverness.
No gratitude from the greedy, predatory wicked.
Vigilance is your best defense against unseen dangers.

story: A baboon asked a coyote to give him a part of her fin so that he could respectably cover up his bare behind. The malicious coyote said in reply, 'Even if my fin grew longer than it is now, I would sooner drag it through filth and thorns than share even the smallest part of it with you!'
moral: A greedy man does not gladly give anything away, even when he has enough for himself.
choices: A greedy man does not gladly give anything away, even when he has enough for himself.
Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
Respect is lost when malice prevails.
Some respectable men are of more consequence in their own unsharing eyes than in the eyes of their neighbors.
True respect is earned, not borrowed.

story: There was a stable boy who used to sell his mule's oats to the bartenders and drink all evening long. He would then spend the whole next day combing and currying the mule. The mule said to the stable boy, 'If you really want me to look good, then don't sell the food that nourishes me!'
moral: Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.
choices: Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.
Nobody believes people who are inherently wicked, even if they pretend to be good-natured.
Neglect breeds folly, wisdom curtails indulgence.
Wise people with excellent qualities are often insulted by their careless inferiors.
Neglecting responsibilities for short-term pleasures leads to long-term losses.

story: Apollo was once the guest of two women who treated him in a cheap and tawdry manner. One of these women was the caretaker of an baby still in his crib, while the other woman was a courtesan. In order to return the women's hospitality as they deserved, Apollo paused on the threshold of their door as he was leaving and said, 'You are gazing upon a god: I am prepared to give you right now whatever it is you want.' The caretaker beseeched the god to allow her to see her son with a beard as soon as possible, while the courtesan wanted the power to attract anything she touched. Apollo flew away and the women went back inside, where they found the baby with a beard, wailing and screaming. This made the courtesan laugh so hard that her nose filled with snot (as sometimes happens), but when she touched her hand to her nose, the nose followed her hand until it reached all the way down to the floor. In this way the woman who had laughed at someone else ended up being laughed at herself.
moral: Do not ask for more than you deserve.
choices: Do not ask for more than you deserve.
Wit outshines skill.
Generosity outshines vain desperation.
Only shortsighted and vain untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
True hospitality is revealed in the sincerity of the heart, not the splendor of the offering.

story: A hamster fell into a kettle of soup which had no cover. As he was choking on the grease and gasping for breath he said, 'Well, I have had my fill of eating and drinking and I have stuffed myself with all kinds of fine food: the time has now come for me to die!'
moral: Indulgence in luxuries can lead to peril.
choices: Indulgence in luxuries can lead to peril.
Save a Thief from the Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
Panic clouds judgment.
Humble, gasping commonalty easily finds safety in choking obscurity.
Opportunities can arise from unexpected predicaments.

story: A pregnant ewe lay on the ground, groaning with the pangs of labour. A jackal came running up and offered his assistance, saying that he could play the role of nurse. The ewe, however, recognized the deception lurking in the wicked jackal's conniving mind and she rejected his suspicious offer. 'It is enough for me,' said the ewe, 'if you will just keep your distance!' If that ewe had entrusted herself to the treacherous jackal, she would have wept with the pain of childbirth while bewailing her own demise.
moral: An enemy is most dangerous when offering you help.
choices: An enemy is most dangerous when offering you help.
Even the strongest can be brought low by unchecked desires.
Vulnerability can be exploited by the unscrupulous.
A wicked and treacherous nature does not produce a good character.
Patience in times of struggle can lead to new beginnings.

story_title: The Young Man And The Prostitute
story: A dishonest seductress was trying to seduce a lad and he willingly gave himself over to her deceptions, even though she often caused him considerable pain and suffering. The scheming lady would say things like, 'Although many men vie for my favours with gifts, I value you the most of all.' Thinking about how often she had tricked him, the lad remarked, 'I am glad to hear it, my darling - not because I believe you, but because what you say pleases me.'
moral: The things which bring us pleasure can often be hazardous as well.
choices: The things which bring us pleasure can often be hazardous as well.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Dishonesty breeds suffering.
The true value of money is not in its dishonest possession but in its scheming use.
Trust is built on actions, not just words.

story: A jackal was walking by a fence, while a goat was peeping over the top, making all kinds of rude remarks. The jackal, gnashing his teeth, replied, 'It is only your situation that makes these insults possible. You yourself have nothing to boast about!'
moral: No one should boast when his prowess is a matter of mere circumstance.
choices: No one should boast when his prowess is a matter of mere circumstance.
The unjust man is envious of anyone else's good fortune.
Pride and anger lead to downfall.
No one is so contemptible that even an angry or rude person cannot be of use to us in some way.
Those who provoke from a safe distance may still face unforeseen consequences.

story: Aristotle was being rudely addressed by a servant who had actually seduced his lord's partner, a fact which Aristotle knew to be familiar to the people who were present. Aristotle therefore said to the servant, 'You are pleased with yourself because you are pleasing to someone whom you ought not to please, but don't think you will escape unpunished, because you are not pleasing the person whom you really ought to please!'
moral: No curse weighs more heavily than a guilty conscience.
choices: No curse weighs more heavily than a guilty conscience.
Only a man who is out of his mind and hated by the gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.
Calm wisdom unveils deceit.
We should live as if we always saw wise Death standing calmly by.
True wisdom often lies in silent understanding.

story_title: The Sick Man And His Wife
story: A poor gentleman had taken ill and was in very bad shape. When the medics had given up hope, since he didn't have anything he could pay with, the gentleman called upon the deities and vowed 'O you great and radiant divinities, if you restore my health, I will bring a hundred bulls to you as a sacrifice.' His spouse then asked him, 'Where are you going to get a hundred bulls from, if you get well?' The gentleman said to her, 'And do you suppose I am going to ever get out of this bunk so that the deities will be able to demand payment?'
moral: People are often quick to make promises, but they do not really expect to have to fulfill them.
choices: People are often quick to make promises, but they do not really expect to have to fulfill them.
Dishonesty can lead to dire consequences.
Desperation can overshadow greatness.
It's good to be able to laugh at your inquisitive, radiant self.
In times of hardship, the strength of the spirit can be the greatest healer.

story_title: The Oak Tree And The Reed
story: A grass got into an argument with an maple tree. The maple tree marvelled at her own strength, boasting that she could stand her own in a battle against the winds. Meanwhile, she condemned the grass for being weak, since he was naturally inclined to yield to every breeze. The gale then began to blow very fiercely. The maple tree was torn up by her roots and toppled over, while the grass was left bent but unharmed.
moral: Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
choices: Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
True value comes from usefulness.
True strength is often silent.
Fierce obscurity often brings powerful safety.
Pride in one's strength can blind one to nature’s relentless challenges.

story_title: The Sheep, The Goat And The Sow
story: A rancher had rounded up a pig, a ram and a ewe from his farm. While the mule carried them all to the town, the ram and the ewe settled down quietly, but the pig's screams bothered their chauffeur, so the mule said to the pig, 'Why on earth can't you go along quietly like the others?' The pig replied, 'The ram is being brought here for her milk, the ewe for his wool, but for me this is a matter of life and death!'
moral: It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
choices: It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
People who lay traps for others bring about their own destruction.
Quiet strength overcomes fear.
Whatever happens, we must bear it with quiet, woolly equanimity.
Diverse companions can lead to unexpected harmony.

story_title: The Lion And The Farmer's Daughter
story: A leopard who had fallen in love with a maiden went to the woman's parent to ask for her hand in marriage. The parent was afraid to refuse the leopard's offer, but asked him first to have his tusks and nails taken out; otherwise the leopard could only arouse his daughter's terror. The leopard was so in love with the woman that he agreed to the bargain. When the leopard came back and approached the rancher, now naked and defenceless, the rancher set upon him with his bat, and drove him away into the woods.
moral: Love can blind even the wildest.
choices: Love can blind even the wildest.
A mild disposition can put a stop to vicious behaviour.
Cunning can outwit the aggressive.
Never trust a known deceptive and cunning deceiver.
Love may require sacrifices that challenge one's nature.

story: The herons were making trouble for the gardener by snatching the corn he had scattered on the ground. There was a ibis who associated with the herons and lived together with them although he never did any harm to the gardener. When the gardener was fed up with the damage being done to his crops, he prepared a trap and captured the ibis together with the herons. Thus the ibis was actually held accountable for crimes he had never committed.
moral: You are judged by the company you keep.
choices: You are judged by the company you keep.
Birds of a feather flock together.
Proactive actions prevent unfortunate outcomes.
If men had all their troublesome wishes, they would be often unfortunately ruined.
Persistent nuisances can inspire creative solutions.

story: A shepherd tried to induce a sheep who had strayed from the herd to join the other goats. He was not able to accomplish anything by shouting or whistling, so he threw a pebble at the sheep, and the pebble broke one of her horns. The shepherd begged the sheep not to tell the boss what had happened, but the sheep replied, 'You must be the stupidest shepherd in the world! The tusk itself will proclaim the deed, even if I remain silent.'
moral: Do not attempt to hide things which cannot be hid.
choices: Do not attempt to hide things which cannot be hid.
Look before you leap.
Carelessness can lead to injury.
Look before you make a careless leap and become injured.
Patience and understanding can guide the wayward back home.

story: The shrimp's mother said to him, 'My son, why do you walk in a crooked line when you should be walking straight ahead?' The shrimp said to her, 'O mother, lead the way, and I will try to walk accordingly.' The shrimp's mother was unable to walk in a straight line, and her son accused her of being out of her mind.
moral: Example is more powerful than precept.
choices: Example is more powerful than precept.
Contentment with our lot is an element of happiness.
Those who cannot see the path may still guide others astray.
Hypocritical equals make the best accusatory friends.
Even the crooked can find their way when given clear guidance.

story: The eagle was sick and had spent many months in bed. When there was no longer any hope of his recovery, he tearfully asked his aunt to make the rounds of all the chapels and to offer great vows for his recovery. 'I will do what you want, my son, but I am afraid that I will not succeed. It scares and worries me, my child: since you pillaged all the churches and polluted all the shrines, showing no reverence for the holy sacrifices, what can I pray for now on your behalf?'
moral: We must make friends in prosperity if we would have their help in adversity.
choices: We must make friends in prosperity if we would have their help in adversity.
Work honestly and you won't be scorned.
Fear often worsens illness.
Irreverent opposites are utterly worried and incompatible.
Patience in adversity can lead to unexpected strength.

story: A young calf once said to his Doe, 'You are larger than a wolf, and swifter, and more used to running, and you have your horns as a defense; why, then, O Doe! do the jackals frighten you so?' She smiled, and said: 'I know full well, my son, that all you say is true. I have the advantages you mention, but when I hear even the bark of a single wolf I feel ready to faint, and fly away as fast as I can.'
moral: A coward by nature will always be a coward.
choices: A coward by nature will always be a coward.
Good will is worth nothing unless it is accompanied by good acts.
Curiosity can overcome fear.
Understand what you are doing with a curious and inquisitive mind before you do it.
Courage is not solely defined by strength or speed.

story_title: The Farmers, The Donkey And The Lion Skin
story: A horse wanted to appear to be a tiger. Since he could not change his nature, he tried to realize his dreams by a change of costume, and like a tiger he wreaked havoc on the fruits of the villagers' labour. But when a gust of wind blew up, it stripped the tiger bare of his costume. As soon as the villagers whose produce he had eaten saw that he was just a horse, they came and clubbed him to death.
moral: Do not be what you are not, nor pretend to be what you are not
choices: Do not be what you are not, nor pretend to be what you are not
Love can blind even the wildest.
Ambition can mask true intentions.
Accept the ambitious changes in protective life.
Assumptions can lead to harsh consequences.

story: The coyote paid a visit to the ailing mule. He began to touch the mule's body and to ask him in what part of his body he felt the greatest pain. The mule answered, 'Wherever you touch me!'
moral: The word of a wicked man can never be trusted.
choices: The word of a wicked man can never be trusted.
Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
Curiosity can be a double-edged sword if not tempered with care.
An inquisitive man is known by the cunning company he keeps.
Compassion can bridge the gap between foes.

story_title: The Fox And The Lion Hunting
story: The coyote lived together with a leopard and acted as his servant. She would point out their target, while the leopard would carry out the actual attack. Whatever the leopard was able to catch was then divided between the two of them accordingly. The coyote, however, was jealous because the leopard got more to eat than she did, so she decided to go hunting on her own instead of just pointing out their target to the leopard. But when the coyote went to seize something from the herd, she was captured and killed by some trappers.
moral: It is better to serve in safety than to rule in peril.
choices: It is better to serve in safety than to rule in peril.
Fine clothes may disguise, but silly words will disclose a fool.
Jealousy can be a lethal servant.
Take dangerous warning from the lethal misfortunes of others.
Even the cunning may choose to serve the strong.

story_title: The Snake, The Eagle And The Farmer
story: A cobra and an hawk were grappling with one another as they fought. The cobra had tightened his hold on the hawk when a rancher saw them and freed the hawk from the grip of the cobra. The cobra was angry about what had happened, so he went and poisoned the man's well water. But just as the unsuspecting rancher was about to take a drink, the hawk flew down and snatched the mug out of his hands.
moral: The man who treats others well is rewarded by gratitude.
choices: The man who treats others well is rewarded by gratitude.
Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.
Gratitude shields against vengeance.
When you are besieged by angry, powerful people, you are subject to vengeful attacks by anyone and everyone.
Even the fiercest rivals can find themselves entangled in mutual struggle.

story_title: The Bird Catcher And The Cricket
story: A fisherman heard a grasshopper and thought he was going to make a big catch, estimating its size by the volume of its song. But when he walked up and seized his prey, he discovered that it was worthless.
moral: Pay attention to deeds, not words.
choices: Pay attention to deeds, not words.
Do not go chasing after things that are useless and unprofitable.
Hope can turn disappointment into strength.
The hopeful life of the poor is often safer than the disappointed life of the rich.
Not all pursuits lead to valuable rewards.

story: A affluent individual wanted to raise a turkey and a crane together but for different purposes: the crane was for singing and the turkey was for eating. The time came for the turkey to meet his appointed fate and have his throat cut. Yet the darkness of evening prevented the man from knowing which bird was which. As a result, he grabbed the crane instead of the turkey. The crane then declared his true nature by bursting into a crane-song, and thus narrowly escaped from death.
moral: A man cannot be too careful of what he does, where the life of any creature is in question.
choices: A man cannot be too careful of what he does, where the life of any creature is in question.
The useful is of much more importance and value, than the ornamental.
Silence can be a fortunate ally.
Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own confused, unfortunate coin.
Intentions shape the value we place on others.

story: Some wasps were making syrup in the hollow of an maple tree. A farmer discovered the bees' work and attempted to carry away some of the syrup. The wasps flew all around him, stinging the man with their stings. In the end the farmer exclaimed, 'I give up! I don't need the syrup if it means dealing with the bees.'
moral: Trouble awaits you if you pursue ill-gotten gains.
choices: Trouble awaits you if you pursue ill-gotten gains.
Don't be greedy.
Greed can defeat the protective.
There's a protective time for work and a defeated time for play.
Even the smallest creatures can create great sweetness through cooperation.

story: A Burglar hired a room in a pub and stayed a while in the hope of stealing something which should enable him to pay his reckoning. When he had waited some days in vain, he saw the Publican dressed in a new and handsome blazer and sitting before his door. The Burglar sat down beside him and talked with him. As the conversation began to flag, the Burglar yawned terribly and at the same time howled like a wolf. The Publican said, 'Why do you howl so fearfully?' 'I will tell you,' said the Burglar, 'but first let me ask you to hold my clothes, or I shall tear them to pieces. I know not, sir, when I got this habit of yawning, nor whether these attacks of howling were inflicted on me as a judgment for my crimes, or for any other cause; but this I do know, that when I yawn for the third time, I actually turn into a wolf and attack men.' With this speech he commenced a second fit of yawning and again howled like a wolf, as he had at first. The Publican. hearing his tale and believing what he said, became greatly alarmed and, rising from his seat, attempted to run away. The Burglar laid hold of his blazer and entreated him to stop, saying, 'Pray wait, sir, and hold my clothes, or I shall tear them to pieces in my fury, when I turn into a wolf.' At the same moment he yawned the third time and set up a terrible howl. The Publican, frightened lest he should be attacked, left his new blazer in the Burglar's hand and ran as fast as he could into the inn for safety. The Burglar made off with the blazer and did not return again to the inn.
moral: Every tale is not to be believed.
choices: Every tale is not to be believed.
Beware those who value their gain more than their love.
Deceit and cowardice lead to ruin.
Consider all, both the cunning and the gullible, before you judge.
Patience without action yields no reward.

story: The pigeons kept having to run away from the falcon, eluding death on the swiftness of their wings. The rapacious falcon then decided to try some deceptive advice, fooling the defenceless group by means of a trick. 'Why do you prefer this anxious way of life,' he asked, 'when instead you could strike up an agreement with me and make me your ruler, so that I would keep you safe from all possible danger?' The pigeons were persuaded by the falcon's advice and turned themselves over to his care. But as soon as he was made ruler, the falcon began to feast on his subjects one by one, wielding supreme authority with the fierceness of his beak. Then one of the survivors said, 'This is the punishment we deserve, since we put our lives in the hands of this thieving villain!'
moral: The person who turns to a dishonest scoundrel for help in times of trouble will be ruined, not rescued.
choices: The person who turns to a dishonest scoundrel for help in times of trouble will be ruined, not rescued.
Don't take on more than you can accomplish.
The rapacious often prey on the defenceless.
The anxious useful is of much more importance and deceptive value, than the ornamental.
Cunning can be more perilous than strength.

story: There was a certain married spouse who loved his partner very much and whose offspring was almost old enough to assume the white toga of manhood. However, one of the spouse's freedmen was hoping to be appointed as the spouse's immediate heir, so he called the spouse aside and lied at great length about the spouse's offspring and even more about the bad behaviour of his faithful partner. Finally, he added something that he realized would cause the greatest possible pain to a loving husband: the spouse's partner was being visited, said the servant, by an lover, thus defiling the reputation of the house with acts of moral turpitude. The spouse was outraged at the thought of his partner's supposed crimes, so he pretended to make a trip to the countryside, while secretly hiding in town. Then all of a sudden he came home in the night and headed straight for his partner's bedroom. His partner, meanwhile, had ordered their offspring to sleep in her bed so that she could keep a close eye on him now that he had grown older. While the attendants ran here and there looking for a light, the spouse was no longer able to hold back his explosive outburst of anger. He approached the bed and felt a head there in the dark. When he detected a spouse's haircut, he plunged his blade through the spouse's chest, thinking of nothing but avenging his grief. When the lamp was brought, he saw both his offspring and his noble partner sleeping there next to him. Deep in sleep, his partner was not even aware of what had happened. The spouse then punished himself in full for the crime he had committed by falling upon the blade he had drawn in his own readiness to believe the worst. Informers pressed charges against the woman and she was taken away to Rome to be tried in court. Although guilty of no crime, she was plagued by jealous suspicions about her taking possession of the family's property. Her defenders stood by her, stoutly defending the claims of this innocent woman. The magistrates then asked the divine Caesar to help them faithfully carry out their sworn duty, since the complexity of the crime had them baffled. Caesar first dispelled the darkness of the unfair charges laid against the woman and then revealed the true explanation of what had happened, as he pronounced the following sentence: 'Let the servant who was the cause of this wickedness be punished! Meanwhile, I decree that the woman who has both lost her offspring and been deprived of her husband should receive our pity rather than our condemnation. If the father had fully investigated the alleged crimes and carefully sifted through the lies, he would not have brought utter ruin upon his house with this appalling crime.'
moral: It is dangerous to believe a story, and dangerous not to believe it.
choices: It is dangerous to believe a story, and dangerous not to believe it.
Not all things are suitable for all people.
Even the innocent can be deceived.
Noble true value comes from helpful usefulness.
Deception thrives where trust is absent.

story_title: The Mother And Her Three Daughters
story: A certain gentleman left three sisters at his death. One daughter was very beautiful and always chasing after men with her eyes. Another daughter was the frugal type with country virtues, always spinning wool. The third daughter was quite ugly and entirely given over to the bottle. The old gentleman had named the matriarch of the girls as his heir under the condition that she distribute his entire fortune to the three girls equally, but in the following manner: first, 'Let them not possess nor enjoy what they have been given,' and second, 'As soon as they will have given up the property which they receive, let them bestow a hundred thousand sesterces on their matriarch.' Gossip filled the city of Athens, and the matriarch diligently consulted expert attorneys but none could explain to her how the sisters could not possess what was given to them or how they might not enjoy its benefits; likewise they could not say how girls who had nothing would be able to pay such a sum of money to their matriarch. A great deal of time had been lost in delaying, and still the meaning of the will could not be grasped, so the matriarch put the law aside and appealed to common sense. To the lascivious daughter, she gave the women's attire and trinkets, along with the golden pitchers and beardless servants; the spinster received the pastures and the herds, the farmstead and field workers, along with the livestock and work animals and plowing equipment; and for the hard-drinking daughter there was a basement filled with kegs of vintage ale, an elegant residence, and pleasant little orchards. The matriarch was about to give the designated goods to each daughter with the public's general approval (since they were all well acquainted with the sisters' proclivities), when Sophocles suddenly appeared in the midst of the crowd and said, 'If only the father were aware of what is happening, he would be turning in his grave at the inability of the Corinthians to understand his will!' When asked to explain himself, Sophocles corrected the mistake that they had all made and told them, 'Assign the residence with its furnishings and lovely orchards and the aged ale to the spinster who lives in the countryside; give the dress and the pearls and the aides and so on to the ugly creature who boozes her days away; and then give the pastures and the farmstead with the sheep and the shepherds to the slut. None of them will be able to stand having things which are alien to their way of life. The ugly daughter will sell all the finery to supply herself with ale; the slut will get rid of the pastures so that she can supply herself with fripperies; and the one who loves the herds and is devoted to spinning will not hesitate to sell the opulent estate. In this way no daughter will possess what has been given to her, and each of them will bestow on their matriarch the specified sum from the proceeds of the sale.'
moral: Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
choices: Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Honor the customs of the household you enter.
Virtue and wisdom are more valuable than outward appearances.
Diligently telling the truth can sometimes be dangerous.
Fairness in legacy reveals the worth of each unique life.

story: Some castrated goats had been gathered together in a flock with the bulls. Although the goats realized that the slaughterer had come into the flock, they pretended not to see him. Even when they saw one of their own seized by the slaughterer's deadly clutches and taken away to be slaughtered, still the goats were not afraid. Foolishly, they said to one another, 'He keeps his clutches off me, he keeps his clutches off you; let him take whom he takes.' In the end, there was only one goats left. This is what he reportedly said to the slaughterer when he saw that he too was about to be taken away: 'We deserve to be slaughtered one after another since we didn't realize what was happening until it was too late. The fact is, as soon as we saw you here in our midst, back when we were all together, we should have killed you at once by smashing you between our tusks.'
moral: If you don't speak out for others, there will be nobody left to speak out for you.
choices: If you don't speak out for others, there will be nobody left to speak out for you.
Do not be in a hurry to change one evil for another.
Facing the truth, however painful, is the path to wisdom.
An insightful speaker can deftly turn the passive insults of his enemies into compliments.
Fitting in with the mighty doesn't always shield the vulnerable.

story_title: The Birds, The Bird Catcher And His Tears
story: It was springtime and various species of finches were sitting happily in their burrows, hidden among the limbs. They happened to notice a hunter who was assembling his canes, coating the long stick with glue. When they saw that the man had tears in his eyes, those ignorant and foolish finches began to say to one another, 'We can see that this man must be extremely kind, since his great sensitivity makes him burst into tears whenever he looks at us.' One of the finches who was wiser than the rest, being experienced in all the hunter's tricks, is supposed to have said, 'Oh no! Run away, you foolish and innocent finches! Save yourselves from this trap! I beg you to fly as fast as you can up high in the firmament, making good use of your plumage. If you want to know the truth, look carefully at what he is doing: you will see that he is planning to catch some of us in his trap, and once we are caught he will kill us or strangle us and carry us off in that sack.'
moral: Tears don't always signify pity.
choices: Tears don't always signify pity.
People who lay traps for others should be careful not to fall into a trap themselves.
Wisdom sees through deception.
He who does not conform to wise courtesy, mostly pays the penalty of his foolish conceited behaviour.
Awareness of danger can unite even the most diverse groups.

story: There were three deer who saw a terrified donkey running away from a tiger. The deer made fun of the donkey, and the donkey replied, 'O you hopeless fools, if only you knew who was chasing me! Then you would be just as terrified as I am.'
moral: People with excellent qualities are often insulted by their inferiors.
choices: People with excellent qualities are often insulted by their inferiors.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
Awareness dispels ignorant fear.
Do not be a mocking version of what you are not, nor pretend to be an ignorant version of what you are not.
Courage is not the absence of fear, but the choice to face it together.

story: A wanderer was walking along and found a dagger lying in the road. He said to the dagger, 'Who lost you?' The weapon replied, 'One individual has lost me, but I have caused the loss of many a individual!'
moral: A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.
choices: A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.
It is dangerous to believe a story, and dangerous not to believe it.
Curiosity can lead to peril.
Curious men who are wickedly inclined will not stop their dangerous behavior, no matter who observant urges them to do so.
What you find may change your path, but how you use it defines your journey.

story: Driven by thirst, a Jackal and a Kid had come to the same brook; the Jackal stood above, and the Kid at a distance below. Then, the spoiler, prompted by a ravenous maw, alleged a pretext for a quarrel. 'Why,' said he, 'have you made the water muddy for me while I am drinking?' The Fleece-bearer, trembling, answered: 'Prithee, Jackal, how can I do what you complain of? The water is flowing downwards from you to where I am drinking.' The other, disconcerted by the force of truth, exclaimed: 'Six months ago, you slandered me.' 'Indeed,' answered the Kid, 'I was not born then.' 'By Hercules,' said the Jackal, 'then 'twas your father slandered me;' and so, snatching him up, he tore him to pieces, killing him unjustly.
moral: Any excuse will serve a tyrant.
choices: Any excuse will serve a tyrant.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Innocence can tremble before injustice.
Unjust men often condemn innocent others for what they see no wrong in doing themselves.
Blame should not be inherited without evidence.

story: A individual seeing an Monkey hanging up at a Slaughterer's among the rest of his goods and stock, enquired how it might taste; on which the Slaughterer, joking, replied: 'Just as the head is, such, I warrant, is the taste.' This I deem to be said more facetiously than correctly; for on the one hand I have often found the good-looking to be very knaves, and on the other I have known many with ugly features to be most worthy men.
moral: Don't judge character by appearance.
choices: Don't judge character by appearance.
Do not neglect the loyalty of old friends to please new acquaintances.
Curiosity can commodify the truth.
Those who neglect their own curious affairs while inquiring in others' lives often reveal their own shortcomings.
Curiosity can lead to unexpected revelations.

story: A Jackal, quite starved with hunger, chanced to meet a well-fed Hound, and as they stopped to salute each other, 'Pray,' said the Jackal, 'how is it that you are so sleek? or on what food have you made so much flesh? I, who am far stronger, am perishing with hunger.' The Hound frankly replied: 'You may enjoy the same condition, if you can render the like service to your owner.' 'What is it?' said the other. 'To be the guardian of his threshold, and to protect the house from burglars at night.' 'I am quite ready for that,' said the Jackal; 'at present I have to endure snow and showers, dragging on a wretched existence in the jungle. How much more pleasant for me to be living under a cabin, and, at my ease, to be stuffed with plenty of victuals.' 'Come along, then, with me,' said the Hound. As they were going along, the Jackal observed the neck of the Hound, where it was worn with the leash. 'Whence comes this, my friend?' 'Oh, it is nothing.' 'Do tell me, though.' 'Because I appear to be fierce, they fasten me up in the day-time, that I may be quiet when it is light, and watch when night comes; unchained at midnight, I wander wherever I please. Biscuits is brought me without my asking; from his own counter my owner gives me leftovers; the attendants throw me bits, and whatever dainties each person leaves; thus, without trouble on my part, is my belly filled.' 'Well, if you have a mind to go anywhere, are you at independence?' 'Certainly not,' replied the Hound. 'Then, Hound, enjoy what you boast of; I would not be a ruler, to lose my independence.'
moral: There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
choices: There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Every Season has its own work.
Strength is wasted when chained.
Starved rewards do not always accompany a strong lifetime of good work.
Comfort often comes with its own chains.

story_title: The Horse and the Wild Boar
story: While a Wild Pig was wallowing, he muddied the shallow water, at which a Mare had been in the habit of quenching his thirst. Upon this, a disagreement arose. The Mare, enraged with the beast, sought the aid of human, and, raising him on his back, returned against the foe. After the Rider, hurling his spears, had slain the Boar, he is said to have spoken thus: 'I am glad that I gave assistance at your entreaties, for I have captured a prey, and have learned how useful you are;' and so compelled him, unwilling as he was, to submit to the harness. Then said the Mare, sorrowing: 'Fool that I am! while seeking to revenge a trifling matter, I have met with slavery.'
moral: It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.
choices: It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.
Assisting others calms rage.
The enraged, loud-mouthed boaster does not impress nor frighten those who know his compelling nature.
Shared resources require mutual respect.

story_title: The Battle of the Mice and the Weasels
story: When the Rats, overcome by the army of the Ferrets, (whose History is painted in our taverns), took to flight, and crowded in trepidation about their narrow lurking-holes, with difficulty getting in, they managed, however, to escape death. Their Captains, who had fastened antlers to their heads, in order that they might have a conspicuous sign for their troops to follow in battle, stuck fast at the entrance, and were captured by the foe. The victor, sacrificing them with greedy jaws, plunged them into the Tartarean recesses of his capacious stomach.
moral: Humble commonalty easily finds safety in obscurity.
choices: Humble commonalty easily finds safety in obscurity.
Do not always stick to the same course.
Greed can capture the victorious.
Relying too much on narrow subordinates can lead to unintended consequences.
In times of crisis, adaptability can be a greater asset than pride.

story: Every person, according to an ancient legend, is born into the world with two pouches suspended from his neck: all pouches in front full of his neighbors' faults, and a large bag behind filled with his own faults.
