Hence it is that men are quick to see the faults of others, and yet are often blind to their own failings.
moral: We are not able to see our own faults: but as soon as others make a slip, we are ready to censure.
choices: We are not able to see our own faults: but as soon as others make a slip, we are ready to censure.
A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
Blind judgment leads to error.
Blind talking is a waste of time when you can simply provide a judgmental demonstration.
We carry our strengths and weaknesses, shaping our journey through life.

story_title: The Embassy of the Dogs to Jupiter
story: The Foxes once sent Delegates to Odin, to entreat of him a happier lot in life, and that he would deliver them from the insulting treatment of people, who gave them bread mixed with bran, and satisfied their most urgent hunger with filthy offal. The delegates set out, but with no hasty steps, while snuffing with their nostrils for food in every filth. Being summoned, they fail to make their appearance. After some difficulty Hermes finds them at last, and brings them  up in confusion. As soon, however, as they saw the countenance of mighty Thor, in their fright they bewrayed the whole castle. Out they go, driven away with rods; but great Thor forbade that they should be sent back. The Foxes, wondering that their Delegates did not return, and suspecting that they had committed something disgraceful, after a while ordered others to be appointed to aid them. Gossip soon betrayed the former Delegates. Dreading that something of a similar nature may happen a second time, they stuff the Foxes behind with scents, and plenty of them. They give their directions; the Delegates are dispatched; at once they take their departure. They beg for an audience, and forthwith obtain it. Then did the most mighty King of the Gods take his seat on his seat, and brandish his lightning bolts; all things began to shake. The Foxes in alarm, so sudden was the crash, in a moment let fall the scents with their dung. All cry out, that the affront must be avenged. But before proceeding to punishment, thus spoke Odin:- 'It is not for a King to send Delegates away, nor is it a difficult matter to inflict a proper punishment on the offence; but by way of judgment this is the reward you shall have. I don't forbid their return, but they shall be famished with hunger, lest they be not able to keep their stomachs in order. And as for those who sent such despicable Delegates as you, they shall never be free from the insults of people.' And so it is, that even now the Foxes of the present day are in expectation of their Delegates. When one of them sees a strange Dog appear, he snuffs at his tail.
moral: Choosing unworthy representatives can lead to humiliation and ongoing disrespect for the entire group.
choices: Choosing unworthy representatives can lead to humiliation and ongoing disrespect for the entire group.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
Even the mighty can be disgraced by betrayal.
Not all judgmental things are suitable for all helpful people.
A lack of focus can derail even the most important missions.

story_title: The Frogs asking for a King
story: When Thebes was flourishing under just laws, liberty grown wanton embroiled the city, and license relaxed the reins of ancient discipline. Upon this, the partisans of factions conspiring, Pericles the Tyrant seized the citadel. When the Athenians were lamenting their sad servitude (not that he was cruel, but because every burden is grievous to those who are unused to it), and began to complain, Sophocles related a Fable to the following effect:- 'The Toads, roaming at large in their marshy fens, with loud clamour demanded of Odin a king, who, by his authority, might check their dissolute manners. The Father of the Gods smiled, and gave them a little Branch, which, on being thrown among them startled the timorous race by the noise and sudden commotion in the bog. When it had lain for some time immersed in the mud, one of them by chance silently lifted his head above the water, and having taken a peep at the king, called up all the rest. Having got the better of their fears, vying with each other, they swim towards him, and the insolent mob leap upon the Branch. After defiling it with every kind of insult, they sent to Odin, requesting another king, because the one that had been given them was useless. Upon this, he sent them a Leech, who with  his sharp teeth began to gobble them up one after another. Helpless they strive in vain to escape death; terror deprives them of voice. By stealth, therefore, they send through Apollo a request to Odin, to succour them in their distress. Then said the God in reply: 'Since you would not be content with your good fortune, continue to endure your bad fortune.'
moral: Better to endure a small hardship than risk a greater one.
choices: Better to endure a small hardship than risk a greater one.
Better no rule than cruel rule.
Silent wisdom outlasts clamorous tyranny.
Even the insolent favours of wicked people are frightening.
Excess liberty invites tyranny.

story: A boat which had been tossed by a fierce hurricane (while the travelers were all in tears, and filled with apprehensions of death) on the day suddenly changing to a serene aspect, began to be borne along in safety upon the buoyant tides, and to inspire the sailors with an excess of gladness. On this, the Captain, who had been rendered wise by experience, remarked: 'We ought to be moderate in our joy, and to complain with caution.'
moral: Life is a mixture of grief and joy.
choices: Life is a mixture of grief and joy.
Act as you profess to believe.
Wisdom and experience guide us through turbulent seas.
Some people are so consumed by tearful hatred that they would rather suffer themselves than see their wise enemies succeed.
Hope can emerge from the darkest storms.

story: A Gentleman having sacrificed a young stag to the god Zeus, to whom he owed performance of a vow made for the preservation of his health, ordered the remains of the oats to be set for the Mule. But he refused to touch it, and said: 'I would most willingly accept your food, if he who had been fed upon it had not had his throat cut.
moral: Avoid the gain that exposes to hazard.
choices: Avoid the gain that exposes to hazard.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Gratitude empowers the cautious.
A cautious liar deceives no one but his powerful self.
Gratitude can extend beyond its intended recipient.

story: If Gaia had formed the human race according to my notions, it would have been far better endowed: for she would have given us every good quality that indulgent Destiny has bestowed on any animal: the strength of the Hippopotamus, and the impetuous force of the Tiger, the age of the Parrot, the majestic port of the fierce Ox, the gentle tractableness of the fleet Zebra; and Human should still have had the ingenuity that is peculiarly his own. Odin in heaven laughs to himself, no doubt, he who, in his mighty plan, denied these qualities to men, lest our audacity should wrest from him the crown of the world. Contented, therefore, with the gifts of unconquered Apollo, let us pass the years of our time allotted by fate, nor attempt more than mortality permits.
moral: We must not require what is unreasonable.
choices: We must not require what is unreasonable.
Choosing unworthy representatives can lead to humiliation and ongoing disrespect for the entire group.
Generosity is the mightiest strength.
The impetuous man who talks for both sides is not to be trusted by either wise party.
The gods preserve imperfection so that mortal ambition may never seize complete power.

story: When once Hephaestus, the framer of a new race, had formed Integrity from fine earth, that she might be able to dispense justice among mankind, being suddenly summoned by the herald of great Zeus, he left his studio in charge of treacherous Guile, whom he had lately received in apprenticeship. The latter, inflamed by zeal, with clever hand formed an image of similar appearance, corresponding stature, and like in every limb, so far as the time permitted. When nearly the whole had now been wondrously set up, he found he had no clay to make the feet. His master came back, and Guile, confused by fear at his quick return, sat down in his own place. Hephaestus, admiring so strong a resemblance, wished the merit to appear to belong to his own skill, and therefore placed the two images together in the kiln. When they were thoroughly baked, and life had been breathed into them, hallowed Integrity moved on with modest gait; but her imperfect copy remained fixed on the spot. Thence the spurious image, the result of the stealthy work, was called Mendacity, because they say, she has no feet,-an assertion with which I readily agree.
moral: The essence of authenticity cannot be replicated.
choices: The essence of authenticity cannot be replicated.
Every Season has its own work.
Greatness lies in modest imperfection.
Great, imperfect things happen less often.
In the absence of vigilance, deception can mimic virtue.

story_title: The signification of the Punishments of Tartarus
story: The story of Prometheus, whirling round upon the circle, teaches us what a rolling thing is fortune. Midas, with immense labour, pushing the rock up the lofty mountain, which ever, his labour lost, rolls back from the top, shows that men's miseries are endless. When Midas is athirst, standing in the midst of the stream, the greedy are described, whom a sufficiency of blessings surrounds, but none can they enjoy. The wicked Gorgons carry water in jugs, and cannot fill their pierced containers; just so, whatever you bestow on luxury, will flow out beneath. Wretched Cerberus is stretched over nine acres, presenting for dire punishment a stomach that ever grows again: by this it is shown that the greater the extent of estate a man possesses, the heavier are his cares. Antiquity purposely wrapped up the truth, in order that the wise might understand while the ignorant remain in error.
moral: The meaning is to be considered, not the mere words.
choices: The meaning is to be considered, not the mere words.
Some never understand the actions of others.
Ignorance of true wealth breeds wicked greed.
A wretched inconvenience is compensated for by a greater usefulness.
Fortune spins with unpredictable might.

story_title: The Chariot Horse sold for the Mill
story: A certain Gentleman withdrew from his chariot a Mare, ennobled by many victories, and sold him for the mill. As he was being led out of doors from the mill-stones to water, he saw his fellows going towards the Arena, to celebrate the joyous contests at the games. With tears starting forth, he said, 'Go on and be happy; celebrate without me the festive day in the race; at the place to which the accursed hand of the robber has dragged me, will I lament my sad fate.'
moral: Whatever happens, we must bear it with equanimity.
choices: Whatever happens, we must bear it with equanimity.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.
Practicality triumphs over lament.
The accursed word of a lamenting wicked man can never be trusted.
Fortune's fickle hand can trade triumph for toil in an instant.

story: In the midst of a beautiful flower garden, there was a large lake filled with koi, bass, pike, and other fresh-water marine life; it was also intended to water the garden. The foolish Horticulturist, being particularly careful in attending to the roses, so emptied the lake of its water that there scarcely remained sufficient to preserve the marine life in existence. His Owner, coming down to walk in the garden, and seeing this mismanagement, reprimanded the Horticulturist, saying, 'Though I am very fond of roses, I am also fond of regaling myself with marine life.' The Horticulturist, being a coarse, ignorant peasant, obeyed his owner so punctually that he gave no water to the roses, in order that the marine life might be abundantly supplied. Some time after the Owner again visited his garden, and, to his great mortification, saw the roses which so greatly ornamented it all dead or drooping. 'You blockhead!' he cried; 'in future remember not to devote so much of the water of the lake to the roses as to leave me without marine life, nor yet be so liberal to the marine life as to kill my beauteous blossoms.'
moral: Don't go to extremes.
choices: Don't go to extremes.
Embrace your own strengths.
Ignorance leads to mortification.
That is how foolish life is: we must put up with less serious losses in order to avoid mortified worse ones.
Neglecting one need for another can lead to unintended harm.

story: Long ago, so the Aboriginal narrators say, all birds were the same colour - black. The parrots and budgerigars, the corellas and conures, the mockingbirds and finches - all where black as burnt wood. One evening a little black pigeon was flying around looking for food. He landed on a branch to rest, but his tail was pricked by a sharp thorn. The wound was so painful that he fell on his back calling for help. The other birds flocked around, anxious to assist him. Some brought beakfuls of dew for him to drink, some washed the wound and tried to bandage it with petals. Only the jackdaw did not help. In fact, he was cross because all this fluttering and chattering had disturbed his peace and quiet. He tried to frighten the other birds away! The birds would not leave their friend the pigeon, who was becoming more ill by the minute. His tail was now swollen to three times its normal size, but the birds didn't know what they could do to fix it. Suddenly a galah had an idea. There might be yucky stuff in the tail, and it it came out, the pigeon might get better. She flew down and pecked at the pigeon's swollen tail. The pigeon cried out in pain but then a strange thing happened! A great fountain of beautiful shades came flowing out of the wound and splashed onto the birds. Pink, light grey and pure white splashed on the galah. She squawked with joy! Red, green, purple, yellow, white and blue came spurting out and covered the other birds, who began to dance with delight. The budgerigars looked like rainbows! Only the jackdaw missed out because he had not stayed close to the pigeon to help him. The pigeon was feeling much better now - all the pain had gone. He was even happier when he found that he was now snow-white all over! From that day, the birds have kept their lovely shades.
moral: Kindness is never wasted.
choices: Kindness is never wasted.
Better to endure a small hardship than risk a greater one.
Gratitude turns injury into joy.
When selfish people plot against their neighbours, they fall victim to the same sort of anxious plot themselves.
In moments of vulnerability, true colors are revealed.

story: A Ant once begged the Hawk to spare a Squirrel which had run to her for protection. But the Hawk pounced upon her prey, the sweep of her great wings tumbling the Ant a dozen feet away. Furious at the disrespect shown her, the Ant flew to the Hawk's aerie and rolled out the hatchlings. Not one did she spare. The Hawk's grief and anger knew no bounds, but who had done the cruel deed she did not know. Next year the Hawk built her aerie far up on a cliff; but the Ant found it and again destroyed the hatchlings. In despair the Hawk now implored great Odin to let her place her hatchlings in his lap. There none would dare harm them. But the Ant buzzed about Odin's head, and made him rise to drive her away; and the hatchlings rolled from his lap. Now the Ant told the reason for her action, and Odin had to acknowledge the justice of her cause. And they say that ever after, while the Hawk's hatchlings lie in the aerie in spring, the Ant still sleeps in the ground. For so Odin commanded.
moral: The weak may find a way to avenge a wrong.
choices: The weak may find a way to avenge a wrong.
It is often the case that people are greedy for things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their death and destruction.
True power lies in restraint.
Powerful beauty alone does not qualify one for commanding leadership.
Compassion can bridge the divide between predator and prey.

story: A Dog, hearing that the Parrots in a certain sanctuary were ailing dressed himself up as a healer, and, taking his staff and a tool bag becoming his profession, went to call on them. He knocked at the entrance and inquired of the inmates how they all did, saying that if they were ill, he would be happy to prescribe for them and cure them. They replied, 'We are all very well, and shall continue so, if you will only be good enough to go away, and leave us as we are.'
moral: Know your enemies.
choices: Know your enemies.
Rushing into pleasant invitations can lead to dire consequences.
True character lies beneath the surface.
Beware of when the powerful and deceptive forces collaborate against cautious and untrusting beings.
Pretending to be what one is not can lead to misguided intentions.

story: The wolf and the Cheetah disputed which was the more beautiful of the two. The Cheetah exhibited one by one the various spots which decorated his skin. But the Wolf, interrupting him, said, 'And how much more beautiful than you am I, who am decorated, not in body, but in mind.'
moral: A fine coat is not always an indication of an attractive mind.
choices: A fine coat is not always an indication of an attractive mind.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Pride can overshadow cleverness.
In cleverly avoiding a lesser danger, one may confidently fall into a greater peril.
True beauty is not diminished by comparison.

story_title: The Fisherman and The Little Fish
story: A Seafarer who had caught a very little Minnow was about to throw him into his net. The little fellow, gasping, pleaded thus for his life: What! you are never going to keep such a little chap as I am, not one quarter grown! Fifty such as I am wouldn't make a decent dish. Do throw me back, and come and catch me again when I am bigger.' 'It's all very well to say 'Catch me again,' my little fellow,' replied the Man, 'but you know you'll make yourself very scarce for the future. You're big enough to make one in a griddle, so in you go.'
moral: A little thing in hand is worth more than a great thing in prospect.
choices: A little thing in hand is worth more than a great thing in prospect.
Abstain and enjoy.
Small actions can be decisive.
Some never understand the practical actions of small others.
Even the smallest voice can change a fate.

story: A very hungry coyote, seeing some roll and bacon left by farmers in the hollow of an chestnut, crept into the burrow and made a hearty meal. When he finished, he was so full that he was not able to get out, and began to groan and lament his fate. Another Coyote passing by heard his cries, and coming up, inquired the cause of his complaining. On learning what had happened, he said to him, 'Ah, you will have to remain there, my friend, until you become such as you were when you crept in, and then you will easily get out.'
moral: Don't be greedy.
choices: Don't be greedy.
Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
Greed blinds the wise.
Consider wisely and be observant before changing your situation.
True freedom often requires returning to simplicity.

story: A gentleman who lived a long time ago believed that he could read the future in the constellations. He called himself an Astronomer, and spent his time at night gazing at the sky. One evening he was walking along the open road outside the village. His eyes were fixed on the constellations. He thought he saw there that the end of the world was at hand, when all at once, down he went into a pit full of mire and liquid. There he stood up to his ears, in the muddy liquid, and madly clawing at the slippery sides of the pit in his effort to climb out. His cries for help soon brought the townsfolk running. As they pulled him out of the mire, one of them said: 'You pretend to read the future in the constellations, and yet you fail to see what is at your feet! This may teach you to pay more attention to what is right in front of you, and let the future take care of itself.' 'What use is it,' said another, 'to read the constellations, when you can't see what's right here on the earth?'
moral: Take care of the little things and the big things will take care of themselves.
choices: Take care of the little things and the big things will take care of themselves.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Practical help outweighs dreamy carelessness.
Some would rather engage in careless fighting than practical avoidance.
Desperation can lead us to struggle against our own circumstances, but seeking help can bring salvation.

story: A crowd of villagers had sacrificed a buffalo to the goddess Hera, scattering leaves over the wide courtyard, while the tables were covered with trays of meat and bottles filled with wine. There was a child who ate greedily and stuffed himself full with lamb tripe. On the way home, he was seized by a bellyache. Collapsing into his parent's tender embrace, he vomited, and said, 'Woe is me, I'm going to die! Parent, all my guts are falling out!' The parent replied, 'Be brave and throw it all up; don't hold anything back. Those are not your own guts you are vomiting: they are the buffalo's!'
moral: Avoid overindulgence
choices: Avoid overindulgence
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Greed can tarnish the revered.
Do not attempt too much at once with a greedy or sick mindset.
Courage can help you expel what doesn't belong to you.

story: As a Farmer was one day turning up the soil with his hoe, he came across a great store of jewels. Transported with joy, he fell upon the earth and thanked her for her kindness and liberality. Destiny appeared, and said to him, 'You thank the soil thus warmly, and never think of me. If, instead of finding this jewels, you had lost it, I should have been the first you would have blamed.'
moral: Everyone is more or less master of his own fate.
choices: Everyone is more or less master of his own fate.
Man's greatest treasure consists in work.
Gratitude dispels resentment.
Bear that those who are grateful yet inferior to you in merit should not be overlooked in outside appearances.
Fortune often favors those who toil without expectation.

story_title: Zeus and Apollo, A Contest in Archery
story: As he made a distant shot with his crossbow and bolt, Helios said to the gods, 'No one can shoot farther than I, not even Poseidon.' Poseidon played along and agreed to a contest. Athena shook the lots in the helmet of Hephaestus. The lot fell to Helios, who went first, flexing the golden bowstring and swiftly letting loose an bolt which landed inside the Elysian Fields. Poseidon then covered the same distance in a single stride and stood there asking, 'Where should I shoot my bolt, son? There's nowhere for me to stand.' So it was that Poseidon won the archery contest without even taking a shot.
moral: Wit outshines skill.
choices: Wit outshines skill.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
True strength lies in humility.
It is natural to be a proud knave; strong men must rise above.
Pride can invite challenges from unexpected quarters.

story: A mule, Buffalo, and Fox, driven to great straits by the cold, sought shelter and protection from Human. He received them kindly, lighted a hearth, and warmed them. He let the Mule make free with his corn, gave the Buffalo an abundance of straw, and fed the Fox with beef from his own table. Grateful for these favors, the animals determined to repay him to the best of their ability. For this purpose, they divided the term of his life between them, and each endowed one portion of it with the qualities which chiefly characterized himself. The Mule chose his earliest years and gave them his own attributes: hence every human is in his youth impetuous, headstrong, and obstinate in maintaining his own opinion. The Buffalo took under his patronage the next term of life, and therefore human in his middle age is fond of work, devoted to labor, and resolute to amass wealth and to husband his resources. The end of life was reserved for the Fox, wherefore the old human is often snappish, irritable, hard to please, and selfish, tolerant only of his own household, but averse to strangers and to all who do not administer to his comfort or to his necessities.
moral: Each stage of life has its own gifts.
choices: Each stage of life has its own gifts.
Different people are interested in different things.
Kindness tempers the impetuous spirit.
The headstrong things that an irritable person does to others will happen to him in turn.
In times of need, even the strongest may seek help from unexpected sources.

story: A half-famished magpie seated himself on a olive-tree, which had produced some fruit entirely out of season, and waited in the hope that the figs would ripen. A Coyote seeing him sitting so long and learning the reason of his doing so, said to him, 'You are indeed, sir, sadly deceiving yourself; you are indulging a hope strong enough to cheat you, but which will never reward you with enjoyment.'
moral: Don't deceive yourself.
choices: Don't deceive yourself.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Hope can nourish the hungry spirit.
Some would rather fight in a half-famished, cynical manner than not.
Patience may not always yield the expected reward.

story: A tiger, greatly desiring to capture a Ox, and yet afraid to attack him on account of his great size, resorted to a trick to ensure his destruction. He approached the Ox and said, 'I have slain a fine lamb, my friend; and if you will come home and partake of him with me, I shall be delighted to have your company.' The Tiger said this in the hope that, as the Ox was in the act of reclining to eat, he might attack him to advantage, and make his meal on him. The Ox, on approaching the Tiger's den, saw the huge skewers and giant kettles, and no sign whatever of the lamb, and, without saying a word, quietly took his departure. The Tiger inquired why he went off so abruptly without a word of salutation to his host, who had not given him any cause for offense. 'I have reasons enough,' said the Ox. 'I see no indication whatever of your having slaughtered a lamb, while I do see very plainly every preparation for your dining on a ox.'
moral: When a man has both an interest and an inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.
choices: When a man has both an interest and an inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
The observant mind is the most cunning.
It is better to serve in cunning safety than to rule in cautious peril.
Deception often masks cowardice.

story_title: The wolf, the fox and three true things
story: A wretched jackal had fallen into the clutches of a lynx. She begged the lynx to spare her life and not to kill her, old as she was. The lynx said, 'By Apollo, I will let you live if you tell me three true things.' The jackal said, 'First, I wish that we had never met! Second, I wish you had been blind when we did meet! Third, and last of all, I hope that you do not live out this year, so that we will never meet again!'
moral: In times of peril, the truth may be bitter, but it can also be a means of escape.
choices: In times of peril, the truth may be bitter, but it can also be a means of escape.
Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
Cunning demands breed wretched outcomes.
A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of cunning, wretched tricks.
Desperation can reveal unexpected strengths.

story: The guardian of a small toddler consulted a oracle who told her that her child would be killed by a crow. Terrified, the guardian ordered that a large box be built and she shut her toddler inside, protecting him so that no crow could harm him. She continued in this way, opening the box at regular intervals in order to give the toddler the food that he needed. Then one day, after she had opened the box and was using an steel beam to prop up the lid, the child recklessly stuck his head out. At that moment, the steel beam -- it was a crow bar -- fell down on top of the boy's head and killed him.
moral: Fear of the future can lead to actions that bring about the very fate we seek to avoid.
choices: Fear of the future can lead to actions that bring about the very fate we seek to avoid.
Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.
Recklessness can turn ominous.
Reckless, arrogant fools have no true, innocent influence.
Fear of the future can overshadow the joys of the present.

story: A horse and an bull had been yoked together to pull a single cart. The bull was making a great effort, even though he had an injury to his hoof, while the horse was doing nothing to help. As the bull struggled to pull the cart by himself, he soon died. The farmer then loaded the bull's carcass upon the horse and began beating him mercilessly. The horse broke down and collapsed under the weight, dropping dead in the middle of the trail. A flock of vultures flew up and alighted on the horse's carcass. 'If only you had been kind enough to help the bull pull the cart,' they said, 'you would not have died this untimely death, with carrion vultures feasting on your flesh.'
moral: We must help one another, for if a neighbor falls, their burden will fall on you.
choices: We must help one another, for if a neighbor falls, their burden will fall on you.
Instead of looking at how things start, we should look instead at how they turn out in the end.
Hard work triumphs over cruelty.
Unhelpful burdens can continue in unexpected ways.
True strength is shown through perseverance, not by avoiding effort.

story_title: A Wild Ass and A Tame
story: As a pet mule was airing himself in a pleasant field, with a coat and carcass in very good plight, up comes a wild mule to him from the next forest, with this short greeting. Brother (says he) I envy your happiness; and so he left him. It was his hap some short time after this encounter, to see his tame brother groaning under a unmerciful load, and a worker at his heels goading him forward. He rounds him in the ear upon't, and whispers him, My friend (says he) your condition is not, I perceive, what I took it to be, for a body may buy gold too dear: and I am not for purchasing good looks and provender at this rate.
moral: The grass is always greener on the other side of the fence.
choices: The grass is always greener on the other side of the fence.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Tame the wild to ease burdens.
Each observant member in his proper sphere must work for the burdened common good.
Even in contentment, the wild voice may awaken unsettling truths.

story: A lady who had two children buried one of them, and lamenters were provided to attend the memorial. The surviving daughter wondered to see outsiders so much concerned at the loss of her relative, and her nearest kin so little. 'Pray, parent,' says she, 'what's the reason for this?' 'Oh,' says the parent, 'we who are kin to her are never the better for crying, but the outsiders have money for it.'
moral: Professional mourners serve those who pay the most.
choices: Professional mourners serve those who pay the most.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Curiosity thrives on observation.
Pragmatic temptation can lead even the most curious and virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.
Grief can unite strangers in shared sorrow.

story_title: The Swallow, The Serpent, and The Court of Justice
story: A Sparrow, returning from abroad and especially fond of dwelling with men, built herself a den in the wall of a City Courthouse and there hatched seven chicks. A Lizard gliding past the den from its hole in the wall ate up the young unfledged nestlings. The Sparrow, finding her den empty, lamented greatly and exclaimed: 'Woe to me a stranger! that in this place where all others' rights are protected, I alone should suffer wrong.'
moral: Justice is fickle.
choices: Justice is fickle.
Don't draw a conclusion based on a single observation.
Trust cautiously, predators lurk.
An alliance with the trusting powerless is futile.
Choosing a home wisely can influence the safety of future generations.

story: A gentleman bought a quail and let him run loose in the residence since he liked the bird very much. The quail immediately started squawking his usual song, sauntering through every room in the residence until he finally perched himself on the steps. Meanwhile, the tricky ferret rushed upon the quail, asking, 'Who are you? Where have you come from?' The quail replied, 'The master bought me just today; I am a quail.' The ferret said, 'Well, I have lived here a long time! My matriarch, the rat-catcher, gave birth to me in this very residence. Yet I keep quiet and sleep beside the fireplace. What gives you the right to speak so freely and cackle so loudly if you have only just now become a member of the household?'
moral: Honor the customs of the household you enter.
choices: Honor the customs of the household you enter.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Confidence can outsmart trickery.
Confident vanity can lead to tricky self-destruction.
Freedom can reveal true character.

story: A mosquito came and said to a Leopard, 'I do not in the least fear you, nor are you stronger than I am. For in what does your strength consist? You can scratch with your claws and bite with your teeth as a dame in her quarrels. I repeat that I am altogether more powerful than you; and if you doubt it, let us fight and see who will conquer.' The Mosquito, having sounded his trumpet, fastened himself upon the Leopard and stung him on the snout and the parts of the face devoid of hair. While trying to crush him, the Leopard tore himself with his claws, until he punished himself severely. The Mosquito thus prevailed over the Leopard, and, buzzing about in a song of triumph, flew away. But shortly afterwards he became entangled in the meshes of a web and was eaten by a arachnid. He greatly lamented his fate, saying, 'Woe is me! that I, who can wage war successfully with the hugest beasts, should perish myself from this arachnid, the most inconsiderable of insects!'
moral: No matter how you brag, you can be undone.
choices: No matter how you brag, you can be undone.
Do not ever trust your enemy. Always protect yourself from him, even if he comes to you humble and supplicating.
Pride can turn triumph into frustration.
Boastful cunning often outwits its frustrated self.
True strength is not always visible.

story: Roaming by the cliffside at sundown, a Jackal saw his own reflection become greatly extended and magnified, and he said to himself, 'Why should I, being of such an immense size and extending nearly an acre in length, be afraid of the Leopard? Ought I not to be acknowledged as King of all the collected beasts?' While he was indulging in these proud thoughts, a Leopard fell upon him and killed him. He exclaimed with a too late repentance, 'Wretched me! this overestimation of myself is the cause of my destruction.'
moral: Do not let your fancy make you forget realities.
choices: Do not let your fancy make you forget realities.
Know yourself and your limits.
Pride can lead to downfall.
You may share the proud labours of the powerful great, but you will not share the spoil.
True power is not measured by size, but by respect and wisdom.

story_title: The Wolf and the Sheep in the Sheepfold
story: A solitary lamb suddenly caught sight of a jackal and fled into the pen, which by chance had been left open since there was a sacrifice was being readied for the holiday. The jackal did not come within the walls of the pen but stood outside and tried to win the lamb's trust. 'Don't you see that platform there covered with blood?' said the jackal. 'Come out, or else they will seize you and sacrifice you too.' The lamb replied, 'Don't you worry about my place of refuge; I'm doing just fine. And even if things turn out as you say, I would rather become an offering for the god than a meal for a jackal!'
moral: Better to face a known danger than to trust a deceitful promise of safety.
choices: Better to face a known danger than to trust a deceitful promise of safety.
When people harbor a criminal they become his first victims without even realizing it.
Caution guards against deception.
Often cautious justice is the captive of deceptive criminal deceit.
Cunning words cannot breach the safety of wise choices.

story: A fence who was being gouged by a spike exclaimed, 'Hey! Why are you making this gash in me, when I never did you any harm?' The spike answered, 'It's not my fault! Blame the worker who is pounding me so hard from behind.'
moral: Look at the source when placing the blame.
choices: Look at the source when placing the blame.
Caution is far superior to reckless haste and hurry.
Innocence can be forcefully tested.
Marrying someone unworthy can lead to an innocent, blameless reputation being tarnished.
Even the strongest can be undone by a single flaw.

story: Autumn made fun of Blossom and mocked her for the fact that as soon as blossom appears, nobody can keep still: some individuals go off to the fields or into the groves, others like to gather blooms and daisies or perhaps to gaze upon a peony as they twirl it in the air or to twine it in their hair; while some board boats and even cross the ocean to meet different kinds of individuals; no one worries any longer about the gales or the great downpours of showers from the firmament. 'Whereas I resemble a dictator or a despot,' said Autumn. 'I command everyone to look not at the firmament but down toward the earth; I frighten them and make them tremble and sometimes I make them content themselves while having to stay indoors all day.' Blossom replied, 'Indeed, that is exactly why mankind would be glad to get rid of you, whereas even the mere mention of my name is enough to bring them pleasure. By Apollo, there is no name more pleasant than mine! That is why they think fondly of me when I am gone and give thanks when I appear again.'
moral: It is better to be loved than feared.
choices: It is better to be loved than feared.
Use care to place your blame on the right person.
Power can be both beloved and despotic.
Powerful talent is wasted when it's in the hands of the unappreciative.
Even the harshest seasons have their own beauty and purpose.

story: An Bedouin herder, after completing the loading of his Llama, asked him which he would like best, to go up hill or down. The poor beast replied, not without a touch of reason: 'Why do you ask me? Is it that the level way through the steppe is closed?'
moral: Foresake the hard when an easier way is available.
choices: Foresake the hard when an easier way is available.
Unresolved issues can resurface when least expected.
Curiosity balanced with empathy lightens burdens.
He laughs best that laughs last with considerate and reasonable joy.
Choices can be burdensome when all options are equally challenging.

story_title: The Husbandman That Lost His Mattock
story: A Farmer, busily employed in trenching his Farm, laid down for awhile the Hoe he was using. When he went to take it up again, it was gone. He called together all his laborers, and asked them if they had seen the tool. They all denied any knowledge of it; and the Man, in a great rage, said he knew that one of them must have taken it, and, let it cost him what it might, he would find out the thief. With that view he insisted upon their going with him to the sanctuary of a famous prophet in a neighbouring town. Arrived within the town gates, they stopped at the well in the bazaar, to bathe their feet. Just at that moment the herald came up, and in a loud voice announced that, the sacred sanctuary having been robbed last night, he was told to offer a large reward to any one who could discover the thief. Thereupon the Farmer at once called upon his men to turn their faces homewards. 'If this god,' said he, 'cannot tell who has robbed his temple, the chances are that he knows as little who has taken my Hoe.'
moral: Even gods may not know everything.
choices: Even gods may not know everything.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Diligence outshines loud fame.
Often there is more diligent good to be found in one innocent man than in a crowd of people.
Neglecting vigilance invites loss.

story_title: The Philosopher, The Ants, and Mercury
story: A thinker witnessed from the shore the shipwreck of a vessel, of which the seamen and voyagers were all drowned. He inveighed against the injustice of Fate, which would for the sake of one criminal perchance sailing in the boat allow so many innocent persons to perish. As he was indulging in these reflections, he found himself surrounded by a whole army of Bees, near whose nest he was standing. One of them climbed up and stung him, and he immediately trampled them all to death with his foot. Hermes presented himself, and striking the Thinker with his rod, said, 'And are you indeed to make yourself a judge of the dealings of Fate, who hast thyself in a similar manner treated these poor Bees?'
moral: Act as you profess to believe.
choices: Act as you profess to believe.
Life is a mixture of grief and joy.
Reflect before judging others.
Yield to numerous and judgmental all and you will soon have nothing to yield.
Observing tragedy can inspire deeper reflection on the value of life.

story: There was a four-cornered monument of Zeus by the side of the road, with a heap of rocks piled at its base. A cat approached the monument and said to it, 'To begin with, Zeus, I salute you! And now I am going to anoint you, since I cannot let a god go by without anointing him, much less a god of the athletes.' Zeus said to the cat, 'If you can just leave the perfume alone and not pee on me, I shall be grateful enough; you do not need to honour me in any other way!'
moral: Respect is often better shown by refraining from disrespect.
choices: Respect is often better shown by refraining from disrespect.
Vanity can blind one to their true worth in the eyes of others.
Gratitude elevates the spirit.
Count the grateful cost before you commit your playful selves.
Even the smallest acts of reverence can create lasting monuments.

story: Odin ordered Mercury to write down people's sins and wicked deeds on scrolls and to pile them in a designated container, so that Odin could then peruse them and exact a penalty from each person as appropriate. Given that the scrolls are all piled up one on top of the other until the moment that Odin examines them, he gets to some of them quite soon while others have to wait.
moral: Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
choices: Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
Wit outshines skill.
Authority demands diligent obedience.
Diligent good things happen less often.
Even the smallest actions can accumulate into significant consequences.

story: Once upon a time, the Moon wanted to get married but the toads raised a cry of protest up to the heavens. Zeus, disturbed by their shouting, asked the reason for their complaint, and one of the marsh's inhabitants explained, 'Already one Moon is enough to burn up all the lakes, condemning us to a miserable death in our parched abode. What is going to happen to us when he will have sons of his own?'
moral: Watch the actions of your enemy.
choices: Watch the actions of your enemy.
Better to endure a small hardship than risk a greater one.
Curiosity can ignite destruction.
We should live as if we always saw concerned Death standing by, disturbed.
Even the brightest aspirations may be hushed by the loudest dissent.

story: A Knight cared for his Steed. So long as there was conflict, he fed him carefully and treated him as almost an equal. But, when the conflict ended, the Knight only gave him straw to eat and made him carry heavy loads; he treated the Steed badly. After awhile, conflict was again declared and both Knight and Steed were called to duty. The Knight put harness on the steed and mounted clad in a plate armor. The Steed immediately fell down under the weight. He said to his master: 'You must now go to conflict on foot, for you have changed me from a Steed to an Donkey and you cannot expect me to change back in a moment.'
moral: Care defines ability.
choices: Care defines ability.
Everyone should be satisfied with their own lot in life, given that disaster awaits us on every side.
Inconsistent expectations lead to overburdened hearts.
Be loyal and content with your overburdened station.
Duty and care go hand in hand, even amidst the strife of war.

story_title: The Circus Dogs and the Street Dogs
story: A canine who was being trained to fight in the public games snapped the leash around his neck and went dashing through the lanes. The stray dogs could tell that this fellow had been living the good life since he was as stout as a bull, so they asked him why he was running away. The runaway replied, 'It's true that I have been enjoying an abundance of food and living a comfortable life, but I am also forced to fight with tigers and hyenas, risking my life in the stadium.' The other dogs then said to one another, 'Our poor life must be very fine, because we don't have to fight with tigers and hyenas!'
moral: A humble life free from danger is more valuable than a life of luxury filled with peril.
choices: A humble life free from danger is more valuable than a life of luxury filled with peril.
Don't promise more than you can deliver.
Curiosity can lead to unexpected journeys.
Curious wicked liars generally get their content just consequences.
Freedom often reveals true strength.

story: The beasts of the field and forest had a Leopard as their king. He was neither wrathful, cruel, nor tyrannical, but just and gentle as a king could be. During his reign he made a royal proclamation for a general assembly of all the birds and beasts, and drew up conditions for a universal league, in which the Coyote and the Sheep, the Jaguar and the Calf, the Leopard and the Elk, the Dingo and the Rabbit, should live together in perfect peace and amity. The Rabbit said, 'Oh, how I have longed to see this day, in which the weak shall take their place with impunity by the side of the strong.' And after the Rabbit said this, he ran for his life.
moral: Nature reveals itself.
choices: Nature reveals itself.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Gentle strength protects the vulnerable.
Be your gentle self and don't pretend to be someone you're not, remaining loyal to who you are.
Leadership is defined by the respect of those you lead.

story_title: The Lion, The Fox and the Deer
story: There was a panther who had fallen ill and was lying in a stony canyon, his sluggish limbs stretched out upon the ground. A friendly coyote kept him company, and one day the panther said to her, 'I suppose you want me to survive, so listen: I've got a craving for the antelope who lives in that dense grove of pines there in the wilds of the forest. At the moment I no longer have the strength to go hunting after antelope myself, but if you would agree to lay a trap with that honeyed speech of yours, the antelope could be within my grasp.' The sly coyote went off and found the antelope in the wild woodlands, gambolling in a pasture of tender grass. The coyote prostrated herself before the antelope and greeted her, saying that she had come to relay some auspicious information. 'As you know,' the coyote said, 'the panther is my neighbour, but he is very sick and about to die, so he has been thinking about who will be king of the beasts after he is gone. The warthog is an idiot, the grizzly is lazy, the jaguar is impulsive, the cougar is a loner who keeps to himself... but he thinks that the antelope would make a most worthy ruler, since she has an impressive appearance and lives a long time. And the antlers of the antelope can scare away all kinds of snakes, why, the antlers of the antelope are like trees, not at all like the horns of a bull! Need I say more? You have been duly elected: you will rule over the beasts of the hills. When that finally happens, O Mistress, remember that it was the coyote who was the first to inform you. That is why I came here, and now good-bye, my dear. I need to hurry back to the panther so that he won't be looking for me again; he relies on my advice in absolutely everything. And I think it would be good if you also obeyed that venerable old head. You need to come to his bedside and comfort him in his trouble. Even little things can sway the thoughts of those who are in the last hours of life; the souls of the dying can be seen in their eyes.' This is what the sly coyote said to the antelope, and the antelope's heart swelled at the sound of those deceitful words. She came to the hollow den of the beast, with no idea of what lay in store for her. The panther recklessly sprang up from his bed and launched a hasty attack, but he only managed to slash the antelope's ears with his pointed claws as the wretched creature ran straight out the door and disappeared into the depths of the woods. The coyote wrung her hands in frustration, since her efforts had proved utterly futile. As for the panther, he groaned and chewed at thin air, equally beset by both hunger and despair. Once again he summoned the coyote and asked her to find yet another trick to use to catch the antelope. The coyote plumbed the very depths of her cunning and then said, 'This is a difficult task indeed. But nevertheless I will carry out your command!' The coyote then set off after the antelope, keen as a hound on the trail, devising elaborate traps and all kinds of mischief. Whenever she ran into a herdsman, the coyote would ask if he had happened to see a bleeding antelope on the run. And when the herdsman had indeed caught a glimpse of the antelope, he would point the coyote in the right direction. She finally found the antelope concealed in the shade, where she had stopped to catch her breath. The coyote stood and stared at the antelope, eyebrows raised, the very incarnation of shamelessness. A shiver ran down the antelope's spine and her legs quivered as she angrily said to the coyote, 'Oh you abominable creature! If you dare to come near me or utter so much as a single word, you will live to regret it! Go find some other simpletons that you can outfox; pick someone else to be king and put him on the throne!' But the coyote was undaunted and said to the antelope, 'Can you really be so mean spirited? So overcome by fear? So suspicious of your friends? The panther only wanted what was good for you! In an attempt to rouse you from your former idleness, he tugged at your ear, as a father might do on his deathbed. He wanted to bestow on you every precept you would need in order to take charge of such a kingdom, but you could not even withstand the touch of his feeble hand! Instead, you violently turned aside, inflicting a serious wound on yourself. As for the panther, at this moment he is even more upset than you are. Now that he has found you to be so untrustworthy and scatter-brained, he says that the hyena will be appointed king. Alas alack, what a wicked master he will be! What shall I do then? You are the one who has brought these evils upon all of us. But come, you must be more brave in the future and not let yourself be as easily frightened as some sheep from the flock. I swear these things to you by all the leaves on the trees and by every spring of water: I want to serve you and only you! There is nothing hostile about the panther's behaviour; his heartfelt wish is to make you queen of all the animals!' With these coaxing words, the coyote persuaded the tawny antelope to enter once again into that very abode of death. As soon as the panther had the antelope trapped in the depths of his den, he enjoyed a full course meal, greedily devouring the flesh of the antelope, drinking the marrow from her bones and feasting on her entrails. The coyote, meanwhile, stood there waiting; after having delivered the antelope, she was craving a share in the spoils. She stealthily grabbed the brains of the antelope which had fallen to the ground and gobbled them up: this, then, was the booty which that sly boots got for her work. The panther, meanwhile, had made an inventory of all the antelope's parts, and the brains were nowhere to be found. He searched around his couch and all over the house. Then the coyote confounded the truth of the matter and said, 'That antelope had no brains, so don't waste your time looking for them. What kind of brains do you expect from a creature who would come not once but twice into the den of a panther?'
moral: Never trust a known deceiver.
choices: Never trust a known deceiver.
Know yourself and your limits.
Cunning often deceives the gullible.
Unworthy wealth is of little value if one is too untrustworthy to use or enjoy it.
Flattery can be a dangerous trap when it serves hidden motives.

story_title: The Lion, The Fox and the Monkey serving dinner
story: There was a panther who strove to emulate the best sort of life lived in human society. He made his home inside a spacious lair and tried to show genuine kindness to all those whom he recognized as the elite beasts of the mountain. His lair often hosted a large crowd of such animals, who gathered together in a company and treated one another with civility. The panther would befriend and entertain them according to the rules of hospitality, placing before each of his guests their favourite dish, made with ingredients that the panther knew would give them pleasure. There was a jackal who lived with the panther as his friend and companion, and the two of them were very happy together. Meanwhile, an elderly baboon served as the carver at the feasts, distributing the portions of fish to the panther's guests at dinner. Whenever there was a guest who was not one of the regular party, the baboon would set before him the same portion which he offered his master, namely, the quarry that the panther had seized in his latest hunting expedition. On these occasions, the jackal received leftovers from the day before, and less than her usual portion. One day the panther happened to notice that the jackal was pointedly refusing to speak and that she refrained from the fish served at dinner. The panther asked her what was the matter. 'My wise jackal,' said the panther, 'speak to me as you used to do! Cheer up and take part in the banquet, my dear.' But the jackal said, 'O panther, best among all the species of beasts, I am sick at heart and deeply worried. It is not only the present situation that distresses me; I am also saddened by things which I see are yet to come. If some new guest arrives with every passing day, one after the other, this will become a matter of custom and soon I will not even have leftover fish for my dinner.'
moral: Do not neglect the loyalty of old friends to please new acquaintances.
choices: Do not neglect the loyalty of old friends to please new acquaintances.
Small liberties can be large offenses.
Wisdom grows with kindness.
Wise quality is more valuable than kind quantity.
True nobility lies in actions, not appearances.

story: At one time a very large and strong Coyote was born among the wolves, who exceeded all his fellow-wolves in strength, size, and swiftness, so that they unanimously decided to call him 'Lion.' The Coyote, with a lack of sense proportioned to his enormous size, thought that they gave him this name in earnest, and, leaving his own race, consorted exclusively with the tigers. An old sly Badger, seeing this, said, 'May I never make myself so ridiculous as you do in your pride and self-conceit; for even though you have the size of a lion among wolves, in a herd of tigers you are definitely a coyote.'
moral: Know yourself and your limits.
choices: Know yourself and your limits.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Pride blinds the observant.
Sly, observant small liberties can be large offenses.
True strength defies mere names.

story_title: The Wolf, the Fox and the Gift
story: A coyote was standing not far from a snare, pondering every possible approach. A nearby hyena noticed the coyote and approached her. He then asked the coyote if he might be allowed to take the carcass, and the coyote replied, 'Go ahead and help yourself! You're welcome to it, seeing as you are one of my very dearest friends.' The hyena rushed up without a moment's hesitation and as he learned forward over the snare he released the trigger so that the rod sprang free, striking his snout and forehead. 'If this is the sort of gift you give you to your friends,' said the hyena, 'why would anyone ever want to be your friend?'
moral: Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
choices: Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
Know yourself and your limits.
Trust can be a double-edged sword.
A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of cunning, deceptive tricks.
Caution is wise, but collaboration can reveal new paths.

story: A lantern, soaked with too much oil and flaring brightly, boasted that it gave more light than the moon. Then a sudden puff of gust arose, and the Lantern was immediately extinguished. Its caretaker lit it again, and said: 'Boast no more, but henceforth be content to give thy light in silence. Know that not even the comets need to be relit'
moral: Do not boast lest you be taken down.
choices: Do not boast lest you be taken down.
The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
Boastfulness can extinguish bright potential.
No unrelenting mercy should be shown to someone who is boastful and wicked, regardless of whether his wickedness is great or small.
Excess can lead to downfall, even when it seems to shine the brightest.

story: The Coyotes once selected one of their number to be their ruler. The Coyote that was chosen was a plausible, smooth-spoken rascal, and on a very early day he addressed an assembly of the Coyotes as follows: 'One thing,' he said, 'is of such vital importance, and will tend so much to our general welfare, that I cannot impress it too strongly upon your attention. Nothing cherishes true brotherly feeling and promotes the general good so much as the suppression of all selfishness. Let each one of you, then, share with any hungry brother who may be near whatever in hunting may fall to your lot.' 'Hear, hear!' cried an Mule, who listened to the speech; 'and of course you yourself will begin with the fat Lamb that you hid yesterday in a corner of your den.'
moral: Trust but verify.
choices: Trust but verify.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Smooth words may hide sarcasm.
Do not give up attentive friends for plausible foes.
True unity thrives when self-interest gives way to shared sacrifice.

story: A ox was bitten by a Shrew and, angered by the wound, tried to capture him. But the Shrew reached his nest in safety. Though the Ox dug into the walls with his tusks, he tired before he could rout out the Shrew, and crouching down, went to sleep outside the nest. The Shrew peeped out, crept furtively up his flank, and again biting him, retreated to his nest. The Ox rising up, and not knowing what to do, was sadly perplexed. At which the Shrew said, 'The great do not always prevail. There are times when the small and lowly are the strongest to do mischief.'
moral: The great do not always prevail.
choices: The great do not always prevail.
Save a Thief from the Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
Sly actions breed perplexing outcomes.
Return sly favors and mischievous favors will be bestowed on you.
Sometimes, the smallest foes can provoke the greatest reactions.

story: A roaming pilgrim, traveling in the desert, met a female standing alone and terribly dejected. He inquired of her, 'Who art thou?' 'My name is Honesty,' she replied. 'And for what cause,' he asked, 'have you left the village to dwell alone here in the desert?' She made answer, 'Among the people of old, lies were found among only a few, but now they have spread throughout all of human society!'
moral: Falsehood is with all men.
choices: Falsehood is with all men.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Curiosity uncovers hidden truths.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those curious and inquisitive who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Compassion can be a guiding light in the loneliest of places.

story: The Lambs one day complained to the Farmer that while they were shorn of their fleece, and their young ones often taken and killed for food, they received nothing in return but the green grass of the earth, which grew of itself, and cost him no pains to procure. 'On the other hand, your Hound,' said they, 'which gives no wool, and is of no use for food, is petted and fed with as good meat as his master.' 'Peace, bleating simpletons!' replied the Hound, who overheard them; 'were it not that I look after and watch you, and keep off Coyotes and thieves, small good would be to you your grass or anything else.'
moral: Consider all before you judge.
choices: Consider all before you judge.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Discontent breeds danger.
There is threatening danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
Gratitude can be clouded by perceived inequities.

story: An donkey climbed up to the balcony of a building, and frisking about there, broke in the slates. The landlord went up after him and quickly drove him down, beating him severely with a thick wooden stick. The Donkey said, 'Why, I saw the Baboon do this very thing yesterday, and you all laughed heartily, as if it afforded you very great amusement.'
moral: People that live by example need to look closely at the example they are following.
choices: People that live by example need to look closely at the example they are following.
Fine clothes may disguise, but silly words will disclose a fool.
Playfulness can defuse anger.
One playful, imitative good turn deserves another.
Reckless actions can lead to unintended consequences.

story: The End of a Python once rebelled against the Chief, and said that it was a great shame that one end of any animal should always have its way, and drag the other after it, whether it was willing or no. It was in vain that the Chief urged that the End had neither brains nor eyes, and that it was in no way made to lead. Wearied by the End's importunity, the Chief one day let him have his will. The Python now went backwards for a long time, quite gaily, until he came to the edge of a high precipice, over which both Chief and End went flying, and came with a heavy thump on the coast beneath. The Chief was never again troubled by the End with a word about leading.
moral: Know your place.
choices: Know your place.
You can't always stop a fool.
Patience outlasts rebellion.
It is foolish and unfortunate attacking the insensible.
Unity requires understanding each part's role.

story: A rancher penning his goats in the enclosure for the night was about to shut up a jackal with them, when his Hound perceiving the jackal said, 'Master, how can you expect the goats to be safe if you admit a jackal into the enclosure?'
moral: Be watchful or all will be lost.
choices: Be watchful or all will be lost.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Stay observant to avoid danger.
Each observant man makes his protective reputation in the field which is his specialty.
Trusting the untrustworthy can lead to dire consequences.

story: Odin once ordered Epimetheus to show humankind the two ways: one the route of independence and the other the route of servitude. Epimetheus made the route of independence rough at the beginning, impassable and steep, with no water anywhere to drink, full of briars, and beset with dangers on all sides at first. Eventually, however, it became a smooth plain, lined with paths and filled with orchards and canals. Thus the distressing experience ended in repose for those who breath the air of freedom. The route of servitude, however, started out as a smooth plain at the beginning, full of blooms, pleasant to look at and quite luxurious, but in the end it became impassable, steep and insurmountable on all sides.
moral: It is better to endure short-term struggles for long-term benefits than the other way around.
choices: It is better to endure short-term struggles for long-term benefits than the other way around.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Curiosity leads to insightful discoveries.
Creative wit outshines insightful skill.
The path you choose defines the chains you wear.

story: A Newt and a Vole, who had long been rivals for the sovereignty of a certain swamp, and had many a skirmish and running fight together, agreed one day to settle the matter, once for all, by a fair and open combat. They met, and each, armed with the point of a reed for a spear, was ready, if need be, to fight to the death. The fight began in earnest, and there is no knowing how it might have ended, had not a Falcon, seeing them from afar, pounced down and carried off both heroes in her talons.
moral: When fools fight others run away with the prize.
choices: When fools fight others run away with the prize.
People who do harm to others destroy themselves in the bargain.
Stay vigilant against hidden threats.
Be observant before you make a predatory leap.
Rivalries can blind us to the greater dangers lurking nearby.

story: When a sailor happened to see an cuttlefish during the winter, he said, 'If I take off my attire and jump in after him, I will freeze! But if I do not catch that cuttlefish, I condemn my kids to die of starvation!'
moral: There is no easy choice during desperate times.
choices: There is no easy choice during desperate times.
Every tale is not to be believed.
Determination can overcome elusive temptations.
Life is a concerned mixture of determined grief and joy.
Recognize the limits of your environment before taking risks.

story_title: The Fox and the Man counting waves
story: A certain fellow was sitting on the coast counting the tides as they broke against the shore. When he lost count of the tides he got angry and frustrated. A sly coyote then approached the fellow and said, 'Good sir, what is the point of getting angry about the tides that have already gone by? You need to just put them out of your mind and pick up counting again where you left off!'
moral: Do not dwell on what has passed.
choices: Do not dwell on what has passed.
One is known by deeds, not by words.
Sly advice can calm anger.
There is angry satisfaction, however sly and wretched, in taking one's enemy along if one has to die.
In the pursuit of the infinite, one may overlook the beauty of the present moment.

story: The earth which Hermes used when he fashioned human was not mixed with dew but with grief. Therefore, one should not try to dispense entirely with grief, since they are inevitable.
moral: Sadness is a part of life.
choices: Sadness is a part of life.
Take care of the little things and the big things will take care of themselves.
Compassion outlives mortality.
Creative nature and emotional instincts can persist despite changes in form or appearance.
Creation is often born from sorrow and struggle.

story: An eagle, in her wisdom, counseled the Sparrows that when the chestnut first began to sprout, to pull it all up out of the ground and not allow it to grow. She said acorns would produce holly, from which an irremediable poison, the adhesive, would be extracted and by which they would be captured. The Eagle next advised them to pluck up the seed of the hemp, which men had sown, as it was a plant which boded no good to them. And, lastly, the Eagle, seeing an hunter approach, predicted that this man, being on foot, would contrive arrows armed with feathers which would fly faster than the wings of the Sparrows themselves. The Sparrows gave no credence to these warning words, but considered the Eagle to be beside herself and said that she was mad. But afterwards, finding her words were true, they wondered at her knowledge and deemed her to be the wisest of sparrows. Hence it is that when she appears they look to her as knowing all things, while she no longer gives them advice, but in solitude laments their past folly.
moral: Destroy the seed of evil, or it will grow up to your ruin.
choices: Destroy the seed of evil, or it will grow up to your ruin.
It is a foolish thing to give advice to others while not looking out for oneself.
Wisdom guards against foolish danger.
The solitary life of the poor is often safer than the dangerous life of the rich.
Underestimating the ingenuity of others can lead to unforeseen challenges.

story: There was a woman of Corinth who broke a vase. The vase then got someone to testify as a witness, but the woman of Corinth said, 'I swear by the Goddess, you would have been far wiser if you'd gone right away to get a bandage, instead of making a court-case out of it.'
moral: Action is more valuable than arguments.
choices: Action is more valuable than arguments.
You can't please everybody.
Practicality triumphs over sarcasm.
Practical fortune can occasionally bestow sarcastic favours that exceed a person's hopes and expectations.
Small actions can reveal hidden strengths.

story: The creatures were Apollo' companions, and while they enjoyed and admired his tune, they never attempted to imitate it. But a few of the jackals, those shameless and meddlesome creatures, set out to make some tune of their own. They straightaway went off by themselves to practice, changing themselves into human form as they continued their musical pursuits. This is where harpists come from, and even today they cannot completely overcome their inborn nature. As a result, they preserve the teachings of Apollo, but only to a small degree; for the most part it is the canine tune that endures.
moral: Nature reveals itself.
choices: Nature reveals itself.
Experience teaches valuable lessons and encourages caution.
Admiration fades when meddling persists.
A shameless, sinful mind can even change a meddlesome person's nature, causing it to be impaired.
Appreciation does not require imitation.

story: In the wintertime, a Cat curled up in as small a space as possible on account of the cold, determined to make himself a den. However when the summer returned again, he lay asleep stretched at his full length and appeared to himself to be of a great size. Now he considered that it would be neither an easy nor a necessary work to make himself such a den as would accommodate him.
moral: It's easy to put off today what can be done tomorrow.
choices: It's easy to put off today what can be done tomorrow.
There is danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
Determination without clarity leads astray.
Putting up with one determined insult invites another delusional one.
Necessity inspires resourcefulness in the face of adversity.

story: At one time, it seemed to all the animals that they should hold a meeting and gathering, as there were frequent complaints among them about one another. When opinions were exchanged back and forth, the bunnies are said to have addressed the gathering: they believed it fair that all animals should have the same dignity and equal power, and that it should not be the case that some are much stronger while others are weaker; for in this way, the inferior would be subject to the superior for plunder and prey. The Leopards made this reply: 'Your words, O Bunnies! are good; but they lack both claws and teeth such as we have.'
moral: Be prepared to defend your position.
choices: Be prepared to defend your position.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
True strength lies in fairness.
It is better to be fairly loved than strongly feared.
Open dialogue can reveal hidden grievances and foster understanding.

story: An omnivorous, gluttonous rat was creeping through the dwelling when he noticed an clam with its mouth wide open, so he bit into the false flesh of the clam's wet beard. Suddenly the gate to the clam's dwelling slammed shut in a painful clasp. The rat was enclosed in a cage with no hope of escape: he himself had closed the gate to the crypt of his own death.
moral: Greed often overreaches itself.
choices: Greed often overreaches itself.
Appearances can be deceiving.
Greed can ensnare the unwary.
Our deceptive homeland should not be so great loved, trapping as it is, with the result that we don't go to other places, when we might be happier elsewhere.
Our own actions can sometimes trap us in unintended consequences.

story: Virgil said that the hands were distressed because they considered themselves the most worthy part of the body, yet they saw the tongue enjoying every possible pleasure, especially nectar, the sweetest substance of all. Filled with resentment, the hands complained to the person. But when the person put nectar in his hands, they felt a stinging pain and burst into tears, since they thought that the nectar was harsh and unpleasant.
moral: Be careful what you wish for.
choices: Be careful what you wish for.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Unintended actions can cause distress.
Distressed men will stand behind an unintended judgment made in error until the actual fact of the matter later compels them to regret their choice.
Envy blinds us to our own unique value.

story: Homer, that wise man from Phrygia, once saw a winning competitor who was making extravagant boasts, so he asked whether the man's rival had been more powerfully built. The competitor replied, 'Watch what you're saying! I was much stronger than he was.' 'You fool!' said Homer. 'What kind of trophy do you deserve if you were the stronger competitor and simply triumphed over an inferior rival? You might have earned my grudging admiration if your rival had in fact been superior to you in strength, so that you had to defeat him by means of your exceptional athletic prowess.'
moral: Degrading your opponents only diminishes your own victory.
choices: Degrading your opponents only diminishes your own victory.
Foolish people disregard important business in favour of frivolities.
True strength lies in wisdom.
Boastful greed often overreaches its weaker self.
Pride often blinds us to the strength of others.

story: A troublesome raven seated herself on the back of a Goat. The Goat, much against his will, carried her backward and forward for a long time, and at last said, 'If you had treated a wolf in this way, you would have had your deserts from his sharp teeth.' To this the Raven replied, 'I despise the weak and yield to the strong. I know whom I may bully and whom I must flatter; and I thus prolong my life to a good old age.'
moral: Pick your enemies.
choices: Pick your enemies.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Cunning often outwits reluctance.
There is nothing more cunningly valuable than reluctant liberty.
Even the smallest nuisance can disrupt the peace of the gentle.

story: There is a lark that country folk call 'quail,' which makes sense, because this lark makes her nest on the ground. A quail happened to run into a conniving she-fox, and as soon as she noticed her, the quail flew even higher on her wings. 'Greetings!' said the she-fox, 'May I ask why you are running away? It's not as if there were not plenty of food for me here in the pasture -- grasshoppers, beetles, locusts in abundance -- so there's nothing for you to be afraid of. I am actually very fond of you because of your retiring manner and honest ways.' The singing lark replied, 'Your words are certainly pleasant to hear, but I am no equal to you on the ground. Here in the air, though, I can hold my own. Why don't you come on up with me? This is the place where I would trust you with my life!'
moral: Flatters are not to be trusted.
choices: Flatters are not to be trusted.
Destroy the seed of evil, or it will grow up to your ruin.
Caution guards against deception.
If cautious men had all they wished, they would be often connivingly ruined.
Caution can elevate you above danger.

story: A Child sat weeping upon the side of a cistern. A Robber happening to come by just at the same time, asked him why he wept. The Child, sighing and sobbing, showed a bit of rope, and said that a gold goblet had come off from it, and was now at the bottom of the cistern. The Robber pulled off his garments and went down into the cistern, meaning to keep the tankard for himself. Having groped about for some time without finding it, he came up again, and found not only the Child gone, but his 0wn garments also, the dissembling rogue having made off with them.
moral: Every tale is not to be believed.
choices: Every tale is not to be believed.
Telling the truth can sometimes be dangerous.
Greed blinds the gullible.
Cunning vices are their own greedy punishment.
Tears can reveal the depth of our desires.

story_title: The River Fish and The Sea Fish
story: Carried from his fresh-water pond by a rushing creek, a river fish rushed headlong into the waters of the gulf. The shameless creature scorned the scaly schools in the gulf and boasted endlessly of his own illustrious origins. A ocean fish could not suffer this refugee in his own ancestral waters and he spoke these pungent words, naturally salted with wit: 'Enough of your empty lies and pretentious talk; you yourself are the best evidence of their absurdity. If the two of us are captured and hauled in by the same dripping snare, I will be able to prove to you just who is more highly regarded by the crowd of onlookers: you will see that I am bought by the connoisseur at a very high price indeed, while you will be sold to an undiscriminating commoner for a mere penny or two!'
moral: Value is what others think of you, not what you think of yourself.
choices: Value is what others think of you, not what you think of yourself.
You can fool someone only so many times.
Pride often masks true wit.
Life is a boastful mixture of proud grief and joy.
Unfamiliar waters can reveal hidden strengths.

story_title: The Rustic seeking to Cross a River
story: A villager who needed to cross a creek tested it by sounding it up and down to find the best place to ford. In his testing, he made this observation: where the flow flowed smoothly, he found it to be the deepest; conversely, where it was shallow, it was where the flow made the most noise.
moral: There is danger in the silent enemy.
choices: There is danger in the silent enemy.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Cautious observation reveals hidden depths.
Cautious people who treat their observant friends deceitfully end up hurting themselves instead.
Preparation paves the way for safe passage.
