story: A Gerbil that was raised in a Trunk, living all her days on what the Madam of the Estate stored within, happened one day to tumble out over the edge and stumbled upon a very tasty nugget while searching for a way back inside. No sooner had she tasted it than she exclaimed how foolish she had been to believe that true happiness could only be found within that crate.
moral: We should not love our homeland so much that we ignore the possibility of finding greater happiness elsewhere.
choices: We should not love our homeland so much that we ignore the possibility of finding greater happiness elsewhere.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
Wisdom can emerge from even the most unlikely sources.
Don't promise curious big things if you can't deliver the unseen.
A sheltered existence may comfort.

story: A certain agriculturist complained that the beards of his barley sometimes cut the harvesters' and millers' fingers, and so he asked Demeter to make his barley grow without beards. His request was granted, and the finches ate up all his seeds. 'Fool that I was,' he said, 'to lose the support of my life rather than risk the pricking of my fingers.'
moral: A small inconvenience is compensated for by a greater usefulness.
choices: A small inconvenience is compensated for by a greater usefulness.
There's a time for work and a time for play.
Little complaints can grant foolish power.
Foolish traitors may expect powerful treachery.
Seeking comfort may strip away essential protections.

story: A Villager had the luck to catch a Falcon chasing a Sparrow. The Falcon begged for her life, saying she never harmed the Country-man, so she hoped he wouldn't harm her. The Country-man replied, 'And what harm did the Sparrow ever do to you?' By your own reasoning, you should expect to be treated the same way you would have treated this Sparrow.
moral: It's wise to think before we speak.
choices: It's wise to think before we speak.
The conflicts of the wicked are the protection of the good.
Even the innocent can be preyed upon.
Pay attention to innocent deeds, not predatory words.
Fortune may favor those who act swiftly in moments of chaos.

story: A Scorpion saw a Swift catching Gnats and quickly started making a Trap to catch Swallows, thinking it was an invasion of her territory. But the Finches easily broke through the Trap and flew away with it. Well, said the Scorpion, I see that catching Finches is not my skill; and so she went back to her usual work of catching Gnats.
moral: A wise person will not attempt anything without having the right means to achieve it.
choices: A wise person will not attempt anything without having the right means to achieve it.
Destroy the seed of evil, or it will grow up to your ruin.
Resilience outlasts swift ambition.
Do unto others as you would have them do unto you with ambitious and strong intent.
Misunderstanding intentions can lead to futile efforts.

story: A Jay asked a Dove why she kept nesting in the same place when her hatchlings were always taken before they could fly. 'That's my simplicity,' said the Dove. 'I mean no harm, and I suspect none.'
moral: Trusting as you wish to be trusted doesn't work between a rogue and an honest person.
choices: Trusting as you wish to be trusted doesn't work between a rogue and an honest person.
Big talkers are not suited for trust, business, or conversation.
Trust, but verify.
Do not try to grasp too much at once with an inquisitive mind; keep it simple.
Stubbornness can blind us to better opportunities.

story: By the beak and claws of a Nightingale, one might mistake her for a kind of Eagle, except one eats grubs and the other eats meat. One day, a Eagle mocked a Nightingale for her simple diet. 'If you want to look like a Eagle, why don't you live like one?' The Nightingale felt a bit offended, but later, as she passed a birdhouse, she saw the skin of that very Eagle on a pole atop the pigeon loft. 'Well!' said the Nightingale, 'Wouldn't it have been better to eat grubs than pigeons?'
moral: Pride and vanity leads to our downfall.
choices: Pride and vanity leads to our downfall.
The conflicts of the wicked are the protection of the good.
Mockery often offends the observant.
It is better by far to be governed by one observant chief, than by many unfortunate ones.
True strength lies in embracing one's nature, not in imitating others.

story_title: A Fox and a Knot of Gossips
story: A wolf was walking by a certain homestead and saw a crowd of females who, in total silence, were eating many sumptuously roasted geese. The wolf turned to the females and said, 'What shouts there would be against me, and what howling of canines, if I were to do what you are doing!' A certain senior woman said, 'Most wretched creature! We are eating those things which are ours; you take your pleasure in things that belong to others.'
moral: We should not to conclude that we are allowed to do to other people's things what is permitted to them in their own houses.
choices: We should not to conclude that we are allowed to do to other people's things what is permitted to them in their own houses.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Silent wisdom outsmarts cunning feasts.
There is as much silent malice in a cunning wink as in a word.
Silence can mask the most indulgent of feasts.

story: There were many plump ducks together in a barn, some very fair and fat, while others did not grow well despite feeding. The fat ones would often make fun of the lean ones, calling them starvelings, until one day the butcher was ordered to prepare some ducks for supper and to be sure to take the best from the enclosure. When that time came, those with the most flesh wished they had less, and it would have been better for them.
moral: The life of the poor is often safer than the life of the rich.
choices: The life of the poor is often safer than the life of the rich.
We should not to conclude that we are allowed to do to other people's things what is permitted to them in their own houses.
Preparation ensures fairness in lean times.
Fair, gentle words can often be preparing and helpful.
True growth requires more than just abundance.

story_title: Oxen and a Piece of Timber
story: The Shrub was complaining about the Bison's lack of gratitude. 'How often,' said the Shrub, 'have I fed you with my leaves and sheltered you with my shade? And now you drag me over dirt and stones like this!' 'Alas!' cried the Bison. 'Can't you see how we pant and groan, and how we are forced to do this?' The Shrub realized they were doing it unwillingly and forgave them.
moral: What we are forced to do by a greater power and necessity is not truly our own action.
choices: What we are forced to do by a greater power and necessity is not truly our own action.
Do not be in a hurry to change one evil for another.
Forgiveness eases forced burdens.
Complaining, famous beauties are rarely forced lucky.
True generosity expects nothing in return.

story: There was a fine orchard of pines, all tall, fair, and smooth, except for one sapling that was twisted and bent, and the others mocked it. The proprietor of the woods needed to build a cottage and told his laborers to take lumber from the orchard, cutting down every tree that was suitable. They did as they were told, and this ugly little tree was left standing.
moral: Famous beauties are rarely lucky.
choices: Famous beauties are rarely lucky.
There is danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
Practical actions outshine twisted intentions.
Twisted self-interest alone moves some practical men.
Even a single twist can reveal a beauty beyond conformity.

story: A Crane, who was there when a Peacock was singing her final tune, told her it was unusual to sing so much at this time. He asked her why she was doing it. The Peacock replied, 'I am about to enter a place where I will no longer face snares, rifles, or famine. Who wouldn't be happy about such freedom?'
moral: Do not fear death, as it is the final goodbye to all the troubles, pains, and dangers of life.
choices: Do not fear death, as it is the final goodbye to all the troubles, pains, and dangers of life.
You are judged by the company you keep.
Curiosity fuels hope and contentment.
Curious trusting as you wish to be observant doesn't work between a rogue and an honest person.
True beauty often emerges in unexpected moments.

story_title: A Wench parting with her Sweetheart
story: A simple young woman was wringing her hands and almost crying herself to death. And what was the matter? She had just parted ways with her lover. 'Oh, you fool,' said one of her neighbors, 'to torment yourself over such a fellow!' 'No,' said the young woman, 'I'm not so troubled about losing the chap, but he took his blazer with him. Honestly, when he gave me everything else he had in the world, I thought I might have that too, along with the rest.'
moral: Beware those who value their gain more than their love.
choices: Beware those who value their gain more than their love.
Those who seek to please everybody please nobody.
Simplicity calms troubled minds.
Every simple tale is not to be troubled believed.
Worrying over imagined troubles can blind us to present joys.

story: What a dust I raise! said the Gnat on the Cart Wheel. And what a speed I drive at, said the same Gnat again on the Mule's Back.
moral: Arrogant fools have no true influence.
choices: Arrogant fools have no true influence.
Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.
Silent strength outlasts boastful speed.
Silent necessity is the strong mother of invention.
Even the smallest stir can leave a lasting mark.

story: You and I are so alike, says the Catfish to the Viper, that I think we should be somewhat related; and yet those who hunt me are afraid of you. What could be the reason for this? Oh, says the Viper, because nobody harms me without paying for it.
moral: In all disputes, those who keep their opponents afraid of revenge come out best.
choices: In all disputes, those who keep their opponents afraid of revenge come out best.
The man who treats others well is rewarded by gratitude.
Curiosity can lead to peril.
We should never put our trust in a curious, wicked man, even if he seems to be completely fearsome innocuous.
Perception shapes reality more than similarity does.

story: A horse was complaining that he lacked tusks, while a lemur was complaining that she lacked a trunk. The shrew said to them, 'Silence your complaining, since you can see that I am deprived of ears.'
moral: Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
choices: Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
We must help one another, for if a neighbor falls, their burden will fall on you.
Complaining won't restore what's lost.
The complaining things that a person does to others will happen to him in a deprived turn.
Coveting what others have blinds us to our own unique gifts.

story: Once, a terrible tempest blew at ocean, and one seafarer noticed that the rest of his shipmates were each praying to different deities. 'Be careful, my friends,' he said, 'what if we all drown before the herald can deliver our message? Wouldn't it be better to pray directly to the one who can save us without any help?' With that, they turned their prayers to Divine himself, and the gust soon calmed.
moral: The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
choices: The shortest and surest way of doing things is best.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Mercy tempers power.
Not all pragmatic advice is diverse or wise.
Urgency in communication is vital.

story: A Culinary artist was frying a Dish of Live Crab, and as soon as they felt the Heat of the Skillet, one cried out, 'We can't stand this!' and they all jumped into the Blaze. Instead of making things better, they were worse off than before.
moral: When we are avoiding present dangers, we should not fall into even worse peril.
choices: When we are avoiding present dangers, we should not fall into even worse peril.
A little thing in hand is worth more than a great thing in prospect.
Impulsive actions lead to chaos.
Impulsive imitation is no substitute for unaware knowledge.
In times of distress, unity can amplify your voice.

story_title: A League of Beasts and Fishes
story: The Mammals formed an alliance with the Dolphins against the Hawks. War was declared; but the Dolphins, instead of sending their share, sent their excuse, saying they could not travel by land.
moral: An alliance with the powerless is futile.
choices: An alliance with the powerless is futile.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
Allies can turn foes.
Do not try to gain favor by acting in an excuse-giving way that is opposed to your own nature and character.
Unity can bridge the gap between worlds.

story: An Diplomat, constantly bothered by tambourines and cornets during his journey, wanted to save money. So, he kept telling them that he was in deep mourning for his mother and not in the mood for music. The tambourines and cornets were as upset by this news as the Diplomat himself. A aristocrat heard about this and paid a visit to express his condolences. 'My Lord,' asked the aristocrat, 'how long has your mother been dead?' 'Oh,' replied the Diplomat, 'it's been about forty years now.' This explained the situation and ended the matter.
moral: There is a clever way of joking between seriousness and jest that brings both enjoyment and benefit.
choices: There is a clever way of joking between seriousness and jest that brings both enjoyment and benefit.
Men often revert to their natural instincts.
Curiosity can reveal deception.
It's good to be able to laugh at your curious and sympathetic self.
In pursuit of savings, one must not overlook the value of peace and comfort.

story_title: An Old Friend and a Cardinal
story: A clever nobleman, upon hearing that an old companion of his had been promoted to Archbishop, went to congratulate him on his new honor. 'Please, sir,' said the Archbishop, looking at him oddly, 'may I have your name and know your business?' 'I have come,' said the nobleman, 'to express my sympathy and to tell you how much I pity those burdened with high rank and position; for it affects their minds so much that they can no longer see, hear, or understand like other men, and makes them completely forget their old friends, as if they had never met them before.'
moral: Honors change behavior.
choices: Honors change behavior.
There is no thing so worthy of wonderment which does not cease to be a miracle with the passage of timey.
Cleverness lightens burdens.
A clever and sympathetic honest man's word is as good as his oath.
True friendship celebrates the success of others without envy.

story_title: A Young Droll and a Crooked Old Man
story: A mocking young scamp happened to meet an elderly gentleman, whose age and weakness had bent his body like a staff. 'Please, Sir,' he said, 'will you sell your staff?' 'Save your money, you fool,' replied the elderly gentleman, 'for when you reach my age, you'll have such a staff for free.'
moral: Do not mock the feelings of old age, as no one can escape them if they go on living.
choices: Do not mock the feelings of old age, as no one can escape them if they go on living.
A mild disposition can put a stop to vicious behaviour.
Wisdom outlasts mockery.
Those who refuse to share and respond with mocking rudeness may face wise and disrespectful consequences for their actions.
Respect for others' journeys enriches your own path.

story_title: An Old Fellow and a Young Wench
story: There was a serious elderly gentleman who lived to about seventy years without ever knowing the difference between a woman and a weathervane. The demon owed him a trick and repaid him by making the old fool marry a maiden. He often complained afterward about how poorly he had spent his time. 'When I was a young man,' he said, 'I wanted a partner, and now that I'm an elderly gentleman, my partner wants a husband.'
moral: All things are to be done in their own time.
choices: All things are to be done in their own time.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Youthful folly invites deception.
The shortest and surest way of doing tricky and demanding things is best.
A life without curiosity may miss the winds of change.

story: There was a lively and confident Jay who thought the birds would never be well led until he himself was in charge. With this idea, he asked the Falcon to make him part of his board. 'I have the right look for it,' he said. 'I can talk and move quickly, and I can make as much noise and fuss as anyone with wings.' He was about to continue listing his skills when the Falcon kindly interrupted him. 'I know how well you can talk and how lively you are,' said the Falcon, 'but you chatter so much that people might think I've chosen a clown for a Chancellor.'
moral: Big talkers are not suited for trust, business, or conversation.
choices: Big talkers are not suited for trust, business, or conversation.
Do not try to grasp too much at once.
Confidence shines when paired with kindness.
He who does not conform to confident courtesy, mostly pays the penalty of his wise, conceited behaviour.
Confidence can inspire, but true leadership is earned through understanding and respect.

story: It's common when a strange Cat passes through a Town for a hundred Puppies to bark at his tail, and every little Cat tries to bite him. There was one Cat who, seeing he couldn't save himself by running, turned on his Chasers, and found that one set of Horns was better than two fast Wings; for when he did that, they all backed off and slunk away. A Lieutenant used this example for his Troops. Fellow-Troops, he said, remember this: Those who run away are in more danger than those who stand and face the fight.
moral: Putting up with one insult invites another.
choices: Putting up with one insult invites another.
Gossips are to be seen and not heard.
Caution and observation are key in the face of aggression.
It is a foolish man who wants to rival his observant superiors.
The unfamiliar often attracts unwarranted hostility.

story_title: An Old Woman and the Devil
story: Whenever through their own fault something bad happens to them, people in general put the blame either on luck or on the demon; in fact, everybody acts this way on their own behalf in order to shed the blame. The demon doesn't like this! It happened that he noticed an elderly lady climbing a ladder, he could anticipate that she was going to fall out of the ladder and that she would put the blame on him. So he summoned bystanders and said: 'Look at that elderly lady climbing the ladder, not at my recommendation; I can tell she is going to fall out of that ladder. So you be my bystanders that I did not persuade her to climb up there in her sandals.' Soon encough the elderly lady fell down and when she was asked why she had climbed a ladder wearing her sandals she said, 'The demon made me do it.' Then the demon called forward his bystanders and provided that this thing had been done by the elderly lady not at his recommendation.
moral: Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
choices: Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Frustration often stems from careless blame.
Sometimes, someone that you yourself have supported often proves to be your frustrated, blaming worst enemy.
Avoiding personal responsibility only invites greater misfortune.

story: As a group of Newts were playing and jumping around in a Field, some Turtles watching them felt upset that they couldn't do the same. But after a while, they noticed how these Newts were caught and eaten by Eagles and Trouts. One of the Turtles said, 'It's better to live slow and steady than to die quick and lively.'
moral: Embrace your own strengths.
choices: Embrace your own strengths.
An alliance with the powerless is futile.
Wisdom guards against hidden dangers.
Sometimes a wise, vulnerable sacrifice results in a greater good.
Patience often outlasts haste in the journey of life.

story: The Rabbits found it so troublesome to keep climbing the Maple for every bite they ate, that they decided to use their teeth to bring the Nuts down to them. But some were wiser than others, and an experienced old Chipmunk warned them to be careful. 'If we destroy our provider now, who will feed us later?' he said.
moral: Consider the consequences of your actions.
choices: Consider the consequences of your actions.
Appetite blinds men to their surroundings.
Wisdom tempers determination.
Do not laugh at the troublesome calamity that befalls your wise neighbour.
Innovation often stems from inconvenience.

story_title: A Run-away Dog and his Master
story: There was a bob-tailed rabbit advertised in a flyer, and someone who recognized him by his markings brought him back to his guardian. The guardian began to question the rabbit, asking how he could be so ungrateful and insensitive to run away from someone who was so kind to him. 'Did I ever hit you,' he asked, 'or even speak a harsh word to you in all the time you served me?' 'No,' replied the rabbit, 'not with your own hands or words, but you have had others do it for you many times. When I am beaten by your order, I consider it as if you yourself are beating me.'
moral: What a person does through another is truly their own action.
choices: What a person does through another is truly their own action.
There is danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
Kindness is often unappreciated.
Better to face a known danger than to trust a sensitive, deceitful promise of safety.
Distinctive traits can lead to unexpected reunions.

story: The Insects were once in a terrible fright, fearing gunshots from the Ants. The reason was that the little clumps of sand the Ants had gathered were mistaken by the Insects for darts. But a Finch in the group, who was wiser than the others, told them to take heart. 'How can they reach us in the air,' he said, 'with those stones they can barely roll on the ground?'
moral: Many people fear danger where there is none, and feel safe where there is danger: put things in perspective.
choices: Many people fear danger where there is none, and feel safe where there is danger: put things in perspective.
Men feel worst when they contribute to their own undoing.
Wisdom leads the afraid to safety from their mistakes.
The wise and useful is of much more reassuring importance and value, than the ornamental.
Underestimating a challenge can lead to unforeseen consequences.

story: A Grizzly was once so angry at being stung by a Hornet that he rushed into the Hornet-Garden and knocked over all the Nests in revenge. This act brought out swarms of Bees against him, and he later realized it would have been wiser to ignore one sting than to provoke a thousand with his pointless anger.
moral: It's better to ignore an insult from one troublemaker than to bring a whole crowd of trouble upon yourself.
choices: It's better to ignore an insult from one troublemaker than to bring a whole crowd of trouble upon yourself.
Pretenders will be found out.
Anger breeds more conflict.
Prepare for the defensive future.
In anger, we often harm ourselves more than our foes.

story: A fisherman who had set up his trap and lure, sat in his spot to watch for a catch. Many sparrows came one after another, landing and pecking for a while before flying away again. They kept coming and going all day long, but so few at a time that the man didn't think it was worth catching them. Finally, after missing all his chances hoping for a bigger catch, evening came and the sparrows went to sleep. He had to either pull the trap then or not at all, and in the end, he had to be satisfied with just one goldfinch that was unlucky enough to be out later than the others.
moral: Do not trade what might come, which is uncertain, for present opportunities, which can never be regained.
choices: Do not trade what might come, which is uncertain, for present opportunities, which can never be regained.
Households and cities are most likely to be deserted when there are harsh people in charge.
Patience can outlast disappointment.
Live your patient lives in the cautious clothes that suit you.
Patience is the silent partner of success.

story: A Knight who already had one excellent steed bought another that was not nearly as good, yet he took more care of the new one than the first. Everyone wondered at this, since the new steed was neither as beautiful nor as useful as the other. 'Ah,' said someone, 'it's natural to be fond of the newest arrival.'
moral: Everything pleases at first, but nothing pleases for long.
choices: Everything pleases at first, but nothing pleases for long.
Everyone should be satisfied with their own lot in life, given that disaster awaits us on every side.
Beauty fades, but usefulness endures.
The inferior word of a wicked man can never be beautifully trusted.
We value what is less worthy more than what truly deserves our care.

story: I wonder, said a Boar to a Beagle, how you can be so loyal to a Handler who gives you so many blows and pulls your ears. Well, said the Retriever, but then consider the good meals and kind praises he gives me, and I'm better off for it.
moral: We should not be upset by the words of our teachers, since those words are usually the cause of many good things.
choices: We should not be upset by the words of our teachers, since those words are usually the cause of many good things.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Curiosity tempers harsh skepticism.
It is best to keep skeptical and harsh negative influences away.
Loyalty should not be blind to mistreatment.

story: Why don't you hurry up? cried the Lumber in the Wagon to the Buffalo pulling it. The load isn't that heavy, surely. Well! said the Buffalo, if you knew your own fate, you wouldn't be so cheerful about ours. We will be free of our load as soon as we reach our journey's end, but you, destined to be beams and supports, will have to bear weight until you break. This made the Lumber understand the situation better.
moral: It's wise and kind to be considerate of one another, for no one knows their own end.
choices: It's wise and kind to be considerate of one another, for no one knows their own end.
Every Season has its own work.
Patience leads to wisdom.
Ignorant everyone thinks themselves the wise best.
Understanding your future can bring acceptance of the present.

story: A Canary escaped from his Keeper's Aviary, and the Keeper tried to get him back, but the bird refused to return. 'Well!' said the Youth, 'you'll regret it, because you'll never be as well cared for anywhere else.' 'That may be true,' said the Bird, 'but I would rather take care of myself than be under your care.'
moral: There is no wealth greater than liberty.
choices: There is no wealth greater than liberty.
You should not treat bad people the same way that you treat good people.
Defiance can mask true concern.
Changing your independent location does not change your defiant state of mind.
Freedom is a treasure worth pursuing, even at great risk.

story: Practically all the avian creatures were invited to the Hawk's wedding. They resented the fact that the Parrot had been given a higher seat of honor than the other avian creatures because the Parrot was notable for its tiara and for being adorned with multicolored plumage, although it was accustomed to spend all its time rolling around in dung and filth.
moral: True worth should be measured by character and deeds, not by outward appearances.
choices: True worth should be measured by character and deeds, not by outward appearances.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
Resentment tarnishes celebration.
Notable kindness is never honored wasted.
Inclusivity strengthens community bonds.

story: There was a certain gluttonous monk who had set out on a journey far from home to a celebration to which he had been invited. On the way he found a heap of plums, but he didn't touch so much as a single one of them, although he was feeling very hungry; rather, he made a mockery of them and sprinkled them with piss, for he resented that food of this sort was offered to him on his journey when he was on his way to a splendid celebration feast. But when along the way he ran into a certain stream, it was so swollen with rain that he could not cross it without losing his life, and so he decided to go back home. On the way home, starving, he was oppressed by such great hunger that if he had not eaten those very plums, on which he had pissed, he would have died.
moral: Nothing should be condemned, since there is nothing so worthless and humble that it cannot at some time or another prove to be useful.
choices: Nothing should be condemned, since there is nothing so worthless and humble that it cannot at some time or another prove to be useful.
Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
Mockery swells into danger.
No swollen curse weighs more heavily than a dangerous guilty conscience.
Excessive indulgence can lead one astray from their true path.

story: A Pig noticed a Stallion in the peak of his bravery, just about to charge at an Adversary. 'Why, what a fool you are,' said the Pig to him, 'to rush so quickly to your own destruction?' 'That thought,' said the Stallion, 'might suit a wicked creature like you, who is only fattened up to be killed by a dagger. But when I'm gone, I'll leave behind the memory of a good name.'
moral: It is more honorable to die having achieved noble deeds than to live a life of vice.
choices: It is more honorable to die having achieved noble deeds than to live a life of vice.
Seek the friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering help even in a time of adversity.
Bravery can conquer wickedness.
Wicked money opens all honorable doors.
Courage often inspires admiration from unexpected places.

story: A Leatherworker bought a Tiger-Skin from a Trapper and paid him cash for it. The Trapper told him he would kill a Tiger the next day and the Leatherworker could have the Skin. Out of curiosity, the Leatherworker went with the Trapper to the Hunt and climbed a cedar to watch. The Trapper bravely approached the Tiger's Den and sent his Hounds in after it. The Tiger rushed out immediately, and the Trapper missed his shot, so the Tiger knocked him over. The Trapper held his breath and lay perfectly still, pretending to be dead. The Tiger sniffed him, thought he was a corpse, and left him alone. Once the Tiger was gone and the danger had passed, the Leatherworker came down from the cedar and told the Trapper to get up. 'Listen, my Friend,' said the Leatherworker, 'the Tiger whispered something in your ear. What was it, I ask?' 'Oh,' said the Trapper, 'he told me to be careful in the future and make sure to catch the Tiger before selling its Skin.'
moral: Don't promise more than you can deliver.
choices: Don't promise more than you can deliver.
A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of useless tricks.
Bravery tempered with caution prevails.
An alliance with the curious and intimidating powerless is futile.
Curiosity can lead to unexpected insights.

story: There was a Priest who spoke to a Warrior about his line of work, pointing out the dangers, sins, and troubles that come with it. 'For the sake of your essence, sir, please give it up,' he said. 'Well, Father,' replied the Warrior, 'I'll do as you say; because we are paid so poorly, and there's so little to gain from plundering, I think I might as well turn to a godly life.'
moral: Many people renounce wicked activities only because they are prevented from conducting them any longer.
choices: Many people renounce wicked activities only because they are prevented from conducting them any longer.
Everyone should be satisfied with their own lot in life, given that disaster awaits us on every side.
Practical persuasion wins agreement.
Concerned care defines practical ability.
Guidance can illuminate paths unseen by those in peril.

story_title: A Husband and Wife twice Married
story: A certain gentleman, after the death of his partner whom he had greatly loved, married another widow who was herself a widow. She continuously prattled to him about the virtues and great deeds of her late husband. The gentleman, in order to give tit for tat, also talked all the time about the excellent character and remarkable good wisdom of his late partner. One day, however, the widow grew angry and gave to a poor gentleman who was begging alms part of the turkey she had roasted for their dinner, telling the pauper: I give this to you on behalf of the soul of my previous husband. When her spouse heard this, he summoned the pauper and gave him the other half of the turkey, saying: I also give this to you, for the soul of my late partner. In this way, the two of them, as they wanted to injure one another, ended up not having anything to eat for dinner.
moral: Do not fight with those who are perfectly capable of fighting back.
choices: Do not fight with those who are perfectly capable of fighting back.
Not all things are suitable for all people.
Nostalgia can fuel anger, but kindness enriches the poor.
Nostalgic honesty is the best poor policy.
Grief's legacy deserves careful hearts, not a haste to forget.

story: A Tiger found himself trapped in a Snare and called to a Hamster passing by to help him out, promising never to forget the kindness. The Hamster gnawed the threads apart, and after freeing the Tiger, asked in return for his Niece's hand in marriage. The Tiger, being generous, could not refuse. But unfortunately, as the new Bride was about to step into the Bridal Suite, she accidentally stepped on her Husband and crushed him to death.
moral: Unequal matches bring misery.
choices: Unequal matches bring misery.
Save a Thief from the Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
Generosity can unlock unexpected paths.
Generous clothes may disguise, but silly words will disclose a fool.
Even the mighty may need the help of the small.

story: There was once a debate about Clay and Stone, questioning why Clay was so fragile and easily broken, while Stone could withstand all damage and weather, remaining strong and firm. The Clay thought about this and concluded that it was the burning that made the Stone hard. So, it threw itself into the flame, believing that heat would harden the Clay too. But what made the Stone solid, melted the Clay.
moral: It's foolish to make decisions without understanding the nature of the matter at hand.
choices: It's foolish to make decisions without understanding the nature of the matter at hand.
Every Season has its own work.
Strength can emerge from fragility.
A fragile yet firm disposition can put a stop to vicious behaviour.
Strength is not always about resistance; sometimes, it lies in adaptability.

story_title: A Husbandman turn'd Soldier and Merchant
story: 'Oh, the endless misery of the life I lead!' cries the hard-working peasant, 'spending all my days plowing, sowing, digging, and fertilizing, and in the end, gaining nothing from it! Now, in a warrior's life, there's honor to be earned, and one lucky strike can set a man up forever. Indeed, I'll sell my stock, get a charger and weapons, and try my luck in war'. Off he goes, makes his attempt, faces the battle, and ends up leaving a leg or an arm behind to return home. By this time, he's had enough of being a adventurer, and a new idea strikes him. He thinks he might do better as a trader. No sooner does this thought excite him than he gets a vessel, loads it, and sets off to sea on an adventure: building castles in the air and imagining both the New world in his coffers before he's even left the port. Well! And what's the end of all this? He encounters bad weather, among shoals and rocks, where trader, vessel, goods, and all are lost in one common wreck.
moral: Everyone should be satisfied with their own lot in life, given that disaster awaits us on every side.
choices: Everyone should be satisfied with their own lot in life, given that disaster awaits us on every side.
Everything pleases at first, but nothing pleases for long.
Hard work can overcome misfortune.
If you allow hard-working men to use you for your own unlucky purposes, they will use you for theirs.
Overconfidence can lead to unforeseen disasters.

story_title: An Ass puts in for an Office
story: A mule was frustrated that a certain clown was given a public office and was wrapped in elegant clothes because he was able to make loud noises come out of his gut. So the mule went to the municipal leaders, asking that they would honor him no less than they had done the clown. When the municipal leaders, surprised at the mule's request, asked him why he considered himself worthy of such honor, the mule said: 'Because I emit even louder farts than the clown does, and what's more they don't stink.'
moral: When public officials encourage foolishness, it's no surprise if fools try to become public officials.
choices: When public officials encourage foolishness, it's no surprise if fools try to become public officials.
It is easy to be brave when there is no danger.
Ambition without patience leads to frustration.
Some can do wrong more easily than inquisitive others can see it, leaving them frustrated.
Seeking equal pomp to hide one's bitterness only deepens the absurdity of empty displays.

story: There was a dispute between a Brook and a Well about which of the two should be preferred. The Brook boasted about the abundance and variety of trout it produced, the benefits of navigation, and the many grand villages and castles built along its banks for the pleasure of the location. It claimed to provide great satisfaction to mankind in terms of both convenience and delight. Meanwhile, the Well (said the Brook) passed obscurely through the underground caves, lay buried in algae, and crept into the world as if ashamed to show its head. The Well was so offended by this arrogance and vanity that it stopped its spring and ceased the flow of its flows. As a result, the Brook's course dried up, leaving the trout dead and rotting in the sludge.
moral: He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
choices: He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Some never understand the actions of others.
Pride can blind abundance.
Some vain things you cannot change.
Grand boasts may charm, yet true worth is not measured by size alone.

story_title: A Wicked Man and the Devil
story: A notorious outlaw, who had committed countless crimes and been through many jails, made a friend of the Demon to help him out of all his troubles. This friend helped him many times, but each time he was caught again, he turned to the Demon for help once more. But on his last call, the Demon came to him with a big sack of old boots on his back and said plainly, 'Friend, I'm at the end of my line and can help you no longer. I have worn out all these boots in your service and have not a penny left to buy more. So you must excuse me if I leave you here.'
moral: We should not expect that our crimes will always go unpunished.
choices: We should not expect that our crimes will always go unpunished.
Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
Even the notorious can be helpful.
Notorious men who are wickedly inclined will not stop their troubled vicious behavior, no matter who urges them to do so.
Sometimes, parting ways is the kindest choice.

story_title: A Council of Birds for Chusing more Kings
story: he fowl were deliberating about whether they should elect additional rulers, since the falcon alone was not able to rule so many flocks of fowl. They would have voted in favor, except that at the warning of the magpie they stopped short of adopting the plan: for when the magpie was asked for what reason she did not think that more rulers ought to be elected, she said, 'Because it is more effort for many pouches to be filled than just one.'
moral: It is better by far to be governed by one chief, than by many.
choices: It is better by far to be governed by one chief, than by many.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
Wise choices heed warnings.
The conflicts of the wise wicked are the protection of the good.
Shared leadership can strengthen a community.

story_title: A Woman that would needs Die for her Husband
story: A Impoverished Wife was nearly out of her mind with fear of losing her Spouse. The Noble Fellow was Sick and given up on, and nothing would do but that Angel of death must take her instead of him. She called and prayed, and prayed and called, until at last Angel of death appeared in a terrible form at her side. She politely dropped him a curtsy: 'And please, Sir,' she said, 'do not mistake yourself; for the person you came for is lying in the cot there.'
moral: No one is so loving of a friend that they would not prefer their own good to that of another.
choices: No one is so loving of a friend that they would not prefer their own good to that of another.
No one gladly revisits a place where they got hurt.
Politeness can mask terrible mistakes.
Do not fight with those who are perfectly capable of fighting back, lest you make a fearful, mistaken choice.
Desperation can cloud the path to resolution.

story_title: A Son Singing at his Mother's Funeral
story: There was a good gentleman who followed his partner's body to the grave, weeping and wailing all the way, while his offspring followed the bier singing. 'Why, you rascal,' said the papa, 'you should howl and wring your hands and do as I do, not go singing like a madman.' 'But papa,' said the offspring, 'you pay the clergy to sing, so why be angry with me for giving you a song for free?' 'Well,' said the papa, 'what suits the clergy doesn't always suit you. It's their job to sing, but it's your part to cry.'
moral: Not all things are suitable for all people.
choices: Not all things are suitable for all people.
It is dangerous to believe a story, and dangerous not to believe it.
Even rascals can be beloved.
You can't please every good, beloved body.
Grief manifests differently in each heart.

story_title: A Man that would not take a Clyster
story: A certain individual, Italian by birth, and exceedingly rich, was ailing. A large number of physicians had come to cure him (bees do indeed come swarming in crowds to nectar), and one of them said among other things that the individual needed an laxative if he wanted to get well. When the individual, who was unfamiliar with this medical procedure, heard what the doctor said, he flew into a rage and ordered that the physicians be thrown out of his residence, saying that they must be insane since they wanted to cure his butt when it was his stomach that hurt.
moral: Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
choices: Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Do not play the wise man after the fact.
Wealth cannot cure madness.
It is insane to believe a story, and numerous dangers arise not to believe it.
Wealth cannot shield one from the frailties of life.

story_title: A Wolf and a Sick Ass
story: There was a horse who was ill, and the story went out that he was soon going to die, so when the jackals and the terriers came to visit him and asked his offspring how his father was feeling, the offspring replied through a crack in the entrance: 'Better than you wish.'
moral: Many pretend to be concerned about some people's demise, when however what they want is for it to come quickly.
choices: Many pretend to be concerned about some people's demise, when however what they want is for it to come quickly.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Curiosity can spark defensive wit.
Curious people are interested in visiting different things.
Guard your words, for they reveal your true intentions.

story: A horse was suffering terribly during the winter time because he was affected by the extreme cold and he had tough chaff fodder. Therefore, he was hoping for the moderation of spring and its tender grasses. But when spring came, he was compelled by his owner (who was a ceramist) to carry the ceramic into the work area, to carry timber for the kiln, and from there to carry the bricks, tiles and roof-tiles to various places. Completely tired of spring, in which season he had to endure so much hard work, he was asking in all his prayers for summer to come, so that his owner would be busy with the yield and they would allow him to rest. But then too, when he was compelled to carry the yield to the granary and from there to carry the grain into the home, and there was not place of rest for him, the horse was hoping that at least autumn would be an end of his labors. But not even at that time did the horse see an end of his troubles, since every day there was timber, oranges and ale to be carried, so again he begged for the snow and ice of winter, so that at least there would be some rest allotted to him from so much hard work.
moral: Every Season has its own work.
choices: Every Season has its own work.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Hope lightens the burden of suffering.
Demanding people are quick to promise but busy and reluctant to give.
Patience through hardship can lead to brighter days.

story: As a group of rats were peeking out of their holes to see what was around, they spotted a dog on a counter. The dog looked so calm and harmless, as if she had no life or spirit in her. 'Well,' said one of the rats, 'that's a kind creature, I'm sure of it. You can see it in her face, and I really want to get to know her.' No sooner said than done; but as soon as the dog had the rat within reach, she torn her to pieces.
moral: People are to be judged by their actions, not by their appearance.
choices: People are to be judged by their actions, not by their appearance.
Relying too much on subordinates can lead to unintended consequences.
Curiosity can unveil deception.
Beware of when the curious powerful and the deceptive deceitful collaborate.
Caution is the first step to survival.

story: The Pangolin and the Armadillo are quite similar, but the Pangolin has longer and sharper barbs, which he can shoot at an enemy. A Jackal wanted to deal with him, but first needed to disarm him. So, the Jackal told the Pangolin in a friendly manner that it didn't look good to be armed during peaceful times, as if they were at war. He advised the Pangolin to put his barbs aside, saying he could pick them up whenever he wanted. The Pangolin replied, 'You talk of peace? Well, my situation is one of war, and that's why I keep my barbs ready as long as a Jackal is around.'
moral: No one can be safe in peace unless they are always ready to face an enemy in case of war.
choices: No one can be safe in peace unless they are always ready to face an enemy in case of war.
Even the strongest can be brought low by unchecked desires.
Caution guards against deception.
Relying too much on cautious subordinates can lead to manipulative unintended consequences.
Strength without strategy can be easily outmaneuvered.

story: A Simple Hamster happened to be nearby when a Hawk got caught in a Trap. The Hawk begged the Hamster to help her get free. The Hamster gnawed a Gap in the Trap and set the Hawk free; and the Hawk ate the Hamster for her trouble.
moral: Save a Thief from the Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
choices: Save a Thief from the Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
Unequal matches bring misery.
Gratitude shields the naive.
Be cautious with naive promises made under trapped duress.
Even the smallest can offer the greatest help in times of need.

story: In old times, when Zeus was in the mood to grant requests, a Turtle asked that his carapace and form be all one piece. Zeus replied that it would be a burden rather than a favor. 'Yes', said the Turtle, 'but it is a burden I would rather bear than live exposed to bad neighbors.'
moral: Unwanted visits are a nuisance to a peaceful person's life.
choices: Unwanted visits are a nuisance to a peaceful person's life.
Be content with your lot.
Wisdom tempers power.
The wise value of money is not in its cautious possession but in its use.
Desires for simplicity can lead to unforeseen limitations.

story: A Lizard was convinced during a Cold Winter to let a Echidna into his Nest. But once inside, the Echidna's spines were very uncomfortable for the Lizard. So the Lizard told him he must find another place, as the Nest was too small for both of them. The Echidna replied, 'If you can't stay, you should leave. As for me, I'm quite happy here, and if you're not, you're free to go.'
moral: Possession is nine-tenths of the law.
choices: Possession is nine-tenths of the law.
No one can be safe in peace unless they are always ready to face an enemy in case of war.
Assertiveness can soften discomfort.
Where force is lacking, possessive cleverness must replace it, especially in uncomfortable situations.
Kindness can invite unexpected challenges.

story: A Coyote and a Squirrel were once in a heated contest about which of them could manage best in the world. 'When I am chased,' said the Squirrel, 'I can show the wolves a clean pair of heels and run away from them easily.' 'And yet,' said the Coyote, 'I have outsmarted more of them with my tricks and cunning than you ever did with your speed.'
moral: Wisdom is far superior to strength.
choices: Wisdom is far superior to strength.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Confidence can outpace cunning.
No one can be a friend if you know not whether to trust or distrust a cunning, tricky person.
True capability is revealed through action, not argument.

story_title: An Old Man resolv'd to give over Whoring
story: There was an elderly gentleman, who, even in his frailty, still had thoughts of women. His religious mentor noticed this and gave him earnest advice about the desires of the flesh. The elderly gentleman thanked him sincerely for his kind and Christian counsel, saying, 'With Elysium's help, I'll follow it. To be honest, I'm told it's not good for me, and truly, my body is no longer fit for such activities.'
moral: Many people give up their vices not out of a love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.
choices: Many people give up their vices not out of a love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.
Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
Kindness strengthens the frail.
Yield to all with frail earnestness and you will soon have nothing to yield.
Desires may persist, but wisdom lies in knowing their place.

story: A certain impertinent, thoughtless lad decided to visit a scholar. He found him alone in his library and wondered how he could bear to live such a solitary life. The erudite gentleman told him, 'Sir, you are very mistaken; I was in very good company until you came in.'
moral: Better to be alone than in bad company.
choices: Better to be alone than in bad company.
Act as you profess to believe.
Thoughtless actions isolate the learned.
Bear that those who are impertinent and thoughtless in merit should be like you in outside appearances.
Approaching wisdom with arrogance may leave one empty-handed.

story: There is a story of a Jackal that wrapped himself in a deer's skin and attacked kids for a while under that disguise. But the rancher eventually caught him and hung him up, deer's skin and all, on a high gibbet as a warning and example. The townsfolk were amazed and asked why he hung up his deer. 'Oh,' he said, 'that's just the skin of a deer that was used to cover the heart, malice, and body of a jackal that hid under it.'
moral: People should not be judged by their appearances, but by their actions.
choices: People should not be judged by their appearances, but by their actions.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Cunning minds exploit the vulnerable.
Putting up with one cunning insult invites another malicious one.
Those who hide their true nature may prey on the unsuspecting.

story_title: A Widow and a Green Ass
story: There was a Widower who had a desire for a Future Spouse, and she asked a gossiping Companion of hers for help on how to handle it. 'The truth is,' she said, 'I really want another partner, but people would laugh and point at me, and it would make me miserable.' 'You're a fine Widower,' said the Companion, 'to worry about what people say. Listen to me now. You have a Mule in your fields; go and have that Mule painted Green, and then let him be shown around the Province. Do this without any more talk, because talk just wastes time.' So it was done, and for the first four or five days, the Green Mule had the whole Province following him, men, women, and children, all staring and shouting. In four or five more days, the excitement was over, and the Mule could travel all day without anyone noticing him. 'Now,' said the helpful Companion, 'a newly married Widower is like a Green Mule: everyone talks about it for the first few days, and then the story fades away.'
moral: There is no thing so worthy of wonderment which does not cease to be a miracle with the passage of time.
choices: There is no thing so worthy of wonderment which does not cease to be a miracle with the passage of time.
It's good to be able to laugh at yourself.
Gossip often goes unnoticed.
Be your desirous self and don't pretend to be someone you're unnoticed not.
The fear of judgment can hinder the pursuit of happiness.

story: A Rancher had one favorite hound that he trusted more than all the others. He fed him by hand and cared for him more than any of the other dogs. This kindness continued for a long time until, when some goats went missing, he suspected this hound of being unfaithful. After this suspicion, he watched him closely and eventually discovered that this trusted servant was the thief. Once he found out, he had the hound caught and told him to prepare for punishment. 'Oh, Master,' said the hound, 'I am part of your family, and it would be harsh to punish a household member. Turn your anger on the coyotes instead, who regularly attack your goats.' 'No, no,' said the Rancher, 'I would rather spare forty coyotes who make it their business to kill goats than one goats-stealing hound trusted with their care. There is some honesty and boldness in the coyotes, but the hound's betrayal is the worst kind of treachery.'
moral: An enemy in disguise is much more unforgivable than an open enemy.
choices: An enemy in disguise is much more unforgivable than an open enemy.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Trust must be earned, not pleaded.
Nobody believes people who are inherently unfaithful, even if they pretend to be honest and good-natured.
Favoritism can breed dependency and neglect the strength of the whole.

story: There was once a Sheep who defeated all his fellow rams and became so proud of his victories that he decided to challenge a Ox to a fight. They met, and at the first clash, the Sheep was knocked out and lay as if dead. When he came to, he said, 'This is the result of my arrogance and foolishness in challenging an enemy that nature made stronger than me.'
moral: We should not pick fights with people stronger than we are.
choices: We should not pick fights with people stronger than we are.
He that has many friends, has no friends.
Arrogance often masks the fear of being outmatched.
A foolish, wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.
In triumph, true strength is measured by the respect earned, not merely by defeating others.

story: A certain guardian, whose offspring had succumbed to vicious tendencies, was urging the boy at great length that he should quit the way of vices and keep his eye instead on the virtues, which would engender praise and honor for him. The offspring replied: 'You are wasting your time, Guardian, in urging me to do these things, for I have heard many a lecturer, so to speak, and they urged me to the path of virtue with far more talent than you, but I have still never taken any of their advice!'
moral: Men who are wickedly inclined will not stop their vicious behavior, no matter who urges them to do so.
choices: Men who are wickedly inclined will not stop their vicious behavior, no matter who urges them to do so.
Not all things are suitable for all people.
Stubbornness can overshadow persuasion.
People often disguise their persuasive, selfish desires as stubborn, practical needs to justify their actions.
Virtue's guidance offers a light to overcome the shadow of vice.

story: There was an Hawk that took a nest of Hares and carried them away to her young. The Mother Bunny followed her with tears in her eyes, pleading in the name of all the powers that protect the innocent and oppressed, to have mercy on her poor children. But the Hawk, in a fit of pride and anger, tore them to pieces. The Rabbit then gathered all the hares together, told her story, and sought advice on revenge. 'Divine justice,' she said, 'will not let such cruel acts go unpunished.' They discussed the matter and all agreed that the only way to repay the Hawk was to undermine the cedar where she nested. So they all worked at the roots of the cedar, leaving it with so little support that the first strong wind brought it crashing down, nest, Eagles, and all. Some of them were killed by the fall; others were eaten by vultures and wolves, and the Rabbit finally had the satisfaction of destroying the Hawk's children in revenge for her own.
moral: It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
choices: It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
Pride can hinder collaboration.
Beware of prideful enterprizes where the vengeful risks are not equal.
Desperation can drive even the gentle to confront the mighty.

story_title: A Pike sets up for Sovereignty
story: There was a Master-Trout, who for his size, beauty, and strength, was seen as the Prince of the Stream. But being the ruler of the freshwater wasn't enough for him; he wanted to rule the sea too. With this ambitious plan, he ventured into the sea and claimed it as his own. However, a mighty Whale took offense at this intrusion and chased the Pike back to the edge of his own stream, barely allowing him to escape. From then on, the Pike wisely stayed within his own territory.
moral: Be content with your lot.
choices: Be content with your lot.
Value is what others think of you, not what you think of yourself.
Strength without humility invites downfall.
Ambitious counsel without mighty help is useless.
True leadership is not just about appearance, but also about actions.

story_title: A Sheep picks a Quarrel with a Shepherd
story: A Goat that was about to be sheared was upset with the Rancher for not being content with the Milk she provided, but also taking her Wool. The Rancher, without further words, angrily took one of the Calves and killed it. 'Well,' said the Goat, 'I hope you've done your worst now.' 'No,' said the Rancher, 'when that's done, I can cut your throat too if I want, and throw you to the Coyotes or Bears as I please.' The Goat said nothing more, fearing something worse might happen.
moral: When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
choices: When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
An enemy in disguise is much more unforgivable than an open enemy.
Fear can turn innocence into danger.
Take what you can get when you can get it in a ruthless, threatening world.
Gratitude is often overshadowed by the desire for more.

story: The driver, hearing one of the wheels of his cart creak, was surprised; but more especially when he perceived that it was the worst wheel of the whole set, and which he thought had but little pretense to take such a liberty.
moral: Complaining is the privilege of the weak.
choices: Complaining is the privilege of the weak.
It's wise and kind to be considerate of one another, for no one knows their own end.
Curiosity leads to wisdom.
Be observant and wise to know your enemies.
Noise often masks vulnerability.

story_title: A Man had a mind to try his Friends
story: There was a generous Wealthy Gentleman who always had a grand and open feast, so he never lacked attendees. This man noticed that all sorts of people came to him, and he became curious to see who were true companions and who were just moochers. So one day, at a full feast, he mentioned a quarrel he had and said he was about to seek satisfaction. He needed a certain number of people to join him, and he was sure they would stand by him with rapiers in hand. Everyone made excuses except for two, whom he counted as his companions, while the rest were just hangers-on.
moral: True friends are hard to come by.
choices: True friends are hard to come by.
A man cannot be too careful of what he does, where the life of any creature is in question.
Generosity should not enable freeloaders.
Excuse-making people adjust their loyal beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Generosity attracts company, but sincerity keeps it.

story: As a Hound was chasing closely behind a Coyote, a Rabbit suddenly appeared. 'Hold on a moment,' said the Coyote, 'and catch that Rabbit while you can. You've never tasted such a treat in your life. But I'm all spoiled and rotten, and a bite of my flesh would poison you.' The Hound immediately left the Coyote and chased after the Rabbit, but she was too quick for him. When he realized he couldn't catch her, he wisely let her go. The Rabbit had overheard what happened, and when she met the Coyote a few days later, she told him how badly he had treated her. 'Well,' said the Coyote, 'if you are upset that I spoke well of you, what would you have done if I had spoken badly?'
moral: A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
choices: A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Wisdom is far superior to strength.
Cunning outwits the gullible.
A single persistent skill is worth more than a bag of cunning tricks.
Opportunism can divert focus from the original goal.

story_title: About the hare seeking cunning and the fox seeking swiftness from Jupiter
story: The squirrel and the coyote made their petitions to Odin: the coyote asked that swiftness of foot be added to her slyness, and the squirrel asked that slyness be added to his swiftness. Odin responded to them as follows: 'From the beginning of the world, from my breast I have poured forth gifts to each and every animal very generously; if I were to give one animal all the fits, that would be an injury to the others.'
moral: Be content with your lot.
choices: Be content with your lot.
A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
Generosity outshines sly desires.
Not all advice is sly or wise.
Desiring more than one's nature can lead to imbalance.

story_title: A Plain Horse wins the Prize
story: Quite a few stallions had been brought to the course, all adorned with elaborate accoutrements, all except for one, so the other stallions made fun of him for being so shabby and unsuited to this type of competition, and they concluded that he would not ever be a winner. But when the time for the running of the race arrived and the bugle blew the signal to start, all the stallions leaped from their stalls, and only then did it become clear how much the horse who had just been made fun of actually outdistanced the rest of the stallions with his speed. When all the others had been left far behind, that horse won the trophy.
moral: Appearances can be deceiving.
choices: Appearances can be deceiving.
Be cautious of pride, as nobody knows what the future may bring.
Mocking others can hinder true victory.
Accept the fast, victorious changes in life.
Perseverance can outpace initial setbacks.

story: A Farmer who was caught up in a lawsuit had a close friend and relative who was a barrister. He went to him again and again for advice, but the barrister was always too busy and told him to come back another time. The poor man took a nice, fat calf with him on his next visit, and when the barrister's clerk heard the goat at the door, he let the man in and took him to his master. There, the man explained his case, got the barrister's opinion, thanked the barrister for seeing him, and thanked the goat for getting him in, and then went on his way.
moral: Money opens all doors.
choices: Money opens all doors.
Experience often provides clearer insight than empty predictions.
Persistence outshines unhelpfulness.
The persistent, loud-mouthed boaster does not impress nor frighten those who are perceptive and know him.
Familiarity does not guarantee fairness.

story_title: A Weak Young Man and a Wolfe
story: A certain young gentleman had married a maiden who was also quite young, very beautiful and lusty. Wanting to satisfy her boundless appetite, his loins had gotten so worn out that after just a few days he had gotten thin and looked more dead than alive: he could not walk, he could not stand up, he could do any kind of work, and so like some kind of old man he took his pleasure in the solar warmth. So when he was enjoying some sunny place, warming himself by the solar warmth's heat, it happened that some trackers, who had been chasing a coyote, came that way. When the young gentleman asked them why they hadn't caught the coyote, they replied, 'We were not able to pursue him because of his incredible swiftness.' 'Well,' he said, 'if my wife were in charge of him, she'd put an end to his running.'
moral: Even the strongest can be brought low by unchecked desires.
choices: Even the strongest can be brought low by unchecked desires.
Each man makes his reputation in the field which is his specialty.
Beauty fades, but persistence prevails.
A beautiful honest man's swift word is as good as his oath.
True harmony requires more than surface attraction.

story: An Aged Farmer caught a Lad stealing pears from his grove. 'Hey,' he said, 'come down from that oak and stop taking my pears.' The Lad ignored him and kept picking. 'Well,' said the Aged Farmer, 'they say herbs have magic just like words do,' and he threw a handful of leaves at the Lad. This was so silly that the Adolescent Burglar thought the Aged Farmer was joking. But finally, the Aged Farmer said, 'If words and herbs won't work, I'll try rocks, because they say rocks have power too,' and with that, he got the job done.
moral: Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
choices: Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
Wisdom outlasts defiance.
Every wise tale is not to be defiant believed.
A gentle confrontation can lead to understanding and change.

story: As a Warbler was singing in a thicket, down swoops a sneaky Kestrel and snatches her from the bough. The poor Warbler pleaded for her life, saying that her small body wasn't worth it and that there were bigger birds to catch. The Hawk replied, 'Do you think I'm so foolish as to give up a little bird I have for a bigger one I don't have?' Then she offered, 'I'll sing you a lovely song for my life.' 'No, no,' said the Hawk, 'I need food for my belly, not music for my ears.'
moral: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
choices: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
Pride and vanity leads to our downfall.
Small actions can have sneaky impacts.
People who grasp at more than they need lose the small, sneaky little that they held in their hands.
Even in moments of beauty, one must remain vigilant.

story: A Leopard, who found it very bothersome to live alone, let the Animals of the Woods know that he had decided to choose one of them as a Friend and Companion. There was a great commotion about who would be the Favorite and the envy of all the others. The Leopard chose a Pig, saying, 'He is true and faithful to his friend and will stand by him in all times and dangers.'
moral: Seek the friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering help even in a time of adversity.
choices: Seek the friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering help even in a time of adversity.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
True faith overcomes bothersome doubts.
Bothersome small liberties can be true large offenses.
Loneliness can drive even the mighty to seek companionship.

story: A Mosquito, nearly frozen and hungry, went to a Wasp-Hive on a cold morning to ask for help. The Mosquito offered to teach art to the Wasp's family in exchange for food and shelter. The Wasp politely declined, saying, 'I teach all my children my own trade so they can earn a living through hard work.'
moral: Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.
choices: Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.
It's better to ignore an insult from one troublemaker than to bring a whole crowd of trouble upon yourself.
Politeness warms the frozen heart.
Hardworking, fine work gets frozen, preserved, and treasured.
In times of need, humility can open doors to unexpected kindness.

story: When a war broke out between the Eagles and the Mammals, the Panther called all his subjects from ages sixteen to sixty to gather with weapons at a specific time and place, or face his great displeasure. Among those who showed up were many Mules and Rabbits. Some of the leaders wanted to dismiss them, thinking they were not fit for service. 'Do not be mistaken,' said the Panther, 'the Mules will do well as horn players, and the Rabbits will make excellent couriers.'
moral: No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
choices: No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
Be prepared to defend your position.
Strategy without fitness falters.
Commanding yet unfit, arrogant fools have no true influence.
Threats and orders breed fear, not loyalty.

story: Once there was a fierce civil war among the Eagles. The gentle and innocent Doves, out of pure kindness, sent their envoys to try and make peace between them. While the Eagles were busy fighting each other, they paid no attention to anything else. But as soon as they made peace, they returned to their old habit of attacking the Doves. This made the Doves realize their mistake and understand the danger of helping a common enemy, which led to their own downfall.
moral: The conflicts of the wicked are the protection of the good.
choices: The conflicts of the wicked are the protection of the good.
Pride and vanity leads to our downfall.
Gentleness tames aggression.
Beware the fierce sort of innocent person who uses tricks.
Internal strife weakens even the strongest forces.

story_title: An Old Man that was willing to put off Death
story: There is a story that Grim reaper visited an Aged Fellow and told him to come along. The Man tried to excuse himself, saying that the journey to the Next Realm was too long to take on such short notice, and he asked for a little more time to make his Last wishes before he died. Grim reaper replied, 'You have had enough warning, one would think, to have been ready by now.' 'In truth,' said the Aged Fellow, 'this is the first time I have ever seen you in my whole life.' 'That's not true,' said Grim reaper, 'for you have seen daily examples of mortality before your eyes, in people of all kinds, ages, and ranks. Isn't the frequent sight of others' deaths a reminder enough to make you think of your own? Your dim and hollow eyes, the loss of your hearing, and the faltering of your other senses should remind you, without much ado, that Grim reaper has already taken hold of you. And do you think this is the time to keep putting it off? Your final hour, I tell you, has now come, and there's no thought of a reprieve in the case of Fate.'
moral: We should live as if we always saw Death standing by.
choices: We should live as if we always saw Death standing by.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Old age can bring deadly consequences if unprepared.
Unprepared people often make extravagant, excuse-making promises which they are completely unable to carry out.
The signs of aging should serve as reminders of our mortality.

story: There was a certain avaricious fellow who was dying and about to part with his enormous heap of money, ill-gotten as it was. He ordered that the pouch of silver be brought to him as he was dying and then asked the bag to whom it would bring pleasure. The bag answered him: 'I'm going to bring pleasure to your descendants, who will squander these coins, over which you sweated, on women and drinks, and I'll also bring pleasure to the fiends who are going to turn your soul over to eternal torments.'
moral: A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
choices: A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
It is better by far to be governed by one chief, than by many.
Ill-gotten gains bring eternal torment.
Even beneficial things all appear to be enormous and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced, making them seem tormenting.
The fruits of toil may not always yield the intended legacy.

story: An oak tree sprang up on the bank of a stream, and the oak tree mocked the poplar tree who was her neighbor for being weak and feeble, as it bent with every surge of the water, no matter how light, while the oak tree praised her own stoutness and strength with extravagant words, because for many years the oak tree had remained unshaken by even the most persistent movement of the stream. On one occasion, however, the oak tree snapped from the tremendous violence of the currents and as she was being dragged along by the waters the poplar tree laughed and said: Why are you abandoning me, neighbor? Where is your stoutness now?'
moral: Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
choices: Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
Life's disasters can often bring boastful and presumptuous people back down to earth.
Mocking the weak reveals inner frailty.
Stout gratitude should be shown through resilient kindness, not harm.
Pride often fades in the face of adversity.
